fields.headline: Rangers bid for Rebrov
fields.trailText: Rangers have made an undisclosed offer for the Dynamo Kiev striker Serhiy Rebrov, who is rated at £12m.
fields.body:
Rangers have made an undisclosed offer for the Dynamo Kiev striker Serhiy Rebrov, who is rated at £12m.

The chairman David Murray has released funds for Dick Advocaat to strengthen his squad for next season, and the 25-year-old Ukrainian international has emerged as the manager's first choice.

"It seems everybody wants to talk about balance sheets," Murray said, "but all I'm interested in is the improvements we can make to Rangers FC."

Rangers face intense competition for Rebrov, from Barcelona and Milan among others, but are determined to improve their European challenge. They are also chasing the AZ Alkmaar defender Fernando Ricksen and Sunderland's winger Allan Johnston, and Advocaat said an approach for Paul Ritchie would be made at the end of the season when the Hearts defender, currently on loan at Bolton, will be out of contract.

fields.headline: Newcastle's Glass finally cracks
fields.trailText: Newcastle's Stephen Glass yesterday handed in a written transfer request at St James' Park, where he has slipped down the pecking order since the departure of Ruud Gullit.
fields.body:
Newcastle's Stephen Glass yesterday handed in a written transfer request at St James' Park, where he has slipped down the pecking order since the departure of Ruud Gullit.

The 23-year-old Scotland winger has started only two first-team games this season, the last of them against Tottenham in November. "I'm disappointed at the lack of first-team opportunities since Ruud Gullit left the club," he said.

It clearly annoyed Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson, who retorted: "His agent has totally disregarded all the usual protocols one would expect from someone in his position.

"I had no opportunity to discuss any possible options with the player or even to inform my own board about his request before the agent had released the news."

It is the second transfer request Robson has received recently, following one from the forward Paul Robinson.

Glass arrived from Aberdeen in July 1998 for £650,000 after signing a pre-contract agreement, but he did not play for the soon-to-depart manager Kenny Dalglish though he became a fixture in the side under Gullit, playing 22 league games and scoring three times. He also won a first cap for Scotland.

Senegal fans went on the rampage in Dakar yesterday, attacking Nigerian-owned businesses and their owners after Monday's 2-1 defeat by the Super Eagles in an African Nations Cup quarter-final.

Club-and knife-wielding youths roamed the streets, injuring at least a dozen Nigerians and attacking their embassy, where many others were taking refuge. Zimbabwe's embassy was also targetted due to the belief that the referee, a Zimbabwean, was biased.

Tottenham have admitted an interest in signing Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink upon receipt of the news that Steffen Iversen has sprained ankle ligaments and may be out for six weeks.

The Atletico Madrid striker, who arrived from Leeds last summer for £12m, is the top scorer in Spain with 20 goals but could be made available to alleviate heavy debts. It is reported that the Dutchman is owed around £200,000 in wages and has a clause in his contract allowing him to leave on a free transfer at the end of the season if he is not paid up.

Arsenal's Dennis Bergkamp scored against Tottenham in a behind-closed-doors friendly yesterday afternoon, a match that also featured an appearance from Silvinho and Tony Adams's first for a month. Stephen Hughes got the other goal in a 2-0 win. "They came through with flying colours," said Pat Rice, the Gunners' assistant manager.

Ipswich Town have taken Toulouse's midfielder Patrice Maurel, 21, on loan until the end of the season.

fields.headline: Away day first for Wales
fields.trailText: Wales will start their World Cup qualifying campaign in September away to Belarus. It will mean a return to Minsk and the venue in which they recorded a brilliant 2-1 victory in a Euro 2000 qualifier last year, Mark Hughes's first game in charge as caretaker manager before he was given the job proper.
fields.body:
Wales will start their World Cup qualifying campaign in September away to Belarus. It will mean a return to Minsk and the venue in which they recorded a brilliant 2-1 victory in a Euro 2000 qualifier last year, Mark Hughes's first game in charge as caretaker manager before he was given the job proper.

In what is a very tough group, the Belarus trip is followed by two difficult games in October: home to the top seeds Norway on the 7th and away to Poland a couple of days later. Both games will be a severe test and the fear is that Wales could find themselves, after only three matches, virtually out of contention.

Hughes remained upbeat, however, and is pleased the hardest games will come first, at the start of the season, when Wales will be fresh. "As it panned out, things could have been worse," he said. "We are not too unhappy."

After the initial qualifiers, matches start up again the following March. Wales then face a tough double-header - away to Armenia and home to Ukraine in the space of four days.

In a group that has been branded "the group of debt" because of the extensive travel involved and the lack of a genuine world football power to pull in the crowds, Wales's first home game against Norway is set to be played at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff.

Wales's World Cup qualifying matches:

Sept 2/3 2000 Belarus (a)
Oct 7 Norway (h)
Oct 10/11 Poland (a)
Mar 24 2001 Armenia (a)
Mar 28 Ukraine (h)
Jun 2 Poland (h)
Jun 6 Ukraine (a)
Sept 1 Armenia (h)
Sept 5 Norway (a)
Oct 6 Belarus (h).

webTitle: Gudjohnsen warms Wanderers in Nordic chill

fields.headline: Gudjohnsen warms Wanderers in Nordic chill
fields.trailText: Port Vale 0 - 1 Bolton
fields.body:
Bolton Wanderers, with a second-half goal by Eidur Gudjohnsen, his 15th of the season, moved into eighth place in the table last night.

Dean Holdsworth, having just replaced the veteran Bob Taylor, provided the crucial pass and the in-form Icelandic striker stole past two defenders before rolling the ball slowly and precisely wide of the Port Vale goalkeeper, Paul Musselwhite.

Bolton had threatened to squander all their considerable possession, with Vale making a spirited revival in the second half, in which Sagi Burton almost put the home side ahead. But the visitors were always the more composed, inventive side.

For the numerous Finns, Danes, and Icelandic players in the Bolton side the swirling, icy, northerly wind probably represented nothing more than a mild breeze. Certainly Bolton played with loose-limbed ease and were almost totally dominant for long periods.

Vale, by contrast, appeared slow and disjointed, save for Martin Bullock, who, despite looking as if any decent-sized gust might blow him over, was the one home player who seemed as if he might conjure up a path to embarrass the Bolton defence.

Indeed one attempted shot by Bullock took the sort of deflection that brings goalkeepers out in a cold sweat no matter what the temperature and Jussi Jaaskelainen, almost grounded as he attempted to change direction, just managed to grab the ball before the hordes arrived.

But Bolton would have felt hard done by if they had not been at least level at half-time. In truth they should have been ahead by some distance, but for all the tidiness of their approach play their finishing was notably lacking.

With Vale looking a much more potent attacking force in the second half, Bolton began to struggle and lose their rhythm.

However a double substitution was rewarded almost immediately with Gudjohnsen's cleverly worked goal. Vale struggled to salvage a point but remain solidly stuck second from bottom.

webTitle: Gray's double rekindles Luton's play-off hopes

fields.headline: Gray's double rekindles Luton's play-off hopes
fields.trailText: Luton 2 - 1 Stoke
fields.body:
It's that time in the season again when teams hovering just above mid-table know they have to start producing if their hopes are not to fade away. Luton duly delivered when it mattered last night through two second-half goals.

Their veteran striker Phil Gray struck twice within 16 minutes to overturn Stoke's lead and hoist his side to within five points of their play-off zone opposition. Gray's winner was unusual because its creator, Stuart Douglas, had seemed reluctant to continue the move, convinced that he had been guilty of a foul.

Luton had clearly been stung by their manager's criticism after Bournemouth had taken all three points here at the weekend. Lenny Lawrence noted a tendency to stroll their way through the opening phase of games but last night his team began aggressively with the two strikers Liam George and Douglas eager.

George would have succeeded had he aimed straighter with the game's first chance. He came close following a free-kick and closer still in the 17th minute when improvising a shot over his shoulder.

But Stoke had come prepared. Apart from their three central pillars and two wing-backs they also had Brynjar Gunnarsson positioned deep to give additional protection. Luton found a weight of bodies guarding the goal.

Stoke eventually started to attack, though, and just past the half-hour they went in front when Clive Clarke got away from two defenders down the left and cut back a ball which O'Connor drove high into the far corner.

After the break Kavanagh burst through, exchanged passes with Paul Connor but with only the goalkeeper to beat rolled his shot past the upright. Two minutes later Luton were level when Gray powered home a corner struck long by Matthew Taylor.

webTitle: Celtic take low road with abject defeat

fields.headline: Celtic take low road with abject defeat
fields.trailText: Celtic 1 - 3 Inverness CT
fields.body:
Celtic suffered the worst defeat in their history, losing their third-round cup tie to Inverness Caledonian Thistle, who were in the Highland League only five years ago. They did so by some margin in front of their own distraught unbelieving and angry supporters, and their manager John Barnes may find that there is no way back.

Some 5,000 had followed Thistle down for the original tie, which was called off when part of a grandstand came loose hours before the game. And half that number returned to see whether, metaphorically at least, the roof would fall in on the Premier League side. Their effort was handsomely rewarded.

Twice in the first half Thistle took the lead, and they did not need to play much more than straightforward First Division football. In that period Celtic's defence was truly dreadful, looking like men who had not struck up the barest acquaintanceship with one another. Olivier Tebily must surely have wished he was back in an Ivory Coast army camp.

Thistle were neither overawed nor did they feel obliged to do anything at all fussy. They did not need to do so to take the lead in the 17th minute. Stuart Golabek simply played the ball down the line on the left to Paul Sheerin, the busiest of their midfielders. He hit an orthodox cross into the penalty area and the striker Bobby Wilson had nobody with him as he headed strongly past Jonathan Gould.

It seemed it had been an aberration when Celtic equalised less than 60 seconds later. With Thistle still celebrating and not really believing their luck, Eyal Berkovic struck a through-ball down the middle. He gained a lucky deflection from a defender and it dropped into the stride of Mark Burchill, who clipped it past Jim Calder.

That should have been the sign for Celtic to calm down but it only increased their apprehension. Six minutes later the First Division side were back in the lead. Sheerin won a corner and tossed the ball over, Golabek was unmarked for his header and was lucky when the ball took a wicked deflection off Lubomir Moravcik to end up in the net.

Worse followed for Celtic. In the 55th minute Wilson's pace worried them, Reggie Blinker brought him down from behind and the impressive Sheerin scored from the penalty spot.

webTitle: Wet suits only Duckworth and Lewis

fields.headline: Wet suits only Duckworth and Lewis
fields.standfirst: Monsoon rains leave Hussain looking to cover all options
fields.trailText: The ghastly countenances of Messrs Duckworth and Lewis added to the grey skies over Johannesburg yesterday as rain of biblical proportions threatened to turn England's chances of reaching the final into a lottery.
fields.body:
Just when it looked possible that England might win something the ghastly countenances of Messrs Duckworth and Lewis filled the sullen skies here yesterday.

This is not to heap further scorn upon the already much-ridiculed Frank Duckworth and Tony Lewis, whose ingenious method for revising targets in interrupted matches is the best yet devised, even if it does make cracking Einstein's theory of relativity look something of a doddle.

It is just that England would rather do without calculators, slide rules and galoshes today as they prepare to play Zimbabwe at Centurion Park in what is, in effect, a semi-final. The winners will play South Africa at the Wanderers in Saturday's final of the triangular one-day series.

But we have had rain. Monsoon rain. Biblical rain. The sort of rain that seeps into the bone and dampens the soul. If you show a weary professional cricketer a drop of rain he will normally beam at you in the manner of a man who has just snared eight score-draws or stumbled over an attic Rembrandt. But this is different.

England, who have sometimes counted their chicken farmers before they have hatched, have lost six of their nine one-day internationals against Zimbabwe, and one out of two so far in this series.

This wretched record notwithstanding, they feel reasonably confident of prevailing in today's day-night game against the weakest side in international cricket. If the match is rained off, or is a tie for that matter, England would go through on run-rate.

At least 25 overs must be played per side today for it to be deemed a match. But the shorter the game, and with Duckworth-Lewis loitering, the greater the lottery. Play might start as late as 8.25pm and go on to almost midnight, so both sides could be reduced to pumpkins before the end of this particular ball.

"To be honest, I don't care how we get to the final," the very honest England captain Nasser Hussain said last night. "I just want to be there.

"But I'd prefer to wake up in the morning and have the game called off in torrential rain, or open the curtains and see not a cloud in the sky, so we can play 100 overs on a pitch that is even for both sides.

"The worst scenario is going down there and messing around, with no one knowing what's happening. It just might be one of those days, with Duckworth-Lewis coming in. It might be a 25-over slog. We just have to be professional and be aware of all possible eventualities and make sure we cover them.

"It's a tricky one, and that applies to choosing the right team and making the right decision after the toss. The pitch is under-prepared and damp. We must be switched on and be very professional because this Zimbabwe side have proved very good at exploiting any weakness.

"We have to remember that we are the professional country. These two games, if we go through, will be good for us. We've got a lot of young lads here and it is nice for them to play big games, day-night games, pressure games. We can't afford to lose any more matches at this stage and we'll find out a bit about people."

The players netted indoors at Centurion yesterday. The team is likely to be chosen from the 11 who played in East London last Friday plus Craig White, who is still returning to full fitness.

A glance at last night's paper, which splashed with the headline "Rain's Trail of Death and Destruction", put today's match in context.

At least 15 people were reported dead, five children are feared drowned, dozens reportedly missing and 200 visitors were trapped in the Kruger national park. In Johannesburg the Jukskei river burst its banks in the morning and traffic around the team hotel was forced to a standstill.

It is wet, and not only here. More than 100,000 are homeless in Mozambique's capital, Maputo. In neighbouring Zimbabwe they are incredulous that England are due to arrive in the middle of the rainy season instead of during September-October or March-April.

This could be yet another embarrassment for Simon Pack, who has already shown maladroitness as international teams director. In fact he has shot himself in the foot so often that there is a suspicion he has no toes left, although the way the sponsorship money is failing to materialise for the English game right now, he may never have to count beyond 10.

webTitle: Something new for this England team: a win

fields.headline: Something new for this England team: a win
fields.trailText: A new captain, a new country and a new feeling of optimism for the England women's team yesterday when they began their tour of New Zealand with a victory.
fields.body:
A new captain, a new country and a new feeling of optimism for the England women's team yesterday when they began their tour of New Zealand with a victory.

It is a win that will go a way to easing the memories of Australia, where England played two friendlies and four one-day internationals and lost them all. They also lost their captain when Karen Smithies OBE, who had led England since the 1993 World Cup triumph resigned after the 220-run defeat in New South Wales, leaving the 23-year-old teacher Clare Connor to lead her country into the 21st century.

England's new era began with an 11-run win over Wellington at the Basin Reserve in a warm-up before the five-match international series, which starts at Palmerston North on Saturday.

But this was also the warm-up for something bigger. The next World Cup takes place in Christchurch in December and Connor needed to start winning before it was too late. She was helped by the fact that Wellington were without three of their best players, all away on international duty with New Zealand.

Nevertheless, she was delighted. "A win is a win is a win," she said. "Now we have something to build on and I hope we can take it from there."

That would also sum up the thoughts of Claire Taylor, 24, who until this game had spent much of the tour watching Smithies and Connor open the batting with little success. Yesterday she had her chance and took it with a fluent 83 off 84 balls, including 10 fours, in England's 196 for eight.

"Claire (Taylor) has given us something to think about," said Connor. "It is a good position to be in."

Under the rules of these one-day games a team, in addition to playing 11 batsmen, can introduce another player to bowl. It was a rule England used to their advantage, bringing in the left-arm fast bowler Lucy Pearson as Wellington were kept to 185 for five in their 50 overs.

England's new era began with an 11-run win over Wellington at the Basin Reserve in a warm-up before the five-match international series, which starts at Palmerston North on Saturday. But this was also the warm-up for something bigger. The next World Cup takes place in Christchurch in December and Connor needed to start winning before it was too late. She was helped by the fact that Wellington were without three of their best players, all away on international duty with New Zealand. Nevertheless, she was delighted. "A win is a win is a win," she said. "Now we have something to build on and I hope we can take it from there." That would also sum up the thoughts of Claire Taylor, 24, who until this game had spent much of the tour watching Smithies and Connor open the batting with little success. Yesterday she had her chance and took it with a fluent 83 off 84 balls, including 10 fours, in England's 196 for eight. "Claire (Taylor) has given us something to think about," said Connor. "It is a good position to be in." Under the rules of these one-day games a team, in addition to playing 11 batsmen, can introduce another player to bowl. It was a rule England used to their advantage, bringing in the left-arm fast bowler Lucy Pearson as Wellington were kept to 185 for five in their 50 overs.

fields.headline: Action stations
fields.standfirst: About 100,000 under-16s run away from home each year. Some of the lucky ones make the right phone call and 'get connected', writes  Nicola Hill
fields.trailText: About 100,000 under-16s run away from home each year. Some of the lucky ones make the right phone call and 'get connected', writes Nicola Hill.
fields.body:
Nine out of 10 young people believe there is a role for charities in today's society and two-thirds of them would like to do more to help. But information about how to get involved with charities and be a more active citizen isn't reaching them. These findings are published in a survey released today by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations at its annual conference in London. The theme of the day is opportunity and inclusion, and it seems the voluntary sector has its work cut out to find new ways of drawing in young people.

A stone's throw away from the NCVO offices, one charity initiative, Get Connected, has managed to build up a bank of 65 volunteers in its first years. They run a helpline from a garret five flights above the platforms of King's Cross station.

The volunteers are given training, ongoing support and the chance to shape an evolving organisation. In return, they give three to four hours a week offering advice to young runaways, many of whom arrive at London's stations without food, shelter or money. According to the Children's Society, more than 100,000 under-16s run away from home each year, and one in seven experiences violence or sexual assault.

Volunteers give advice and counselling, often connecting callers to other agencies providing shelter, food or information.

One of the volunteers, Mary, says learning about counselling is one of the benefits she has gained from her experience. "My friends always told me I was good at listening, but having training has been very useful," she says. Mary returned from travelling and wanted to do something positive. She saw an advertisement in the Guardian's volunteer recruitment section and went along to the induction day. "It was fantastic," she says. "The staff were really enthusiastic and knew where they were going with the organisation."

Justin Irwin, communications manager for Get Connected, explains that the initiative comes under the auspices of the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, the charity which aims to create a safer society. Irwin says: "Research has shown that within 20 minutes of arrival at a mainline London station, a vulnerable young person may be approached by someone who will not have the child's best interests at heart." Within hours, this can lead to prostitution, theft or drug-taking.

Get Connected volunteers are trained to listen closely to callers to ensure that they feel supported enough to explore their options - including returning home if appropriate. The aim then is to refer the caller to any other necessary services. This is done by a "connection" where the volunteer is able to con tact the chosen organisation without putting the caller on hold; they can stay on line and have a three-way conversation free of charge. Callers are connected to voluntary and statutory organisations such as Centrepoint, Childline, Lesbian and Gay Switchboard or Drugline. Although the office is based in London, the service is offered nationwide.

Mary says she has learned a lot about what is available around Britain for vulnerable people. "Putting someone through to the right person is an amazing feeling," she says. "One boy had been in regular contact with another helpline and then it went under. He called us and we managed to get in contact with the counsellor he had been speaking to and put them back in touch with each other."

Other examples of calls include a 15-year-old girl from Scotland who was contemplating suicide. A Get Connected volunteer put her in touch with her local branch of the Samaritans. Another was from a boy of 15 being bullied at school. He thought he was too old to call Childline. The volunteer assured him this was not the case, but was also able to discuss options with him.

The fact that callers can have such a range of needs is part of the stimulation for volunteers. Mary says: "You have to be ready to deal with any situation and find out what people really want." Another aspect which appeals to Mary and her colleagues is the fact that the four paid staff recognise that volunteers are giving up their spare time and they are not pushed into doing any more.

Irwin says: "We have learned from the expertise of other agencies, such as Childline and the Samaritans, and developed our own volunteer care policies."

With the apparent willingness of young people to contribute to society, delegates at today's conference will hear about how to offer opportunities and inclusion for volunteers, who in turn offer the same to vulnerable members of society.

 Nicola Hill is part-time news editor of NCVO News. Get Connected helpline: 0800 096 0096; office: 0208-260 7373.

fields.headline: Partners or puppets?
fields.standfirst: One of the crucial questions at this year's NCVO conference will  be whether working with government is healthy for the sector
fields.trailText: One of the crucial questions at this year's NCVO conference will be whether working with government is healthy for the sector.
fields.body:
Is partnership between government and the voluntary sector inherently dangerous? This provocative thought will be among a number of issues discussed today at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations' annual conference.

Charles Secrett, of Friends of the Earth, will propose the motion. He says: "The point of the sector is to be independent and there is a danger of the watchdogs becoming lapdogs when in partnership with government." Leading the opposition will be Victor Adebowale, of the homelessness charity, Centrepoint.

The overarching theme of the conference is opportunity and inclusion. Stuart Etherington, chief executive of NCVO, says: "Creating opportunity for all and building a more inclusive society remains as much a challenge for this new century as it was in the last. These themes underpin so much of what the sector is about and are high on the government's list of priorities."

Delegates will hear exactly what is on the government's list when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, gives the keynote speech.

Etherington is pleased that the government is increasingly turning to the voluntary sector for solutions, but acknowledges the added pressure this places on resources. One seminar will address the implications of the government's recent review of charity taxation, which many believe could sap the sector's vibrancy. Another will look at the sector's funding base.

Speakers invited to the conference reflect the drive for the sector to become more professional. McKinsey Consultancy hosts a lecture on knowledge management - how to harness an organisation's intellectual and technological powers; Northern Rock Foundation is fielding a speaker on quality standards; and Pesh Framjee, of accountants Binder Hamlyn, looks at the challenges of leadership in the sector.

Looking at wider issues, the conference will consider the implications of the government's life-long learning initiative, the impact of devolution and the regeneration of communities, and will discuss the worldwide development of civil society.

Closer to home, the focus will be on how to encourage the participation of young people in its work. Research released today by NCVO shows that a year after the launch of the government's Active Community Unit, only 40% of 16-25 year olds are aware that Labour wants them to be more involved in their communities - although two-thirds are keen to do so. The theme of opportunity and inclusion, therefore, has a dual purpose: how to create more opportunities for people to be included in the sector's work by giving time or money, and providing more opportunities for those excluded by society.

fields.headline: Celebrity refs? It's happening already
fields.standfirst: WSC thinks the antics of officials like Mike Reed and Uriah Rennie could have serious repercussions for the game.
fields.trailText: Could the antics of officials like Mike Reed and Uriah Rennie have serious repercussions for the game?
fields.body:
The fuss over referee Mike Reed's 'celebration' of a goal in the Liverpool v Leeds game came at the end of a week when a worrying announcement was made. Two of Mike Reed's colleagues on the Premier League list, Graham Poll and Graham Barber, both in the running to take part in Euro 2000, have left full-time jobs to form a promotions company in the expectation of being able to earn a living on the after-dinner circuit.

Now every referee no doubt has a fund of racy stories with which to regale audiences of well-oiled businessmen. And given that they have to serve an apprenticeship on the killing fields of Sunday league football where assaults on officials are sadly common, it is clearly a calling that requires reserves of self-confidence most people don't possess. But football will only suffer if the match officials become full-time 'personalities' and begin to believe that they are as much a part of the entertainment as the two teams.

Before this season there had been signs that this was becoming the case. Uriah Rennie, one of the best known Premier League officials, has been known to go through a warm-up routine on the pitch before a match, followed by a round of autograph-signing for kids gathered behind the perimeter boards. Mike Reed, the man who has just claimed that he punched the air when a goal was scored at Anfield because he'd played an advantage earlier, goes in for extravagant displays when he is the fourth official, joking with the managers on the touchline and displaying the substitution board with a theatrical flourish.

In part, this is a by-product of the increased attention given to the referee's performance now that every incident in every match is analysed to death on television, with officials publicly slated for every wrong decision made in the heat of the moment and rarely praised for getting in right. In such circumstances, it is to an extent understandable that they might develop an inflated sense of their own importance and be keen to show when they have done their job properly.

The feeling persists, however, that some referees simply enjoy whatever attention they attract, good or bad. One hopes that this would never involve actively seeking opportunities to generate headlines - but that would make sound business sense when you need to bring in a paying audience for a speaking engagement.

fields.headline: Welsh first secretary resigns
fields.trailText: February 9 2000: Alun Michael has unexpectedly resigned from the post of Welsh assembly first secretary before a vote of no confidence called by Plaid Cymru could take place.
fields.body:
Alun Michael has unexpectedly resigned from the post of Welsh assembly first secretary before a vote of no confidence called by Plaid Cymru could take place.

Economic development secretary Rhodri Morgan, the man widely regarded as Mr Michael's successor, was appointed acting first secretary shortly afterwards.

Formally handing in his notice, Mr Michael told the packed assembly: "It cannot be right for Plaid Cymru to choose who leads Labour. Nor is it right for the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats to connive with that purpose.

"That is why I have decided to put the choice back clearly with the Labour party by resigning as first secretary with immediate effect."

It had been expected that Mr Michael would fight any vote of no confidence by standing for re-election as first secretary.

He received a standing ovation from many Labour members and Welsh secretary Paul Murphy, but later lost the vote of no confidence by 31 votes to 27 with one abstention.

Rhodri Morgan, who has twice fought for the leadership of the Welsh assembly, told its members that an extraordinary meeting would be held in the chamber at 9.30am tomorrow "to consider the issue of how best to fill the vacancy left by the resignation."

"It is now in everybody's interest that we have a fresh start, rekindling the spirit of the referendum campaign under the leadership of a new first secretary," he added.

The secretary of state for Wales, Paul Murphy, said: "Alun's decision is courageous and right.

"Throughout this period it has been Labour who have sought, at all times, to protect the assembly and strengthen the devolution settlement. The Welsh Labour party will now have to consider how we go forward together.

"Alun's decision ensures that it is our party, and our party alone, that decides who leads us in the assembly."

The vote of no confidence was called over the issue of European funding for the poorest regions of Wales. Plaid Cymru are angered by the treasury's failure to match £1.2bn of EU grants and thereby unlock the necessary funding for west Wales and the valleys.

Plaid Cymru's acting leader, Ieuan Wyn Jones, said last night of Mr Michael: "He should have made the case for Wales and the funding it deserves much stronger... his hotline to Tony Blair has gone cold."

Mr Michael had claimed the tabling of the vote was "a nonsense" and a result of Plaid's own arbitrary deadline on the EU funding process. He said that funds were already in place for the first phase.

Liberal Democrat assembly leader Mike German later suggested there were divisions within the Labour party. "He may feel he has not got their support," he added.

Outside the chamber, Conservative leader Nick Bourne said he would be "extremely surprised" if another candidate did not step forward. "But this isn't about personalities. We need someone who is going to fight for Wales," said Mr Bourne.

"We need someone to give the assembly a fresh start, to fight the treasury for these funds and get the money we need to help the valleys and west Wales."

Ieuan Wyn Jones said Mr Michael's resignation was "nothing more that a cynical ploy to circumvent the assembly". Such action suggested, he said, that Mr Michael viewed the nomination for a replacement first secretary as an issue for the Welsh Labour group, not the assembly and its members.

webTitle: Labour's man in Wales faces crisis vote

fields.headline: Labour's man in Wales faces crisis vote
fields.standfirst: Assembly on course for constitutional turmoil with 10-word motion condemning first secretary over European funding for poor areas
fields.trailText: February 9 2000: Assembly on course for constitutional turmoil with 10-word motion condemning first secretary over European funding for poor areas
fields.body:
The infant Welsh assembly was heading rapidly towards a period of constitutional uncertainty last night as opposition parties made good their threat to table a motion of no confidence in the Labour first secretary, Alun Michael, over the issue of European funding for some of the poorest areas of Wales.

The terse, 10-word motion will be considered by members in a special hour-long debate this afternoon.

But Mr Michael, who faces almost certain defeat at the hands of the three opposition parties, remained determined to let his name go forward for re-election as first secretary should the motion succeed.

That would raise the immediate prospect of further no confidence motions and take the assembly into wholly uncharted constitutional waters.

The assembly's presiding officer, Dafydd Elis Thomas, is still wrestling with the question of how often such ping pong moves could take place.

Plaid Cymru, which has been gunning for Mr Michael over European funding since the assembly elections last May, tabled the no confidence motion immediately following yesterday's debate on the £8bn Welsh budget. It made its move after failing to secure an unequivocal guarantee that the treasury would come up with the match funding needed to unlock £1.2bn of grants earmarked for west Wales and the valleys as part of the EU's so called objective 1 programme to aid the most economically disadvantaged parts of Europe.

"Mr Michael should have made the case for Wales to get the money it deserves much stronger," the party's acting leader, Ieuan Wyn Jones, said last night. "He has been reluctant to battle with the treasury and his hotline to Tony Blair has gone cold."

Mr Michael, who insisted he had no intention of standing down, claimed the opposition move was a "nonsense" based on a series of artificial deadlines and figures that bore no relation to reality.

He maintained that funds were already in place for the first year of the seven year objective 1 programme. Negotiations were taking place with the treasury for the following years as part of the government's comprehensive spending review and he was determined to get the best deal for Wales. Under assembly rules Mr Michael will be forced to resign if the no confidence vote goes against him, as assembly arithmetic says it will.

But Labour has made it clear that he will be its only candidate for first secretary when the assembly presiding officer calls for nominations tomorrow morning.

Plaid Cymru confirmed yesterday that such a move would immediately trigger a renewed no confidence move. "The grounds upon which we would do it is that no first secretary who has lost the confidence of the assembly can immediately come back," the Plaid Cymru leader said. But he said the party would not be tempted to bring down any Labour successor in a similar way.

"We have made this an issue of confidence in Mr Michael's leadership. Our view is that he has not argued the case strongly enough with the treasury and made it absolutely clear to them that Wales needs the money to reinvigorate the economies of west wales and the valleys."

Mr Wyn Jones added: "What we would expect a new first secretary to do is to argue the case with the treasury. We wouldn't use votes of no confidence like confetti. This is a very serious weapon we are using and it is not a weapon you use lightly or often."

Ann Jones, chairman of the Labour group in the assembly, claimed Plaid had chosen to plunge the assembly into chaos by imposing a wholly arbitrary deadline on the objective 1 process.

 Wales is one of four UK areas earmarked to receive hundreds of millions of pounds from Brussels under the EU's Objective 1 aid programme.

 The programme is aimed at reinvigorating the least developed regions of Europe where GDP per head is less than 75 % of the EU average.

 The seven-year programme, which runs until the end of 2006, was agreed at the Berlin summit when west Wales and the valleys was included along with Cornwall, Merseyside and South Yorkshire.

 The four regions, desperate to be included before EU enlargement brought even poorer economies into the calculations, have been promised more than £3 bn between them - £1.2 bn of it for Wales.

 In order to draw down the EU money member states are required to come up with match funding for the regeneration projects.

 Opposition parties in Wales insist this funding should come from the treasury and be in addition to £8bn handed over to the assembly under the formula that governs the size of the Welsh budget.

 Labour says the issue will be resolved in the government's spending review, but there are already sufficient funds to kick-start the programme this year.

fields.headline: Alun Michael: rise and fall
fields.trailText:
Who is Alun Michael?
The former first secretary's official job description was to take responsibility for the actions of the devolved Welsh government, and to maintain relations with the secretary of state for Wales and the ministers of other government departments.
fields.body:
Who is Alun Michael?
The former first secretary's official job description was to take responsibility for the actions of the devolved Welsh government, and to maintain relations with the secretary of state for Wales and the ministers of other government departments.

However, Mr Michael did not enjoy widespread support in his party and was viewed by many as a Millbank appointee in Wales - in the final no confidence vote 28 Labour assembly members abstained. The vote was precipitated by the Welsh budget crisis and Mr Michael's apparent refusal to stand up to Downing Street.

Why did he go?
Opposition parties accused Mr Michael of failing to persuade prime minister Tony Blair and chancellor Gordon Brown to spend extra money on Wales. A total of £1.2 billion of European money is earmarked for west Wales and the Welsh valleys over the next six years but on condition that the funds are matched by the UK.

How did he get there?
Mr Michael, MP for Cardiff South and Penarth since 1987, became Welsh secretary in 1998 when Ron Davies, who was expected to become first secretary of the devolved assembly, resigned after he was mugged on Clapham Common, south London. Mr Michael beat Rhodri Morgan in a vote to become Labour's candidate for the first secretary in an electoral college similar to that which is now being used to decide the party's favoured mayor. Mr Morgan, who claimed to have the Welsh Labour party's grassroots support, is now tipped to succeed Mr Michael.

What else has he done?
After a spell as a journalist and community worker, Mr Michael became a Cardiff city councillor in 1973. He entered parliament in 1987 and became opposition spokesman on Welsh affairs soon after followed by spokesman on home affairs in 1992. When Labour came to power he was appointed deputy to the home secretary in 1997 and then secretary of state for Wales.

fields.headline: Confidence tricks
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown on the latest goings-on at the Welsh assembly
fields.trailText: The first secretary of the Welsh assembly, Alun Michael, is   almost certainly going to lose his job today - and get it back     tomorrow.
fields.body:
The first secretary of the Welsh assembly, Alun Michael, is almost certainly going to lose his job today - and get it back tomorrow.

This Alun-in-Wonderland state of affairs is based in part on the raw electoral arithmetic of Wales, where Michael heads a minority Labour administration.

The combined opposition of Plaid Cymru nationalists, liberal democrats and conservatives in the assembly has tabled a motion of no confidence in the first secretary. They accuse him of failing to press Downing Street and the treasury to provide matching funds which would release EC development aid for depressed areas of west Wales and the valleys.

On the face of it, the opposition parties are playing a bit of a confidence trick. They risk alienating that very large section of the voting public which never wanted an assembly, and which believes that devolution is just another way politicians have to create jobs for themselves.

But another school of thought in Wales, well represented in Michael's own party, is heartily sick of the way, as they perceive it, that the London and Labour party establishments are insisting on pulling the strings. Michael, who was catapulted rather unwillingly into the top job, is seen as Tony Blair's placeman, whose job in Cardiff is faithfully to follow the instructions of No.10 and Millbank.

That is a harsh judgement. Michael is after all a loyal member of the ruling party. Of course he is not going to lead a pointless rebellion over money which the treasury simply will not give. All the same, the impression that he is no more than His Master's Voice is deeply damaging to him, his party, and the whole devolution enterprise.

In that sense, what is happening today is a fascinating exploration of virgin constitutional territory. The Welsh assembly, like the House of Commons, has no written constitution to guide its deliberations. Unlike the Commons, it has no accumulated flummery of interpretation and precedents. What it does today, and tomorrow, will go down as important landmarks in its infant history.

As things stand, Michael will be forced to resign. But he will stand for re-election, with the support of the Labour group. And so far, it seems he will be the only candidate. That is a severe indictment of the opposition parties, which seem more interesting in scoring a cheap political point than in challenging Labour's longstanding hegemony in the principality.

Although Michael will not be holed below the waterline by the shenanigans in Cardiff, the high-profile squabble in the assembly could cost his party dearly in the next general election. The electors of Wales, long accustomed to delivering Labour votes in shovel-loads, have no great reason to feel grateful to the present government - not least because it has delivered a lukewarm, feeble version of devolved power. The same applies, for quite different reasons, in Scotland, where Labour also enjoys a surreal electoral advantage.

These are early days, but it is fair to speculate that what used to be condescendingly called the Celtic fringe could yet turn out to be the fulcrum of the next election; Labour's Achilles heel.

fields.headline: Welsh first secretary resigns
fields.trailText: Alun Michael has unexpectedly resigned from the post of Welsh assembly first secretary before a vote of no confidence called by Plaid Cymru could take place.
fields.body:
Alun Michael has unexpectedly resigned from the post of Welsh assembly first secretary before a vote of no confidence called by Plaid Cymru could take place.

Economic development secretary Rhodri Morgan, the man widely regarded as Mr Michael's successor, was appointed acting first secretary shortly afterwards.

Formally handing in his notice, Mr Michael told the packed assembly: "It cannot be right for Plaid Cymru to choose who leads Labour. Nor is it right for the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats to connive with that purpose.

"That is why I have decided to put the choice back clearly with the Labour party by resigning as first secretary with immediate effect."

It had been expected that Mr Michael would fight any vote of no confidence by standing for re-election as first secretary.

He received a standing ovation from many Labour members and Welsh secretary Paul Murphy, but later lost the vote of no confidence by 31 votes to 27 with one abstention.

Rhodri Morgan, who has twice fought for the leadership of the Welsh assembly, told its members that an extraordinary meeting would be held in the chamber at 9.30am tomorrow "to consider the issue of how best to fill the vacancy left by the resignation."

"It is now in everybody's interest that we have a fresh start, rekindling the spirit of the referendum campaign under the leadership of a new first secretary," he added.

The secretary of state for Wales, Paul Murphy, said: "Alun's decision is courageous and right.

"Throughout this period it has been Labour who have sought, at all times, to protect the assembly and strengthen the devolution settlement. The Welsh Labour party will now have to consider how we go forward together.

"Alun's decision ensures that it is our party, and our party alone, that decides who leads us in the assembly."

The vote of no confidence was called over the issue of European funding for the poorest regions of Wales. Plaid Cymru are angered by the treasury's failure to match £1.2bn of EU grants and thereby unlock the necessary funding for west Wales and the valleys.

Plaid Cymru's acting leader, Ieuan Wyn Jones, said last night of Mr Michael: "He should have made the case for Wales and the funding it deserves much stronger... his hotline to Tony Blair has gone cold."

Mr Michael had claimed the tabling of the vote was "a nonsense" and a result of Plaid's own arbitrary deadline on the EU funding process. He said that funds were already in place for the first phase.

Liberal Democrat assembly leader Mike German later suggested there were divisions within the Labour party. "He may feel he has not got their support," he added.

Outside the chamber, Conservative leader Nick Bourne said he would be "extremely surprised" if another candidate did not step forward. "But this isn't about personalities. We need someone who is going to fight for Wales," said Mr Bourne.

"We need someone to give the assembly a fresh start, to fight the treasury for these funds and get the money we need to help the valleys and west Wales."

Ieuan Wyn Jones said Mr Michael's resignation was "nothing more that a cynical ploy to circumvent the assembly". Such action suggested, he said, that Mr Michael viewed the nomination for a replacement first secretary as an issue for the Welsh Labour group, not the assembly and its members.

webTitle: ITV ruling comes closer as Carlton merger referred

fields.headline: ITV ruling comes closer as Carlton merger referred
fields.trailText: A ruling on ITV's future as a consolidated company could come as early as May, it emerged yesterday when Carlton Communication's proposed merger with United News & Media was referred to the competition commission.
fields.body:
A ruling on ITV's future as a consolidated company could come as early as May, it emerged yesterday when Carlton Communication's proposed merger with United News & Media was referred to the competition commission.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry minister, referred the deal following the advice of the office of fair trading last week and the commission will report to him on May 16. He is then expected to take up to a month to make his decision.

The deal raises competition concerns in two areas: their joint share of the television advertising market, which would exceed levels laid down and their potential domination of ITV programme production.

The third ITV player jostling for position, Granada Group, has asked the OFT whether it would be able to bid for either or both companies, a request which is expected also to be referred to the commission in the next few weeks. Any takeover by Granada of Carlton or United would raise the additional question of combined share of the total TV viewing audience, which would exceed the 15% limit.

Granada's request was prompted by Carlton and United's announcement in November that they intended to merge, amid speculation that the largest ITV player had been caught on the back foot.

United and Carlton each own three of the 15 ITV franchises, while Granada owns four. Further consolidation of ITV into one company could only come about by changing the media ownership laws, but this latest round of mergers is said by most analysts to be positioning before the broadcasting bill due early in the next parliament. That bill is expected to open the way for single ownership of the network.

All three ITV companies welcomed the announcement last night with sources saying they anticipated a clearer regulatory framework. Carlton and United issued a joint statement saying they looked forward to putting their case to the competition commission with "vigour and clarity".

Under the terms of the merger the offers for Carlton's shareholders have now lapsed, so acceptances already received will not take effect, but Lord Hollick, chief executive of United said the companies continued to believe in the "compelling logic" of the merger. However, a Granada spokeswoman said: "There are important issues which need to be examined objectively to ensure ITV's continued future success. We've consistently argued that a merger of Carlton and United would create a north-south divide which would be bad for broadcasting and for Britain."

webTitle: EU opens antitrust probe of Microsoft

fields.headline: EU opens antitrust probe of Microsoft
fields.trailText: EU antitrust officials today said they have started an investigation of Microsoft's Windows 2000 amid complaints that the new operating system will give the company a dominant position in the software market.
fields.body:
EU antitrust officials today said they have started an investigation of Microsoft's Windows 2000 amid complaints that the new operating system will give the company a dominant position in the software market.

Mario Monti, the EU competition commissioner, said several customers and competitors have expressed concern at the antitrust implications of Windows 2000, designed for high-powered computers and networks for business. It is the successor for NT.

"Whoever gains dominance in the software service market gains dominance in electronic commerce too," Mr Monti said, adding that the EU sent Microsoft a letter last week, asking for more information. Microsoft has four weeks to respond to the request.

"Microsoft has designed (Windows 2000) in a way which may permit it to leverage its dominant position in PC operating systems into operating markets such as server operating systems and e-commerce," Mr Monti said.

The EU action means Microsoft could face a two-pronged legal attack. In the US, the justice department is weighing up its options with the software giant after a judge rule that Microsoft is a monopoly. But Mr Monti noted that it would be "hugely premature" to talk about possible sanctions against Microsoft.

Microsoft said it looked forward to providing information requested by the EU. "We received the request for information. They have asked us to provide the information by the beginning of March and we look forward to doing that," said John Frank, Microsoft's European director of law and corporate affairs."

Mr Frank said the commission's action followed a complaint filed last year by Sun Microsystems, which he said had complained that advances on Windows 2000 would make it harder for Sun to compete. "We have shared a great deal of information with Sun. We strongly support high quality interoperability," Mr Frank said.

webTitle: Royal Bank wins heavyweight support for NatWest bid

fields.headline: Royal Bank wins heavyweight support for NatWest bid
fields.trailText: NatWest's second and third largest shareholders last night decided to throw their weight behind Royal Bank of Scotland's £23bn bid for the clearing bank.
fields.body:
NatWest's second and third largest shareholders last night decided to throw their weight behind Royal Bank of Scotland's £23bn bid for the clearing bank.

The decisions by Schroders and Mercury Asset Management, who between them account for nearly 8% of NatWest, added further confusion to the outcome of the four-month fight over NatWest and came just hours after Royal Bank announced that it had support from nearly 13% of NatWest's investors.

Senior bankers were still reluctant to pick a winner last night before learning of the decisions of Prudential, NatWest's biggest shareholder, and other major investors who have until Valentine's day to decide whether to back the competing bids by Royal Bank and Bank of Scotland, or support NatWest's incumbent managers. A day which appeared to start with BoS running in the lead after Phillips & Drew - the seventh largest holder of NatWest stock - backed its bid, ended with Royal Bank edging ahead.

To pile more pressure on Sir David Rowland, chairman and chief executive of NatWest, to agree to a deal both Scottish banks need to create a bandwagon behind their competing bids. Only then will they stand a chance of winning out right control of NatWest and prevent their rivals from gaining 50% of shareholders' votes.

One banking source said last night that the decision by Schroders and MAM could swing the outcome in Royal Bank's favour more easily if Pru also opted to back the bid.

"It is hard to go against MAM," the source said.

"There is an increasing chance of stalemate if Pru goes behind BoS."

Pru's management has clinched a deal with BoS to sell insurance through NatWest's branches if its bid is successful, but the fund managers have assured the takeover panel - which policies takeover bids - that this will not affect their decision.

Reflecting the finely balanced situation Bill Baker, the co-head of UK equities at Schroders, which owns 5% of BoS, admitted that he and his colleagues had found it a very difficult decision.

"It was a very close-run thing," he said. "On balance, it was in the best interests of our clients to support the Royal Bank offer."

Deutsche Bank also said yesterday it was backing Royal Bank's bid and another large shareholder in NatWest is also ready to back Royal Bank.

Shares in all three jumped yesterday, with Royal Bank ending at £10.53, up 61p, BoS up 19p at 613p and NatWest ending at £11.44, up 52p.

fields.headline: Reuters climbs aboard the net
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Reuters, the news and information group, climbed more than 23% yesterday to a record high of £12.39 after the company announced a £500m plan to move its business online.
fields.body:
Shares in Reuters, the news and information group, climbed more than 23% yesterday to a record high of £12.39 after the company announced a £500m plan to move its business online.

Reuters, which hoped to counter criticism that it has been too sluggish in grappling with the internet, also confirmed widely anticipated plans for a partial flotation of its Greenhouse Fund, which has investments in a series of net start ups.

A flotation of Reuters' American online broking business, Instinet, is also under consideration, the company said.

A clutch of other plans included the launch of an internet service aimed at private investors, a joint venture to develop a second European website for retail investors and another to develop applications of Reuters information for mobile phones.

Reuters' shares were initially spooked by a warning that the investment would hit profits this year while there will be a reorganisation charge of £300m associated with a restructuring of the business and job losses.

The group's dividend will be rebased to reflect only the group's slower growing core services. The interim figure was held at 11p, giving a full year payout of 14.65p.

Reuters' chief executive, Peter Job, said the time had come to start spending money after a decade in which nearly £2bn had been returned to shareholders.

"You might almost say that the internet was invented for Reuters - it loves short expositions of things written clearly for screen, factual and true," he said.

The volume of unreliable information on the net played to the strength of the Reuters brand name, he said.

Much of the investment will be to build the "e-architecture" to support the wider use of Reuters' information.

"The internet is changing dramatically the landscape of Reuters' potential customer base," Mr Job said. "We are no longer about hundreds of thousands of potential customers, but tens of millions. The internet enables us to target individual retail investors, which previously would have been uneconomic."

He said there would be a potential market of 60m individuals dealing in shares who would want basic free information and services which they would pay for.

The venture to develop a financial portal for private retail investors has been set up with online intermediary Multex offering news, stock quotes and broker research.

Reuters plans to launch a retail investment version of its Instinet online broking service in the summer. The mobile joint venture has been struck with US wireless technology firm Aether Systems.

Mr Job said Reuters had been building toward this point for five years and said of the flak taken by the group. "I think people simply didn't realise what we were doing. We already have 40m individuals looking at Reuters information on 900 websites."

The value of the Greenhouse Fund's quoted investments has grown from £68m at the end of July 1999 to £438m by the year's end. Investment bank Morgan Stanley will advise on the flotation.

Reuters pre-tax profits for 1999 were 9% higher at £632m on sales 3% better at £3.1bn.

Reuters, which hoped to counter criticism that it has been too sluggish in grappling with the internet, also confirmed widely anticipated plans for a partial flotation of its Greenhouse Fund, which has investments in a series of net start ups. A flotation of Reuters' American online broking business, Instinet, is also under consideration, the company said. A clutch of other plans included the launch of an internet service aimed at private investors, a joint venture to develop a second European website for retail investors and another to develop applications of Reuters information for mobile phones. Reuters' shares were initially spooked by a warning that the investment would hit profits this year while there will be a reorganisation charge of £300m associated with a restructuring of the business and job losses. The group's dividend will be rebased to reflect only the group's slower growing core services. The interim figure was held at 11p, giving a full year payout of 14.65p. Reuters' chief executive, Peter Job, said the time had come to start spending money after a decade in which nearly £2bn had been returned to shareholders. "You might almost say that the internet was invented for Reuters - it loves short expositions of things written clearly for screen, factual and true," he said. The volume of unreliable information on the net played to the strength of the Reuters brand name, he said. Much of the investment will be to build the "e-architecture" to support the wider use of Reuters' information. "The internet is changing dramatically the landscape of Reuters' potential customer base," Mr Job said. "We are no longer about hundreds of thousands of potential customers, but tens of millions. The internet enables us to target individual retail investors, which previously would have been uneconomic." He said there would be a potential market of 60m individuals dealing in shares who would want basic free information and services which they would pay for. The venture to develop a financial portal for private retail investors has been set up with online intermediary Multex offering news, stock quotes and broker research. Reuters plans to launch a retail investment version of its Instinet online broking service in the summer. The mobile joint venture has been struck with US wireless technology firm Aether Systems. Mr Job said Reuters had been building toward this point for five years and said of the flak taken by the group. "I think people simply didn't realise what we were doing. We already have 40m individuals looking at Reuters information on 900 websites." The value of the Greenhouse Fund's quoted investments has grown from £68m at the end of July 1999 to £438m by the year's end. Investment bank Morgan Stanley will advise on the flotation. Reuters pre-tax profits for 1999 were 9% higher at £632m on sales 3% better at £3.1bn.

fields.headline: Violence before Zimbabwe vote
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party has been accused of unleashing a campaign of violent intimidation against people campaigning for a no vote in Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum, to be held this weekend.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party has been accused of unleashing a campaign of violent intimidation against people campaigning for a no vote in Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum, to be held this weekend.

Several recent incidents indicate that Mr Mugabe's supporters have been beating up and threatening those working to reject the draft constitution in the referendum.

Police are accused of failing to take action against those responsible for the attacks.

On Saturday, a woman distributing pamphlets opposing the draft constitution in the Mabvuku township in Harare was beaten by a gang of thugs suspected to be Zanu-PF supporters. They were also alleged to have ripped off her "Vote No" T-shirt. The previous night a group of Zanu-PF supporters were alleged to have surrounded her house and threatened her.

On Sunday, an opposition supporter, Diamond Karanda, was badly beaten in Harare's Highfield township. Mr Karanda suffered broken teeth and serious head and facial injuries. Nearby police were alleged to have taken no action to stop the violence. When he filed a report at the Machipisa police station he claimed a group of Zanu-PF supporters had threatened him. He said armed police then took him to identify some party supporters - but he was beaten again, while officers stood by.

In Raffingora, 125 miles north-west of Harare, a woman campaigning against the draft constitution also claimed she had been beaten up and that police had refused to act on her complaint.

"Many of our campaigners are facing intimidation," said Lydia Zigomo, the chairwoman of the Women's Coalition. "But we are used to that, and we know how to stand up for our rights. We also find the community at large supports opposition to this draft constitution."

Mrs Zigomo said women's groups opposed Mr Mugabe's draft constitution because it denies women basic rights, such as property ownership.

"All women's rights - and, in fact, fundamental human rights - can be taken away from any individual in the name of 'public morality, public security and public order'. Who would decide that?" said Mrs Zigomo, who is also the head of Zimbabwe Women Lawyers Association. "Protection of rights is weaker than in our current constitution," which was set up during independence negotiations in London in 1979.

Mr Mugabe's government is using the state-controlled television, radio and newspapers to press for a yes vote in the referendum. Meanwhile groups opposing the referendum have been refused the right to air their advertisements in the state media.

But public opinion remains largely opposed to the draft constitution. Thousands of people have attended public hearings on the constitution and the vast majority of speakers have stated that they wanted to see the power of the president reduced.

The new draft leaves virtually all state power in the hands of the president. The constitutional commission, appointed by Mr Mugabe, is accused of failing to listen to the public's views before writing the new constitution.

The government printed the draft constitution in September, long before public hearings had finished, the newspaper the Standard reported.

fields.headline: Alun in Wonderland
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown on Alun Michael's dramatic resignation this afternoon at the Welsh assembly
Plus: No Wiener schnitzel for Charles
fields.trailText: Derek Brown on Alun Michael's dramatic resignation this afternoon at the Welsh assembly
fields.body:
Alun Michael, first secretary of the Welsh Assembly, dramatically resigned this afternoon - moments before losing a vote of confidence.

Up to the last minute, it was widely forecast that Mr Michael would step down after the vote, then immediately stand again as the ruling Labour group's unopposed candidate for the top job. That is still possible, but the smart money is now on Mr Michael's long-standing rival, Rhodri Morgan.

Such an outcome would be a bitter blow for Downing Street, where Mr Michael is seen as a staunch New Labour loyalist, and Mr Morgan as a dangerous independent. And that is precisely the analysis which led this afternoon's shenanigans in Cardiff.

Mr Michael was accused by the opposition parties in the assembly of failing to extract cash from the treasury for development projects in chronically poor areas of west Wales and the Valleys.

The European Union has earmarked millions for development, but will only release the funds if they are matched by the national exchequer.

The hapless first secretary, who got the job because he was close to Tony Blair, is now perceived to be too close to be an effective champion of Welsh interests - a perception rather crudely exploited today by an ad hoc alliance of Plaid Cymru nationalists, liberal democrats and conservatives.

Although between them the three parties can muster a narrow majority in the assembly, they are deeply divided on policy.

It is unthinkable that they could come up with an agreed candidate for the first secretaryship. So it will be Labour, again, which forms the next Welsh administration.

Still, there is more than a touch of arrogance about the ruling party's assumption of control despite having a minority of members.

Mr Michael told the assembly this afternoon, as he brandished his written resignation: "It is for the Labour Party to decide who should be presented to this assembly as our candidate for the role of first secretary."

Welsh secretary Paul Murphy, who witnessed the resignation, said afterwards that "it is our party, and our party alone, that decides who leads us in the assembly".

Indeed Labour is entitled to choose its own leader - but so is the assembly, and today the latter decided that it had no confidence in Alun Michael. If Labour's mandarins put him back in the firing line, they will be sneering at the entire devolution process.

Even more ominously for Mr Michael's chances, an unnamed Labour member actually abstained in the vote.

That clearly indicates that there are continuing rumbles of dissent in the party, a significant section of which passionately supports Mr Morgan, and believes that Mr Michael was foisted on them by the control freaks of Millbank.

Related documentaries
Devolution in Wales: special report

No Wiener schnitzel for Charles

The foreign office-inspired decision of the Prince of Wales not to visit Austria is an insult to the people of that country. It seems rather far-fetched to argue that a princely presence in Vienna amounts to some kind of endorsement of Jörg Haider's Freedom party.

There are already clear signs that Haider in power is a good deal more savoury than Haider goose-stepping on the margins of politics. He is now constrained by the conventions of government, and no longer mouthing off to gain dubious publicity. We don't have to like him, or cosy up to him. But we do have to respect his mandate, so long as he does nothing to disgrace it.

Prince Charles could have made a useful contribution, by tweaking the norms of royal diplomacy. He could have delivered a well-mannered snub or two to the Freedom party, and reminded Austria that Europe is the antithesis of narrow nationalism.

Related documentary
The Austrian far right in power: special report

fields.headline: Alun Michael: rise and fall
fields.trailText:
Who is Alun Michael?
The former first secretary's official job description was to take responsibility for the actions of the devolved Welsh government, and to maintain relations with the secretary of state for Wales and the ministers of other government departments.
fields.body:
Who is Alun Michael?
The former first secretary's official job description was to take responsibility for the actions of the devolved Welsh government, and to maintain relations with the secretary of state for Wales and the ministers of other government departments.

However, Mr Michael did not enjoy widespread support in his party and was viewed by many as a Millbank appointee in Wales - in the final no confidence vote 28 Labour assembly members abstained. The vote was precipitated by the Welsh budget crisis and Mr Michael's apparent refusal to stand up to Downing Street.

Why did he go?
Opposition parties accused Mr Michael of failing to persuade prime minister Tony Blair and chancellor Gordon Brown to spend extra money on Wales. A total of £1.2 billion of European money is earmarked for west Wales and the Welsh valleys over the next six years but on condition that the funds are matched by the UK.

How did he get there?
Mr Michael, MP for Cardiff South and Penarth since 1987, became Welsh secretary in 1998 when Ron Davies, who was expected to become first secretary of the devolved assembly, resigned after he was mugged on Clapham Common, south London. Mr Michael beat Rhodri Morgan in a vote to become Labour's candidate for the first secretary in an electoral college similar to that which is now being used to decide the party's favoured mayor. Mr Morgan, who claimed to have the Welsh Labour party's grassroots support, is now tipped to succeed Mr Michael.

What else has he done?
After a spell as a journalist and community worker, Mr Michael became a Cardiff city councillor in 1973. He entered parliament in 1987 and became opposition spokesman on Welsh affairs soon after followed by spokesman on home affairs in 1992. When Labour came to power he was appointed deputy to the home secretary in 1997 and then secretary of state for Wales.

fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The following memo was reputedly circulated by the accounts department of a large corporation, and is now making the rounds on the internet.
fields.body:
