fields.headline: 33 years, 38,162 supporters and 72 million pounds
fields.trailText: LOOK AT THIS ADVERTISEMENT
fields.body:
LOOK AT THIS ADVERTISEMENT

Great Travel Deals! To receive a FREE daily email listing all the best bargains for flights and holidays, send an email to freelist@travelfinder.co.uk or click mailto:freelist@travelfinder.co.uk with a message 'please send'.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OH DHEAR

Time could be running out for Celtic head coach John Barnes. Three days after snatching a home defeat from the jaws of victory against Hearts, his team really surpassed themselves by crashing out of the Scottish Cup 3-1 at home to Inverness Caledonian Thistle. And to top the biggest shock in Scottish football for 33 years - since Rangers bowed out of the same competition against Berwick in 1967 - top scorer Mark Viduka was substituted at the break after what Barnes described as "a serious situation" over the half-time cuppa.

Barnes has promised what exactly happened with Viduka "will all come out in the next few days". As Viduka's agent insists the Australian striker "had a knee injury, that was all", it's a story likely to make everything worse instead of better. But by then will anybody care? Because all this is a trifling affair compared to presiding over the worst result in your club's history, and if a statement issued by Bhoys chief executive Allan MacDonald is to be believed Barnes is currently positioned somewhere between 'very shaky ground' and 'wet tissue paper suspended in mid-air over thin ice'.

"Last night's performance was totally unacceptable... and simply not good enough for the Celtic support," thundered MacDonald today. "I am addressing this situation as a matter of urgency with our director of football, Kenny Dalglish, who is returning this evening from club business overseas." You can be sure that Kenny will be returning from his scouting-mission-stroke-golfing-holiday quicker than you can link the words "vote" and "confidence" with a preposition. So we'll keep an eye on this one.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHAT PRICE A MONKEY'S HEAD?

Firm and fruity Sunderland manager Peter Reid is much in demand. Whether it's a request to chair the UK Swearing 2000 Conference - "Whither ****, **** and ************ in the new Millennium?" - or to help ACAS out in a tricky contract dispute, Reid is the man they all want. Sunderland, who currently employ Reid for his managerial skills, want him too. So much so, in fact, that they are prepared to offer him a contract that will make him the richest manager of all time ever.

Maybe. What is certain is that negotiations are about to start to keep Reid at the Stadium of Light for the foreseeable future. "Performances in our first season back in the Premier League have gone well," said a spokesman today, "and we feel the time is now right to reward him and secure his services for the future." Chairman Bob Murray is of a similar mind: 'We have to make sure we give the guy what he wants or we'll lose him," he said. What if he wants a new set of ears?

Anyway, rumours suggest that the urgency on Wearside is a result of the recent attention lavished upon Reid by Uncle Jack Walker. Walker is believed to have offered Reid £1m-a-year to manage Blackburn, and will surely make another offer in the summer should they get promoted. Why Reid would want to leave the thriving Stadium of Light (average attendance: 38,162) to go to Ewood Park (average attendance: 18,942 - including injured squad members) is beyond the Fiver. However, some big club in the North West are said to be looking for a manager quite soon. He might be tempted to hang on for that.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We could try putting such replays on hold. It would help towards a general reconciliation and put the emphasis back on the skills and technique of the most beautiful game in the world." - Juventus' Ciro Ferrara mooting a ban on television replays. Why he couldn't just say "Vid Pic Ban Blast!" we'll never know.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SHARE AND SHARE ALIKE

Reported debts of £72m; share price at an all time low of 56.5p (down from an initial price of 135p); and unable to afford a fee of £3m to sign Argentinian international midfielder Christian Bassedas (approximately the same price Kenny Dalglish forked out for Andreas Andersson). Things might seem to be looking a little grey for the Magpies of Toon. But, in reality, things are terribly rosy. And that is the truth.

A spokesman was urgently wheeled out this afternoon to explain away any financial difficulties. "When Newcastle United plc reported its last results in October 1999, the company had cash balances of nearly £6m," he said. A "securitisation bond" (ie: big-time loan) of £55m was arranged last winter to "fund the redevelopment of St James' Park", he added. This will "pay for itself", thanks partly to putting executive boxes where supporters used to sit. What's more, one of those "exclusive media agent" deals with NTL has earned Newcastle a loan of £10m, "with a further £15m following in 12 months' time."

So, basically, after years of overspending, Newcastle are being kept afloat on the never-never. Any future prosperity depends on increased attendances, which in turn depend on success on the pitch. A lot of pressure to put on the shoulders of a soon-to-be-67-year-old man. One thing's for sure however, you won't catch the Toon going through £25m a season in transfers again. "As a club we never say how much we have to spend on players," said today's spokesman. 14 times bitten...

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Middlesbrough are interested in Monaco striker David Trezeguet.

Ruud van Nistelrooy has revealed he would prefer a move to Chelsea than to Italy, according to the Daily Mail. Sources report that the Dutch international striker believes life in Serie A would be too fraught and that he would like to live in London.

George Graham will pay £2m to take Manchester United winger Jonathan Greening to Tottenham.

Sheffield Wednesday are set to spend £600,000 on Derby defender Spencer Prior.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Paolo di Canio has been charged with misconduct by the FA for an alleged insulting gesture during the Premiership game against Aston Villa. The West Ham striker has 14 days to respond.

Sunderland midfielder Carsten Fredgaard has joined West Brom on loan until the end of the season.

The SFA have insisted that Morton's Scottish Cup fourth-round tie with Rangers must be played at St Mirren's Love Street ground and not Hampden Park as planned. Morton, whose Cappielow ground was deemed too small for the tie, plan to protest.

York have parted company with manager Neil Thompson "by mutual agreement."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 8.30pm SS2, 12.15am)
A programme which takes international football into its bosom and loves it like a son.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm)
"We've got some emails about that point," says McCaff. Emails? We'll give you emails!

Sky Sports 3: Premiership Classics (10pm)
The 1993 match between Southampton and Newcastle which saw Matthew Le Tissier chipping one in from just outside the box, volleying in a spectacular second whilst standing in a queue for burgers in the Milton Road end, and narrowly missing his hat-trick with a cheeky back-heel effort while stacking the shelves in the club shop (town centre branch).

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
Scottish Cup replays. Will this competition ever make the news?

Chairman Bob Murray is of a similar mind: 'We have to make sure we give the guy what he wants or we'll lose him," he said. What if he wants a new set of ears? Anyway, rumours suggest that the urgency on Wearside is a result of the recent attention lavished upon Reid by Uncle Jack Walker. Walker is believed to have offered Reid £1m-a-year to manage Blackburn, and will surely make another offer in the summer should they get promoted. Why Reid would want to leave the thriving Stadium of Light (average attendance: 38,162) to go to Ewood Park (average attendance: 18,942 - including injured squad members) is beyond the Fiver. However, some big club in the North West are said to be looking for a manager quite soon. He might be tempted to hang on for that. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "We could try putting such replays on hold. It would help towards a general reconciliation and put the emphasis back on the skills and technique of the most beautiful game in the world." - Juventus' Ciro Ferrara mooting a ban on television replays. Why he couldn't just say "Vid Pic Ban Blast!" we'll never know. * * * * * * * * * * * * * SHARE AND SHARE ALIKE Reported debts of £72m; share price at an all time low of 56.5p (down from an initial price of 135p); and unable to afford a fee of £3m to sign Argentinian international midfielder Christian Bassedas (approximately the same price Kenny Dalglish forked out for Andreas Andersson). Things might seem to be looking a little grey for the Magpies of Toon. But, in reality, things are terribly rosy. And that is the truth. A spokesman was urgently wheeled out this afternoon to explain away any financial difficulties. "When Newcastle United plc reported its last results in October 1999, the company had cash balances of nearly £6m," he said. A "securitisation bond" (ie: big-time loan) of £55m was arranged last winter to "fund the redevelopment of St James' Park", he added. This will "pay for itself", thanks partly to putting executive boxes where supporters used to sit. What's more, one of those "exclusive media agent" deals with NTL has earned Newcastle a loan of £10m, "with a further £15m following in 12 months' time." So, basically, after years of overspending, Newcastle are being kept afloat on the never-never. Any future prosperity depends on increased attendances, which in turn depend on success on the pitch. A lot of pressure to put on the shoulders of a soon-to-be-67-year-old man. One thing's for sure however, you won't catch the Toon going through £25m a season in transfers again. "As a club we never say how much we have to spend on players," said today's spokesman. 14 times bitten... * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Middlesbrough are interested in Monaco striker David Trezeguet. Ruud van Nistelrooy has revealed he would prefer a move to Chelsea than to Italy, according to the Daily Mail. Sources report that the Dutch international striker believes life in Serie A would be too fraught and that he would like to live in London. George Graham will pay £2m to take Manchester United winger Jonathan Greening to Tottenham. Sheffield Wednesday are set to spend £600,000 on Derby defender Spencer Prior. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Paolo di Canio has been charged with misconduct by the FA for an alleged insulting gesture during the Premiership game against Aston Villa. The West Ham striker has 14 days to respond. Sunderland midfielder Carsten Fredgaard has joined West Brom on loan until the end of the season. The SFA have insisted that Morton's Scottish Cup fourth-round tie with Rangers must be played at St Mirren's Love Street ground and not Hampden Park as planned. Morton, whose Cappielow ground was deemed too small for the tie, plan to protest. York have parted company with manager Neil Thompson "by mutual agreement." * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 8.30pm SS2, 12.15am) A programme which takes international football into its bosom and loves it like a son. You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm) "We've got some emails about that point," says McCaff. Emails? We'll give you emails! Sky Sports 3: Premiership Classics (10pm) The 1993 match between Southampton and Newcastle which saw Matthew Le Tissier chipping one in from just outside the box, volleying in a spectacular second whilst standing in a queue for burgers in the Milton Road end, and narrowly missing his hat-trick with a cheeky back-heel effort while stacking the shelves in the club shop (town centre branch). Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm) Scottish Cup replays. Will this competition ever make the news?

fields.headline: Straw still feels the sting
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's home affairs editor analyses the home secretary's online debate

Read the debate here
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's claim to have proved a "flaccid" liberal when he took the Guardian Unlimited "woolly liberal" test was enjoyable but also revealing. It shows that the home secretary, as a former member of Liberty, is quite stung by the accusation that his proposals, such as limiting the right to choose trial by jury, ride roughshod over long-held civil liberties.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's claim to have proved a "flaccid" liberal when he took the Guardian Unlimited "woolly liberal" test was enjoyable but also revealing. It shows that the home secretary, as a former member of Liberty, is quite stung by the accusation that his proposals, such as limiting the right to choose trial by jury, ride roughshod over long-held civil liberties.

That is why he keeps trying to put some distance between himself and those extreme "woolly liberals" - such as the Guardian - who keep criticising him and who obviously, according to Mr Straw, believe everyone in his Blackburn constituency wears clogs and shawls and eat tripe and onions. I think he was acting on the principle that when you have a bad case the best line of defence is to abuse the other side.

His defence of the government's case on drugs and freedom of information was unsurprising.

But he gave an interesting hint that the government's determination to press ahead with its plans to restrict access to jury trial might be weakening. When the government was defeated by the House of Lords on January 20, ministers suggested that they would bring the measure back in a few weeks. But today Mr Straw has said he can't say for certain that it will be before the end of this month. It looks as though it is already slipping down the list of the government's priorities.

I enjoyed him calling one Guardian reader "comrade" though.

webTitle: Brown unveils tax boost for charities

fields.headline: Brown unveils tax boost for charities
fields.trailText:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today unveiled tax breaks for charities as an
incentive to boost charitable giving and create a "new civic
patriotism".
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today unveiled tax breaks for charities as an incentive to boost charitable giving and create a "new civic patriotism".

The changes, to be included in March's Budget, will ensure tax relief for direct cash donations - large or small, regular or one-off - to charities. Mr Brown said he hopes the simpler tax regime will encourage greater charitable giving which he estimates could eventually bring in an extra £1bn a year to charities and voluntary organisations. But his comments will be seen by critics as a thinly-veiled attempt to offload the burdens of government on to individuals and private groups.

"I'm talking about first of all making it easier for people to give both money and time to charities and voluntary workers in their own community," Mr Brown said. "For every pound an individual gives in future after April, the treasury will make up an extra 28p. And for every pound that people give to payroll giving, the treasury will make up to 50p."

The chancellor added that the new rules will make it easier for British companies - who give only a fifth of what is given in the United States to charity and community activity - to make donations. In an echo of former president George Bush's "thousand points of light" approach to voluntary service, Mr Brown said he wanted to create a "new civic patriotism", to energise thousands of people in society to play a bigger part in their communities.

Mr Brown outlined his new proposals at the annual conference of the national council for voluntary organisations. Mr Brown said: "Active citizenship: call it little platoons, community work or the giving age. There is a spirit in our country where people want to do more and I want to encourage it in the budget with new financial measures."

The chancellor said the government will appeal to people to give time as well as money to voluntary organisations. He said the government was also looking at new technology to link volunteers with charitable organisations.

Mr Brown said he wanted to open a debate about the relationship between the individual, the community and the state.

"It should recognise the state itself can become a vested interest," Mr Brown said, "and there are public interests that sometimes are better advanced by organisations that are not bureaucratic or state organised."

Housing charity Shelter welcomed the measures, saying that the proposals would mean more money going directly to charities.

Oxfam also applauded the initiative. Simon Collings, head of appeals at Oxfam, said: "It provides an incentive for people to give if they know there is extra bit the government will contribute... as long as the government keeps the scheme as free of red tape as possible."

fields.headline: WAP's up
fields.standfirst: For recommendations on the best WAP phones around, visit this Waptastic page.
fields.trailText: Everyone's talking about WAP - internet access for mobile phones. With the launch of Bob Geldof's WapWorld, we explain what it's all about.
fields.body:
What is WAP and why is it back in the news?
WAP stands for Wireless Application Protocol and basically means internet access from mobile phones. It's back in the news today because Bob Geldof has teamed up with former England rugby union international Brian Moore to launch WapWorld, rolling out an internet portal service to WAP phones.

What can WAP phones do?
The great advantage of WAP is that it frees people from their PCs - or even their laptops. WAP phones allow users to read news, check football scores and monitor share prices wherever they are. Television and cinema listings, cash machine locations and information about traffic congestion or train times are other uses. Email is the next big goal - perfect for tiny screens and users on the move. On-phone shopping will come; and there are countless possibilities for businesses - for example, giving salespeople instant mobile access to stock data.

Will Geldof's service offer anything different?
Geldof and Moore promise celebrity-driven content, with plenty of sports and entertainment figures, plus news and weather, aimed at the young and affluent. They have struck a deal with Carphone Warehouse that will see WapWorld technology installed on every WAP phone sold by the retail chain.

How does the technology work?
It works the same way as a mobile phone works with voices: information is sent by radio signals. But because mobiles are small, they can only deliver small amounts of information - the tiny screen sizes can't accommodate many words, and the links are still relatively slow.

Do all the mobile phone companies do WAP phones?
Yes, WAP is seen as a crucial development for the future of mobile phone technology. Huge amounts of money are being invested in developing the technology. Most have done deals on content - for example, Vodafone, has teamed up with WH Smith, the BBC and the Met Office.

Do you need a special phone to access the internet?
Yes in general - although Virgin Mobile claims to be the first mobile phone company in the world to offer all its customers WAP browsing, allowing them to look at specially converted web pages and order goods from sites from, among others, the BBC and Virgin Megastore. Virgin uses a unique SIM-card based browser, which means you don't have to buy a special WAP phone.

How much do WAP phones cost?
Around £130 plus line rental and call charges for accessing the internet.

How widespread will they be?
Industry estimates are that within a few years there will be more people using WAP phones to access the net than those using computers. It is forecast that there will be 1.2bn mobile phone users in the world by 2003, with about half using phones to access the net. In comparison, there will be about 550m computer users. Internet access is bound to migrate to phones

Can I get Guardian Unlimited on a WAP phone?

Yes, you can access it from any WAP phone. Just bookmark http://www.newsunlimited.co.uk/wml.

You can also see what it's like on a simulator here.

Useful links
Wapforum
Waptastic

Toss: India
New Zealand 349 for 9 in 50 overs (Spearman 68, Astle 120, Twose 56, Venkat Prasad 3-75)
India 306 in 47 overs (Ganguly 41, Tendulkar 32, Dravid 39, Jadeja 95, Styris 3-62, Astle 3-40)
New Zealand won by 43 runs
ODI debut Scott Styris (Northern Districts; RHB, RM; born in Australia). NZ's HS in ODIs (prev 348-8 v India, Nagpur, 1995-96). Nathan Astle (MoM; 136 balls, 12x4, 2x6) 115 for 1st wkt with Craig Spearman (15x4), 109 for 2nd with Roger Twose (4x4, 3x6). Adam Parore 18 in 10 balls inc 2x6. Ajay Jadeja 97 balls, 4x4, 3x6.

November 8, Hyderabad
Toss: India
India 376 for 2 in 50 overs (Tendulkar 186*, Dravid 153)
New Zealand 202 in 33.1 overs (Parore 39, Styris 43)
India won by 174 runs
Sachin Tendulkar (MoM; record 24th ODI 100; 151 balls, 20x4, 3x6) 331 for 2nd wkt with Rahul Dravid (152 balls, 15x4, 2x6),. record for any wkt in ODIs. India's HS in ODIs (prev 373-6 v SL, Taunton, 1999), 2nd-highest by any country after SL's 398-5 v Kenya, Kandy, 1995-96.

November 11, Gwalior
Toss: India
India 261 for 5 in 50 overs (Ganguly 153*, Robin Singh 45*)
New Zealand 247 for 8 in 50 overs (Spearman 32, Astle 97, Chopra 3-32)
India won by 14 runs
Sourav Ganguly (MoM) 150 balls, 18x4, 3x6; 119* for 6th wkt with Robin Singh (1x4, 3x6).

November 14, Guwahati
Toss: India
New Zealand 236 for 9 in 50 overs (Twose 46, Cairns 80)
India 188 in 45.3 overs (Joshi 61*)
New Zealand won by 48 runs
ODI debut Thirunavukarasu Kumaran (India; RFM; aka Kenny because of a fondness for Kenwood hi-fi systems). Chris Cairns (MoM) 114 balls, 4x4, 3x6. Sunil Joshi 56 balls, 2x4, 3x6.

November 17, Delhi
Toss: New Zealand
New Zealand 179 for 9 in 50 overs (Twose 47, Cairns 41, Kumaran 3-24)
India 181 for 3 in 44 overs (Gandhi 30, Ganguly 86)
India won by 7 wickets Sourav Ganguly (MoM; 110 balls, 10x4, 1x6) 117 for 1st wkt with Devang Gandhi (ODI debut). Man of Series: Ganguly.
India won the series 3-2

ZIMBABWE v AUSTRALIA

October 21, Bulawayo
Toss: Zimbabwe
Australia 303 for 6 in 50 overs (Mark Waugh 106, Ponting 67, Martyn 57*)
Zimbabwe 220 in 43.4 overs (Johnson 110, Fleming 3-33, Symonds 3-52)
Australia won by 83 runs
Mark Waugh (Man of the Match) 97 balls, 11x4, 2x6; Neil Johnson 124 balls, 13x4, 2x6; both had scored 100s in previous Australia-Zimbabwe ODI, during the World Cup. Damien Martyn 38 balls, 7x4, 1x6.

October 23, Harare
Toss: Australia
Zimbabwe 116 in 37.3 overs (Fleming 3-14)
Australia 117 for 1 in 28.3 overs (Mark Waugh 54*, Ponting 31*)
Australia won by 9 wickets
MoM Damien Fleming. The highest score for Zimbabwe was Trevor Madondo's 29.

October 24, Harare
Toss: Australia
Zimbabwe 200 for 9 in 50 overs (Andy Flower 99*)
Australia 201 for 1 in 39 overs (Ponting 87*, Bevan 77*)
Australia won by 9 wickets
Andy Flower (MoM) 111 balls, 7x4, 2x6. Ricky Ponting (9x4, 1x6)/Michael Bevan (10x4) 157* for 2nd wicket.
Australia won the series 3-0

COCA-COLA CHAMPIONS' TROPHY

October 13 (day/night)
Toss: Sri Lanka
Sri Lanka 178 in 49.3 overs (de Silva 31, Kaluwitharana 36)
West Indies 181 for 7 in 49.2 overs (Adams 74*, Hinds 35)
West Indies won by 3 wickets
All matches were played at the Sharjah CA Stadium. Jimmy Adams (MoM) 124 balls, 4x4.

October 14 (day/night)
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 260 for 5 in 50 overs (Saeed Anwar 72, Inzamam-ul-Haq 71, Yousuf Youhana 48)
West Indies 130 in 34.4 overs (Campbell 34, Powell 36)
Pakistan won by 130 runs
ODI debut Shoaib Malik (Pak offspinner, 17). Anwar (MoM) 87 balls, 3x4, 4x6. Inzamam 4x4, 2x6. Moin Khan 27* off 16 balls, 2x4, 2x6. Jimmy Adams injured hand while bowling, and did not bat.

October 15 (day/night)
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 196 in 49.4 overs (Saeed Anwar 30, Inzamam-ul-Haq 42, Yousuf Youhana 48)
Sri Lanka 196 in 49.1 overs (Kaluwitharana 75, Arnold 61, Wasim Akram 3-38, Abdur Razzaq 5-31).
Tied
Romesh Kaluwitharana (7x4)/Russel Arnold (7x4) 115 for 2nd wicket. Sri Lanka were 173-2, but lost their last 8 wickets for 23 in 9 overs. MoM Abdur Razzaq.

October 17 (day/night)
Toss: West Indies
West Indies 145 in 45.3 overs (Hinds 58, Chanderpaul 31, Muralitharan 3-22)
Sri Lanka 146 for 1 in 28 overs (Jayasuriya 88, Kaluwitharana 44*)
Sri Lanka won by 9 wickets
Sanath Jayasuriya (MoM) 80 balls, 8x4, 3x6; 128 for 1st wicket with Romesh Kaluwitharana (72 balls, 4x4).

October 18 (day/night)
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 239 for 8 in 50 overs (Shahid Afridi 58, Inzamam-ul-Haq 33, Abdur Razzaq 59*)
Sri Lanka 121 in 33.4 overs (de Silva 35)
Pakistan won by 118 runs
Shahid Afridi (MoM) 50 balls, 2x4, 5x6. Abdur Razzaq 51 balls, 3x4, 4x6. SL were 15-3: only Aravinda de Silva and Marvan Atapattu (29) reached double figures; Shabbir Ahmed 6-2-11-2, Afridi 3-1-6-2.

October 19 (day/night)
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 255 for 5 in 50 overs (Hasan Raza 77, Inzamam-ul-Haq 61, Yousuf Youhana 71*)
West Indies 117 in 31.3 overs (Lara 30, Azhar Mahmood 6-18)
Pakistan won by 138 runs
ODI debut Pedro Collins (WI). Hasan Raza 120 balls, 1x4, 1x6. Yousuf Youhana 46 balls, 3x4, 4x6. Azhar Mahmood (MoM) 10-2-18-6.

Final
October 22 (day/night)
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 211 for 9 in 50 overs (Saeed Anwar 53, Inzamam-ul-Haq 54, Wasim Akram 30, Chandana 3-30)
Sri Lanka 123 in 36 overs (Azhar Mahmood 5-28)
Pakistan won by 88 runs
Pakistan won Trophy ($50,000). MoM Azhar Mahmood. Man of Series: Inzamam-ul-Haq.

BANGLADESH v WEST INDIES

October 8, Dhaka
Toss: West Indies
West Indies 292 for 6 in 50 overs (Adams 56, Hinds 40, Chanderpaul 92*, Powell 34, McLean 39)
Bangladesh 219 for 5 in 50 overs (Shahriar Hossain 45, Al-Sahariar Rokon 62*, Khaled Mashud 53*, Adams 3-24)
West Indies won by 73 runs
Bangladesh's 1st official ODI outside multi-team tournaments. Jimmy Adams (MoM) 3x4; Shivarine Chanderpaul 109 balls, 4x4, 1x6; Ricardo Powell 23 balls, 0x4, 4x6; Nixon McLean 22 balls, 1x4, 3x6. Bangladesh were 96-5, then Al-Sahariar Rokon (103 balls, 5x4)/ Khaled Mashud 123* for 6th wicket.

October 9, Dhaka
Toss: West Indies
West Indies 314 for 6 in 50 overs (Lara 117, Chanderpaul 77*)
Bangladesh 205 in 49.1 overs (Shahriar Hossain 47, Aminul Islam 66, Campbell 4-30)
West Indies won by 109 runs
Brian Lara (MoM) 100 in 45 balls, 17x4, 4x6; in all 62 balls, 18x4, 4x6. ODI debut Ahmed Kamal (Bangladesh).
West Indies won the series 2-0

LG SAFARI CUP India, Kenya, South Africa, Zimbabwe

September 25
Toss: Zimbabwe
Kenya 199 for 8 in 50 overs (Shah 71, Tikolo 33, Modi 31, Guy Whittall 3-29)
Zimbabwe 200 for 7 in 49.2 overs (Goodwin 76*, Andy Flower 55, Tikolo 3-22)
Zimbabwe won by 3 wickets
All matches were played at Nairobi Gymkhana ground. ODI debuts Josephat Ababu (Kenya), David Mutendera (Zimbabwe). Ravindu Shah 100 balls, 11x4. Murray Goodwin (MoM; 13x4)/Andy Flower (9x4) 109 for 4th wicket; Zimbabwe were 192-4, 197-7. Ababu took the wicket of Neil Johnson (16) with his 1st ball in ODIs.

September 26
Toss: South Africa
South Africa 117 in 48 overs (Kallis 38, Joshi 5-6, Chopra 3-26)
India 120 for 2 in 22.4 overs ( Ramesh 36, Ganguly 38)
India won by 8 wickets
ODI debuts Boeta Dippenaar (SA), Vijay Bharadwaj (I). Sunil Joshi (MoM) 10-6-6-5, most-economical analysis in ODIs.

September 28
Toss: South Africa
Zimbabwe 216 in 47.4 overs (Grant Flower 91, Dawson 3-36, Adams 3-43)
South Africa 217 for 1 in 35 overs (Gibbs 48 retired hurt, Klusener 101*, Cronje 31*)
South Africa won by 9 wickets
Grant Flower 120 balls, 11x4, 1x6. Lance Klusener (MoM) 105 balls, 11x4, 4x6; 125* for 1st wicket in 18.4 overs before Herschelle Gibbs retired hurt.

September 29
Toss: Kenya
India 220 for 7 in 50 overs (Ramesh 50, Dravid 30, Jadeja 31, Bhardwaj 41*, Odumbe 3-51)
Kenya 162 in 50 overs (Odoyo 33, Prasad 3-26, Bharadwaj 3-38)
India won by 58 runs
Mannava Prasad (I) ct 4, st 1. MoM Vijay Bharadwaj.

September 30
Toss: Kenya
South Africa 220 for 7 in 50 overs (Kallis 39, Rhodes 45, Pollock 30)
Kenya 196 in 48.1 overs (Tikolo 67, Odoyo 41, Pollock 3-10)
South Africa won by 24 runs
ODI debut Peter Ochieng (K). Kenya conceded 220-7 for the 2nd day running. Steve Tikolo (MoM) 9x4.

October 1
Toss: Zimbabwe
India 277 for 6 in 50 overs (Ramesh 31, Ganguly 139, Singh 41, Guy Whittall 3-55)
Zimbabwe 170 in 38.3 overs (Johnson 52, Grant Flower 38, Chopra 4-33, Bharadwaj 3-34)
India won by 107 runs
Sourav Ganguly (MoM) 11x4, 5x6. South Africa and India qualified for the final.

Final
October 3
Toss: India
South Africa 235 for 9 in 50 overs (Gibbs 84, Cronje 39, Bharadwaj 3-34)
India 209 in 47.3 overs (Dravid 30, Mannava Prasad 63, Jadeja 30, Crookes 3-47)
South Africa won by 26 runs
Herschelle Gibbs (MoM) 124 balls, 6x4, 3x6. Mannava Prasad (6x4) retired hurt when 56. Man of Series: Vijay Bhardwaj.

DMC TROPHY West Indies v Pakistan

September 16
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 230 for 6 in 50 overs (Saeed Anwar 63, Wajahatullah Wasti 40)
West Indies 215 for 9 in 50 overs (Campbell 69, Adams 35*)
Pakistan won by 15 runs
All the games were played in Toronto. The 1500th ODI match. Saeed Anwar (MoM; 9x4)/Wajahatullah Wasti 131 for 1st wicket. Six Pakistan bowlers each took one wicket; there were also three run-outs.

September 18
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 222 for 5 in 50 overs (Yousuf Youhana 104*, Abdur Razzaq 55)
West Indies 180 in 46.2 overs (Hinds 65, Saqlain Mushtaq 3-18)
Pakistan won by 42 runs
Yousuf Youhana (MoM; 114 balls, 13x4)/Abdur Razzaq 149 for 5th wicket. Wavell Hinds 115 balls, 6x4.

September 19
Toss: West Indies
West Indies 161 in 44.4 overs (Campbell 32, Shabbir Ahmed 3-52, Mushtaq Ahmed 3-31)
Pakistan 162 for 3 in 39.4 overs (Abdur Razzaq 57, Inzamam-ul-Haq 55*)
Pakistan won by 7 wkts
ODI debut Shabbir Ahmed. Razzaq (MoM) 111 balls, 8x4. Umpire Steve Dunne allowed two 7-ball overs in the Pakistan innings.
Pakistan won the DMC Trophy 3-0

DMC CUP West Indies v India

September 11
Toss: India
West Indies 163 in 46.2 overs (Campbell 62, Powell 37, Singh 3-43)
India 165 for 2 in 37.3 overs (Ramesh 55*, Ganguly 54*)
India won by 8 wickets
All the games were played in Toronto. ODI debuts Jacob Martin (I), Corey Collymore, Christopher Gayle (WI). West Indies' 1st official ODI in Canada. Ricardo Powell 34 balls, 5x4, 2x6. Sourav Ganguly (MoM; 7x4, 1x6) captained India (Sachin Tendulkar and Ajay Jadeja were both absent injured); 106* for 3rd wicket with Sadagoppan Ramesh.

September 12
Toss: West Indies
West Indies 190 for 6 in 50 overs (Campbell 59, Lara 34, Ganguly 3-37)
India 120 in 41.5 overs
West Indies won by 70 runs
India were 12-3, 43-7; the highest score was Sunil Joshi's 25 from No. 9; Mervyn Dillon 8-2-8-2. Sherwin Campbell (MoM) 8x4.

September 14
Toss: West Indies India 225 for 7 in 50 overs (Ganguly 34, Martin 33, Dravid 77, Dillon 5-51)
West Indies 137 in 34.2 overs (Powell 76, Chopra 5-21)
India won by 88 runs
Rahul Dravid (MoM) 6x4, 2x6. West Indies were 20-4, 52-7, then Ricardo Powell (73 balls, 3x4, 7x6) 84 for the 8th wicket with Corey Collymore (3). Man of Series: Sourav Ganguly.
India won the DMC Cup 2-1

SINGAPORE India, West Indies, Zimbabwe

September 2
Toss: Zimbabwe
Zimbabwe 244 for 9 in 50 overs (Campbell 80, Andy Flower 89, King 3-37, Bryan 3-36)
West Indies 247 for 4 in 43.4 overs (Campbell 63, Jacobs 47, Lara 48, Powell 51*)
West Indies won by 6 wickets
1st ODI on Kallang ground. ODI debut Arnoldus Blignaut (Zim; RHB, RFM). Alistair Campbell (6x4, 3x6)/Andy Flower (11x4, 1x6) 114 for 4th wicket. Sherwin Campbell (10x4)/Ridley Jacobs (MoM; 3x4, 3x6; also ct 4) 114 for 1st wicket. Ricardo Powell 36 balls, 4x4, 4x6.

September 4,
Toss: Zimbabwe
India 245 for 6 in 30 overs (Tendulkar 85, Jadeja 88 retired hurt)
Zimbabwe 130 for 8 in 29 overs (Andy Flower 63*, Mohanty 3-28)
India won by 115 runs
Late start - reduced to 30-overs match; Zimbabwe fined 1 over for slow bowling rate. Sachin Tendulkar (MoM; 7x4, 3x6) 143 for 3rd wicket with Ajay Jadeja (61 balls, 2x4, 6x6), who later retired hurt after pulling a calf muscle. Andy Flower 8x4.

September 5,
Toss: West Indies
West Indies 196 for 7 in 30 overs (Powell 46, Lara 60, Mohanty 3-52)
India 154 for 8 in 30 overs (Ganguly 32, Dravid 39) West Indies won by 42 runs
ODI debut Wavell Hinds (WI; LHB). Sourav Ganguly captained India (Sachin Tendulkar and Ajay Jadeja were both injured). Brian Lara (batted No. 7) 43 balls, 2x4, 5x6. Sadagoppan Ramesh (wicket of Nizon McLean) and Wavell Hinds (Mannava Prasad) both took wickets with their 1st ball in ODIs (the 6th & 7th instances in all ODIs).

Final
September 7
Toss: India
India 149 for 6 in 38.2 overs (Tendulkar 40, King 3-25) v West Indies
No result
Rain stopped play: there was no resumption. The match was replayed next day.

Final
September 8
Toss: West Indies
India 254 for 6 in 50 overs (Dravid 103*, Ganguly 46, Chopra 61, Perry 3-65)
West Indies 255 for 6 in 47.4 overs (Powell 124, Perry 38*, Mohanty 3-33)
West Indies won by 4 wickets.
Rahul Dravid (124 balls, 8x4, 2x6) reached 3000 ODI runs when he had made 52. Nikhil Chopra 3x4, 3x6. Ricardo Powell (MoM; Man of Series) 93 balls, 9x4, 8x6.

AIWA CUP Australia, India, Sri Lanka

Galle, August 22
Toss: Sri Lanka
Australia 205 for 9 in 43 overs (Ponting 38, Bevan 42*, Jayasuriya 5-28)
Sri Lanka 160 in 37.4 overs (Kaluwitharana 33, Chandana 30, Gillespie 3-26)
Australia won by 52 runs (revised target)
ODI debut Samantha de Saram (SL). Adam Gilchrist (27) was given run out by the 3rd umpire DN Pathirana despite inconclusive TV replays: the umpire was suspended from the next match. MoM Jason Gillespie. After a rain break, Sri Lanka's target was revised to 212 in 43 overs under the Duckworth/Lewis rule. Shane Warne took his 204th ODI wicket (Nuwan Zoysa) to break Craig McDermott's Australian ODI record.

Galle, August 23
Toss: India
India 151 for 7 in 38 overs (Jadeja 30, Singh 38)
Australia 159 for 2 in 29.1 overs (Gilchrist 68, Symonds 68*)
Australia won by 8 wickets (revised target) MoM Andrew Symonds. Australia target was revised to 159 in 38 overs (D/L) after rain had interrupted India's innings.

Colombo (Premadasa), August 25 (day/night)
Toss: India
India 205 for 8 in 50 overs (Tendulkar 37, Jadeja 49)
Sri Lanka 206 for 3 in 46.4 overs (Jayasuriya 61, Atapattu 71*)
Sri Lanka won by 7 wickets
MoM Marvan Atapattu. There were four run-outs in India's innings. Sanath Jayasuriya 62 balls, 8x4.

Colombo (Premadasa), August 26 (day/night)
Toss: Australia
Australia 241 for 9 in 50 overs (Gilchrist 38, Mark Waugh 84, Chandana 3-35, Muralitharan 3-50)
Sri Lanka 214 in 47.1 overs (Arnold 41, Silva 54, Chandana 34)
Australia won by 27 runs
ODI debut Lindamlilage Silva (85 balls, 5x4). MoM Mark Waugh (94 balls, 5x4).

Colombo (Sinhalese), August 28
Toss: India
Australia 252 for 8 in 50 overs (Gilchrist 77, Symonds 45, Ponting 32)
India 211 in 48.3 overs (Ramesh 71, Singh 75, Gillespie 4-26)
Australia won by 41 runs
MoM Adam Gilchrist (9x4). India fined 1 over for slow rate; they were 44-5, then Sadagoppan Ramesh (4x4)/Robin Singh (4x4, 1x6) 123 for 6th wicket.

Colombo (Sinhalese), August 29
Toss: Sri Lanka
India 296 for 4 in 50 overs (Tendulkar 120, Ramesh 32, Ganguly 85)
Sri Lanka 247 for 9 in 42 overs (Jayasuriya 71, Atapattu 55, Jayawardene 62)
India won by 23 runs (revised target)
Sachin Tendulkar (141 balls, 11x4, 2x6) record 23rd ODI 100. Sri Lanka's target was revised to 271 from 42 overs (D/L) after rain; they needed to exceed 232 to qualify for the final ahead of India on overall run rate.

Final
Colombo (Premadasa), August 31 (day/night)
Toss: Australia
Australia 202 in 50 overs (Mark Waugh 32, Steve Waugh 43)
Sri Lanka 208 for 2 in 39.3 overs (Kaluwitharana 95*, Arnold 47).
Sri Lanka won by 8 wickets
MoM Romesh Kaluwitharana (12x4). Sanath Jayasuriya (26*) ended the match with a 6 off Darren Lehmann. Man of Series: Adam Gilchrist.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly
fields.bodyText: CARLTON & UNITED SERIES Australia, India, Pakistan January 9, Brisbane (day/night) Toss: Pakistan Pakistan 184 for 8 in 50 overs (Moin Khan 33, Wasim Akram 35, Saqlain Mushtaq 37*, Symonds 3-34) Australia 139 in 39 overs (Ponting 32, Bevan 31*, Shoaib Akhtar 3-31, Abdur Razzaq 4-23) Pakistan won by 45 runs ODI debut Brett Lee (Australia, RF). Pakistan recovered from 60-6; Australia collapsed from 72-2 to 79-7 in 33 balls. Saqlain Mushtaq ODI HS. MoM Abdur Razzaq. January 10, Brisbane (day/night) Toss: India India 195 in 48.5 overs (Ganguly 61, Singh 50, Extras 30, Shoaib Akhtar 3-19) Pakistan 196 for 8 in 49 overs (Yousuf Youhana 63, Srinath 4-49) Pakistan won by 2 wickets ODI debut Sameer Dighe (India, RHB, WK). Pakistan fined 1 over for slow over-rate. Pakistan were 71-6, then Yousuf Youhana (MoM, 8x4) 49 for 7th wkt with Wasim Akram and 33 for 8th with Saqlain Mushtaq. January 12, Melbourne (day/night) Toss: Australia Australia 269 for 7 in 50 overs (Ponting 115, Bevan 41, Martyn 30) India 241 for 6 in 50 overs (Ganguly 100, Dravid 60, Singh 34*) Australia won by 28 runs Ricky Ponting (MoM) 121 balls, 9x4, 1x6. Sourav Ganguly (10th ODI 100, 127 balls, 10x4)/109 for 4th wkt with Rahul Dravid. Play held up for 17 minutes after Ganguly's dismissal when spectators threw bottles onto the pitch. January 14, Sydney (day/night) Toss: India India 100 in 36.3 overs (Extras 32, McGrath 4-8, Symonds 4-11) Australia 101 for 5 in 26.5 overs (Gilchrist 37, Srinath 4-30) Australia won by 5 wickets Glenn McGrath 10-4-8-4, Andrew Symonds (MoM, ODI BB) 3.3-0-11-4. Only 3 Indians reached double-figures; Extras top-scored. January 16, Melbourne Toss: Australia Pakistan 176 for 9 in 41 overs (Saeed Anwar 49, Abdur Razzaq 51*, Shane Lee 3-24) Australia 177 for 4 in 38.5 overs (Steve Waugh 81*, Martyn 39*) Australia won by 6 wickets Match reduced to 41 overs a side after rain delayed start until 12.30pm. Pakistan 92 for 6, then Abdur Razzaq 51* off 54 balls (4x4). MoM Steve Waugh. January 19, Sydney (day/night) Toss: Australia Australia 286 in 49.4 overs (Mark Waugh 43, Bevan 77, Martyn 50, Symonds 47, Wasim Akram 3-40) Pakistan 205 in 45.2 overs (Abdur Razzaq 40, Waqar Younis 37, MacGill 4-19) Australia won by 81 runs ODI debut and MoM Stuart MacGill (LB): 10-2-19-4. Andrew Symonds 26 balls, 5x4, 2x6; Shane Lee 26 in 13 balls, 3x4, 1x6. Pakistan fined 1 over for slow over-rate. January 21, Hobart Toss: India Pakistan 262 for 7 in 50 overs (Saeed Anwar 43, Ijaz Ahmed 67, Yousuf Youhana 45, Abdur Razzaq 70*) India 230 in 46.5 overs (Tendulkar 93, Ganguly 43, Wasim Akram 3-43, Abdur Razzaq 5-48) Pakistan won by 32 runs India fined 2 overs for slow over-rate. Abdur Razzaq (MoM) 52 balls, 4x4, 2x6 (HS); Sachin Tendulkar 10x4. January 23, Melbourne (day/night) Toss: Australia Australia 260 for 9 in 50 overs (Ponting 53, Bevan 83, Symonds 35) Pakistan 245 in 48.5 overs (Shahid Afridi 45, Ijaz Ahmed 85, Moin Khan 33, Shane Lee 4-37) Australia won by 15 runs MoM Bevan. Australia ensured qualification for the final. January 25, Adelaide (day/night) Toss: India India 267 for 6 in 50 overs (Tendulkar 41, Ganguly 141, Dravid 32) Pakistan 219 in 44.4 overs (Ijaz Ahmed 54, Azhar Mahmood 67, Kumble 4-40) India won by 48 runs Sourav Ganguly (MoM) 11th ODI 100, 144 balls, 12x4, 1x6. January 26, Adelaide (day/night) Toss: Australia Australia 329 for 5 in 50 overs (Gilchrist 92, Mark Waugh 116, Ponting 43) India 177 in 46.5 overs (Dravid 63, Brett Lee 5-27) Australia won by 152 runs Adam Gilchrist (102 balls, 7x4, 2x6)/Mark Waugh (131 balls, 5x4, 1x6) 163 for 1st wkt. Ricky Ponting 33 balls; Andrew Symonds 26 in 15 balls; Shane Lee 27* in 15. The highest ODI score in Australia (prev 323, Australia v Sri Lanka, 1984-85). Brett Lee best bowling. January 28, Perth (day/night) Toss: Pakistan Pakistan 261 for 8 in 50 overs (Saeed Anwar 44, Shahid Afridi 41, Inzamam-ul-Haq 35, Wasim Akram 35*, Ganguly 3-34) India 157 in 46 overs (Singh 51, Martin 39, Wasim Akram 3-10, Shahid Afridi 3-41) Pakistan won by 104 runs Pakistan qualified for the final. Wasim Akram (MoM) 7-4-10-3 as India collapsed to 33-5. January 30, Perth Toss: India India 226 for 6 in 50 overs (Dravid 65, Kanitkar 30, Singh 45, Dighe 36*) Australia 230 for 6 in 49.3 overs (Mark Waugh 40, Ponting 33, Bevan 71) Australia won by 4 wickets MoM Bevan (9x4) 1st FINAL February 2, Melbourne (day/night) Toss: Pakistan Pakistan 154 in 47.2 overs (Moin Khan 47, McGrath 3-17, Brett Lee 3-18) Australia 155 for 4 in 42.4 overs (Ponting 50, Bevan 54) Australia won by 6 wickets Glenn McGrath (MoM) removed Shahid Afridi, Ijaz Ahmed and Inzamam-ul-Haq for ducks to reduce Pakistan to 4-3; later 28-5. Australia went 1-0 up in best-of-three finals. 2nd FINAL, February 4, Sydney (day/night) Toss: Australia Australia 337 for 7 in 50 overs (Mark Waugh 53, Gilchrist 51, Ponting 78, Symonds 45, Steve Waugh 37) Pakistan 185 in 36.3 overs (Yousuf Youhana 41, Moin Khan 33, McGrath 5-49, Brett Lee 3-51) Australia won by 152 runs Australia went 2-0 up to lift the Carlton & United Trophy. Adam Gilchrist 42 balls, 8x4; Ponting 80 balls, 9x4; Symonds 45 balls; Steve Waugh 30 balls, 4x4; Waqar Younis 4-0-38-0. Australia's highest ODI total, beating 332 v Sri Lanka at Sharjah in 1989/90. Australia won their last nine matches in the competition. NEW ZEALAND v WEST INDIES January 2, Auckland Toss: West Indies West Indies268 for 7 in 50 overs (Campbell 51, Jacobs 65, Lara 76, Powell 35) New Zealand 250 for 7 in 45.1 overs (Astle 77, Cairns 75, Rose 3-71, King 3-24) New Zealand won by 3 wickets (D/L method) Sherwin Campbell (6x4)/Ridley Jacobs (7x4, 2x6) 111 for 1st wkt. Brian Lara 3x4, 2x6. Jimmy Adams (West Indies) out for 0 in 100th ODI. 20-min rain delay when New Zealand were 153-3 (31.1 overs): target revised to 250 from 46 overs. Nathan Astle (MoM; 101 balls, 7x4, 1x6)/Chris Cairns (2x4, 6x6) 136 for 4th wkt (New Zealand ODI record for any wkt v West Indies). January 4, Taupo (day/night) Toss: New Zealand West Indies 192 in 41.3 overs (Adams 69, Powell 35, Vettori 4-24) New Zealand 194 for 3 in 35.4 overs (Spearman 42, Astle 32, Fleming 59*) New Zealand won by 7 wickets Start delayed due to rain - reduced to 42-overs match. fields.headline: Blair caught off-message
fields.trailText: Question time: New Labour's famous pagers failed today when the prime minister was caught on the hop over Alun Michael's resignation at question time.
fields.body:
New Labour's famous pagers failed today when the prime minister was caught on the hop over Alun Michael's resignation at question time.

Quizzed by Tory leader William Hague on the former first secretary of the Welsh assembly, Tony Blair said that Mr Michael had his full support - apparently unaware that he had tendered his resignation minutes earlier.

Mr Michael had been due to face a vote of no confidence over his handling of the Welsh budget crisis.

Delighted by Millbank's collapse in communication Mr Hague told the House: "He doesn't know what's happened."

In response Mr Blair attacked the Tories over policy and accused them of "being in bed" with Plaid Cymru in trying to secure extra public spending despite the Tories' tax guarantee. He refused to comment on Mr Hague's suggestion that Mr Michael had resigned.

"Once the fun and games are over, Mr Hague is going to have to explain how it is that the nationalists and Tories are joined together in a demand for extra public spending," he said. "They are demanding we spend an extra £200 million in Wales, while maintaining a tax guarantee."

Mr Michael resigned in a formal speech to the assembly.

Other business

Clause 28: The prime minister vowed to press ahead with the abolition of Section 28, prohibiting the promotion of homosexuality in schools, despite a heavy Lords defeat on the issue. Mr Blair attacked those who were using the controversy to "exploit anti-gay feelings" and warned: "These are the opponents I intend to take on."

Tax: Mr Hague told the Commons that his party's 'guarantee to reduce the tax burden over a parliament, remained. "The tax guarantee stands and the tax guarantee will continue to stand," he said.

webTitle: Disability rights: Voice of the people

fields.headline: Voice of the people
fields.standfirst: Naomi Marks meets a  woman who has learned the  hard way why it is essential  to challenge discrimination
fields.trailText: Naomi Marks meets a woman who has learned the hard way why it is essential to challenge discrimination.
fields.body:
When the new Disability Rights Commission held its first meeting last Friday, sitting with the other 14 commissioners was Evelyn Rank-Petruzzietto, the first person with a learning disability to be appointed to such a post. But her presence, she has been assured, is no token gesture. She will have the same input and responsibilities as her counterparts when the DRC opens its doors for business in April.

The purpose of the DRC, like the Equal Opportunities Commission and the Commission for Racial Equality, is to promote the ending of discrimination. It will prepare and review statutory codes of practice, carry out research, champion good practice, make arrangements for conciliation and undertake formal investigations in specific cases of alleged discrimination.

Rank-Petruzzietto's appointment has been heralded as something of a breakthrough for people with learning disabilities. Yet, until her late twenties, she was not even familiar with the term. She had been labelled "dunce", "slow" and other derogatory names which belie the enthusiastic, articulate and socially adept 32-year-old she is.

In the last few years, she has taught herself to read and write, gained an NVQ in business administration, and trained nurses, psychologists and care staff in the rights of people with learning disabilities.

"My mum and dad told me I was backward, and I didn't have a clue what that meant," she says of her early years.

Starved of oxygen at birth, she had a childhood marred by the names she was called. A close brush with a car at the age of seven meant a protective mother kept a close guard on her and she didn't go to a shop on her own until she was 14.

She was put in the remedial class of her Grimsby comprehensive, where, for the last two years of her schooling, she says she was taught nothing, just left alone with a book - somewhat oddly, since she wasn't even literate at that stage.

After school she went on a succession of government schemes, ending with a job making soft toys. "I hated every minute of it," she says. "I was picked on because I was the only one with learning difficulties."

At 18, she was so miserable she ran away to Sheffield with just 90p in her pocket. She found herself placed by social services in a home for battered women because"they didn't know where else to put me".

At 25, after an unhappy six-year marriage, she was placed in a home for people with learning disabilities. It was a good home, she says, and she left only because she had formed a relationship with the man - also with learning disabilities - who subsequently became her second husband.

Settling in Peterborough, she attended a day centre, "drinking cups of tea and doing art stuff", before she decided she wanted to move on. She taught herself to read and write, motivated by becoming a Christian and her frustration at wading through a children's bible. She later enrolled in college, eventually gaining her NVQ.

It was three years ago that Speaking Up, a self-advocacy organisation in Cambridge, heard about her and asked her to help at a training session for Mencap staff on the rights of people with learning difficulties. "I hadn't a clue what I was letting myself in for." she says

What she was letting herself in for was a host of further training work with care professionals, as well as people with learning difficulties themselves.

Rank-Petruzzietto is now chair of Speaking Up, as well as editing its newsletter. She is also spokesperson for People First, another self-advocacy charity, and is European officer for that organisation.

fields.headline: Survival courses
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Weinstein on the way to rescue a profession in crisis
fields.trailText: Jeremy Weinstein on the way to rescue a profession in crisis.
fields.body:
A group of 28 students, half of them white and half black, start their social work programme in an inner-city new university. They are all graduates, all have at least two years' experience working in a care setting and all have undergone individual and group interviews before being offered a place. They seem excited and committed to the training they are about to undertake.

One slips away within weeks, leaving with no explanation; another gets a coveted placement in an area office and then leaves, disillusioned with social work. Two ask to have their places deferred - one is pregnant, the other reports feeling stressed - and neither returns. Three fail - two of them acrimoniously, without submitting any work. Overall, a quarter fail to complete the course.

This salutary story is one aspect of the current crisis in social work, explored in a newly published collection of papers, Education And Training For Care Professionals, from which this material is drawn.

My focus is on the selection and retention of students considered against the backdrop of a decrease, between 1995 and 1998, of 35% in application rates to social work programmes.

In 1999/2000 the free fall continues while job vacancies in social work increase and there are real fears about ensuring that children are protected and the needs of an ageing population are adequately met.

These problems are not unique to social work. Other "caring" (hence underpaid, undervalued) professions, such as teaching, are not attracting sufficient applicants, while the NHS executive notes attrition rates ranging from 5% to 30% on pre-registration nursing and midwifery programmes. But social work does have its own difficult dynamic. Persistent media attacks and uncertainties about the social work role in the mixed economy of welfare have significantly reduced the attractiveness of social work as a profession.

Undergraduates face the abolition of student grants and the introduction of fees without the financial support offered to nursing students. Postgraduates have bursaries but these barely meet the needs of mature students with families and mortgages. Consequently most have to work part-time, fitting in shift work around the demands of essays, placements and domestic commitments.

New requirements, introduced to improve the standards of social work education, mean much more rigorous assessment both of academic work and professional practice. While well overdue, these extra demands have coincided with rapid expansion and resource limitations in higher education. Just when students need more support, many programmes have been forced to abandon the individual tutorial, replace small seminar groups with large lectures and cut back on tutor visits to students on their practice placements.

Changes in the student profile bring both challenges and opportunities. In the 1970s, most students were young, white and middle class and although they rarely failed their courses they stood accused of failing clients who came from backgrounds outside their experience. Ironically, having now succeeded in attracting mature individuals and people from ethnic minority backgrounds into social work, social work tutors struggle to heed their own teaching about institutional racism and disadvantage to provide the necessary support.

This means re-emphasising their traditional role of part educator part counsellor and identifying the potential points of crisis for each individual student noting more proactively attendance, patterns of marks for assignments and signs of personal stress.

Attention must also be paid to the wider culture of the programme, which transcends the experience of the individual. Tutors and students together need to recognise key danger points, putting in place appropriate support mechanisms, especially at the major points of transition such as the pre-programme period and preparing for placement. Academic work needs to be improved; it is here that students fail, not on placement. Strategies include writing workshops and more appropriate assignments, such as report writing and seminar presentations rather than being unduly reliant on the traditional essay.

There is much to be proud of in social work education. We have widened access to training, recruited students that reflect the ethnic diversity of the wider society and established high standards for assessing professional practice - all objectives that other professional groups are still striving for. And we need help. No other European country expects social work students to develop the skills and knowledge necessary for complex work in child protection and care management in a bare two years. The government, as it develops plans to replace the current arrangements for social work education, needs to deliver both additional funding and an extension of the training to raise the qualification, at minimum, to graduate status.

 Jeremy Weinstein is course director for the MSc in social work, South Bank university, London. Innovative Education And Training For Care Professionals, A Provider's Guide, edited by Rachel Pierce and Jenny Weinstein, is published by Jessica Kingsley (tel: 0207-833 2307).

webTitle: Diary of a New Deal participant

fields.headline: Personal affront
fields.standfirst: Margaret Gray was not too impressed with  her training-for-work programme
fields.trailText: Margaret Gray was not too impressed with her training-for-work programme.
fields.body:
Until recently, I had a personal adviser, a personal tutor, a facilitator and a placement tutor. Why all the attention? It's the New Deal, stupid!

Last spring, I joined the New Deal for the 25-plus and visited the smartly refurbished and colour coordinated upper floor of the job centre for my first interview with my personal adviser - from whom I do not recall receiving any useful advice. I was at the "Gateway", where I was to spend 13 weeks supposedly taking action to overcome any barriers to work.

I was enrolled at a programme centre - an updated version of a job club - run by a charitable organisation (everything is contracted out these days).

Each person was allocated a facilitator. Mine didn't have much to do with me. Why? I tried to approach him, but I was told bluntly: "I can see you know what you're doing so I let you get on with it". So for the rest of my time at the programme centre - once a week for seven months - I continued to get on with whatever it was I was supposed to be doing.

After three months, it was time to leave the Gateway. "A full-time course?" I suggested to my personal adviser, who retorted that I was too well qualified. It had to be a work placement, so I chose the provider organisation which offered work placements with the city council. I wanted to get in there and start asking questions. Why was a Labour council involved in the New Deal? What about payment at the rate for the job, etc?

However, to obtain a work placement seemed harder than getting a job. There was a three stage interview: first with the placement provider, next with the council liaison officer and finally with an officer from the relevant council department. Extraordinary! All for no proper job and salary! At the third interview, it was as I had suspected. The work consisted of simple tasks which others were too busy to do. Having ascertained that there would be no job at the end, nor would I have any advantage when applying for council posts, I couldn't honestly say that I was interested. I heard no more about it.

At the job centre, my personal adviser disappeared for the next few months, and I was without one. I was officially on the intensive activity period, yet nothing had changed.

Five weeks later, when summer faded into autumn, I made my way, somewhat unwillingly, to the offices of a voluntary organisation, where I had been told to attend an interview with the placement tutor to discuss a New Deal placement. I was to upgrade my computer skills in the upper floor computer room, where there were a dozen computers.

A personal tutor from the college came to see me there and enrol me on a key skills course; he would visit me every few weeks for a meeting (tutorial?). He had an HND and told me he was doing a postgraduate course. I was given a questionnaire to complete. First, some statements to finish - my mental skills are... (OK) and so on. Then on to the yes/no questions. It was "no" to every one. For example: "Do you need help with writing letters?"

I spent up to four half days a week at the voluntary organisation's offices, practising on a computer. The computer exercises began to pall after a while.

With one exception, I could not credit any of those in authority with whom I came into contact on the New Deal with a great deal of intelligence. Most of the people were fairly pleasant; it was just that empathy was not a word with which they were familiar. Neither did they appear to have much knowledge or understanding of the labour market and the reasons why some of the unemployed find it hard to obtain work.

Soon, my time spent at the voluntary organisation was down to two half days a week, and tea breaks expanded into longish reading breaks.

The three "tutorials" on key skills were an amusing diversion, but rather a waste of time. And I never had a satisfactory explanation, or was able to define for myself, what key skills actually were.

The 10 weeks there ended, as did the seven months at the programme centre - which, despite its peculiarities, I had grown to quite like and would miss the useful access to phones and newspapers and also the people who came and went.

At the job centre just before Christmas I was allocated a new personal adviser for the next 13 weeks on the New Deal. The conversation was such as I had had more times than I cared to remember.

"Why can't you get the jobs you get shortlisted for?"

"I don't get shortlisted for many."

"Do you contact the employer to ask why you weren't appointed?"

"No, I would not be told the truth." And so on.

Later, I started to think about the lottery of application forms, job interviews and obtaining work. Could next time be different? Maybe, just maybe.

 Margaret Gray is a pseudonym

fields.headline: Sense of togetherness
fields.standfirst: Norman Warner, chair of the working group on involving people in their  own communities, rejects claims that it by-passed the grassroots
fields.trailText: Norman Warner, chair of the working group on involving people in their own communities, rejects claims that it by-passed the grassroots.
fields.body:
Wally Harbert's criticisms of our report, Giving Time, Getting Involved, in last week's Society were wide of the mark. The working group I chaired was set up by Tony Blair to produce a strategy for making it easier for more people to get involved in their communities. We were working in the context of a slowdown in people volunteering, especially among the young, and in the giving of money. Active community involvement needs a stimulus - not more of the same that Wally Harbert is suggesting.

Our working group made 26 recommendations to deliver a step-like increase in community involvement over the next decade. These are aimed at encouraging people to get involved in current and new community activities; creating more opportunities; and sustaining momentum. We have to address the way people get their information and find out about opportunities in their communities. Of course, local word of mouth and personal contact are important parts of people becoming volunteers. But the media and internet are of major importance in our society and should be used more.

People use the telephone much more to conduct their daily lives and we need to recognise that in bringing people into community activities. In particular, we want to see more effort to get the young and people from ethnic minorities involved in their communities.

People want to be asked to join in. They may want to join in with their friends or work colleagues, but they want to know more about what they are letting themselves in for before they join. They may have limited time, so they will want to do things when it is convenient to them.

T he public sector, which provides many volunteering opportunities, and the voluntary sector, which manages many of them, need to be more imaginative, flexible and welcoming if more people are to become involved in their communities.

Wally Harbert seems to criticise our proposals for better management of volunteers. But the 1997 Survey of Volunteering found poor organisation was seen by 71% of respondents as the main disadvantage of volunteering. If people are giving up their time, they want to know what's expected of them and that there is proper organisation and management. More professionals and good training in this area would do wonders. But we are fully supportive of making full use of professional managers who retire early from the private and public sectors.

We never suggested wholesale ditching of present arrangements for volunteering. Quite the reverse. We need to build on strengths and tackle weaknesses.

We never assumed that we knew all the answers. That is why we recommended demonstration projects to test out a variety of new approaches in local areas for getting people involved.

I am pleased that the government is funding these new projects. Greater involvement of the media is starting.

Wally Harbert suggests that ours is a centralist-driven and top-down approach to community involvement. This is non sense. The working group was a diverse mix of people from the voluntary sector, the public agencies, business, the media and government. Quite a few had direct experience of volunteering and community involvement.

We all know that people will only get involved in their communities if they want to. But leadership in this area is important, as is public debate.

Our report was not a centralising blue print but an agenda for starting discussion and encouraging more people to get involved in their communities. This involvement is a key part of citizenship and of a vibrant democracy.

 Lord Warner, chairman of the Youth Justice Board, chaired the government working group which produced the report Giving Time, Getting Involved.

fields.headline: Profits of doom
fields.standfirst: Tony Juniper asks if  big business will bear  the costs of protecting  the environment
fields.trailText: Tony Juniper asks if big business will bear the costs of protecting the environment.
fields.body:
This year's World Economic Forum meeting, in the Swiss ski resort of Davos, confirmed that plans to rapidly agree and implement a comprehensive new round of free trade talks are alive and well. Tony Blair captured the tone of the meeting admirably when he told the 1,000 corporate chiefs and dozens of heads of state present that he believed we "can and should try to launch the new trade round this year".

Warming to this theme, President Clinton's message was that the critics of economic globalisation were misguided and suggested that the world's top business executives should develop their own vision for the future and spend the next 10 to 20 years implementing it. "You can change the world," Clinton told the captains of industry.

But how will they change the world if new trade rules give them even more power?

A huge advertising banner in downtown Davos gave a clue: "Think Global, Eat Local". It was not placed by Friends of the Earth's "real food" campaigners, but by McDonald's. This most recent offering of spin from the tenderers of one of the world's most famous brands speaks volumes about unease among business leaders.

An electronic poll of WEF participants in Davos asked what was the most pressing issue facing business in the future. Climate change was their answer. So surprising was this result that the conference organisers re-ran the vote, lest there had been some mistake. Second time around, climate change got an even bigger vote. Significantly, the most popular prediction after climate change was that financial stability would be an issue in the future.

What is apparently less clear to the business leaders is the extent to which these two challenges are linked. As multi-billion pound insurance payouts from storms, floods, heat waves and deep freezes causes economic chaos, the implications for the financial markets are profound. But the fact that the workshop on climate change was one of the most poorly attended sessions in Davos underlines how the awesome challenges posed by human-induced shifts in global weather patterns do not yet register as issues central to business.

One major problem is that sustainable development and economic policy are debated in different forums and by different people. The crucial integration of ideas, policy and law is still not taking place.

And while Davos championed proposals to beef up free trade rules, no participants could be heard calling for tougher targets in the climate change convention or for new incentives to accelerate the market penetration of clean technologies such as solar power and fuel cells.

For all the talk of the new economy, no practical suggestions for merging environmental, social and economic goals could be heard. Instead, it all sounds rather like the old economy, where the ownership of knowledge by the few excludes most of the world from the benefits of "development".

But this year's Davos meeting does at least show that the message is getting through. Blair and Clinton urged the business leaders to listen to their critics. But will they listen when new environmental bills come before parliament or congress? Or will they continue with their old ways of protecting profits at almost any ecological or cultural cost?

 Tony Juniper is policy director of Friends of the Earth.
fields.bodyText: This year's World Economic Forum meeting, in the Swiss ski resort of Davos, confirmed that plans to rapidly agree and implement a comprehensive new round of free trade talks are alive and well. Tony Blair captured the tone of the meeting admirably when he told the 1,000 corporate chiefs and dozens of heads of state present that he believed we "can and should try to launch the new trade round this year". Warming to this theme, President Clinton's message was that the critics of economic globalisation were misguided and suggested that the world's top business executives should develop their own vision for the future and spend the next 10 to 20 years implementing it. "You can change the world," Clinton told the captains of industry. But how will they change the world if new trade rules give them even more power? A huge advertising banner in downtown Davos gave a clue: "Think Global, Eat Local". It was not placed by Friends of the Earth's "real food" campaigners, but by McDonald's. This most recent offering of spin from the tenderers of one of the world's most famous brands speaks volumes about unease among business leaders. An electronic poll of WEF participants in Davos asked what was the most pressing issue facing business in the future. Climate change was their answer. So surprising was this result that the conference organisers re-ran the vote, lest there had been some mistake. Second time around, climate change got an even bigger vote. Significantly, the most popular prediction after climate change was that financial stability would be an issue in the future. What is apparently less clear to the business leaders is the extent to which these two challenges are linked. As multi-billion pound insurance payouts from storms, floods, heat waves and deep freezes causes economic chaos, the implications for the financial markets are profound. But the fact that the workshop on climate change was one of the most poorly attended sessions in Davos underlines how the awesome challenges posed by human-induced shifts in global weather patterns do not yet register as issues central to business. One major problem is that sustainable development and economic policy are debated in different forums and by different people. The crucial integration of ideas, policy and law is still not taking place. And while Davos championed proposals to beef up free trade rules, no participants could be heard calling for tougher targets in the climate change convention or for new incentives to accelerate the market penetration of clean technologies such as solar power and fuel cells. For all the talk of the new economy, no practical suggestions for merging environmental, social and economic goals could be heard. Instead, it all sounds rather like the old economy, where the ownership of knowledge by the few excludes most of the world from the benefits of "development". But this year's Davos meeting does at least show that the message is getting through. Blair and Clinton urged the business leaders to listen to their critics. But will they listen when new environmental bills come before parliament or congress? Or will they continue with their old ways of protecting profits at almost any ecological or cultural cost?  Tony Juniper is policy director of Friends of the Earth.

fields.headline: Pride of place
fields.standfirst: In the 1970s, Bob Holman founded a youth  project on an estate in Bath.  He's been back to find out if  it helped the boys and girls  who are now  thirtysomethings
fields.trailText: In the 1970s, Bob Holman founded a youth project on an estate in Bath. He's been back to find out if it helped the boys and girls who are now thirtysomethings.
fields.body:
Community projects come and go. Rarely are attempts made to ascertain their long-term influence on users. But this was just what I was able to do when I went back recently to interview former youngsters from the Southdown estate, Bath, where there were significant numbers of poor people.

In 1976, I initiated the Southdown Community Project and was joined by Dave Wiles, a local young man with a record of delinquency. For five years it was based at my home, with clubs, parent and toddler groups and individual callers cramming in. Residents then raised money for a purpose-built building next to the public toilets. Dave and I swapped roles, with him becoming the leader.

After 10 years, it was completely in the hands of the community and my family and I moved to Glasgow.

Now I have been back to Southdown. Hundreds of kids went through the project and I made a list of 88 who had been close to it for several years. Of these, eight have died and some could not be traced. However, the third main leader, Jane Sellars, and I were able to interview 51. Nearly all of them had come from low-income parents with almost half raised by lone parents or step-parent families. In their early teens, when they were drawn into the project, 57% were experiencing difficulties at school, 39% were in trouble with the police and 22% were in homes visited by social workers. On a risk scale, 39% were rated as at high risk of future criminality, unemployment and unstable relationships.

So how did they turn out? An assessment was made of them in their late teens and in adulthood. Between the ages of 16-19, a quarter of the youngsters were without any educational qualifications, nine had endured long periods of unemployment and seven had committed a series of offences. However, none had received a custodial sentence and only one girl had been taken into public care.

By 1999, when most were in their early 30s, the outcomes were even more positive. Fourteen per cent had been convicted of mostly minor offences but none was in prison. None had a serious drugs problem. Nearly all were in two-parent situations with just 6% being lone parents. Most were in low-paid employment, although there were exceptions with three men and three women in management posts. Interestingly, 41% had participated in some form of youth work, usually as volunteers. Overall, 86% were deemed as being in satisfactory life situations - a pleasing finding considering that so many had started with childhood disadvantages.

No doubt, many factors contributed to the favourable outcomes, including the qualities of the individuals themselves. But all 51 agreed that the Southdown Project had improved the quality of their childhoods, while a number were convinced it had steered them away from trouble. The following factors were identified as vital.

First, the neighbourhood approach. The youth activities were open to any youngsters and were not restricted to delinquents. Consequently, attendance at the clubs did not stigmatise members. Further, youngsters who did have problems were influenced by peers who did not.

Certainly, the clubs filled a gap. As one woman put it: "We were hanging around on street corners. We didn't do anything else apart from the project. Without that, a lot more people would have gone off the rails."

Second, a place of their own. An old lean-to on the side of our house became a den for 15 teenagers. As one former member said: "It was the focal point for our group. It was where we met every night." They talked, larked around, strummed guitars and smoked. It was their place. They kept out of trouble without adults being present.

Third, individual relationships. Through the clubs, the youngsters got to trust staff to whom they could turn when in need of help. Two-thirds of the 51 developed personal relationships with the three leaders over matters such as truancy, pregnancy, delinquency and difficulties with parents. One present manager of several shops had been frequently in trouble with the police and spent much of his time at our home. He said: "Without the project I would almost certainly have got into more trouble. If I had been kicked out of school permanently what would have happened? What would have happened if I had been sent away?"

Fourth, the staff lived in the neighbourhood and so were always available. As one interviewee explained: "The leaders were not simply people coming in and then going off, with nothing really happening. They were there 24 hours a day." Our presence meant that not only did we become known to youngsters but also to adults, many of whom became volunteers.

Fifth, the staff were committed to staying a minimum of 10 years. We supported the schools, the pubs and the churches of the area and, over time, the project also became regarded as a part of the neighbourhood. Not least, the staff grew up with families. It was easier to relate with some disruptive teenagers when they had been known since they were small.

The essence of the Southdown Project was a neighbourhood approach developed by staff who lived long term in the area. These features do not feature prominently in the publications of New Labour's youth justice board and social exclusion unit. In favour now are short-term interventions aimed at targeted youngsters by professionals who commute in.

Of course, the Southdown strategy is just one way of helping young people. But the outcomes of this study suggest that large statutory and voluntary bodies should direct some money at committed teams who are prepared to become a part of needy areas.

 Bob Holman's book, Kids At The Door Revisited (Russell House Publications, £9.95), is published tomorrow.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Knocking environmentalists
fields.body:
Knocking environmentalists is great media sport, especially when journalists can paraphrase a lot of the stuff being put out by free-market think tanks in Europe and America or can reach for industry-funded "experts". So, good on the Beeb for following up last year's loaded Scare Stories with a Counterblast series, which last week tried to persuade us that organic food was more dangerous to health than conventional pesticide-grown food.

The series, said a publicity woman, is intended to allow "members of the public" to air their views. Well, by definition, the presenter, Roger Bate, is a member of the public, but he comes with a very public agenda, which he pushed for years when head of the eco-unit of the Institute of Economic Affairs - the rightwing ideologues who helped pave the way for Thatcherism. Roger's bunch, identifying early that NGOs and environment groups were a threat to industry and the global order, argued strongly to the effect that global warming was a myth, that the environment is getting better, that tropical forests are not coming down, that killing baby seals is a good thing and that nature should be privatised for its own protection.

All good, batty, contrarian stuff. But the Beeb gave viewers no clue that Roger had a past - or a present, beyond working for the little-known European Science and Environment Forum. So who are they? Judging by their papers, they love nuclear energy, believe that global warming is a myth, argue that environmentalists and NGOs are eco-imperialists and, yes, are dangerous to democracy, etc, etc.

Challenge for Rog: tell us who precisely funds the ESEF? Or the IEA?

 Over to Channel 4, which was humiliated last year by the Independent Televisison Commission (ITC) for selectively editing and misrepresenting the views of some of its green contributors to the prime-time series Against Nature. C4 never apologised and, indeed, seems so pleased with the director, Martin Durkin, that it has commissioned him to do a major programme about GM foods, which should be shown next month. Gosh. Will Martin, a great friend of those other environmental contrarians Living Marxism (some of whose contributors write anti-environment and anti-NGO papers for the ESEF), pin governments or scientists to the wall? Will he investigate dodgy science or what's going on in Brazil? Probably not. The man from the C4 press office says: "I suspect [the programme] is along the lines of, 'Are we depriving the world of a vital food source because of western neurosis?"' Interestingly, Friends of the Earth will not be taking part after their experience with Martin last time round.

Question for Martin: how many contributors will you include who contribute to LM, or ESEF or the IEA?
