fields.headline: Painful truth
fields.standfirst: Gill Pugh on the minefield Barnardo's has to  tread in opening up its confidential files
fields.trailText: Gill Pugh on the minefield Barnardo's has to tread in opening up its confidential files.
fields.body:
In 1995, Barnardo's opened its original records to adults who had been in its care as children. The charity's files, going back to 1866, cover most of the 350,000 children cared for in its homes until the late 1970s. Inquirers had previously received information in the form of a written summary, but now original documents were available. In the same year, the BBC series Barnardo's Children brought the charity's change of heart to the public attention.

Until the 1950s, most children left care with little or no knowledge of their family histories, growing up at a time when starting afresh with a "clean slate" was believed to be in their best interests. Now the charity was deluged with requests for information - 4,000 in the first few weeks alone. Despite doubling the social work team to tackle the demand, the backlog remained high until this year.

Giving people information about their background is not a simple matter of handing over a file; it needs the assistance of a social worker. The records were never intended to be seen by their subjects, and the contents can be difficult to deal with. The language is sometimes harsh and judgmental and the details can be distressing or confusing.

Many people have not had the chance to discuss their early childhood experiences, and they often need help to cope with a range of powerful emotions. People build up hopes, fears and fantasies about what their records may contain, and assim ilating new information about their past can cause pain, confusion, intense excitement or profound disappointment.

In interviews with 12 adults a year after they had viewed their records, I found that, despite the frustrating wait for information, most people who had completed the process were able to appreciate with hindsight the need for social worker support, and had found the counselling on receiving their records helpful.

The people I spoke to fell into three broad groups. First were those who belonged to "real families". They had been separated from their birth families at a very young age and had lived most of their childhood with one foster family, where they had a sense of belonging and being loved. As Mary, aged 58, put it: "Mum used to say she chose us and she loved us and that's why she had us."

At the other extreme were the "rootless" adults. They had been in Barnardo's care from a very young age but had lacked a settled family life, being moved about between residential and foster homes - and, in some cases, being abused or neglected. These adults had felt unloved as children, and their attempts to get information about their families and the reasons for being in care had been rebuffed. "When you went into Barnardo's homes everything was censored and you didn't know anything and you weren't allowed to contact your relations at all," said Fred, aged 66. "I just think at times they were cruel. The older you get the more angry you become."

The third group, which I referred to as "rescued", had spent their early childhood with their birth families, but were removed to residential care following abuse or neglect. These adults seemed grateful to Barnardo's and compared their new lives favourably with what might have been. For them, Barnardo's became the substitute family, the alternative source of belonging and identity come into Barnardo's care after his father's death. He said: "I felt protected in Barnardo's. We were growing up in a stronger world than a world dominated by a woman who really only wanted us out of the way."

For the "rootless" adults, the impact of receiving new information had been almost overwhelming. Lifelong feelings of ignorance about who they were and feelings of stigma because of a lack of family meant that any new information about themselves had a magnified importance, and its impact could be dramatic.

Alf, who discovered at the age of 70 that he had been born within marriage and that he had two brothers, felt huge elation: "As soon as that was mentioned I was a different person. I feel as though something's been lifted off me. I'm just as good as anyone else - I've got a family!".

Neither Alf's wife nor children, let alone his friends, had known that he was a Barnardo's boy. Over the next year, he was able to adapt to a new identity that he could be proud of and open about socially.

Among those from the "real families" group there appeared to be a reluctance to delve too far. They drew their sense of identity from their foster families and feared discovering something which might threaten this security. The new information had not changed their feelings about themselves. "It didn't make me feel any different," said Mary. "I think I had such a good upbringing from the start. Mum always told us, even though she wasn't our real mum, that she loved us, and that means a lot to a child."

For some, such as Fred, the information was painful. He learned that his birth was the result of an incestuous relationship. "It was a shock, but I'd rather I knew," he said. "At least you don't have to wonder about it any more."

Even those who already had some facts about their early lives could be taken by surprise as memories were unlocked and feelings from childhood re-ignited. Tom, who had entered Barnardo's at the age of 12, found tears running down his face: "Suddenly all that information brought my dad back to life. All that old grief and pain welled up."

Counselling helped Tom to deal with his emotions and lay the past to rest. Like many, he had been quite unprepared for the impact, particularly as he already had a reasonable awareness of his past.

"What came out of that was that I'd never actually let my dad go," he said. "All those memories that came flooding back opened up a wound I thought I'd sealed forever. When I came for that Barnardo's information, it burst like a boil."

A year after seeing their records, some people still felt angry about the opportunities they had been denied, but despite a mix of emotions most felt that the new information had made a positive contribution to their sense of self. All but one were glad to have seen their records.

Since 1995, Barnardo's has assisted more than 5,000 people to view their records. The waiting list now numbers just under 700, and some 40 new inquiries are received each month. The charity estimates that around 60,000 of the children formerly in its care are still alive today, and may at any time decide to seek information on their past.

Barnardo's no longer runs children's homes, but the lessons the charity has learned from helping the people once in its care are still relevant today. Young care leavers may benefit from more help in understanding the past before they can move on properly to adult life. Older adults too, who have spent some or all of their earlier lives in care, need ongoing support to make sense of the past.

People responsible for children separated from their families should think carefully about the quality of records they keep, as certain kinds of information become the "official" version of an individual's history, while alternative information or viewpoints are left out. As official secrecy fades, we owe future generations of looked-after children as full and accurate an account of their history as we can manage.

 Gill Pugh is team leader of Barnardo's after-care team. Unlocking The Past - the Impact of Access to Barnardo's Child Care Records, by Gill Pugh, is available from Ashgate Publishing (tel: 01235-827730; website: www.ashgate.com

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: An offer of free drinks for over-80s if accompanied by a parent backfired on the landlord of a pub in Accrington, Lancashire, when a woman celebrating her 80th birthday brought along her 101-year-old mother.
fields.body:
Cold comfort: An Ayrshire PE teacher who tried to ease the swelling on his injured foot with a bag of frozen chips had to be treated in hospital for severe frostbite.

Cure for the blues: Essex police plan to give officers vouchers for treatments such as aromatherapy, acupuncture and counselling as part of a programme to reduce sickness leave caused by stress.

Squawked on: Police believe they are close to catching the person who raided a pet shop in Kingston, Surrey, after a stolen macaw recovered soon after the theft started repeating a man's name.

Queue for action: An armed man got fed up waiting in the queue at a post office in Newport, south Wales, and tried to rob a nearby bank instead.

Sworn to silence: Players at Maidstone United, Kent, have been ordered to tone down their language by the owners of the ground, the Mormon church.

Quackdown: The owner of a flock of ducks has been warned by the council dog catcher in the village of Dore, near Sheffield, that they will be impounded if he continues to allow them to roam around the streets.

Grave mistake: A pet hamster given a burial ceremony in the garden of a house in Droylsden, Greater Manchester, woke from hibernation several hours later and burrowed free.

Degree of sobriety: Cut-price drinks have been banned from campus bars at Warwick university in a move to impress on students that they are at 'an educational establishment, not a brewery'.

Pie and chips: Thieves who stole a family-size chicken and ham pie from a butcher's shop window in Thornaby-on-Tees didn't realise it was a display pastry stuffed with wood chippings.

Inside info: Convicted criminals are being recruited by police in Chesterfield, Derbyshire, to help compile information packs advising how to protect shops and businesses from thieves.

Old joke: An offer of free drinks for over-80s if accompanied by a parent backfired on the landlord of a pub in Accrington, Lancashire, when a woman celebrating her 80th birthday brought along her 101-year-old mother.

Cast aside: A stuffed buffalo that appeared alongside Kevin Costner in the Hollywood movie Dances With Wolves failed to attract any bidders at an international antiques fair in Shrewsbury, Shropshire.

Hard to swallow: A trial at Newcastle crown court was adjourned when the defence barrister reported that his pet bull mastiff had chewed up a video containing vital evidence.

Hole truth: A woman who telephoned Brighton police station to say she had found a hole in the road was put through to the lost property department.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
In these frenzied academic times, when a few hastily constructed research articles can affect the financial viability of a whole university department, it is increasingly unusual to find a study which successfully combines original research, subtle analysis and realistic policy recommendations.

Bridget Anderson's Doing the Dirty Work? The Global Politics Of Domestic Labour handsomely fulfils all these criteria. Why, she asks, is domestic labour so "demeaned and disregarded", when its use enables middle class women and men to "avoid the conflicts of interest inherent in the gendered division of labour and the challenges, both personal and political, that this poses to the 'nuclear family'"? Why is it that feminists who have railed against the indignities of housework have largely ignored the manner in which their own paid employment depends upon the availability of someone else to do the dirty work?

This is not merely a class issue: domestic labour is disproportionately performed by "racialised groups", and racist stereotypes help to create a hierarchy "which uses skin colour, religion, and nationality to construct some women as more suitable for domestic work than others".

Consider this from a placement agency in Barcelona: "Moroccans are difficult to place... though, like Peruvians, they are brought up to be servile... Filipinas are easiest... they are cold, efficient but not affectionate... they speak English, are discreet, they have integrated to some extent. But they are disloyal... They only care about money."

Anderson, currently a research fellow at Warwick university, spent two years investigating the conditions of migrant domestic workers in five European cities. In each setting she found that the worker played a crucial role in raising the status of her female employer by allowing her to pass as a clean, non-labouring member of the middle class, in contrast to her domestic servant.

Although Anderson found extensive evidence of abuse, she readily concedes that some domestic workers were relatively content. But workers frequently talked to each other about how they might improve their situation by being "not just politically organised, but more assertive personally".

It is not surprising, given her intense involvement with her subjects, to learn that Anderson is busy helping domestic workers to form organisations in which they can campaign for a charter of rights.

 Laurie Taylor talks to Bridget Anderson about the politics of domestic labour in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4 pm today.

fields.headline: Early birds of springtime
fields.standfirst: Is it global warming or just a blip in the weather statistics?  Either way, winter is getting shorter, reports Paul Evans
fields.trailText: Is it global warming or just a blip in the weather statistics? Either way, winter is getting shorter, reports Paul Evans.
fields.body:
It's the evening of February 1 and I'm having a quiet moment when, damn me, if that's not a frog on the carpet. What's it doing here in Shropshire so early in the year? It should still be tucked up under a pile of leaves.

Pembrokeshire cousins of this frog produced frogspawn by January 21. On the Lizard peninsula in Cornwall, frogspawn appeared last year before the shortest day, December 21. Pembrokeshire and Cornwall, warmed by the Gulf Stream, are traditionally the earliest places in Britain for this sort of thing. But early is getting earlier.

Frogs, like many other species of wildlife, are responding to a general rising trend in temperature. The 1990s were the warmest decade since 1659, when records began. Spring was, on average, 1.3C warmer in the 1990s than the 1980s. This may not sound much, but when you consider that a 2C drop in temperature could plunge us into an ice age you can appreciate how this small increase is responsible for shifts in many spring events.

Trees come into leaf at least six days earlier these days and autumn is happening four days later, according to a European survey conducted over the past 30 years. Insects emerge from hibernation earlier: the first small tortoiseshell butterfly this year was spotted on New Year's day and I saw a bat last week hunting for flies and moths. Birds begin their migrations earlier, but how on earth do swallows know it's warmer than usual in Aberystwyth when they set off from Africa?

You don't have to be a David Attenborough to see that the weather is getting weirder. Phenology - recording the dates of events such as the first frogspawn, the first butterfly and the first swallow - is not just for wildlife anoraks. The government has recognised that biological events are significant indicators of climate change. Tim Sparks, of the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, who has been advising on these indicators, says: "We need all the closet phenologists to check their diaries. This sort of monitoring was popular with Victorians but it became a bit embarrassing. There is an accumulating body of evidence which shows that we are experiencing earlier springs, later autumns, warmer temperatures. These phenological events may convince people to take global warming more seriously."

There is at least a month's difference, from the south to the north of the country, in the arrival of spring and this difference is being shunted forward a month or so. It's as if someone changed the calendar. I live in Shropshire, which is weeks behind the south-west, in a place which was a notorious frost-pocket. Today I saw daffodils flowering on Wenlock Edge. Time was, not so long ago, that you couldn't find a daffodil for St David's Day on March 1 unless you bought it from Channel Island imports in a shop. The birds here have been singing fit to burst, morning and evening, for weeks now. As far as they are concerned, this is spring.

Whatever the birds are saying does not convince the boffins. The last days of January and the first days of February may be unseasonably warm, but, according to the Hadley Centre of the Met Office, it's only one degree higher than average.

"This is still winter," says Chris Folland, of the Hadley Centre. "It may be of a warmer weather type influenced by the warm westerly winds of the north Atlantic oscilation, with fewer cold northerly and easterly winds, but this is not without precedent. The weather from 1895 to 1935 was similar. The climate models are not consistent and the jury is out on how much this current warming trend is due to global warming."

Garden plants are blooming early, but it's the wild ones which are really surprising. Here in Shropshire, as in many parts of the country, hazel catkins are already golden and shaggy. My own country diary for 1996 doesn't mention fully flowering catkins until March 2. Snowdrops have been flowering for weeks. Primroses and a few dandelions are in bloom. I even had a foxglove in flower on Christmas Day.

New wildflowers are arriving from the south. A group of spectacular orchids called Serapias, the tongue orchids from the Mediterranean, moved as far north as Brittany 20 years ago. In 1992, one was found in Cornwall, but suspicious botanists thought it must have been planted. In the past two years, others have turned up in Guernsey, Kent and Devon. And other Mediterranean species, whose seeds hitch a ride on ocean currents, like sea knot grass and sea daffodil, have begun to colonise the south coast.

Botanist Peter Marren is convinced that there was no skul-duggery behind the arrival of the Serapias and, like other scientists, is excited about the prospect of new species arriving in Britain as a consequence of climate change. "But it's not a simple warming," warns Marren, "and it is potentially horrendous. We are moving into a violent climate - frequent storms and wetter springs.

"In some respects, violent winds may have ecological benefit to woodlands by increasing the naturalness of things which have been supressed by woodland management. But wet Mays and Junes have been disastrous for insects, and they are likely to be the first victims. When seasons are out of sync it affects plant flowering and this can cause an ecological megaproblem."

The seasons certainly seem out of sync. But there are not too many people upset by unseasonally warm weather at this time of year. The sight of catkins, snowdrops and primroses are things which gladden the heart, so why not have them sooner rather than later?

We say Britain doesn't have a climate, only weather, and we grumble about it: it's too cold, too hot, too wet, too dry. But whatever the weather, it is one of the principal ways that we feel nature around us. It shapes local and regional identity. It has seasonal rhythms which shaped our culture, even though we're far more insulated against it than we were.

There is now an anxiety, even on a beautiful spring-like day, with the birds singing and flowers blooming, that there is something wrong. We have put the seasons out of whack and both nature and us will suffer for it. We need a cold spell to keep down the germs, greenfly and rats. We need the keenness of winter to really appreciate the joy of spring.

But there's time yet. The weather could change - and officially it's still winter for at least another six weeks.

 UK Wild 2000 is a series of wildlife surveys to be undertaken by children and will include tracking frogspawn from one end of the country to the other. This will be launched this month and you will find the website at: www.bbc.co.uk/ukwild

webTitle: Human rights: Battle for the sacred oil

fields.headline: Battle for the sacred oil
fields.standfirst: John Vidal on the tribe that is defending its culture against exploitation
fields.trailText: John Vidal on the tribe that is defending its culture against exploitation.
fields.body:
The U'wa tribe of Colombia is remote, little studied, less visited and, until recently, barely registered on the barometer of western or even local Colombian awareness. But in the past two years its fight with Occidental Petroleum (Oxy) has become an international cause celebre. For the tribe, the outcome may be life or death. For the oil company, it could be a PR and financial disaster on the scale that Ken Saro-Wiwa was for Shell.

The latest round in the struggle to prevent oil extraction on what the U'wa say is their land involved families occupying the spot which Oxy intends to drill. The Colombian military surrounded the U'wa after their protest in November and, following a tense stand-off , 26 people were forcibly removed by truck and helicopter last month.

The U'wa are opposed on many levels to oil drilling. The leaders know that, should Oxy go ahead, the whole area will inevitably become militarised and attract rebel groups and paramilitary forces, making impossible a way of life that has at its heart remained unchanged in centuries. The dangers are real: last year, US environmentalist Terry Freitas and two human rights workers were murdered by a Colombian rebel group after visiting the U'wa. Some U'wa leaders have been threatened, and Oxy's existing pipeline taking oil from another field has been attacked more than 600 times in the past 12 years.

But the U'wa are opposed for religious reasons, too. The intensely spiritual tribe, which guards its culture fiercely, believes oil to be the "blood of the earth" and therefore sacred. Several years ago, the tribal leaders declared that members would commit suicide if oil was taken from below their land. This has since been changed to a stance of resistance. "We prefer (our own) genocide sponsored by the Colombian government rather than handing over our Mother Earth to oil companies," said their spokesman, Roberto Cobaria, last month.

The battle, now taken up by US and other international environment groups, has wider implications and is now gathering a head of steam. The latest to be drawn in is US vice-president Al Gore, a committed "environ mentalist" who is the Democratic Party frontrunner in the forthcoming elections and eager to grab the large green vote.

The Gore family and the Los Angeles-based company have been linked for generations. Gore's father worked for Armand Hammer, the founder of Occidental, and funds from the company and its subsidiaries eventually formed the basis of the Gore family fortune.

Activists are also targeting one of the largest shareholders of Occidental stock. Last week, activists from European and other countries, including Britain, demonstrated outside Fidelity Investments, one of the world's largest mutual fund companies, whose US offices are known to invest heavily in the company.

Meanwhile, the U'wa will now present charges before the UN and the Organisation of American States (OAS) against Occidental for the violent expulsion of the protesters.

The Colombian government argues that Oxy's drilling is located outside the indigenous reserve. But independent congressman Gustavo Petro says the "problem is not whether the oil project is inside or outside of the reserve. It is a failure to defend indigenous culture, for which Colombia could be charged with the crime of genocide."

webTitle: Care: A step out of darkness

fields.headline: A step out of darkness
fields.standfirst: With the report on sexual and physical abuse in north Wales  children's homes due next week, former Barnardo's boy  Phil Frampton calls on the government to follow Canada's  lead by introducing compensation schemes for child victims
fields.trailText: With the report on sexual and physical abuse in north Wales children's homes due next week, former Barnardo's boy Phil Frampton calls on the government to follow Canada's lead by introducing compensation schemes for child victims.
fields.body:
The pieces I wrote in Society last year, telling the story of my childhood spent in the care system, had much more impact than I had expected. I was surprised to receive so many letters from care leavers, telling me how much they welcomed someone speaking out.

Since then, many others have told me how much they suffered in the children's homes and how they are still affected. Many are frightened to tell even friends who were in the same homes about the abuse they suffered. Some, fearful of the stigmatisation involved, said that they wouldn't even tell friends that they had been in care.

I have been thrown back into my childhood, face to face with the horrors of the past - a horror much greater than I had ever realised. So many of my childhood friends were mentally scarred for life by authorities which were supposed to protect and nurture them. Yet it seems that society is prepared to ignore this - or, when pressed, do a little hand-wringing and hope that the survivors will suffer in silence.

Now the publication next week of the Clwyd report into widespread physical and sexual abuse in the north Wales children's homes offers the government a chance to start redressing the wrongs, just as it acknowledged the plight of the coal miners who had physically suffered in the mines.

A friend living in Canada tells me that unwanted British children used to be sent to populate the Empire. Their fate was little different from that of the siblings they left behind, yet national and provincial government action there is far more advanced.

Recent attention has focused on Canadian children who were in care in Quebec - the "Duplessis orphans", named after the province's premier in the 1940s and 1950s. They were 3,000 "normal" children transferred into psychiatric institutions. Two years ago, Daniel Jacoby, the Quebec ombudsman, recommended that each child should be offered a package of restorative measures - C$1,000 for every year they spent in an institution. Those who were physically or sexually abused, he argued, should receive an additional amount up to C$20,000.

In March last year, the premier of Quebec, Lucien Bouchard, finally issued a public apology to all those who had suffered in the homes. He also announced the setting up of a C$3m provincial aid fund, although this has been criticised as being too little. Before that, the Canadian government had requested the law commission of Canada to investigate the needs of care leavers. Those UK authorities which currently refuse to apologise to the care survivors, or take any action to repair the damage inflicted, should take a long look at the Canadian commission's findings.

The commission stated: "The abuse of children in institutions run by or on behalf of governments raises serious questions about the health of our society and its process of accountability." The commission called for "a more comprehensive approach focused on survivors and sensitive to their individual needs, to demonstrate that, as a society, we are not afraid to face up to the legacy of the past... We see a pattern of... people refusing to address the complaints that did emerge from the children or from staff or others. We see a closing of official ranks that served to protect those administering institutions and those with authority over the children.

"We see resistance to public accountability and, particularly, a resolve to avoid any legal liability, and we see these concerns far outweighing any sense of duty or concern to protect the children at risk of further abuse." For Canada, we might as well read Britain.

The commission went on to identify the needs of the survivors:
 Acknowledgement of the wrong, apology and commitment to prevention;
 Establishing the historical record;
 Financial compensation;
 Access to therapy and counselling;
 Access to education and training;
 Punishment of perpetrators.

The British government, local authorities, the churches, Barnardo's and the like too often seem to be resistant to these measures. They should heed the warning of the commission that "a preoccupation with the financial calculus can easily be interpreted as the church and state showing themselves unworthy of the public's trust and respect".

Despite those who were abused in the homes being reluctant to come forward, the mounting evidence from police investigations is that Britain, like Canada, saw a national scandal where thousands of children underwent systematic institutional abuse.

In order to seek compensation in the courts, survivors are being asked by solicitors to state how they financially suffered from being in the homes. But what are the costs of abuse, degradation, powerlessness and forcible isolation from parents and siblings? How do you measure those wrecked insides? What do you give back to the child abused in my home who has since spent a lifetime in Rampton?

The results can be lack of confidence, social stigmatisation, alcoholism, drug abuse and sometimes a repeated learned pattern of abuse on children as parents or otherwise. The costs to society are equally great. For what respect can anyone have for laws and morals advocated by governments when the same governments, as "corporate parents" of those who were in care, ignore the plight of those who were victims of flouting of the law in government institutions?

A caring government would be encouraging them. It is widely known how hard it is for those raised in families to come forward with allegations where abuse took place. For those who went through the care system, the feelings of guilt, of deserving their fate and of being social outsiders makes the process so much more painful.

Redressing the situation will have a cost but, as the commission points out, it also will limit the huge costs to the social services, the legal system and the penal system of failing to recognise the burdens carried by the survivors.

I know that Barnardo's was not happy with my pieces in this newspaper. Some feared that Barnardo's image might be damaged, with a consequent dent in its fundraising capacity. Respect is not easily lost, but there are thousands of Phil Framptons out there with much worse stories to tell - as Clwyd and other cases will demonstrate. Respect can be won back by showing that the authorities are prepared to openly confront and deal with the dirt they, or their predecessors, brushed under the carpet.

I went to Barnardo's to secure my files on my childhood and find my father. Now I have discovered that he died two years ago. Barnardo's recently had the courage to apologise for my not having my files earlier. It is time the government got its head out of the dirty sand and made an apology to the thousands of survivors.

Local authorities and voluntary organisations like Barnardo's say that their hands have been tied by the insurance companies, preventing them from making an apology for fear of having to bear the costs of litigation. By taking responsibility for the problem, the government would free the charities and local authorities from the ligature of the insurance companies.

The care organisations should be jointly and publicly lobbying the government to take proper ownership of the problem, set up a special commission and, with the survivors, work out a restorative programme for those who suffered.

Compensation should be uniform and across the board in a manner worked out as acceptable to the survivors. Some of those who were taking Clwyd to court have been offered tens of thousands of pounds in out of court settlements by the authorities, who are suddenly keen to pay out before the report is published. Of course, financial compensation will not repair the psychological destruction caused by the past. But, fixed at a generous level, compensation would give some of those abused a bit of their life back.

fields.headline: WAP
fields.trailText:
What is WAP and why is it back in the news?
WAP stands for Wireless Application Protocol and basically means internet access from mobile phones. It's back in the news today because Bob Geldof has teamed up with former England rugby union international Brian Moore to launch WapWorld, rolling out an internet portal service to WAP phones.
fields.body:
What is WAP and why is it back in the news?
WAP stands for Wireless Application Protocol and basically means internet access from mobile phones. It's back in the news today because Bob Geldof has teamed up with former England rugby union international Brian Moore to launch WapWorld, rolling out an internet portal service to WAP phones.

What can WAP phones do?
The great advantage of WAP is that it frees people from their PCs - or even their laptops. WAP phones allow users to read news, check football scores and monitor share prices wherever they are. Television and cinema listings, cash machine locations and information about traffic congestion or train times are other uses. Email is the next big goal - perfect for tiny screens and users on the move. On-phone shopping will come; and there are countless possibilities for businesses - for example, giving salespeople instant mobile access to stock data.

Will Geldof's service offer anything different?
Geldof and Moore promise celebrity-driven content, with plenty of sports and entertainment figures, plus news and weather, aimed at the young and affluent. They have struck a deal with Carphone Warehouse that will see WapWorld technology installed on every WAP phone sold by the retail chain.

How does the technology work?
It works the same way as a mobile phone works with voices: information is sent by radio signals. But because mobiles are small, they can only deliver small amounts of information - the tiny screen sizes can't accommodate many words, and the links are still relatively slow.

Do all the mobile phone companies do WAP phones?
Yes, WAP is seen as a crucial development for the future of mobile phone technology. Huge amounts of money are being invested in developing the technology. Most have done deals on content - for example, Vodafone, has teamed up with WH Smith, the BBC and the Met Office.

Do you need a special phone to access the internet?
Yes in general - although Virgin Mobile claims to be the first mobile phone company in the world to offer all its customers WAP browsing, allowing them to look at specially converted web pages and order goods from sites from, among others, the BBC and Virgin Megastore. Virgin uses a unique SIM-card based browser, which means you don't have to buy a special WAP phone.

How much do WAP phones cost?
Around £130 plus line rental and call charges for accessing the internet.

How widespread will they be?
Industry estimates are that within a few years there will be more people using WAP phones to access the net than those using computers. It is forecast that there will be 1.2bn mobile phone users in the world by 2003, with about half using phones to access the net. In comparison, there will be about 550m computer users. Internet access is bound to migrate to phones

Can I get Guardian Unlimited on a WAP phone?

Yes, you can access it from any WAP phone. Just bookmark http://www.newsunlimited.co.uk/wml.

You can also see what it's like on a simulator here.

Useful links
Wapforum
Waptastic

fields.headline: Dutch treat
fields.standfirst: Rotterdam film festival
fields.trailText: Among European film festivals, Rotterdam is special for all the distractions that it spares you. There's no PR frenzy, precious little Hollywood content and no stars. That's not to say there aren't names, but Rotterdam is so laid-back and democratic that they barely turn heads.
fields.body:
Among European film festivals, Rotterdam is special for all the distractions that it spares you. There's no PR frenzy, precious little Hollywood content and no stars. That's not to say there aren't names, but Rotterdam is so laid-back and democratic that they barely turn heads. A major figure such as Ice-T can drift in almost unnoticed, to sit on a low-key panel discussing the implications of low-budget cinema. "The virus will infect film," he says, "and I'm backing the virus."

But at Rotterdam, film is the virus, proliferating in every direction until the festival programme weighs a ton. This year many delegates ditched everything else to go Japanese. The festival's tiger logo was eclipsed by variants on the Japanese flag - shimmering digital sun on the programme, big red balloons in the Hilton bar. The Corso, a cavernous 60s cinema, was transformed into the Japan Tech Pop Lounge, an all-day hangout offering cultural flaneurs a bath in state-of-the-art electro culture.

Early in the week, many festival-goers declared they would simply soak up the retrospective of veteran director Kinji Fukasaku. Fukasaku, who has made nearly 60 films since 1961, specialises in yakuza (gangster) pics, and his work is considered highly revealing of the stresses in postwar Japanese society. Battles Without Honour or Humanity (1973), for example, recounts the history of a Hiroshima mob, beginning directly after the Bomb.

A smart video distributor could make Fukasaku a cult among western connoisseurs of hard-men-in-suits movies (the brassy cod-Morricone scores would go down a storm). But the two yakuza films I saw, Battles Without Honour and Cops Vs Thugs, were much of a muchness. Both are relentlessly violent, both feature impenetrable plots, crowds of plug-uglies yelling at each other, and hard-nut icon Bunta Sugawara, a leathery, fag-chomping Kirk Douglas type.

The Fukasaku pic that really set the juices flowing was an anomaly for the director: Black Lizard, a 1968 comic-book thriller that's pure Austin Powers. Its vampy arch- villainess, played by drag artist Akihiro Maruyama, does her nefarious stuff bedecked in froufrous, and hides out in a club decorated with Aubrey Beardsley murals. With its cameo by renowned novelist Yukio Mishima, Black Lizard was a cult favourite in the US in the 80s, and its time has surely come again.

The more recent Japanese selection included Takeshi Kitano, Gamera the giant lizard and a mountain of cartoon epics. But the discovery that set the festival on its ears was director Takashi Miike. Rotterdam takes outrage in its stride (last year's star attraction was Catherine Breillat's meta-porn Romance), but even here, several punters hissed "You're sick!" at Miike as they left his screenings.

There's no doubt Miike represents the new Japanese cinema at its speediest and nastiest. One of three new films, Dead or Alive starts off like thrash-metal yakuza and ends in nothing less than apocalypse. The inconsequential gang-war story kicks off with a head-spinning action montage of bikers, gay assassins, soup-guzzling mobsters and knife-throwing clowns, before things slow down enough to get queasy - there's even a visit to the shooting of an animal porn film.

Audacious but empty, Dead or Alive is nothing compared with Miike's real jaw-dropper, the prize-winning Audition. This begins as a gentle tale about a middle-aged TV exec who searches for the girl of his dreams; unfortunately she proves to have a ghoulish past and a taste for amateur acupuncture. Audition proves Miike to be a master at manipulating audience expectations, mixing the tawdriness of Fatal Attaction with a flavour of Buñuel and Polanski at their most ruthless. We'll be hearing a lot more about him.

Some of the biggest pleasures, though, turned out to be gently old-fashioned. Rien à Faire, by French director Marion Vernoux, is about a blue-collar woman and a male exec falling in love on the dole queue and in the supermarket. Dazzlingly shot and spiked with tender ironies, this brief encounter between romance and sociology confirms its star Valeria Bruni-Tedeschi as one of the current names to watch.

The feeling this year was that there was less real satisfaction than the programme promised, but overall that didn't seem to matter too much. Among the Tiger winners, one created a buzz - Lou Ye's film Suzhou River, which some people labelled a Chinese version of Vertigo. And there was enough other material around to keep the arguments flying, which is really the point of this festival. Rotterdam stimulates the kind of see- anything, risk-anything community that few festivals attract these days. You may come back disappointed, but at least you get to be disappointed by a challenging, eclectic selection that you wouldn't see gathered together anywhere else.

fields.headline: Confidence tricks
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown on the latest goings-on at the Welsh assembly
Plus: No Wiener schnitzel for Charles
fields.trailText: Derek Brown on the latest goings-on at the Welsh assembly
fields.body:
The first secretary of the Welsh assembly, Alun Michael, is almost certainly going to lose his job today - and get it back tomorrow.

This Alun-in-Wonderland state of affairs is based in part on the raw electoral arithmetic of Wales, where Michael heads a minority Labour administration.

The combined opposition of Plaid Cymru nationalists, liberal democrats and conservatives in the assembly has tabled a motion of no confidence in the first secretary. They accuse him of failing to press Downing Street and the treasury to provide matching funds which would release EC development aid for depressed areas of west Wales and the valleys.

On the face of it, the opposition parties are playing a bit of a confidence trick. They risk alienating that very large section of the voting public which never wanted an assembly, and which believes that devolution is just another way politicians have to create jobs for themselves.

But another school of thought in Wales, well represented in Michael's own party, is heartily sick of the way, as they perceive it, that the London and Labour party establishments are insisting on pulling the strings. Michael, who was catapulted rather unwillingly into the top job, is seen as Tony Blair's placeman, whose job in Cardiff is faithfully to follow the instructions of No.10 and Millbank.

That is a harsh judgement. Michael is after all a loyal member of the ruling party. Of course he is not going to lead a pointless rebellion over money which the treasury simply will not give. All the same, the impression that he is no more than His Master's Voice is deeply damaging to him, his party, and the whole devolution enterprise.

In that sense, what is happening today is a fascinating exploration of virgin constitutional territory. The Welsh assembly, like the House of Commons, has no written constitution to guide its deliberations. Unlike the Commons, it has no accumulated flummery of interpretation and precedents. What it does today, and tomorrow, will go down as important landmarks in its infant history.

As things stand, Michael will be forced to resign. But he will stand for re-election, with the support of the Labour group. And so far, it seems he will be the only candidate. That is a severe indictment of the opposition parties, which seem more interesting in scoring a cheap political point than in challenging Labour's longstanding hegemony in the principality.

Although Michael will not be holed below the waterline by the shenanigans in Cardiff, the high-profile squabble in the assembly could cost his party dearly in the next general election. The electors of Wales, long accustomed to delivering Labour votes in shovel-loads, have no great reason to feel grateful to the present government - not least because it has delivered a lukewarm, feeble version of devolved power. The same applies, for quite different reasons, in Scotland, where Labour also enjoys a surreal electoral advantage.

These are early days, but it is fair to speculate that what used to be condescendingly called the Celtic fringe could yet turn out to be the fulcrum of the next election; Labour's Achilles heel.

Related documentaries
Devolution in Wales: special report
Devolution in Scotland: special report

No Wiener schnitzel for Charles

The foreign office-inspired decision of the Prince of Wales not to visit Austria is an insult to the people of that country. It seems rather far-fetched to argue that a princely presence in Vienna amounts to some kind of endorsement of Jörg Haider's Freedom party.

There are already clear signs that Haider in power is a good deal more savoury than Haider goose-stepping on the margins of politics. He is now constrained by the conventions of government, and no longer mouthing off to gain dubious publicity. We don't have to like him, or cosy up to him. But we do have to respect his mandate, so long as he does nothing to disgrace it.

Prince Charles could have made a useful contribution, by tweaking the norms of royal diplomacy. He could have delivered a well-mannered snub or two to the Freedom party, and reminded Austria that Europe is the antithesis of narrow nationalism.

Related documentary
The Austrian far right in power: special report

Related documentaries Devolution in Wales: special report Devolution in Scotland: special report No Wiener schnitzel for Charles The foreign office-inspired decision of the Prince of Wales not to visit Austria is an insult to the people of that country. It seems rather far-fetched to argue that a princely presence in Vienna amounts to some kind of endorsement of Jörg Haider's Freedom party. There are already clear signs that Haider in power is a good deal more savoury than Haider goose-stepping on the margins of politics. He is now constrained by the conventions of government, and no longer mouthing off to gain dubious publicity. We don't have to like him, or cosy up to him. But we do have to respect his mandate, so long as he does nothing to disgrace it. Prince Charles could have made a useful contribution, by tweaking the norms of royal diplomacy. He could have delivered a well-mannered snub or two to the Freedom party, and reminded Austria that Europe is the antithesis of narrow nationalism. Related documentary The Austrian far right in power: special report

fields.headline: Shear madness
fields.standfirst: From creosote to exploding hands, the best entries from our Alan Shearer celebration competition
fields.trailText: Who would have thought that a man renowned for being boring could inspire such flights of fancy? The post-bag has been literally bulging with entries for our competition to find a new celebration for Alan Shearer. Actually, to be honest, it hasn't been literally bulging at all, but that's only because we don't have a post-bag. What we do have however is an inspired collection of inventions for you to read through and, you never know, you may have won a prize.
fields.body:
Who would have thought that a man renowned for being boring could inspire such flights of fancy? The post-bag has been literally bulging with entries for our competition to find a new celebration for Alan Shearer. Actually, to be honest, it hasn't been literally bulging at all, but that's only because we don't have a post-bag. What we do have however is an inspired collection of inventions for you to read through and, you never know, you may have won a prize.

A significant proportion of the entries focussed on Al's reputation as something of a dullard. Some suggested that the England captain should celebrate a strike by pretending to have a nice cup of tea, Philip Harding even adding he should do it "with his little pinkie sticking out (no, not that one)." Others thought that Alan should mime the act of reclining in a nice armchair with pipe and slippers. Probably a bit beyond Al's acting skills if his McDonald's effort is to be believed.

By far the most popular boring celebrations was the 'creosoting the fence' celebration, a reference to one of Alan's self-confessed hobbies. Craig Hamilton took this celebration one post-modern step further: "After finding the net he should wheel away from the prone defenders, lift his left arm into the air, and pretend to be painting his garden fence with creosote. After a short time he could swap arms and begin 'painting' with his right hand, before finally switching back to the left. In a cool noughties gesture, Alan's 'new' celebration would greatly resemble his old one and only Football Unlimited readers and Deadpan Shearer would get the joke. Do I win something?"

No you don't Craig. But then again neither does Matthew Pieri despite his impressive, if slightly disconcerting, display of imagination. "I thought maybe Shearer could tease us a bit," says Matthew, "by starting with his tried and tested run-with-knees-high-and-one-hand-raised-pointing-to-the-sky and then just before everyone loses interest - BANG! - his pointy hand shoots off into the sky where it explodes into all the colours of the rainbow... oooooo aahhhhh. Maybe it could be a false hand or maybe his real one. I'm not fussed which. If you can could you pass this onto him I would appreciate it."

Another entry that involves Alan in performance art comes from Gareth Crossman, his entry entitled 'The son of a humble sheet metal worker'. "Surely the rags to riches tale from humble beginnings to captain of the national team is one that deserves telling again and again and again and again and again. Now, through the medium of mime, the free scoring Geordie can touch our hearts to an even greater extent. Wheeling towards the Toon faithful, he mops the sweat from his manly brow while making large sheet-metal-cutting movements. He then expresses joy and makes baby-rocking movements to show the future footballing messiah has been born. Standing proud he moves his hand higher and higher to show the boy's growth, each movement bringing greater joy as he exceeds all expectations. How touching."

That may be so, Gareth, but it's still not good enough to take the top prize of a copy of LMA Manager for the PlayStation. That treat falls instead to Matt Schofield for his "Cowboy horse dance" celebration. And it goes a little something like this. "Shearer starts the routine by pretending to saddle up then clamber aboard the beaten, prostrate keeper. As the keeper looks up, wondering what madness this is, Shearer would then pretend to lash the rear of his pretend pony with pretend reins, bouncing off about the box, waving his imaginary cowboy hat, shouting 'Yippi-kye-Yie,' and 'I'm the root-inest, toot-inest, goal-shoot-inest cowboy east, west, north, south of the pecos.' To make this a perfect celebration, he would of course, have to dismount at some point to allow play to resume, at which time he would offer a simple, humble prayer."

But, as Matt observes, that's not all. "It would, of course, be necessary, having created an imaginary pony, to then properly care for it during the rest of the match. This would create numerous, humorous breaks in the routine of the game during which he could leave the pitch, pretending to offer hay or an apple to the beast." Hurrah! A copy of the PlayStation's finest Union-endorsed management simulation is on its way to you, Matt.

fields.headline: Sweeping away our liberties
fields.standfirst:
Case by case, the rights of Britons are
         being gutted by governments
fields.trailText:
Case by case, the rights of Britons are
         being gutted by governments.
fields.body:
What is wrong with this government, and with its predecessors, is that it operates on a case by case basis. It has no feeling for the principles of liberty and, clearly, it has no time for them.

For example, the Lords won us a temporary remission by defeating the attempt to restrict trial by jury, but no one should suppose this is more than a temporary respite. Jack Straw and his government will be back.

The principles which preserve between them the rule of law and the rights of individuals have been systematically subverted by recent governments. This government has been the most recent to attack them it has been the most determined. In every case it has cited what seem plausible, even worthwhile, reasons for its actions, but the cumulative effect has been to erode the rules which protect us. Indeed, it is almost as if the government has made out a checklist of those rules, determined to strike them down one by one.

Presumption of innocence was weakened to catch serious fraud cases. After all, we do not want crooked high flyers to get away with their clever and complicated schemes. The upshot is that they may now be required to show that they acted legitimately, rather than having the state prove that they broke the law.

Double jeopardy meant that you could not be put on trial again once you had been acquitted: not any more. It first went out when we allowed civil prosecutions after criminal ones had failed. We do not like to see people walk free when we disagree with the jury, so we allow a second shot. This is why O J Simpson was put on trial again on the same evidence which had seen him acquitted. In a civil trial it is easier, too, because a balance of evidence is sufficient, rather than "beyond any reasonable doubt".

Now new criminal prosecutions are being considered when new evidence emerges. This is partly an aftermath of the Lawrence murder, and the laudable desire not to let racist thugs get away with it.

Limited jurisdiction meant that you had to do something which was a crime in the place which put you on trial. This one went when Lady Thatcher forced a war crimes bill through despite determined opposition in the Lords. It has since been further weakened. We can now try people for things they do abroad which would be offences in Britain, but which are perhaps less well enforced over there. We can even try them for things which were not offences at the time. As always, we are told that this is the only way to get at certain classes of criminals. After all, who cares what happens to suspected paedophiles and war criminals?

The right of silence allowed no presumption to be drawn from the refusal of an accused to say anything. No one could be forced to testify in their defence. It used to help prevent beatings or torture of suspects. If they need not say anything at all, there was less reason to force them to say suitably incriminating things. Now judges may tell juries to draw inferences when an accused exercises this right, and another right is diluted.

Habeas corpus prevented the state from holding people incommunicado while it dealt with them. It had to produce them in open court and charge them. This was all very well, but for suspected terrorists various extensions were allowed because the authorities needed more time. Imprisonment without trial in the form of internment was even permitted under the general heading of prevention of terrorism. Again the defence is that it only concerns terrorists.

Conviction before sentence was a corner-stone principle. You had to convict someone before you could punish them. This is no longer true in the case of suspected drug dealers. Their property can be confiscated if it is suspected to have derived from drug profits, even if this cannot be proved. The alternative would have been to let these sleazy merchants of death and misery laugh at justice and walk off with their gains.

Prior restraint was notoriously difficult to obtain in Britain. People broke the law, and they were caught, tried and punished. It was the way the law worked. Now the government is reported to be considering a scheme under which satellites control the speed of cars to prevent them from exceeding the speed limit by cutting their fuel supply. The imagination leaps to supply what similar things might be done once the principle is breached.

Trial by jury is threatened because crooks are thought more likely to hoodwink juries than magistrates. The notion of facing your peers in open court is all very well, but not if it allows you to get away with it. The Lords saved it once, but no one supposes that the threat will go away.

The pattern emerges quite clearly: government is making laws out of particular cases and eroding the general principles in order to secure a particular aim. It wants to bring to justice the people none of us have any time for: financial swindlers, racist thugs, paedophiles, war criminals, drug dealers and terrorists. Others might include rapists, petty professional criminals who are "obviously guilty'', and multiple offenders whose record will be known to magistrates, but not to juries.

In the interest of bringing these low lifes to justice, the principles which protect the liberties of all of us are swept away. The precepts which have guarded society are destroyed to target particular groups of offenders. After all, we do not want them getting off, do we? In some cases, though, we might accept that, preferring a few unsavoury individuals to walk free rather than compromise the foundations on which our liberties depend. We give the devil himself the benefit of our laws, for how could we otherwise claim it ourselves?

 Dr Madsen Pirie is president of the Adam Smith Institute

webTitle: Hijackers may want new life in Europe

fields.headline: Hijackers may want new life in Europe
fields.trailText: Speculation grew today that the hijackers of the Afghan jet at Stansted were attempting to gain asylum, after the arrival of Hope Hanlon, an adviser from the UN refugee agency.
fields.body:
Speculation grew today that the hijackers of the Afghan jet at Stansted were attempting to gain asylum, after the arrival of Hope Hanlon, an adviser from the UN refugee agency.

The development followed the escape of four crewmen, who broke out of the cockpit late last night, and the subsequent release of a male steward.

Assistant chief constable of Essex, John Broughton, said the hijackers were "starting to talk again" this morning after a tense period in the night. "It is now about restoring the situation as it was before. We never lost confidence. Now we must set about restoring the trust that we had and developing a rapport again."

The crewmen - the 54-year-old captain, a 50-year-old second captain, a 43-year-old first officer and a 54-year-old flight engineer, all believed to be Afghan nationals - ran from the Ariana jet towards waiting police in a nearby hangar and were taken for medical checks before a debriefing session with senior officers.

Assistant chief constable Joe Edwards said that at around 3am the male steward was seen to fall down some steps at the back of the plane. "The man descended rather rapidly out of the plane although he doesn't appear to have suffered any serious injury. It appears he was pushed," said Mr Edwards.

"After that perhaps understandably things went quiet. They stopped talking to us for about an hour. We made contact again shortly before 6am because we needed to re-supply fuel to the generator. And that was OK."

Mr Edwards declined to comment on suggestions that the hijackers, now thought to number up to 10, were also members of the crew.

A number of the hijackers were thought to have relatives among the passengers and crew on board, which increased speculation that the hijacking was part of an attempt to win a new life in Europe.

The hijackers are said to have been told that they will face prosecution, but they have also been promised that they will not be sent back to the Afghan capital Kabul, where they would almost certainly face execution.

Home secretary Jack Straw today declined to comment on the issue. "I have every confidence in the chief officer of police in Essex and his colleagues in the way in which they are handling this matter," he told reporters.

Lawyer Eman Omar, who represented six Iraqis behind the 1996 hijacking to Stansted of a Sudanese airliner carrying 197 passengers and crew, said that the Afghan terrorists are "highly likely" to be seeking asylum.

Miss Omar, who said she would be willing to represent the Stansted hijackers, added: "I do not think it is fair to presume that these people do not have genuine claims. No one actually takes the risk of hijacking a plane lightly, and endanger their lives and the lives of everybody on board."

But shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said it was imperative that hijacking aircraft did not become a means of gaining asylum. "First and foremost you should deal with the criminality of the hijacking."

The developments overnight leave a total of 150 people, including 21 children, 17 women and an unconfirmed number of hijackers on board the aircraft, according to police estimates.

fields.headline: How does asylum work?
fields.trailText: What is an asylum seeker?
fields.body:
What is an asylum seeker?

An asylum seeker is a person who claims to have fled from their home country fearing persecution. The United Nations' 1951 Convention says an asylum seeker, or refugee, has "a well founded fear of persecution", on account of their race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion."

Nations like the UK, which have signed the UN's 1951 Convention and 1967 Protocol, are obliged to receive and formally recognise those fleeing persecution.

The Refugee Council estimates that there are 13 million refugees in the world today. Not all, of course, will apply for asylum in other countries. The United Nations High Commissioner For Refugees (UNHCR) calculated that some 450,000 persons applied for asylum in the 29 industrialised countries in 1998.

How can they get asylum in Britain?

Jack Straw heralded Labour's controversial immigration and asylum act as "fairer, faster and firmer" before it was passed last year. It seeks to curb the growing number of asylum seekers and reform the inefficiency of the old system.

The old system of processing applications for asylum has proved too slow and Britain now has a backlog of 102,870 people seeking asylum. While some of this backlog was inherited from the Conservative government, under Labour in December 7,180 new applications were received, with just 2,320 asylum decisions made.

Coming into force on 1 April, the asylum and immigration act:

 forbids asylum seekers to work to support themselves (and fines employers who pay them);
 introduces vouchers for asylum seekers arriving in Britain, which they use instead of cash to exchange for basic goods to survive;
 cuts the financial support for each refugee from £165 per person each week to £150;
 forces asylum seekers to accept the housing they are given, dispersing them around the country and compelling councils to find accommodation for them;
 gives the home secretary the power to detain groups of asylum seekers en masse, for as long as the home office wants.
 aims to deal with asylum seekers in six months, giving them one chance to appeal.

While these measures have an illiberal ring, under Labour the recognition rate for asylum seekers has doubled to 25% of claims.

Is Britain a soft touch?

Last year, the number of people seeking asylum rose 55%, from 46,015 in 1998 to 71,160. This increase has been widely attributed to the Kosovo conflict, which led to an increase in refugees during last summer.

Many right-wingers argue that asylum seekers are lured over by our generous benefits. Britain's benefit system is marginally more generous than the French system, where asylum seekers must survive on just £21 a week, but the new laws do not offer any more than what most would consider a bare minimum to subsist on.

The belief that more "flood" into Britain than in other countries is a myth. UN figures showed that Britain still took far fewer per 1,000 population last year than many smaller European countries. Switzerland had 5.8 applications per 1,000 population compared with 1 per 1,000 in Britain. 10 European states currently take more refugees (on a per capita basis) than Britain, which found a home for a mere 0.05% of the world's refugees in 1997, according to the Refugee Council.

What will happen now?

In Western Europe, the trend has been for governments to tighten immigration and asylum laws in the last twenty years, in reaction to domestic pressures from the right and the international pressure of a growing number of asylum seekers.

But the rise in the number of people seeking refuge in Western democracies is not only related to political oppression and war. It is also a consequence of the growing inequality between the developed and the developing world. As long as this disparity continues to grow, people will continue to seek what they hope will be a better life in the developed world.
