webTitle: Computer disks ease the risk of a painful start at school

fields.headline: Computer disks ease the risk of a painful start at school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead's "dead years" of new children struggling with life in their large secondary schools scarcely exist at Benton Park in Leeds, thanks to a set of computer disks.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead's "dead years" of new children struggling with life in their large secondary schools scarcely exist at Benton Park in Leeds, thanks to a set of computer disks.

The assistant head, Richard Hoban, spends part of his summer holidays collating spreadsheets and key stage 2 results and keying in data such as: "Don't let this lad sit next to John Smith - they spent too much time chattering and distracting one another at primary school."

The system, developed over Mr Hoban's 27 years at the Leeds comprehensive, has an unusually good chance of percolating into the department for education and employment. One former pupil who benefited is David Miliband, head of the policy unit at No 10 Downing Street. Handing out prizes at Benton a couple of years ago, Mr Miliband recalled the induction system, complete with cartoon-packed Benton Survival Guide and hideous rumours invented by pupils at the school.

"We try to scotch those [rumours] on three separate visits paid to each of our seven main primaries," says Mr Hoban, whose son and daughter went to Benton Park. "They're dealt with, too, in our new Welcome Book, which tries to answer all the nervous questions asked by children on arrival."

Singled out for excellence in Ofsted's annual report, the school reckons to know every one of 250 or so new pupils and to follow them through Mr Woodhead's potential "dead period" leading up to key stage 3. The system, which also matches lone pupils from the more remote of Benton's 21 feeder schools, is reinforced by other teaching colleagues as the children progress through their first three years.

The pupils are monitored through tests and teachers' observation to check that none is struggling or freewheeling.

Mr Hoban says: "It's also important all the information is available to parents if they want to see it."

New pupils are guaranteed to find at least one primary school friend in every class or set.

fields.headline: The best goodbye scene
fields.standfirst: Sleepy Hollow
fields.trailText: Having discovered that a mortal is controlling the villainous Headless Horseman, Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) is preparing to leave Sleepy Hollow.
fields.body:
Having discovered that a mortal is controlling the villainous Headless Horseman, Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) is preparing to leave Sleepy Hollow.

Grim-faced, he leaves the house and strides down the stairs towards his waiting carriage. While descending the stairs, his friend, the young Masbath (Marc Pickering) approaches, eyeing him accusingly.

"You think it was Katrina don't you?" asks a rhetorical Masbeth, referring to the girl Crane has - until now - been busy falling in love with. Crane looks disconsolately at the ground.

"That can never be uttered."

The boy carries on:

"A strange sort of witch, with a kind and loving heart. How can you think so?"

Crane drops to his knees, supposedly to fasten a strap on his bag.

"I have good reason", he replies wearily.

"Then you are bewitched by reason."

"I am beaten down by it," he snaps, rising from the steps and passing his bag to the coachman.

"It is a hard lesson for a hard world and you had better learn it young Masbath. Villainy wears many masks, none so dangerous as the mask of virtue."

The boy appears teary-eyed. Crane pats him on the shoulder, a forlorn look etched into his face.

"Farewell."

See also: Casablanca, North By Northwest, Brighton Rock, The Deer Hunter

Don't see also: On Golden Pond

Pointless trivia: Johnny Depp's 1997 directorial debut The Brave - starring Depp and Marlon Brando - has never been released in the US or Europe.

webTitle: Seven vie for romantic novel prize

fields.headline: Seven vie for romantic novel prize
fields.trailText: Two authors whose earlier earthy books were turned into gritty films were shortlisted yesterday for the romantic novel of the year award.
fields.body:
Two authors whose earlier earthy books were turned into gritty films were shortlisted yesterday for the romantic novel of the year award.

Philippa Gregory's slave trade critique, A Respectable Trade, became a BBC mini-series starring Warren Clarke two years ago, while Angela Huth's Land Girls, about women working in the fields during the second world war, was adapted for a film starring Anna Friel. This year their more recent novels are competing against five others for the £5,000 prize.

The Romantic Novelists' Association chairwoman, Norma Curtis, said the 40-year-old prize had maintained its place by moving with the times. Describing Mike Gayle, speaker at the award dinner on April 13, as the new face of romantic novels, she said: "There is a surprising number of men writing romantic fiction. We hope that Mike Gayle's profile draws attention to our forward-looking approach."

Last year's winner was Clare Chambers, for Learning to Swim.

The shortlist

Commencing Our Descent by Suzannah Dunn, of Brighton

Virgin Earth by Philippa Gregory, of Midhurst, West Sussex

Easy Silence by Angela Huth, of Oxford

Act of Faith by Erica James, of Northwich, Cheshire

Never Too Late by Cathy Kelly, of Dublin

Dancing in the Dark by Maureen Lee, of Bootle, Merseyside

Isabella by Fiona Mountain, of Oxfordshire.

fields.headline: West End rapist remanded
fields.trailText: A man dubbed the West End rapist faces a life sentence after last night being convicted of a series of sexual attacks on women in central London.
fields.body:
A man dubbed the West End rapist faces a life sentence after last night being convicted of a series of sexual attacks on women in central London.

Benarsko Gaisey, 35, was found guilty of four rapes and an indecent assault on three women and remanded in custody by Judge John Rogers at the Old Bailey.

Gaisey carried out his attacks after luring women he met in the West End to his home in Stoke Newington. Police believe he is guilty of a string of attacks, some unreported because they were carried out on tourists who left the country.

A 17-year-old Italian student who Gaisey raped twice suffered serious injuries when she tried to escape through a window while he slept.

Police took the unusual step of issuing Gaisey's photograph in the summer of 1997, warning women he was "extremely dangerous".

Two other women came forward to complain about sexual assaults committed by Gaisey, whom they knew as Samson Mensah.

Gaisey, an illegal immigrant, used a variety of aliases to work in the West End. The day after the attack on the Italian student, he was arrested and bailed. He disappeared, and was eventually traced to Ghana and extradited to Britain last year.

webTitle: Four men leap from cockpit of hijack jet

fields.headline: Four men leap from cockpit of hijack jet
fields.standfirst: Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: Four men escaped from the cockpit of the hijacked Boeing 727 at Stansted airport in a dramatic development to the hostage crisis late last night.
fields.body:
Four men escaped from the cockpit of the hijacked Boeing 727 at Stansted airport in a dramatic development to the hostage crisis late last night.

The men, dressed in dark clothing, jumped from the cockpit and ran towards a hangar where they met police. They were then taken to the medical centre, where they received medical treatment and were interviewed.

The lights of the cabin and cockpit remained on after the escape. "We are talking to people on board, and they are calm," an Essex police spokeswoman said last night.

It was not immediately clear whether the men were crew, hostages or - thought less likely - members of the hijack gang itself. Police said hijackers remained on board.

The development took police by surprise after a day of slow but ordered negotiations with the hijackers, which had seen the release of just one of the remaining 157 Afghan passengers on the plane. Eight had been freed on Monday.

Shortly before the escape the plane's cabin lights were switched on, having been switched off for 45 minutes. Police said it had been a spontaneous escape.

Armed police had spent the day situated about 50 yards from the plane in a south-east corner of the airfield.

Mike Ganes, an aviation expert, said last night that the four men who escaped could have used emergency ropes that are placed in the cockpit to help descent from the plane.

The men were seen to clamber out through the window before sliding down the side of the plane's cockpit to make the 20ft drop to the runway tarmac. They were then seen to run towards a hangar where police have been based during the standoff.

Essex police said last night their first concern, as it had been throughout the hijack situation, was for the safety of the passengers on board. It was unclear immediately whether the men who had escaped were hostages or hijackers who had perhaps split from the others over differing opinions.

A police spokeswoman said early today: "It appears to have been an escape of four people. We are gauging what effect this has had on the other people on board. We are talking to people on board as we speak. Everything appears to be calm. We have no more information at the moment."

After the escape, activity around the plane intensified, with an airport bus seen to pass close to it. It was not clear if it had been dispatched to pick up the four men.

Before the dramatic escape last night, a representative of the UN High Commission for Refugees had arrived at Stansted. Joe Edwards, assistant chief constable of Essex police, told a press conference that the unnamed female UN representative had observer status and was not there as a negotiator.

Talks with the hijackers are continuing to be conducted through Essex police negotiators. Because of the "delicate nature of negotiations" police would not reveal why the representative had arrived or who had asked her to come.

But the announcement added to speculation that the hijackers are seeking political asylum.

The UN spokesman John Mills, speaking from New York, said the UNHCR woman at the hijack scene was the organisation's leading representative in the UK.

Mr Mills said: "The UN has no direct involvement in the negotiations. The UNHCR person is there on standby as a representative of a neutral humanitarian organisation."

He would not say who, if anyone, had requested her presence but said the woman, who is based in London, had intimate knowledge of the situation in Afghanistan and should be able to provide the authorities with valuable background information.

Mike Ganes, an aviation expert, said last night that the four men who escaped could have used emergency ropes that are placed in the cockpit to help descent from the plane. The men were seen to clamber out through the window before sliding down the side of the plane's cockpit to make the 20ft drop to the runway tarmac. They were then seen to run towards a hangar where police have been based during the standoff. Essex police said last night their first concern, as it had been throughout the hijack situation, was for the safety of the passengers on board. It was unclear immediately whether the men who had escaped were hostages or hijackers who had perhaps split from the others over differing opinions. A police spokeswoman said early today: "It appears to have been an escape of four people. We are gauging what effect this has had on the other people on board. We are talking to people on board as we speak. Everything appears to be calm. We have no more information at the moment." After the escape, activity around the plane intensified, with an airport bus seen to pass close to it. It was not clear if it had been dispatched to pick up the four men. Before the dramatic escape last night, a representative of the UN High Commission for Refugees had arrived at Stansted. Joe Edwards, assistant chief constable of Essex police, told a press conference that the unnamed female UN representative had observer status and was not there as a negotiator. Talks with the hijackers are continuing to be conducted through Essex police negotiators. Because of the "delicate nature of negotiations" police would not reveal why the representative had arrived or who had asked her to come. But the announcement added to speculation that the hijackers are seeking political asylum. The UN spokesman John Mills, speaking from New York, said the UNHCR woman at the hijack scene was the organisation's leading representative in the UK. Mr Mills said: "The UN has no direct involvement in the negotiations. The UNHCR person is there on standby as a representative of a neutral humanitarian organisation." He would not say who, if anyone, had requested her presence but said the woman, who is based in London, had intimate knowledge of the situation in Afghanistan and should be able to provide the authorities with valuable background information.

fields.headline: Taliban barred from hostage crisis
fields.standfirst:
Ninth captive freed but 156 face fourth day at gunpoint as foreign office turns down Afghan request to fly into Britain
Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: The hardline Taliban regime in Afghanistan sought permission yesterday to make an extraordinary flight to Britain as the hostages held on board a Boeing 727 at Stansted airport approached a fourth day in captivity.
fields.body:
The hardline Taliban regime in Afghanistan sought permission yesterday to make an extraordinary flight to Britain as the hostages held on board a Boeing 727 at Stansted airport approached a fourth day in captivity.

But the British government turned down the request, fearing the impact that the arrival of Taliban representatives might have on the delicate negotiations between police and the hijackers.

Another hostage was released yesterday - following the three men, three women and two children freed on Monday - from what has become the longest hijack in Britain. The Boeing 727 was captured during an internal Afghan flight on Sunday.

The government in Kabul, which is in the grip of the hardline Islamic Taliban movement, had asked the foreign office if it could fly one of its representatives, thought to be a minister, into Gatwick.

Britain does not have diplomatic ties with the Taliban government, which on Monday described the hijackers as terrorists and urged the British government to storm the plane.

The mood among the hijackers is reported to be calm but the arrival of the Taliban would have introduced an unpredictable and potentially destabilising element. It is thought the minister seeking entry was the Taliban's deputy foreign minister, Abdul Rahman Zahid, who is visiting Germany.

Police hopeful

A spokesman for the Taliban government, Sayed Rahmatullah, speaking before the Taliban request was turned down, said: "If we go to London it will only be to receive our nationals there who are being released. We will not negotiate with the hijackers."

Police at Stansted said they were hopeful of securing the release of the 156 people still on board the Boeing 727. "The fact that we have had nine people released from the aircraft is positive and should be treated in this way. The fact that we are talking and continue to talk is very positive."

John Broughton, the assistant chief constable of Essex police, said last night about 100 police officers, five fire crews and troops including an SAS team remained at the airport monitoring the hijackers, who are reported to be armed with automatic weapons and grenades. Armed police are stationed 50 yards from the plane.

The crisis has already cost the British taxpayer upwards of £1m.

Despite a demand for the release of a rebel leader, Ismail Khan, government sources said the motives of the hijackers remained unclear. A Whitehall source said: "We still do not know why they are here, why they chose to come here or why they left."

Reports from embassies in India, Pakistan and elsewhere suggest part of the motive may be to seek eventual asylum in Britain. While this was not being totally discounted by British authorities yesterday, it was regarded as an odd ploy since the hijackers would automatically face charges for taking the plane, which could lead to a long prison sentence.

The man released yesterday was an Afghan, aged between 40 and 45, who had complained of asthma. Police sharpshooters trained their weapons on him and the exit to the plane as he was pushed from the aircraft and ordered to put down his bags and walk with his hands up towards police.

He was later given oxygen, food and water and was said by Mr Broughton to be "feeling fine".

Since the jet was seized en route from Kabul to the northern Afghan town of Mazar-i-Sharif, shortly after takeoff at 5.30am GMT on Sunday, about 30 hostages have been released in all, including some at stops in Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Moscow.

Although Essex police said the hijackers had issued no political ultimatum, they did acknowledge that "there are issues that will be discussed".

A police spokeswoman said: "There is a difference between discussing issues and making demands." Trained negotiators have kept lines open almost constantly with the hijackers since the plane, belonging to the Ariana airline, arrived at Stansted at 2.01am on Monday, although there was an agreed break for about an hour early on Monday morning.

The negotiators operate in teams of three - usually two in a speaking roll with the third coordinating from Stansted police station.

"Negotiations are taking place in a well ordered and logical way," said Mr Broughton. "It's not been pushed on either side. People need to reflect on what is going on." In talks with the hijackers and with freed hostages police were "building up a detailed picture" of the situation on the plane.

Operation Invicta

One of those involved in what is being called "Operation Invicta" is Detective Chief Inspector Win Bernard, who engineered the successful release of 186 passengers and 13 crew after 18 hours on a hijacked Sudanese plane at Stansted in 1996.

Through a grim third day on board, the hostages stayed "remarkably calm", Mr Broughton said yesterday.

A breakfast of omelette and mushrooms at about 7.30am, another generator for air conditioning and the provision of medical supplies to ease upset stomachs, along with hygiene materials for the toilets, lessened but hardly released the discomfort of the remaining passengers.

The plane was full to capacity on take-off and comfort on the Afghan state airline is limited at the best of times. Since a ban enforced by the United Nations on the airline running international flights, Ariana has found it difficult to get parts and its planes are in poor condition.

But the hostages released on Monday, including two girls aged three months and six months, were reported to have been treated well. The infants were given medication for dehydration.

Four members of one family that were released were put up at the Stansted Hilton hotel under police watch. One of the men, bearded and about 5ft 5in, looked fit and smiled as he gathered his belongings. Although he said he spoke no English, police were anxious to keep him from reporters.

A five-strong team of Persian-speaking interpreters brought in from London to assist the family were also prevented from speaking publicly amid fears that even the most innocuous divulging of information about conditions on board the hijacked plane could jeopardise careful negotiations.

One police source said the hijackers were believed to be monitoring media reports through an on-board television. Mr Broughton, said: "There may well be information that becomes available to the negotiators that if it is released may well jeopardise the safety of passengers. I am sure nobody would expect us to jeopardise that."

John Williams, the head of public affairs at Stansted, said just 12 of the 450 flights to and from the airport yesterday had to be cancelled, because the planes were too large to use the reduced runway space available.

The Afghan opposition leader and former president Burhanuddin Rabbani yesterday denied that the hijackers had requested the release of Ismail Khan. "The legal government of Afghanistan categorically denies its involvement in the plane hijacking," Mr Rabbani said in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. "Rumours that terrorists demand the release of the former governor of the Herat province, Ismail Khan, are groundless, and its the Taliban itself that is spreading those rumours."

fields.headline: Cheated out of a fortune
fields.standfirst: Jörg Haider, the far-right giant of Austrian politics, is the proud ownerof a £10m country estate. But a Jewish professor is claiming the land was swindled from his family by the Nazis.  Matthew Kalman reports
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, the far-right giant of Austrian politics, is the proud ownerof a £10m country estate. But a Jewish professor is claiming the land was swindled from his family by the Nazis.
fields.body:
When Giorgio Roifer first set his eyes on the beautiful forest of Barental near Klagenfurt in the southern Austrian Tyrol, he thought he had found the perfect estate to expand his burgeoning timber business. The Russian-born Jewish entrepreneur, who had become a naturalised Italian, lived with his wife and three children in Pisa. They had servants, horses and two cars. He had timber and sawmill interests all over Italy and southern Austria, and when he acquired the 3,700-acre Barental estate at the age of 37, it seemed the ideal addition to his growing empire.

But his wife and children were destined never to see Barental. Less than a year after Roifer bought the estate in 1937, Hitler became the ruler of Austria under the Anschluss. When Roifer visited Barental in 1938, he found a sign on the door of the Moser Hotel where he used to stay in Klagenfurt. It said: "Dogs and Jews are not welcome."

The Nazis embarked on a ruthless policy of Aryanisation - forcing Jews to sell their property and leave the country. Roifer died that year, and soon after the land was sold to a man called Josef Webhofer, who left it to his son Wilhelm.

Today, it belongs to Jörg Haider, leader of the far-right Austrian Freedom party, who received it as a gift in 1986 from Webhofer, his great-uncle. Worth about £10m, the hunting, fishing, shooting and wood-logging estate is the basis of the vast fortune that has made Haider one of the wealthiest men in Austria. The original sale was, however, illegal. If Haider's family had not deceived Roifer's widow years after the war, the estate would still belong to her family.

Roifer's son, Alexander, who many believe is the rightful heir to Barental, lives today in a modest apartment in a middle-class Jerusalem suburb called French Hill, far removed from the grandeur of Pisa or the beauty of Barental. White-haired, bespectacled, a professor of Bible studies at the nearby Hebrew university, he seems bemused by the sudden interest in his family history and is reluctant to talk about Haider.

He tells the story of the estate in measured tones, despite the disturbing memories it stirs. Roifer says his mother, who died in 1995, was forced to sell the estate for a fraction of its real value, and never discovered that she had been tricked into giving it up until it was too late. "I am certainly not happy about what happened, but I do not wake up every morning angry about it," he says. "A man builds his life and fortunately I have found other things to keep me busy and interested. Of course I am sorry that the Roifer forest is now the Haider forest.

"The property was sold in October 1940 under duress. In the course of the sale an illegal act was committed, but the authorities in Karenten induced the sale in order to Aryanise the land. If you ask me, do we have a legal claim, the answer is no. If you ask if I think what has happened was morally right, I think it stinks.

"The acquisition was made in several stages and was completed in 1937. On August 26 1938 my father died of cancer."

Roifer was 38. His young widow, Matilde, and children Noemi, 10, Josef, 8 and Alexander, 6, fled to Palestine to escape the Nazis.

"In October 1939, we left Italy for Israel. My father, who was a Zionist, told my mother on his deathbed to take the family to Israel. It was almost impossible to get visas, but my mother wrote a letter which eventually got to [Israeli statesman] David Ben-Gurion, who made sure we got a visa.

"My uncle in Italy decided to sell the forest. There was all sorts of virulent anti-semitic propaganda in the press. He was under a great deal of psychological and physical duress. If we had been Austrian citizens and therefore citizens of the expanded German Reich, it would have been very simple. They would have said, 'Here are 10 Reichmarks, the forest is now ours.' But we were Italians and the Italian government would not allow that to happen."

Instead of the estate being confiscated, the family were able to sell it, but the price of 300,000 Reichsmarks - about £750,000 at today's prices - was only about one-tenth of the actual value of the property.

"The buyer was Josef Webhofer from Brunich in Southern Tyrol," says Roifer. "Hitler and Mussolini had signed an agreement about the region where he lived, a German-speaking area of Italy. The Germans living in Tyrol could either stay in Italy and become Italians, changing their names and losing the autonomy they enjoyed, or they could emigrate to the Third Reich. Josef Webhofer bought this land in order to have some stake inside the Third Reich and move there."

Matilde had not wanted to sell the estate and didn't even know of the sale until her brother-in-law wrote to her at the end of the war. Worse was to come. When the money finally reached Italy, it was frozen until after the war, by which time inflation had reduced its value to almost nothing.

In 1953, Roifer's mother went back to Austria to try to get a fairer sum from Webhofer. To their surprise, he agreed to pay another $100,000. "When she received that money, my mother signed a paper foregoing all future claims," says Roifer. "The indemnity was given under restrictive conditions. We were not permitted access to the documentation in the land registry office in Klagenfurt."

It was only years later that the family discovered why Webhofer had insisted on that condition and why he had been so willing to pay the extra cash. In 1989 papers were discovered at the land registry office in Klagenfurt which amazed the Roifers.

"The document said that the power of attorney granted by my mother, Matilde Roifer Galichi, to her brother-in-law, Dr Naphtoli Emdin, was not valid. But because it was desirable to Aryanise the land, the local officials decided to approve the sale anyway. In other words, there was no sale. Until 1953 the forest was legally ours. That is why Webhofer agreed to pay, because he knew that if this became known, the deal would be void."

fields.headline: Greens take on Haider
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria's new conservative-far right coalition government yesterday faced down calls for fresh elections and easily got through a no-confidence vote as the country agonised over how it might manoeuvre itself out of political turmoil.
fields.body:
Austria's new conservative-far right coalition government yesterday faced down calls for fresh elections and easily got through a no-confidence vote as the country agonised over how it might manoeuvre itself out of political turmoil.

The Greens, by far the fiercest critics of Jörg Haider and his far right Freedom party, accused Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel of steering Austria into a state of "political isolation and economic damage" by agreeing to have the Haider party in government with his conservative People's party.

The leader of the Greens, Alexander Van der Bellen, blamed Chancellor Schüssel for taking Austria hostage and said the former foreign minister had "ensured that Austria today stands under a state of international quarantine". He called Mr Haider, who has opted out of the government, the "upper chancellor" because he has dominated the agenda in the past few days.

A Green party MP, Peter Pilz, said that the only way to solve the country's problems was to "ask the people", meaning new elections.

Asked by Mr Van der Bellen "how Austria will get out of this cul-de-sac?" Chancellor Schüssel replied that he and the foreign minister, Benito Ferrero Waldner, had been working to keep up communication with foreign governments. He said he had "firmly distanced" himself from comments by Mr Haider, who has praised Hitler's employment policies and questioned the responsibility of the the Waffen SS for wartime atrocities. "Never will a member of my government say anything like that," he said.

The debate - the most heated in the Austrian parliament since the controversy 10 years ago over President Kurt Waldheim's wartime activities - came on top of revelations that threaten to stoke the international concern about the Haider phenomenon.

A weekly current affairs magazine revealed that the government's new minister for infrastructure, Michael Schmid of the Freedom party, gave 150,000 schillings (£6,700) from party coffers in 1993 and 1994 to an extreme rightwing magazine known for its racist views. In the autumn of 1994 the magazine, Aula, mouthpiece for the Freedom Academic Union, carried an interview with a Holocaust denier.

The article asserted: "The mass gassings with Zyklon B which took place, according to 'witnesses' and 'confessions of offenders', according to the law of nature and technical possibilities could not have taken place in that way."

Yesterday there were calls for the resignation of the minister of justice, Michael Krüger, after records were revived showing that during a parliamentary speech on behalf of the Freedom party in 1995 he said that according to the definition in one dictionary con centration camps were "punishment camps for civilians". Criticism of Mr Haider for his remarks was, he said, "semantic masturbation".

In an interview published in Germany's Die Welt yesterday, Mr Haider said that the Waffen SS could not be seen as collectively guilty for its crimes. Austria was a nation, he said, "where individual guilt is what matters. Hence it can never be the Waffen SS as such but only individuals who have failed and who bear the responsibility" for crimes committed by the organisation.

The Nuremberg trials after the second world war officially declared the Waffen SS illegal and labelled it a "criminal organisation".

Yesterday there were calls for the resignation of the minister of justice, Michael Krüger, after records were revived showing that during a parliamentary speech on behalf of the Freedom party in 1995 he said that according to the definition in one dictionary con centration camps were "punishment camps for civilians". Criticism of Mr Haider for his remarks was, he said, "semantic masturbation". In an interview published in Germany's Die Welt yesterday, Mr Haider said that the Waffen SS could not be seen as collectively guilty for its crimes. Austria was a nation, he said, "where individual guilt is what matters. Hence it can never be the Waffen SS as such but only individuals who have failed and who bear the responsibility" for crimes committed by the organisation. The Nuremberg trials after the second world war officially declared the Waffen SS illegal and labelled it a "criminal organisation".

fields.headline: Sweeping away our liberties
fields.standfirst:
Case by case, the rights of Britons are being gutted by governments

Jack Straw Online
fields.trailText: What is wrong with this government, and with its predecessors, is that it operates on a case by case basis. It has no feeling for the principles of liberty and, clearly, it has no time for them.
fields.body:
What is wrong with this government, and with its predecessors, is that it operates on a case by case basis. It has no feeling for the principles of liberty and, clearly, it has no time for them.

For example, the Lords won us a temporary remission by defeating the attempt to restrict trial by jury, but no one should suppose this is more than a temporary respite. Jack Straw and his government will be back.

The principles which preserve between them the rule of law and the rights of individuals have been systematically subverted by recent governments. This government has been the most recent to attack them; it has been the most determined. In every case it has cited what seem plausible, even worthwhile, reasons for its actions, but the cumulative effect has been to erode the rules which protect us. Indeed, it is almost as if the government has made out a checklist of those rules, determined to strike them down one by one.

Presumption of innocence was weakened to catch serious fraud cases. After all, we do not want crooked high flyers to get away with their clever and complicated schemes. The upshot is that they may now be required to show that they acted legitimately, rather than having the state prove that they broke the law.

Double jeopardy meant that you could not be put on trial again once you had been acquitted: not any more. It first went out when we allowed civil prosecutions after criminal ones had failed. We do not like to see people walk free when we disagree with the jury, so we allow a second shot. This is why O J Simpson was put on trial again on the same evidence which had seen him acquitted. In a civil trial it is easier, too, because a balance of evidence is sufficient, rather than "beyond any reasonable doubt".

Now new criminal prosecutions are being considered when new evidence emerges. This is partly an aftermath of the Lawrence murder, and the laudable desire not to let racist thugs get away with it.

Limited jurisdiction meant that you had to do something which was a crime in the place which put you on trial. This one went when Lady Thatcher forced a war crimes bill through despite determined opposition in the Lords. It has since been further weakened. We can now try people for things they do abroad which would be offences in Britain, but which are perhaps less well enforced over there. We can even try them for things which were not offences at the time. As always, we are told that this is the only way to get at certain classes of criminals. After all, who cares what happens to suspected paedophiles and war criminals?

The right of silence allowed no presumption to be drawn from the refusal of an accused to say anything. No one could be forced to testify in their defence. It used to help prevent beatings or torture of suspects. If they need not say anything at all, there was less reason to force them to say suitably incriminating things. Now judges may tell juries to draw inferences when an accused exercises this right, and another right is diluted.

Habeas corpus prevented the state from holding people incommunicado while it dealt with them. It had to produce them in open court and charge them. This was all very well, but for suspected terrorists various extensions were allowed because the authorities needed more time. Imprisonment without trial in the form of internment was even permitted under the general heading of prevention of terrorism. Again the defence is that it only concerns terrorists.

Conviction before sentence was a corner-stone principle. You had to convict someone before you could punish them. This is no longer true in the case of suspected drug dealers. Their property can be confiscated if it is suspected to have derived from drug profits, even if this cannot be proved. The alternative would have been to let these sleazy merchants of death and misery laugh at justice and walk off with their gains.

Prior restraint was notoriously difficult to obtain in Britain. People broke the law, and they were caught, tried and punished. It was the way the law worked. Now the government is reported to be considering a scheme under which satellites control the speed of cars to prevent them from exceeding the speed limit by cutting their fuel supply. The imagination leaps to supply what similar things might be done once the principle is breached.

Trial by jury is threatened because crooks are thought more likely to hoodwink juries than magistrates. The notion of facing your peers in open court is all very well, but not if it allows you to get away with it. The Lords saved it once, but no one supposes that the threat will go away.

The pattern emerges quite clearly: government is making laws out of particular cases and eroding the general principles in order to secure a particular aim. It wants to bring to justice the people none of us have any time for: financial swindlers, racist thugs, paedophiles, war criminals, drug dealers and terrorists. Others might include rapists, petty professional criminals who are "obviously guilty", and multiple offenders whose record will be known to magistrates, but not to juries.

In the interest of bringing these low lifes to justice, the principles which protect the liberties of all of us are swept away. The precepts which have guarded society are destroyed to target particular groups of offenders. After all, we do not want them getting off, do we? In some cases, though, we might accept that, preferring a few unsavoury individuals to walk free rather than compromise the foundations on which our liberties depend. We give the devil himself the benefit of our laws, for how could we otherwise claim it ourselves?

 Dr Madsen Pirie is president of the Adam Smith Institute

webTitle: Prince Charles cancels trip to Austria

fields.headline: Prince Charles cancels trip to Austria
fields.standfirst:
The future of the monarchy: special report
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles last night postponed a visit to Austria as the British government registered its protest at the inclusion of the far-right leader, Jörg Haider, in the new Austrian coalition government.
fields.body:
Prince Charles last night postponed a visit to Austria as the British government registered its protest at the inclusion of the far-right leader, Jörg Haider, in the new Austrian coalition government.

St James's Palace said it had been an official visit not a holiday trip, and that it had taken advice from the foreign office. A spokesman for the palace said yesterday: "In the light of present circumstances, the visit will be postponed."

The Prince of Wales had been due to attend a trade fair in Vienna in May.

Discussions between the palace and the foreign office began last week after the creation of the coalition government last week, which includes Mr Haider, the leader of the Freedom party, who has made frequent remarks sympathetic to Hitler and the Nazis. The foreign office advised that the trip should not go ahead.

Postponement of the visit marks a hardening on the part of the British government, whose reaction to Mr Haider's rise was initially less emphatic than elsewhere in the European Union. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last week expressed "deep concern and distaste" at the inclusion of Mr Haider in Austria's government.

Britain joined the remainder of the EU in suspending bilateral relations with Austria and downgrading ambassadorial ties. Postponement of Prince Charles's visit is the first unilateral action taken by Britain.

Mr Haider's rise has created turmoil in Austria, including violent protests. Yesterday, 600 police cordoned off the Austrian parliament during a debate on the country's international isolation.

Prince Charles's private visits are left to his discretion. He has made many trips to Austria, mainly to ski at the Lech. But official visits require the government's advice, which is always strictly followed.

The Dutch royal family faced criticism in the Netherlands after going ahead with a ski trip to Austria. Many skiers and other holidaymakers have been cancelling trips in protest over Mr Haider.

A spokesman for the British embassy in Vienna said the royal visit had been cancelled because of the postponement of the Britain Now trade events. "The political climate isn't particularly conducive to getting new commercial business. As the event has been postponed, Prince Charles's visit has also been put off."

The Britain Now show, to have taken place in Vienna and another Austrian town, would have featured UK exporters and home-grown culture. A fashion show highlighting British designers was among the scheduled events.

Sir Anthony Figgis, the British ambassador, has informed the mayor of Vienna about the cancellations.

webTitle: Memory test: Data storage firm moves into music

fields.headline: Memory test: Data storage firm moves into music
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Memory Corporation, the data storage company, is shifting its strategy to focus on delivering entertainment content over the internet and building consumer gadgets.
fields.body:
Memory Corporation, the data storage company, is shifting its strategy to focus on delivering entertainment content over the internet and building consumer gadgets.

The Easdaq-listed company also plans to seek a Nasdaq listing, change its name to Dig and is considering either floating or selling some divisions to realise shareholder value.

At the height of the data storage boom in 1995 Edinburgh-based Memory was worth £600m, but a change in market conditions and technology has seen its value slump to £90m.

Chairman Bill Hipp, speaking yesterday after Memory reported its first full year pre-tax profit - about £500,000 - said content deals for music downloads had been done with artists such as rap star Puff Daddy and American hip-hop company Regenesis.

Also on the agenda was that online television and dig-Music.com, which holds Memory's online music interests, might be taken to market.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: It's early days so I'm not taking it personally yet, but while others have already received invitations to Philip Gould's 50th birthday party in March, I have not.
fields.body:
 It's early days so I'm not taking it personally yet, but while others have already received invitations to Philip Gould's 50th birthday party in March, I have not. Should this be more than an oversight, you will imagine my distress . . . not only because Philip has done so much focus group work for the Diary (it was he who established that 53.6% of readers see this column as lemon fresh Lenor); but also because of the wondrous party he's arranged.

Philip is the first person, so far as we know, to hire the entire Millennium Wheel for a private do! The official cost of the London Eye is £2,400 for two-and-a-half hours, during which guests will be served champagne and canapés as they circle in their pods, but it is unclear whether Philip's close links to the New Labour project earned him a discount. We would have asked him had he returned our call, but forgetting that 69.4% of ABC1 voters connect bad manners with Somerfield tapioca pudding six weeks past its sell-by date, this he has failed to do. Poor show.

 There is nothing worse than the kind of sneerer who describes the term "military intelligence" as an oxymoron, so we are pleased by news of a ministry of defence triumph. Last week, the MoD spent time and effort getting an injunction to withdraw copies of She Who Dared, a book by the first woman member (Jackie George is her nom de plume) of military intelligence special forces in Northern Ireland.

The MoD had to act because last year some bloody fool ministry - the MoD in fact - cleared it for publication. So well has the injunction worked that the book is now available not only in bookshops all over Britain at £16.95, but also via the Barnes & Noble website in the US . . . at just $20 so you can save money and break an MoD embargo at the same time!

 The share-dealing war between the Sun and Mirror becomes more fascinating. Piers Morgan fights back by accusing someone at the Sun of doing something. But the Sun's David Yelland says something cross in reply, arguing something or other. Or something like that. Anyway, if you penetrate the technicalities, it is so fascinating that we could go on reading about it for ever.

 Today's Diary share tip is Guardian Media Group. Buy, buy, buy. In fact you can't buy, since this is not a public company, but we hope to correct this on the lines of a building society "demutualisation". Considering pre-tax profits, cash reserves and the potentially explosive growth of internet activities, the company is loosely valued at £1bn. All this is, of course, is complete fantasy, since selling this paper would end the independence that makes it unique. And yet, in a greedy commercial world, fantasy can become reality, so keep an eye open and if ever you get the chance . . . buy, buy, buy!

 Following Peter Kilfoyle's resignation is more evidence that the age of principle is not dead. New Labour peer Nazir Ahmed fought government attempts to abolish section 28 ferociously. "This is the position of my religion and this is a matter of personal belief," the Rotherham chip shop owner (something important at Usdaw) told the Mail. So strong was this belief that, after gentle consultation with the whips, he decided to fight for section 28 not in the voting lobbies, but in Turkey, where he was dispatched as part of a "fact finding mission". Heroic stuff.

 On a recent flight to Sidney, a Qantas stewardess was handed a note for her boss. "Dear Captain, my name is Nicola, I'm 8 years old, this is my first flight but I'm not scared. I like to watch the clouds go by," read a babyish hand, the words ringed by infantile drawings of the sun, a little girl and a jumbo jet. "My mum says the crew is nice," she continues, "thanks for a nice flight, don't fuck up the landing. Luv Nicola xxxx." Ah, the adorable things kids say!

fields.headline: £450,000 start-up becomes £310m buy
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Phone.com
fields.trailText: Phone.com of the United States yesterday paid £310m for a British company that attracted seed capital of some £450,000 two years ago.
fields.body:
Phone.com of the United States yesterday paid £310m for a British company that attracted seed capital of some £450,000 two years ago.

Paragon Software - which employs 63 people developing synchronisation technology allowing personal computer-based personal information to be transferred to mobile devices - accepted an offer of 3.6m Phone.com shares plus $7.5m (£4.7m) in cash.

The deal underlines the position of the Berkshire town of Newbury - home of Paragon - as the UK's mobile phone capital in the wake of locally based Vodafone's acquisition of Mannesmann.

It also guarantees a personal fortune for Paragon founder and chief executive Colin Calder, who attracted £450,000 in seed financing from investment group 3i after winning a newspaper competition in February 1998.

In November of that year 3i and Kennet Capital, the venture capital affiliate of Broadview, invested a further £1.25m to fund expansion into the US.

Paragon's main product is FoneSync, which allows users of PC and internet-based personal organisers using software such as Lotus Notes and Microsoft Outlook to transfer data to and from 240 types of mobile phone.

Its partners include mobile manufacturers Alcatel, Ericsson, Nokia and Panasonic.

Alain Rossmann, chairman and chief executive officer of Phone.com, said: "Mobile phone users are demanding touch of a button information management between the mobile phone, PC applications, and net services, whether or not they are online. The combination of Paragon Software and Phone.com will drive this technology to market."

Mr Calder said: "Extending our technology to WAP-based over the air synchronisation will revolutionise the way people use their phones."

webTitle: Clinton puts ban on misuse of gene tests

fields.headline: Clinton puts ban on misuse of gene tests
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton moved yesterday to try to defuse growing public anxiety about the misuse of human genetic research.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton moved yesterday to try to defuse growing public anxiety about the misuse of human genetic research.

In one of the most detailed speeches on medical research issues given by a US president, Mr Clinton barred American federal government agencies from discriminating against employees on the basis of genetic tests. He also gave his backing to a senate bill which aims to extend similar protections to the private sector and insurance purchasers.

Concern is mounting that genetic testing and research which allow doctors to predict the future health of their patients are already being used to discriminate against workers, and to assess insurance risks.

"This extraordinary march of human understanding imposes on us a profound responsibility to make sure that the age of discovery can continue to reflect our most cherished values," Mr Clinton said yesterday. "We must protect our citizens' privacy - the bulwark of personal liberty, the safeguard of individual creativity."

Mr Clinton also waded into the current controversy over problems surrounding clinical trials of gene therapies. Gene therapy research projects at several US centres have been halted since news of the death of a patient in a university of Pennsylvania experiment last year became public.

The president announced that federal health bodies must "expedite their review of gene therapy guidelines and regulations to determine whether the current informed consent requirements need to be strengthened."

The president announced his initiatives yesterday in a speech to the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington.

In addition to issuing an executive order affecting every federal government department and agency, Mr Clinton said he endorsed a bill sponsored by the Democratic senators Tom Daschle and Edward Kennedy and the Republican congresswoman Louise Slaughter, which extends the same provisions to the private sector.

The Daschle bill would prohibit all employers from refusing to hire workers who are at risk as a result of health problems and would prevent insurers refusing to sell them cover.

Mr Clinton, who spoke with Dr Francis Collins, the director of the US human genome research institute, standing at his side, echoed a plea which he has made in several recent speeches, including in his recent state of the union address that "we must see that science serves humanity, not the other way around".

Mr Clinton said it was vital not to allow concerns about the misuse of genetic information to discourage people from seeking the tests which could improve their lives. "If we do not protect the right to privacy, we may actually impede the reach of these breakthroughs in the lives of ordinary people, which would be a profound tragedy," he said.

The White House said that the speech sent "a powerful message" to the private sector to adopt a similar approach. "I think it starts an important process on an issue that all the surveys show Americans are very concerned about, moving into the future," presidential spokesman Joe Lockhart told reporters.

The central issue in the new policy initiative is to prevent progress in genetic testing from being used by employers and risk assessors to discriminate against workers - including those who have not yet or may never show the signs of illness - in an attempt to avoid possible health care costs.

The fear of such discrimination is very real, American research has shown. A 1996 study in the journal Science showed that 15% of individuals who had been identified as being at risk of developing a genetic condition reported that they had been asked questions about genetic diseases on job applications. One in 10 claimed that they had been denied a job or had been fired because of a genetic condition in their families.

Such experiences and anxieties are likely to increase in the coming years as improved medical research techniques mean that more people become aware of their own genetic conditions.

In one of the most detailed speeches on medical research issues given by a US president, Mr Clinton barred American federal government agencies from discriminating against employees on the basis of genetic tests. He also gave his backing to a senate bill which aims to extend similar protections to the private sector and insurance purchasers. Concern is mounting that genetic testing and research which allow doctors to predict the future health of their patients are already being used to discriminate against workers, and to assess insurance risks. "This extraordinary march of human understanding imposes on us a profound responsibility to make sure that the age of discovery can continue to reflect our most cherished values," Mr Clinton said yesterday. "We must protect our citizens' privacy - the bulwark of personal liberty, the safeguard of individual creativity." fields.headline: Net snares editor-in-chief
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mark Wood, the youngest editor-in-chief in Reuters' history, yesterday succumbed to the lure of the internet by moving to the company's Greenfield Fund, writes David Teather .
fields.body:
Mark Wood, the youngest editor-in-chief in Reuters' history, yesterday succumbed to the lure of the internet by moving to the company's Greenfield Fund, writes David Teather .

Reuters insisted the move was a "huge new opportunity" rather than a sideways push for Mr Wood, editor-in-chief of the newsagency for 10 years.

He is being replaced by Reuters insider Geert Linnebank, 43, who was previously editor of news products. Mr Linnebank is a multilingual Dutchman who has worked at Reuters for 16 years.

Mr Wood, 47, will direct the editoral content of the Greenhouse Fund, a portfolio of internet investments worth as much as $1bn.

Reuters plans to float off part of Greenhouse, hiring David Lookwood from Goldman Sachs recently, and Mr Wood can expect to join in the riches increasingly associated with internet flotations.

The shake-up among the top editors came amid wider changes to the group's management. Mr Linnebank reports to Tom Glocer, recently appointed chief executive of the group's information arm, as well as to Peter Job, the overall chief executive.

fields.headline: Brain drain tax costs QXL £15m
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
QXL.com
fields.trailText: QXL.com, the online auction house, has tripled its membership but losses have escalated even faster as a government tax clampdown backfires on hi-tech firms.
fields.body:
QXL.com, the online auction house, has tripled its membership but losses have escalated even faster as a government tax clampdown backfires on hi-tech firms.

The London-based group took a £15m hit from the tax on share options and warned of a "brain drain" unless the chancellor changed the fiscal regime in the next budget.

Shares rose 16% in early trading yesterday as QXL reported new deals with British Midland Airways and four distribution agreements in France.

Internet companies are bought by investors on future profit expectations and most of these start-ups expect to run up a deficit in the early stages. But pre-tax losses at QXL rose to £38.1m in the third final quarter of 1999 from £11.2m for the previous quarter as it absorbed £12.6m from acquisitions as well as a £15m hit for national insurance tax.

Company executives are furious that the tax on share options forces them to make a provision in the profit and loss account, meaning that the higher shares rise the lower future earnings will be. Like many internet ventures, QXL's 150 employees have options as part of an incentives-led remuneration package.

Stripped of this tax and acquisitions, chief executive Jim Rose said, the pre-tax loss was £10.7m, compared to £8.1m in the previous quarter.

Chip designer ARM Holdings, also stung by the new tax, has said it will recruit staff in the US to find a way round the rules, which were meant to penalise deals for top directors.

Robert Dighero, chief financial officer at QXL, said it might look to the US, Spain and Luxembourg for new employees. That would exactly contradict the government's intention.

"A lot of these jobs are just going to move offshore. It's negative, a brain drain."

Mr Dighero added: "It's a very nasty tax: you cannot forecast it and it makes budgeting impossible."

But QXL's trading figures pleased the City. A Goldman Sachs analyst described them as encouraging, adding: "QXL is putting down barriers to entry with these online distribution deals.

"The agreement with British Midland shows it levering its platform in the community. QXL is fighting for market share. Today's losses should be met by tomorrow's profits."

Members eligible to participate in online auctions rose from 130,000 at the end of September to 400,000 while registered users, including email list subscribers ,doubled to half a million.

The deal with British Midland allows QXL to auction 20,000 seats across Europe.

It comes two months after an initial partnership during which QXL exceeded expectations with an offer of more than 13,000 seats.

It announced it had forged distribution agreements with France Telecom, Nomad, Club Internet and NRJ in France and plans to tie up agreement by the end of next month in Spain - the only big European market where it is not represented.

Late last year QXL bought the leading online auctioneers in Norway and Denmark. More than 50% of QXL's members live outside the UK.

Gross margins improved to 10.4% from 8.2% as QXL moved away from buying goods and auctioning them to just acting as facilitator for deals.

Mr Rose said: "These strong results illustrate we are establishing a solid platform from which to continue to accelerate our growth."

The company claimed more than 30m page impressions in January, the first time it has put a figure on that traffic.

Shares ended the day up 102p at £13.12p.

webTitle: Now MP3 is suing record industry

fields.headline: Now MP3 is suing record industry
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
MP3.com
fields.trailText: Online music provider MP3.com yesterday turned the tables on the recording industry by announcing it would sue the Recording Industry Association of America for "unfair business practices".
fields.body:
Online music provider MP3.com yesterday turned the tables on the recording industry by announcing it would sue the Recording Industry Association of America for "unfair business practices".

The San Diego-based company, which distributes music by largely unknown artists, said it had experienced aggressive action by the RIAA, which represents most of the world's big record companies.

The two parties have been involved in a brawl since the RIAA slapped a copyright lawsuit on MP3.com last month.

The RIAA objects to MP3.com's software, which allows customers to create digital copies of compact discs they have purchased.

MP3.com claims it is simply acting as a virtual CD player.

If the recording industry's suit is successful it could result in MP.com's closure and the award of $6.75bn in damages.

Michael Robertson, the chief executive of MP3.com, said yesterday: "Since its inception MP3.com has faced the increasingly aggressive tactics of the RIAA and its leadership. We can no longer tolerate the bullying tactics of this not-for-profit trade association.

"After we get to the bottom of all of their actions toward MP3.com, we will vigorously pursue all of our legal remedies," he said.

The RIAA lobbies on behalf of companies such as BMG, Sony Entertainment and Warner Music.

The RIAA was not available for comment yesterday.

MP3.com claims that Hilary Rosen, the chief executive of the RIAA, was talking to equity analysts about its lawsuit three days before it was filed.

MP3.com also said that while Ms Rosen was talking to analysts RIAA lawyers were at MP3.com learning about its technology.

Mr Robertson said: "The next day I met with her in Washington to engage in an open discussion about business models for bridging our respective interests.

"Little did I know that she was more concerned about talking to equity analysts about our stock price."

Michael Rhodes, a partner in the law firm Cooley Godward - which represents MP3.com - added: "You tell me why the head lobbyist of a not-for-profit organisation is concerned with our stock price."

In a letter to MP3.com last month, Ms Rosen said: "Simply put, it is not legal to compile a vast database of our members' sound recordings with no permission and no licence.

"And, whatever the individual's right to use their own music, you cannot exploit that for your company's commercial gain."

The copyright case is scheduled to be heard in court in April.

MP3.com is expected to argue that its service connects artists to their consumers and promotes their music while its proprietary technology protects the interests of artists and the music industry as a whole.

webTitle: No such thing as safety net as hackers bring Yahoo! to a halt

fields.headline: No such thing as safety net as hackers bring Yahoo! to a halt
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Yahoo!
fields.trailText: No internet site is safe from attack by hackers, experts said yesterday after the leading search engine, Yahoo!, was brought down for several hours.
fields.body:
No internet site is safe from attack by hackers, experts said yesterday after the leading search engine, Yahoo!, was brought down for several hours.

"It appears that unfortunately it was a planned attack that looked like it was directed at Yahoo! specifically," said Jeff Mallett, president of the most popular site on the internet.

Hackers crippled the site for more than two-and-a-half hours by flooding it with automated requests from multiple locations in what is known as a "denial of service" attack.

The assault was comparable to a number of people repeatedly calling a firm's telephone number to block other incoming calls.

"We had an excess amount of automated mock traffic that was generated to one of our server clusters here in California where there was such demand in a short period of time that we were unable to serve all the pages that were requested," said Mr Mallett.

The company, which is based in Santa Clara, California, and delivers an average of 465m pages a day, said that the hackers had not gained access to its computers. The company had taken precautions to prevent a repetition of the incident.

But Elias Levy, chief security officer at SecurityFocus.com in San Mateo, California, said: "It basically says nobody is safe if Yahoo! can be taken down with all the resources behind it."

The attack indicated the vulnerability of a media tool that was designed to be an open system. The FBI, which was hit by hackers last year, warned operators last month about denial of service attacks and the electronic auction site eBay went down for two days last July and one day in August.

James Atkinson, president and senior engineer of Granite Island group, an internet security consultant in Massachusetts, said: "It's kind of silly it took so long. The fact it went on for hours indicates a management and infrastructure problem that does not involve technology. This should have taken them off the map for 15 to 20 minutes, 30 at the most."

Yahoo!, which claimed 36m visitors in December, has a market capitalisation of about $93bn (£58bn) and its users conducted more than $6.7bn in business during the fourth quarter of 1999.

The firm makes money by selling advertising space and by taking a cut from merchandise sold through it. Sponsorship fees can be reduced if it fails to hit minimum levels of user impressions.

Lise Buyer, an analyst at CS First Boston, said: "There is no technology anywhere that is completely bug-free. Outages are significant only to see how the site's management reacts, how fast they get the news out and how quickly they get the site back up."

Diane Hunt, a spokeswoman for Yahoo!, said a flood of data requests from different computers on the internet had overwhelmed the routers which help to direct traffic on the website.

webTitle: Geldof puts celebrities on WAP map

fields.headline: Geldof puts celebrities on WAP map
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Live Aid organiser Bob Geldof, fresh from reinventing himself as a dot.com entrepreneur through his travel site, has leapt on the WAP bandwagon.
fields.body:
Live Aid organiser Bob Geldof, fresh from reinventing himself as a dot.com entrepreneur through his travel site, has leapt on the WAP bandwagon.

Mr Geldof has teamed up with partners including former England rugby union international Brian Moore to promote WapWorld, which they claim is Europe's first free, independent dial-up wireless application protocol or WAP gateway and portal.

WapWorld has secured a distribution deal with Carphone Warehouse to ensure its technology is installed on all WAP-enabled phones sold through the retail chain.

Mr Moore said the portal would have celebrity-driven content and that he and Mr Geldof would use contacts in the sports and entertainment fields to sign star columnists.

"WapWorld will have hip content generated by an in-house editorial team who know the sort of things people want to read and listen to," Mr Moore said.

WapWorld was founded last year, and already claims a user base of "thousands". It makes money from call costs, sponsorship and advertising.

Mr Moore said he was not worried by competition from larger rivals such as Vodafone, AOL and News Corporation, which are working on WAP plans. "WapWorld is a small, visionary company that is able to move fast and has first mover advantage.

"It is also platform-independent and can sit alongside offerings from the likes of Vodafone and Orange."

WapWorld is a joint venture between Mr Geldof's Ten Alps media company, Mr Moore's digital marketing firm, Abacus, and Jingo Communications, an internet solutions company. It is about to embark on second-round fundraising.

Carphone Warehouse said it hoped to shift 250,000 WapWorld-enabled phones by the end of the year.

webTitle: Neglect of road safety spending 'costs lives'

fields.headline: Neglect of road safety spending 'costs lives'
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Thousands of people are needlessly dying on British roads because the government fails to invest in basic road safety measures, new research suggests today.
fields.body:
Thousands of people are needlessly dying on British roads because the government fails to invest in basic road safety measures, new research suggests today.

While the government has promised that no expense will be spared to make railways safer following the Paddington train crash, the treasury has told ministers there will be little extra cash available for road safety measures - even though 37 people have died in rail crashes in the past three years, compared with more than 10,000 in road accidents.

In a report published today, the parliamentary advisory council on transport safety (Pacts) claims that road deaths and injuries are costing the nation 20 times more than the government is spending to avert road crashes.

The lobby group claims that the government's figures show the estimated costs of death and injury on the roads at £10.9bn a year. Yet the combined government spending on police enforcement, safety engineering, driver licensing and education total only £470m, according to the analysis by Pacts.

Pacts criticised the disparity between spending on measures such as traffic calming and improved traffic enforcement and the promise last year by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, that "money is no object" on rail safety. It predicted that the government would spend up to £1bn on a train protection system which would have prevented the Paddington rail disaster - the equivalent of millions of pounds for every human life saved.

Rob Gifford of Pacts said: "Someone needs to do some hard thinking and ask why we are prepared to invest so heavily in rail safety and so little in road safety which offers much better value for money per life saved."

Although Britain's general road safety record compares well with other industrial nations, with 3,500 deaths every year, Britain has one of the worst child road safety records in Europe. The government is due to publish its road safety strategy later this month.

Kevin Delaney, spokesman for the RAC Foundation, said: "The trouble is that we have a rail crash and 20 or 30 people are killed, whereas there may be 10 road deaths a day but they don't happen in the same place at the same time and they happen for a variety of reasons which, more often than not, are related to human error.

"We clearly would like the government to spend more on road safety but it must be in a targeted way. Tens of millions of pounds have already been wasted on road safety measures which are not appropriate to specific areas."

A department of transport spokesman said: "The UK has the best record on road safety among the major industrialised countries but the government is not complacent. There is still a lot more to be done."

Ministers will be challenged on the figures at a BBC-sponsored debate tonight where they will also be asked to justify the move announced last week by police chiefs to allow drivers to break speed limits.

New guidelines from the Association of Chief Police Officers say drivers will not be booked unless travelling at more than 35mph in a 30mph zone. This contradicts the government's advertising campaigns warning that driving at 35 mph doubles the risk of killing a child in any collision.

The road safety debate will be broadcast tonight on Newsnight on BBC2 at 10.30pm.

fields.headline: Smoking is an illness, say doctors
fields.standfirst:
College calls for controls on nicotine as addictive drug
Smoking: special report
Royal College of Physicians tobacco advisory group report
fields.trailText: Smoking is not just an anti-social habit but a dangerous disease which needs medical treatment, leading physicians said yesterday at the launch of a hard-hitting report calling for a new approach to tobacco addiction.
fields.body:
Smoking is not just an anti-social habit but a dangerous disease which needs medical treatment, leading physicians said yesterday at the launch of a hard-hitting report calling for a new approach to tobacco addiction.

Doctors and nurses should consider nicotine addiction a medical priority, they said. About 120,000 deaths every year - one in five of Britain's total number of deaths - are caused by cigarettes. All GPs should ask patients about smoking and tackle it as seriously as alcoholism and addiction to heroin or cocaine, says the report from the Royal College of Physicians.

All smokers should be given nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), as patches, gum, or in other forms, on the NHS, the report recommends. At the moment, the department of health permits free NRT only for those on income support living in deprived areas designated as healthy action zones. Clinics to help people ditch the habit should be available to all.

The focus of the report is the addictiveness of nicotine, a drug similar to heroin and cocaine in its capacity to create dependence and difficulty in abandoning it. Cigarettes must be regarded as nicotine delivery systems and should be subject to stringent controls administered by a new regulatory body, the doctors advise.

At the moment cigarettes are not policed by the drug regulatory body, the medicines control agency, nor do they fall under food regulations.

"Why do we allow this major cause of death to continue unregulated and uncontrolled?" asked John Britton, chair of the tobacco advisory group within the Royal College of Physicians.

A regulatory body could test cigarette emissions in the same way that car exhausts are monitored, and force the industry to cut out some of the dangerous chemicals contained in cigarettes.

Martin Jarvis, of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, said a fundamental change in people's perceptions of cigarette addiction was needed. A typical smoker would readily concur with the idea they were "hooked", but compare the addiction to internet browsing or shopping. It is a false comparison, he says. "There is a mountain of evidence that shows nicotine is a powerful drug of addiction."

Like heroin and cocaine, nicotine elicits the release of dopamines in the brain, which leads to a sense of well-being. Over a third of smokers light up within 15 minutes of waking in the morning, and 72% say it would be difficult to go without a cigarette for a day. Only between 1% and 3% succeed in quitting without help.

"Overall, nicotine stands out as a form of drug addiction that is second to none, and it is probably harder to give up smoking than to give up other drugs of abuse," said Mr Jarvis.

The report delivers what Clive Bates of ASH (action on smoking and health) describes as "the death knell for low-tar cigarettes and the comforting but wrong idea that these are somehow less dangerous". The report says that smokers, not the cigarettes, determine how much nicotine, and therefore how much tar, is taken into the body - the impact of low-tar cigarettes, for instance, would be increased by longer, harder puffing.

Mr Bates said the report was of huge importance. "The Royal College of Physicians is saying that society should wake up and recognise that it has a deadly and pervasive addictive drug syndrome covering a quarter of the adult population and that we should stop pretending that cigarettes are just some innocuous or quirky lifestyle habit."

fields.headline: Deadly habit refuses to die
fields.standfirst:
Young smokers are replacing those killed by disease - but help is at hand in giving up
Smoking: special report
Royal College of Physicians tobacco advisory group report
fields.trailText: In 1948 about 65% of men and 40% of women were regular cigarette smokers. Many have since been casualties of the epidemic of smoking-related disease and death in the wake of a once universally popular social habit.
fields.body:
In 1948 about 65% of men and 40% of women were regular cigarette smokers. Many have since been casualties of the epidemic of smoking-related disease and death in the wake of a once universally popular social habit.

There was a steady decline in the numbers of smokers until 1994, when 28% of men and 26% of women had a regular habit. Since then, statistics suggest there has not been much movement. Those with enough motivation and willpower to quit have done so, and there is a hardcore among those left who find it particularly hard to give up.

But for the figures to have stabilised at one in four adults, there must be new smokers to replace those who die of lung and other diseases. These are young people, especially girls. The proportion of 15-year-old girls who smoke at least one cigarette a week rose from a quarter in 1982 to a third in 1996. The rate among boys of the same age is also going up, although 287% of 15-year-old boys smoke against 33% of girls.

"The rate at which new smokers are joining the prevalent smoking population has therefore been increasing for some years, making it likely that unless cessation rates also begin to increase, the overall prevalence of smoking in Great Britain will soon again begin to rise," says the report published yesterday by the Royal College of Physicians.

Smoking is the biggest cause of lung cancer - causing about 80% of more than 30,000 deaths from the disease in 1997 in England and Wales. The younger a person is when they start to smoke, the greater their risk of death.

Smoking is also a risk factor for cancers associated with the larynx, oral cavity and oesophagus. Out of 120,000 smoking-related deaths each year, around one fifth are from chronic obstructive lung disease, including bronchitis and emphysema. There are also 30,000 smoking-related deaths from heart disease in the UK each year.

Those most likely to smoke, to find it hardest to stop and to die a smoking-related death are the poorest, and the children of the poorest who watch their parents smoking. Those who live in council or rented accommodation, in overcrowded conditions, who did not do well at school, who are unemployed, divorced, separated or single mothers, are all more likely to smoke.

The department of health has recognised that smoking is an issue of health inequality, and provides clinics to help people give up and free nicotine replacement therapy to those on income support in deprived areas classified as health action zones (HAZ).

Nicotine is addictive, but is thought to be relatively harmless compared with the cocktail of chemicals and tobacco smoke that are inhaled. Of the 4,000 chemicals in tobacco smoke, at least 40 are believed to be cancer-causing.

Doctors now recognise that unadulterated nicotine in fairly low doses helps fight withdrawal symptoms.

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) comes in various forms but not on prescription except for those attending smoking cessation clinics in a HAZ. There are three brands of nicotine chewing gum in 2mg and 4mg doses - studies have shown that more heavily dependent smokers do better with the higher dose.

There are four brands of patches on the market. These deliver up to 1mg an hour through the skin into the bloodstream. Nicotine nasal sprays give as quick a hit as cigarettes - about 10 minutes - but they are unpleasant at first to use. One spray delivers 0.5mg and can be used 16 times a day. Then there are inhalators - a plastic holder which resembles a cigarette.

Studies have not shown that any of these NRT are better than others, but they work, especially in conjunction with counselling and support. On the horizon now are drugs that may also help to get people over the withdrawal symptoms.
