webTitle: Road chaos fear after legal ruling

fields.headline: Road chaos fear after legal ruling
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: The government yesterday began fighting a legal ruling which renders roadside speed cameras useless and curtails the police's ability to investigate drink-driving offences.
fields.body:
The government yesterday began fighting a legal ruling which renders roadside speed cameras useless and curtails the police's ability to investigate drink-driving offences.

Lawyers took the first steps to appeal against the ruling at Edinburgh high court which allows car owners to refuse to tell police who was behind the wheel at the time of any driving offence.

The ruling means motorists can refuse to say who was driving a car caught speeding by roadside cameras and threatens to throw the whole system of traffic policing into disarray.

Last week, Scotland's top judge, Lord Rodger, ruled that compelling motorists to disclose the information on threat of prosecution was in breach of their human rights.

The ruling is based on the European convention on human rights, which was adopted into Scottish law last May.

The appeal judges agreed that section 172 of the road traffic act, which makes it an offence for motorists not to tell police who was driving their vehicle at the time of an alleged offence, contravenes the right to silence and the right against self-incrimination.

The section is crucial to sustaining convictions from roadside cameras and is used in some hit-and-run and drink-driving prosecutions.

For the moment the ruling concerns only Scottish motorists but, if the government is unsuccessful in its appeal, its effects will also be felt in the rest of the UK when the convention is adopted in October.

The original appeal was brought by a woman stopped in a supermarket car park in Dunfermline, Fife, last year.

Police noticed that Margaret Brown, from Dunfermline, smelled of alcohol and, when they asked her how she got to the shop, she told them she had travelled by car.

Ms Brown pointed her car out to officers, and she was asked formally - under the road traffic act - to say who was driving the car. Ms Brown admitted that she was at the wheel and she was charged with two offences, including driving while under the influence of excessive alcohol.

Her lawyers argued that making Ms Brown disclose who was driving her car infringed her right to a fair trial.

Last week Lord Rodger ruled Ms Brown was subjected to compulsion to incriminate herself under threat of being found guilty of an offence. He acknowledged this would have a "momentous effect on the use of roadside cameras".

A spokesman for the department of transport said: "We are studying the judgment and deciding what measures we need to take to conform to the convention on human rights."

fields.headline: Nowt so queer as lords
fields.trailText: Regardless of our opinion on the repeal of section 28, its repeal or non-repeal should not be tied up with a bill regarding the election of mayors. These two subjects are unrelated, so why on earth are they to be shoved through on the same bill?
fields.body:
"Should that fail, section 28 is almost certain to be abandoned for this parliament, since ministers will not sacrifice a bill which also provides for creation of elected mayors" (Ministers suffer heavy defeat on section 28, February 8). Regardless of our opinion on the repeal of section 28, its repeal or non-repeal should not be tied up with a bill regarding the election of mayors. These two subjects are unrelated, so why on earth are they to be shoved through on the same bill? Section 28 went onto the statute book (as did the original law prohibiting homosexual acts) by tagging it on to the end of a bill.

It's high time that the bill process in Britain was updated so that important manifesto issues are given their own bills and that unelected, pompous fools are not allowed to block bills that the House of Commons (representative of the people) have passed.
Scott Morrison
Queens College, Cambridge
sfmm2@cam.ac.uk


I note with dismay that one of the rebel Labour peers who backed Lady Young's homophobic amendment was Lord Longford. Here is a man who has spent the last 30 years campaigning for the rights of the child murderer Myra Hindley. It seems that the rights of gay and bisexual children not to be taunted and bullied at school are rather less important to him than the rights of a convicted killer. Perhaps he sees Hindley and Brady's committed heterosexual relationship as a good role model?

This is proof yet again that something even more radical has to be done with the House of Lords. And why are representatives of the Church of England in there anyway? As if they represent anything but the smallest minority interest!
James Martin Charlton
London
jamesmartincharlton@ hotmail.com


Lady Young believes in marriage. People can marry when they're 16. Lady Young "personally" doesn't "believe anyone should have sex in their teens". Lady Young therefore believes marriages should be celibate for the first four years. Has she a point or is she unwell?
Michael Dunn
Shrewsbury
m.dunn@england.com


As a gay man, it was with incredulity and dismay that I read of the House of Lords debate. Lady Young and her allies are correct when they say children are vulnerable: vulnerable to the kind of bigotry the noble lady preaches.
Stephen Leyshon
London


Prohibiting the "promotion" of homosexuality suggests that what is banned is proselytising . The reality is that teachers feel unable to discuss an issue of crucial importance to many young people.
Dr Simon Roberts
Loughborough University
S.Roberts@lboro.ac.uk


If William Hague is so relieved, why isn't his party advocating that the "protection" of the section be extended to all schools, ie to private schools as well as local authority ones?

Does he think that the promotion of homosexuality in Eton or Harrow is acceptable? Or does he think that the moral fibre of upper class youth is simply stronger?
Paul Hardy
London


The dis-honourable lords and ladies who voted for bigotry and against tolerance prove that there's nowt so queer as folk.
Dr Brian Jones
University of Bradford
b.t.jones@bradford.ac.uk

webTitle: MPs chew on the big political issue of the day: gum

fields.headline: MPs chew on the big political issue of the day: gum
fields.trailText: The Commons discussed the problem of chewing gum yesterday. At first you think, well, this is silly. Surely they've got more important things to worry about. Then you realise that, no, they haven't.
fields.body:
The Commons discussed the problem of chewing gum yesterday. At first you think, well, this is silly. Surely they've got more important things to worry about. Then you realise that, no, they haven't.

There is not a lot they can do in Kosovo, and almost nothing in Northern Ireland. So why not get to grips with something they can really tackle, such as chewing gum?

They could have a select committee on confectionery nuisance, a minister for ungummed trousers, and an early pledge to reduce sticky soles by 30% before the next election. At least it would improve all our lives.

Before the pledge, of which more later, Archie Norman, William Hague's latest environment spokesman, made his first appearance in his new job.

He did not help himself by bottling out of a confrontation with John Prescott and spending most of the time sitting with a foolish grin on his face, like a schoolboy who has put chewing gum on the teacher's chair and can't wait for her to sit down.

Mr Norman has been much criticised for working for Railtrack, the greatest disaster for railways since 1830, when the former minister William Huskisson was killed by one of the first steam trains - surprisingly, not run by Virgin.

Mr Norman leapt up to respond to question one, having spotted that it was being answered not by Mr Prescott, but by his less truculent understrapper, Hilary Armstrong. If Mr Hague were a football manager, he would sign a new star forward for £6m, then play him against Hull City reserves.

"In the light of the last few days' revelations regarding my interests, I would like to make an apology," Mr Norman said.

When MPs offer an apology, it is usually in a spirit of heavy-footed irony, and so it proved on this occasion.

"I apologise for the fact that my 20 years' real world experience of planning, the environment and transport, means I have some practical grasp of the subject - not a problem that has afflicted the deputy prime minister."

(When MPs talk about their lives in "the real world" they mean "while stuffing my pocket with squillions". For some reason, their experience of the real world never includes teaching, nursing, or working 10 hours a day in a call centre.)

Mr Norman managed a mild dig at Peter Kilfoyle, the defence minister who left to spend more time with his principles. "Labour has abandoned the north and the cities, which is why ministers have abandoned this government."

Ms Armstrong sat down, Mr Prescott scowled at all of us, and Mr Norman resumed his foolish grin.

They solved their Prescott poser by having him say almost nothing. One of his answers consisted of the single word "yes", which even he could not mangle.

Soon afterwards Peter Pike asked Michael Meacher what he would do about "this discarded chewing gum problem we meet everywhere?"

Mr Meacher played for time. "I am certainly not 'stuck up' with this kind of problem!"

(Loud laughter. This is an example of parliamentary humour, and so impenetra ble to normal humans.) "But it is disgusting. I am in touch with the major manufacturers to ask if they can find a way of providing biodegradable chewing gum."

Later we moved on to the bill that dissolves the Northern Ireland assembly. Martin McGuinness, over in England on a charm offensive, like a rottweiler learning to curtsey, stared glumly down.

He was perfectly placed to drop a grenade on the Rev Ian Paisley, although of course he didn't: Mr Paisley's existence is far too valuable for the IRA.

After one attack on Sinn Fein, Mr McGuinness rose and stalked out, tugging a strand of non-degradable chewing gum with him. (Sadly, I made that bit up.)

fields.headline: More fuel for controversy
fields.trailText: In making the case for nuclear energy, Gerald Doucet (Analysis, February 7) compares land utilisation of 2 sq km for a 1,000 megawatt nuclear plant with the 30 sq km for the same output from solar cells. He fails to acknowledge that solar cells can be widely distributed, for example on the roofs and walls of buildings.
fields.body:
In making the case for nuclear energy, Gerald Doucet (Analysis, February 7) compares land utilisation of 2 sq km for a 1,000 megawatt nuclear plant with the 30 sq km for the same output from solar cells. He fails to acknowledge that solar cells can be widely distributed, for example on the roofs and walls of buildings.

Underlying the article is the assumption that the future lies with big generators, and in that scenario nuclear, despite its public image, is the only way forward if significant CO2 reductions are to be achieved. However, the alternative picture is that small-scale generation from a variety of renewable sources will make a national grid redundant, creating huge savings.
Prof Peter F Smith
Sustainable Futures Committee, RIBA
Gerald Doucet calls for more nuclear power to fill the "energy gap". Before considering new energy generation, much more effort is needed to improve energy efficiency.

The US and UK are among the most wasteful users of energy. In the UK over 50% of energy is wasted. Buildings are a major waster of energy. If all south facing house roofs in the UK were fitted with solar voltaic panels, it would provide for most UK electricity needs.

The newly industrialising countries should be given energy efficient technologies, and the western world convert to being less wasteful and therefore reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

webTitle: True cost of a call for help

fields.headline: True cost of a call for help
fields.trailText: When quoting the spokeswoman for BT Cellnet (Gripes soar on mobile phones, February 8), there was no mention of the fact that from next month the company intend to start charging for calls to their "big new" customer care centre - at 20p per minute; currently these calls are free from pre-pay mobiles.
fields.body:
When quoting the spokeswoman for BT Cellnet (Gripes soar on mobile phones, February 8), there was no mention of the fact that from next month the company intend to start charging for calls to their "big new" customer care centre - at 20p per minute; currently these calls are free from pre-pay mobiles.

I have called BT Cellnet's customer care centre several times in the four months that I have owned one of their pre-pay phones. On each occasion this was because of a fault at their end of the system. Each call took several minutes. I am concerned that customers will be paying to rectify problems of BT Cellnet's own making.
Mark Fairman
Matlock Bath, Derbyshire
mark@spookyhouse.freeserve.co.uk


Has any calculation been made of how many man-and woman-hours are wasted by consumers waiting on telephone queues and help-lines? My particular bugbear is Orange, who have the cheek to take my money, as Mattthew Engel rightly points out (Hanging on the telephone, February 8), and then tell me that all the lines are busy due to high demand (why not employ more operators at peak times?) but that my call is important to them, yet they are not going to answer it anyway.

We have suffered in silence (Vivaldi apart) for too long. Automated "help-lines" are one of the scourges of our age and it is high time the worst offenders were named and shamed.
Nigel Pickard
Hull Business School
npickard@humber.ac.uk

webTitle: The jury is not out - yet

fields.headline: The jury is not out - yet
fields.trailText: Ludovic Kennedy quotes the common fiction that an accused is deemed innocent until the jury returns its verdict (Comment, February 7). But of the two sides in a case - the prosecution and the defence - only the defence takes this position.
fields.body:
Ludovic Kennedy quotes the common fiction that an accused is deemed innocent until the jury returns its verdict (Comment, February 7). But of the two sides in a case - the prosecution and the defence - only the defence takes this position. From the outset the prosecution deems the accused to be guilty. The best that can be said, overall, is that the case is effectively "not proven" from the start, which may survive to the verdict in Scotland.

The adoption of an inquisitorial system will do nothing to reduce the one-sidedness inherent in the present adversarial procedures. In the German system, advocated by Mr Kennedy, there is no jury, the courts are authoritarian in nature, and a witness may appear on behalf of a defendant only with the express permission of the court. Under such circumstances there is an even greater possibility that prejudiced witnesses will go unchallenged; and if a miscarriage of justice occurs the chance that it will ever be detected is minimal. Particularly in view of the widespread concern over the proposed restrictions on the right to trial before a jury, it is remarkable that a non-jury system should be seen as a remedy to the present situation.
John Lloyd
Oldbury, West Midlands

fields.headline: A sacrifice for peace
fields.trailText: Peace or decommissioning? Which would Ulster politicians choose if they cannot have both? Maintenance of peace does not necessarily require decommissioning of arms. In a world where guns are readily available, decommissioning is almost irrelevant, having only a symbolic meaning.
fields.body:
Peace or decommissioning? Which would Ulster politicians choose if they cannot have both? Maintenance of peace does not necessarily require decommissioning of arms. In a world where guns are readily available, decommissioning is almost irrelevant, having only a symbolic meaning. Are the Ulster politicians and the Irish and British governments about to sacrifice actual peace for a mere symbol?

Let's focus on the peace and goodwill that already exist. Remarkably, guns have been silent for some years now; what more do you want? The rest will follow in time, of its own accord.
Akemi Horie-Webber
St Genis-Pouilly, France
The IRA is not a threat to the peace process; a return to direct Westminster rule unquestionably is. The absence of an ongoing dynamic bringing about significant political change will present a similar peril. Demands for disarmament only succeed in diverting attention from the real issues. It is obvious the IRA are receptive to the current political climate. The duration and success of their comprehensive cease-fire bares testament.

The decommissioning issue is clearly not related to bringing about long term just peace. It is a last ditch attempt to retain David Trimble's participation in the power sharing executive.
Paul O'Brien
Newcastle Upon Tyne

fields.headline: Fair hearing
fields.trailText: Garrick Alder (Letters, February 7) complains that the Guardian's coverage of the Irving libel case may prevent a fair trial. This begs the question as to how the antedeluvian English libel laws could ever result in a "fair trial".
fields.body:
Garrick Alder (Letters, February 7) complains that the Guardian's coverage of the Irving libel case may prevent a fair trial. This begs the question as to how the antedeluvian English libel laws could ever result in a "fair trial".

Would Aitken or Hamilton have dared try their luck if the libel laws did not place the burden of proof on the defendant? No sane plaintiff should consider being placed in the company of Archer and Maxwell as a vindication of their reputation. What purpose can the libel laws then serve other than as an instrument of censorship or malice?
Phillip Hallam-Baker
Medford, Massachusetts
hallam@ai.mit.edu 52

fields.headline: Bigotry wins the day
fields.standfirst:
But there is room for a deal on section 28
More about section 28
fields.trailText: It was an easy mistake to make. With even the Daily Mail forced by its own polls to recognise "the tolerance, generous, live-and-let live instincts of the British people", ministers believed there would be little difficulty in repealing section 28 of the local government act, which bans the promotion of homosexuality by schools or local councils.
fields.body:
It was an easy mistake to make. With even the Daily Mail forced by its own polls to recognise "the tolerance, generous, live-and-let live instincts of the British people", ministers believed there would be little difficulty in repealing section 28 of the local government act, which bans the promotion of homosexuality by schools or local councils. The Mail poll found 68% of the British public saw nothing wrong in teaching children that a gay lifestyle should be tolerated. What ministers failed to take into account was the fervour of evangelical groups, the intolerance of many religious leaders, the homophobia of rightwing newspapers, and the implacable nature of Baroness Young, the former Tory minister, who has led the opposition to the government's moves in the Lords.

At the beginning of Monday's debate on the local government bill, the Bishop of Blackburn introduced an amendment which answered all the fears raised by the opponents of the repeal. The bishop's amendment would have got rid of the section and and introduced a substitute clause. It would have declared that marriage should be the fundamental building block of the family, but that pupils' sexual orientation should be allowed to develop without being subjected to any physical or verbal abuse or to any encouragement of sexual activity. This was not just in line with ministerial thinking, but brought together both sides: the Church of England, the Catholic Education Society and the leading Catholic weekly, the Tablet, on one side, and Stonewall, the gay pressure group which was set up in 1989 to fight section 28, on the other. A former Conservative colleague of Lady Young's, Lord St John of Fawsley, urged her to withdraw her amendment, but she remained intransigent. So much for tolerance.

Monday's debate did not reach the depths to which Cardinal Winning descended - defining gay love as "perverted" - but there was a succession of nasty homophobic contributions. What should happen now? Lady Young's coalition, which roped in both a band of cross-benchers and 15 Labour peers, is not going to retreat. But the bishop of Blackburn, who withdrew his amendment once the government signalled its support and readiness to talk, has indicated the way in which the government could put things right. His amendment should be refettled and brought back to the house at report stage.

Ministers need to do more to get across the damage which section 28 has done in schools. The case for repeal is not just about preventing gay pupils from being verbally or physically bullied; it also recognises the degree to which teachers have been prevented from providing help, understanding and counselling to gay students. Anyone who feels this is being exaggerated by gay organisations should read yesterday's Guardian Education. A host of schools declined to let our feature writer sit in on sex education classes, but heroic Hodge Hill in Birmingham did consent and demonstrated just how important such classes are.

Ministers have already wobbled once on this reform - attempting to appease their rightwingers by allowing a free vote - but they had their backbone stiffened by a meeting of the parliamentary Labour party, which rightly insisted that eliminating discriminatory legislation should not be a matter for private conscience. Of course the right will resist, as it resisted opening the armed services to gay personnel and will later this week oppose lowering the age of consent for gays to 16. Labour promised progressive policies and ideas. It must deliver.

fields.headline: I'm aghast
fields.trailText: The BBC is proud to have made Gormenghast. It is a project of ambition which has created much debate. It is exactly what the BBC is here to do. Why, then, has Sarah Hall decided that the "BBC made a crisis out of drama" (February 5) and what does that mean?
fields.body:
The BBC is proud to have made Gormenghast. It is a project of ambition which has created much debate. It is exactly what the BBC is here to do. Why, then, has Sarah Hall decided that the "BBC made a crisis out of drama" (February 5) and what does that mean? It is a view not shared by many commentators nor by viewers - nearly 4m of them.

Part of the BBC's job is to create drama which becomes a talking point - whether it is EastEnders, Warriors, or Gormenghast. The important point is that the BBC unflinchingly offers viewers projects on the scale of Gormenghast in order to generate the range of opinions which are now being shared in lively and engaged ways across the country.

To suggest that a BBC drama should be measured by audience figures is to denigrate the award-winning success of such programmes as Our Mutual Friend, Great Expectations, Shooting The Past and Holding On - alongside which Gormenghast compares favourably. Is Sarah Hall suggesting that we should not have attempted them?
Alan Yentob
Director of Television, BBC

fields.headline: Ban the cash registers
fields.standfirst: Museum charges ought to be scrapped
fields.trailText: Admission to Tate Modern (the definite article is passé when you are hanging Dali) will be free. Chris Smith pledged yesterday that his department of culture, media and sport will, straightforwardly, increase the Tate Gallery's grant-in-aid.
fields.body:
Admission to Tate Modern (the definite article is passé when you are hanging Dali) will be free. Chris Smith pledged yesterday that his department of culture, media and sport will, straightforwardly, increase the Tate Gallery's grant-in-aid. Fine, but why should this qualify as news? The Tate on Millbank opens its doors to the public gratis every day; to do anything else would insult the memory of a great artist (JMW Turner) and a less great but mightily generous sugar refiner. It would have been inconceivable to discriminate against the modern by charging on Bankside, especially since the public has paid through its lottery tickets for outfitting the power station which the gallery now so magnificently inhabits.

Not charging is news only because a pall of ambiguity hangs over the government's intentions towards the slice of national patrimony curated in the great collections. Officially, grants are being revised in order to permit Science, the V&A and the other museums that have been charging the public to offer free admission to children, then pensioners. Free admission for all is "up to the trustees". Some of these appear to have got Thatcherite religion and believe you appreciate only what you pay for. Others - sensibly - do not want to upset their balance sheets until Whitehall guarantees the money and resolves ticklish questions about eligibility for VAT.

In the middle sits Mr Smith. A single inference can be made from his compelling personal rhetoric about access to art and culture: the national collections should once again be gloriously open to all. Manacled by the treasury, he seemingly cannot draw it. He is a mild man, perhaps too mild. A fighter would not just demand from the comprehensive spending review enough to satisfy the charging museums' genuine claim for compensation. He would publicly threaten to replace each and every trustee who dared to veto open doors.

fields.headline: All losers in Lebanon
fields.standfirst:
Is Syria serious about peace with Israel?
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: It was a vile piece of work, even by the standards of Syria's lackey press. The Holocaust was a myth got up by Israel to deflect criticism of its Nazi-like crimes against the Arabs, the Tishreen newspaper in Damascus declared last week. The recent Holocaust conference in Stockholm was part of a Zionist scheme to silence "credible voices" like British historian David Irving and block opposition to Israel's "expansionist policies".
fields.body:
It was a vile piece of work, even by the standards of Syria's lackey press. The Holocaust was a myth got up by Israel to deflect criticism of its Nazi-like crimes against the Arabs, the Tishreen newspaper in Damascus declared last week. The recent Holocaust conference in Stockholm was part of a Zionist scheme to silence "credible voices" like British historian David Irving and block opposition to Israel's "expansionist policies".

From a regime openly at war with Israel, such bilious polemics might have been explicable, although not forgivable. But coming from a country which only two months ago began supposedly historic peace talks with its old foe, the Tishreen editorial and many other recent Syrian actions raise significant doubts about whether President Hafez Assad is serious about peace. The boorish behaviour of Syria's chief delegate before the Shepherdstown talks, the absence of any discernible flexibility in Syria's negotiating position on the Golan Heights and other issues, and its current refusal to re-engage in the stalled process all point in the same direction.

On the ground, meanwhile, Syria's reactivation of Hizbullah militants in south Lebanon, after a lull following Ehud Barak's election as Israeli prime minister, has led to the deaths of six Israeli soldiers, the assassination of the second-in-command of the Israeli-backed South Lebanese Army, and now to escalatory Israeli reprisals deep inside Lebanon. Civilian casualties add to the pressure on Mr Barak who, unlike Mr Assad, is a democrat, and so at a disadvantage. Tempers within his coalition fray. The relatively unshackled Israeli press questions his strategy. The clashes threaten to derail what frantic US mediators call the "Syrian track". But Mr Assad, who directs Hizbullah in concert with Iran, who calls the shots in Lebanon with the aid of 35,000 Syrian troops, and who is chief architect of this renewed mayhem, sits pat as his "fellow peacemakers" writhe.

Perhaps he calculates, since Mr Barak has pledged a Lebanon withdrawal this July, that he can fight on and then proclaim a victory. Perhaps he feels by turning aggressive he can wring more concessions from Jerusalem or bring Mr Barak low, dividing and weakening Israel. Perhaps the old man in Damascus does not really want any deal at all. It is an icy thought that after so many years of hating, like Tishreen's editorialist, hatred may be all Mr Assad has to offer.

webTitle: EU steps up efforts to cramp Milosevic cronies

fields.headline: EU steps up efforts to cramp Milosevic cronies
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: EU sanctions against Serbia are to be tightened to hit the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic's ruling elite harder, while a ban on flights will be lifted in an attempt to boost opposition activity.
fields.body:
EU sanctions against Serbia are to be tightened to hit the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic's ruling elite harder, while a ban on flights will be lifted in an attempt to boost opposition activity.

Diplomats in Brussels said last night that EU foreign ministers are expected to agree next Monday to add some 300 new names to an existing 600 strong blacklist.

Members of the Yugoslav judiciary as well as key industrialists and business leaders are likely to be banned from travel in Europe.

The aim is to hit the outer circle of power in Belgrade as well as big companies which earn badly-needed hard currency for the regime by freezing their funds in and transactions with EU member states.

At the same time, the lifting of the flight ban is designed to encourage the opposition by signalling that ordinary Serbs are not being held responsible for their leadership - a lesson learned the hard way from years of punitive UN sanctions against Iraq.

Last month Britain and the Netherlands were isolated in their defence of the EU's flight ban as France and Italy led calls for ending it.

EU member states have been divided over what to do about sanctions as long as President Milosevic remains in power, even though his domestic opponents favour lifting both the flight ban and an oil embargo.

The US is strongly against lifting the oil embargo, even though it is widely breached.

Since the end of the Kosovo war last summer, the EU has been involved in sending heating oil to two opposition-held towns in Serbia, Nis and Pirot, under its energy for democracy programme.

webTitle: Kosovo killings force UN to act

fields.headline: Kosovo killings force UN to act
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Troops from the international peacekeeping force stepped up controls on Kosovo's border with Serbia yesterday to stop special police and paramilitaries in civilian clothes infiltrating Mitrovice.
fields.body:
Troops from the international peacekeeping force stepped up controls on Kosovo's border with Serbia yesterday to stop special police and paramilitaries in civilian clothes infiltrating Mitrovice.

The increased border security, along with extra foot patrols in the northern part of the Kosovan town, followed the worst attack on Albanian civilians by Serbs since K-For troops arrived last June.

At least five people died and up to 30 were injured on Thursday night after French troops failed to stop gangs firing bullets and throwing grenades into Albanian flats. They also burned vehicles belonging to the United Nations police and aid agencies.

The ostensible trigger for the assault was a grenade attack on a bus last Wednesday which killed two Serbs.

Crowds of Albanians have turned out daily to jeer at the French soldiers who are in charge of security and who have continually blocked free access across Mitrovice's three bridges. The northern part of the town is largely populated by Serbs and the south by Albanians.

The protesters' claims that the French have allowed Mitrovice to slide into partition are receiving an increasingly sympathetic hearing from members of the international police deployed in the town.

An American officer with the UN police said his Albanian interpreter saw Serbs hand out grenades on Saturday. "He rang a colleague at police headquarters on the southern side who alerted me. I asked K-For to do something, but the French told me they didn't want to inflame the Serbs.

"The rules of engagement are screwed up," he said. "When it's an issue of weapons, the police cannot go in unless we're accompanied by K-For. They refused to do that."

The American said that, as the Serb gangs marauded on Thursday, another policeman watched from his balcony as Serbs beat a woman to death. "French K-For troops were nearby but they just stood and watched," the American said.

Lying in hospital with a wounded leg, Emina Gjaka, 12, recalled her terror at the attacks. "It was the noise, the pain, and the shouts of the Serbs that they would kill us all." Grenades were flung into the flat where she was sheltering, killing a 13-year-old boy. Her mother died a day later.

After the killings the French ferried around 100 people to safety in southern Mitrovice. Another hundred left separately, leaving around 3,000 Albanians in the north.

"The Serb action was deliberately timed when the French were rotating their troops with a new general and new men coming to the city on February 1," said Nexhmedin Spahiu, the editorial controller of Radio Mitrovice, an independent broadcasting station.

He also speculated that the attack was meant to raise tensions as the UN administrator, Bernard Kouchner, tried to persuade moderate Kosovo Serb leaders to join a new interim governing council for the territory.

Mr Kouchner appeared to agree when he said: "It was the first day for the French general and his troops, and it was not easy to move in an unknown town in the dark. Politically, we were on the verge of moving forward. I have a letter from Bishop Artemije [the leader of Kosovo's Orthodox Serbs] saying he was coming to the meeting of the new administrative council. That was the reason for the attacks."

Lieutenant Commander Philip Anido, the K-For spokesman, confirmed yesterday that German and Italian troops had been deployed in northern Mitrovice to strengthen the French-led team.

webTitle: Who killed Bulatovic? Serbs grieve for assassinated minister and lawless state

fields.headline: Who killed Bulatovic? Serbs grieve for assassinated minister and lawless state
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The assassination of the Yugoslav defence minister, Pavle Bulatovic, has raised the spectre of civil unrest in the small republic of Montenegro as rival clans start settling scores.
fields.body:
The assassination of the Yugoslav defence minister, Pavle Bulatovic, has raised the spectre of civil unrest in the small republic of Montenegro as rival clans start settling scores.

Analysts in Belgrade are linking Monday night's killing to the feud between Montenegro's government - which wants to extricate itself from the Yugoslav federation, where its state is Serbia's sole partner - and the northern Montenegrin clans.

These clans include the Bulatovic family, who are loyal to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

The minister, 51, was killed by automatic gunfire on Monday night in what the Yugoslav authorities described as "a classic terrorist act". The killer opened fire through the window of a restaurant in the Banjica suburb of Belgrade as the minister was sitting at his favourite table. Two other people were wounded, including the former general and bank director, Vuk Obradovic. The killing of Pavle Bulatovic has caused shock and confusion in Belgrade and in his native Montenegro. Unlike others in the political elite in Yugoslavia, he was considered a modest man untainted by corruption or black market activities. Neither was he among Serb leaders charged by the UN tribunal in The Hague with war crimes in Kosovo war last year, nor linked in press reports to the past decade of political and underworld killings in Serbia.

The Serb paramilitary leader Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, assassinated in a Belgrade hotel last month, had been the most recent of these.

However at the time of Arkan's killing the Yugoslav information minister, Goran Matic, blamed the Montenegrin mafia - remarks he later denied making.

Bulatovic was a staunch supporter of President Milosevic and one of the fiercest critics of the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, who has made a series of moves to break up what is left of Yugoslavia.

The minister was active in organising clan meetings in northern Montenegro to rally support for continued federal rule from Belgrade.

There is a danger that Bulatovic's family and political followers will accuse the Montenegrin authorities of the murder and that pro-Belgrade clans may start fomenting plans to avenge the killing. This could further destabilise Montenegro where tensions are already high as a result of President Djukanovic's defiance of Belgrade and courtship of the west.

Inevitably there are those in Serbia who have blamed the west - the all-purpose bogeyman - for the Bulatovic murder. The Serb ultra-nationalist leader, Vojislav Seselj, whose own bodyguard was shot dead last month, accused the British, French and American intelligence services of carrying out the assassination.

"Their goal is to bring to power in Yugoslavia incompetent opposition leaders who are toadies to the west," said Mr Seselj's Serbian Radical party.

The Belgrade authorities have responded to the killing by announcing a "strong battle against the biggest evil of mankind at the end of the 20th century: terrorism". The announcement was made at a special joint session of the Yugoslav and Serbian governments, presided over by Mr Milosevic. The authorities are under pressure to show that they are still in control of a society that is increasingly violent and lawless.

But officials have yet to give any concrete details of their proposed fight against terrorism. Opposition leaders have expressed the fear that the assassination could be used as the pretext for a general crackdown against President Milosevic's opponents.

Yesterday at a memorial service in Belgrade, colleagues paid tribute to Bulatovic.

"The Yugoslav army and the defence ministry have lost a leading man in its organisation, an army minister who was first in the line of the defence of the fatherland," said the army chief, General Dragoljub Ojdanic.

Memorial services were also held in regional army headquarters throughout Serbia.

webTitle: Jacobs sets trend with sixties look

fields.headline: Jacobs sets trend with sixties look
fields.trailText: Who was responsible for the rash of outsize stripy scarves in the shops this winter? Marc Jacobs - who shot to fame in 1992 by pioneering the grunge look. This trend-setter is an important one to watch. And in New York this year he has gone back to the 1960s.
fields.body:
Who was responsible for the rash of outsize stripy scarves in the shops this winter? Marc Jacobs - who shot to fame in 1992 by pioneering the grunge look. This trend-setter is an important one to watch. And in New York this year he has gone back to the 1960s.

The designer, more recently credited with turning round the Louis Vuitton label since his appointment as creative director in 1997, sent out an assured collection for autumn/winter 2000 that dripped affluence and shouted "carefree".

For women, herringbone trapeze-shaped pinafore dresses, their hems and armholes trimmed with leather, were worn over skinny cashmere polo necks and teamed with dainty court shoes.

For men, there were cropped boxy jackets in corduroy, chunky thick-ribbed polos and tapered denim trousers.

Heavy fabrics such as camel, tweed, moleskin and canvas were rendered light and airy by being cut to skim the body. Oversized fasten ings - zippers, eyelets and scout locks - added humour to a restrained colour palette of beige, brown and duck-egg blue.

The only element missing from this hyper-coordinated design equation was the handbag - but that is because Jacobs was saving it for a special launch on Friday.

So far, the lucrative handbag market has been dominated by Europeans: not even a bag by Ralph Lauren or Calvin Klein has half the cachet of a Fendi, Gucci, Hermes or Dior. Jacobs's first signature handbag line will hope to change that.

The wide range of leatherwear will include tiny "car clutch" bags worn over the wrist and boxier "wonderbread" bags tucked under the arm - the latter presumably Jacobs's answer to the Fendi baguette and the Gucci croissant.

Whether Jacobs will challenge the European behemoths remains to be seen, but with Vuitton's top-quality production capabilities added to his own soaring reputation, his victory could soon be in the bag.

fields.headline: Bush tries a relaunch
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: After a ruthless rethink with his advisers at the weekend, George W Bush is attempting to repackage himself as "a reformer with results" to his credit, as he fights back against John McCain in the race for the Republican party's presidential nomination.
fields.body:
After a ruthless rethink with his advisers at the weekend, George W Bush is attempting to repackage himself as "a reformer with results" to his credit, as he fights back against John McCain in the race for the Republican party's presidential nomination.

Mr Bush has thrown out the programmed events and repetitive speeches criticised by many as making his campaign seem remote and complacent.

Instead, he now aims to meet the voters more often, giving much more time to question-and-answer sessions. He hopes to give his bid the grit and spontaneity which have been such assets to Mr McCain, who won a stunning 19-point victory in the New Hampshire primary poll last week.

But Mr Bush has decided to go on using his father, the former president, George Bush, and his mother, Barbara, on the campaign trail, despite widespread criticism of their appearances on his behalf in New Hampshire.

With the future of the Republican contest now riding on next week's South Carolina primary, both candidates have abandoned much of their high-mindedness and started attacking one another much more forcefully, conduct that is certain to intensify as the February 19 primary draws nearer.

The Bush relaunch follows an emergency campaign meeting at the weekend in Austin, Texas, seeking to reverse the situation where Mr McCain has had a free run as the candidate of change.

"I stand before you as a governor who led my state to managed health care reform," Mr Bush said yesterday. "Some people in Washington say we can't get anything done because of all the lobbyists and special interests. That's somebody who doesn't understand how to lead."

Mr Bush campaigned yesterday in Delaware, where voters went to the polls in a Republican primary that has been ignored by Mr McCain. A widely forecast solid win for Mr Bush in Delaware would help to steady nerves in the Texas governor's camp.

Concentrating his campaign in South Carolina, Mr McCain said: "We're going to respond harder than we're hit, and that's an old tactic in warfare."

As evidence of that approach, the McCain campaign hit back at a hostile Bush television ad in South Carolina with one of its own, which ended: "Do we really want another politician in the White House America can't trust?"

But Mr Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleisher, said: "Suggesting Governor Bush is as dishonest as Bill Clinton is a disservice to our party and our principles. Our nation has been through enough, and John McCain's ad has gone too far."

The urgency of the task facing Mr Bush was underlined by a Washington Post poll in South Carolina showing Mr McCain trailing by only five points among likely Republican voters.

Further confirmation of the change in the Bush fortunes in recent weeks came in poll results in New York state, whose primary is on March 7. It showed that Mr Bush's lead over Mr McCain has been reduced from 44 points to nine.

fields.headline: Anger at Lebanon attacks
fields.standfirst:
Soldier killed in Hizbullah counter-attack as Israel's prime minister defends the air assaults which knocked out power stations

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Lebanon yesterday reacted with verbal defiance - and Hizbullah guerrillas with counter attacks - to Israeli air raids which destroyed electricity power plants across the country for the second time in seven months.
fields.body:
Lebanon yesterday reacted with verbal defiance - and Hizbullah guerrillas with counter attacks - to Israeli air raids which destroyed electricity power plants across the country for the second time in seven months.

Although the damage was described by the Lebanese government as more extensive than in last June, when the capital was reduced to severe electricity rationing for several months, the toll of civilian casualties - 18 wounded, one gravely - was smaller.

The midnight-to-dawn blitz targeted the outskirts of Beirut, the ancient city of Baalbek, the outskirts of the northern town of Tripoli, and the mountain town of Zgharta - all sites of power stations.

The F-16 bombers struck in waves at the Jamhour plant outside Beirut. Firefighters battled all night to put out the blaze. The plant has been hit twice before: in Israel's "Grapes of Wrath" air and artillery onslaught in April 1996, and in last June's raids on the country's infrastructure.

In the latest attacks, said the industry minister, Suleiman Trabulsi, the Jamhour and Baalbek stations were "totally obliterated".

The director of the state electricity company estimated the total cost of repair for all three plants as between £22m and £25m. The government, which is heavily in debt, faces the same difficult choice that it did last time: between repairing obsolescent equipment, if spare parts are available; and rebuilding from scratch.

Hizbullah's retaliation was swift. At least one Israeli soldier was killed yesterday when guerrillas attacked his post in Dabshe, on the edge of Israel's south Lebanon occupation zone. The assault raised to six the number of Israeli soldiers killed in Lebanon in the past two weeks.

In an earlier statement, Hizbullah described the air raids as "blind aggression and a violation of the April accords" - a reference to the US-brokered agreement that brought Israel's Grapes of Wrath offensive to an end.

Under these "rules", neither side is permitted to hit civilian targets, but Hizbullah is free to attack military ones inside Israel's self-declared "security zone". The guerrillas' statement implied that in addition to keeping up their raids into the zone, they might resort to Katyusha rocket salvoes on northern Israel.

"We know that the inhabitants of settlements in the north are hiding in their shelters; but they [Israelis] must pay the price of their prime minister [Ehud Barak]'s criminal policies, of which they approve," the Hizbullah statement said.

The Lebanese prime minister, Salim al-Hoss, said that it was "Lebanon's destiny to suffer Israel's repeated aggressions, which aim at softening our resistance to its occupation of our land".

"If Israel believes it can coerce our people by hitting their infrastructure, it is dead wrong. They [the Lebanese] are unshakably determined to liberate their land, whatever levels of belligerence the enemy night reach."

The raid was denounced throughout the Arab world. Syrian radio said that Mr Barak wanted to "obliterate" all chances of peace in the Middle East.

In Cairo, the secretary general of the Arab League, Ismail Abdul Magid, said that "with this criminal act, which passes all limits, Israel is seeking to hide its failure in the face of the Lebanese resistance".

Mr Barak, visiting a crowded air raid shelter in northern Israel, defended his country's bombing of Lebanese civilian targets and said he would do "whatever it takes" to save Israeli lives.

Tens of thousands of Israelis prepared to spend a second night in shelters after Hizbullah guerrillas threatened to retaliate for the bombing blitz.

"I'm not a prophet," said Mr Barak. "I'm the prime minister of Israel and I'm determined to do whatever it takes to protect the citizens of Israel, its armed forces and the South Lebanon Army, which works with us."

A decade of raids - Major operations by Israel in Lebanon in the 1990s:

February 1992:
Assassination, by helicopter, of Hizbullah secretary general, Abbas Musawi

July 1993:
Operation Accountability. A 'seven-day war' directed mainly against Hizbullah, it leaves 132 Lebanese dead, mainly civilians

June 1994:
Israeli air raid on Hizbullah training camp kills 32

April 1996:
The 16-day Operation Grapes of Wrath, intended to 'break' Hizbullah's military capability, leaves 175 dead, mainly civilians

September 1997:
12 Israeli soldiers are killed in a commando raid

June 1999:
Air raids knock out two power stations and kill 10 civilians

The guerrillas' statement implied that in addition to keeping up their raids into the zone, they might resort to Katyusha rocket salvoes on northern Israel. "We know that the inhabitants of settlements in the north are hiding in their shelters; but they [Israelis] must pay the price of their prime minister [Ehud Barak]'s criminal policies, of which they approve," the Hizbullah statement said. The Lebanese prime minister, Salim al-Hoss, said that it was "Lebanon's destiny to suffer Israel's repeated aggressions, which aim at softening our resistance to its occupation of our land". "If Israel believes it can coerce our people by hitting their infrastructure, it is dead wrong. They [the Lebanese] are unshakably determined to liberate their land, whatever levels of belligerence the enemy night reach." The raid was denounced throughout the Arab world. Syrian radio said that Mr Barak wanted to "obliterate" all chances of peace in the Middle East. In Cairo, the secretary general of the Arab League, Ismail Abdul Magid, said that "with this criminal act, which passes all limits, Israel is seeking to hide its failure in the face of the Lebanese resistance". Mr Barak, visiting a crowded air raid shelter in northern Israel, defended his country's bombing of Lebanese civilian targets and said he would do "whatever it takes" to save Israeli lives. Tens of thousands of Israelis prepared to spend a second night in shelters after Hizbullah guerrillas threatened to retaliate for the bombing blitz. "I'm not a prophet," said Mr Barak. "I'm the prime minister of Israel and I'm determined to do whatever it takes to protect the citizens of Israel, its armed forces and the South Lebanon Army, which works with us." A 'seven-day war' directed mainly against Hizbullah, it leaves 132 Lebanese dead, mainly civilians June 1994: Israeli air raid on Hizbullah training camp kills 32 April 1996: The 16-day Operation Grapes of Wrath, intended to 'break' Hizbullah's military capability, leaves 175 dead, mainly civilians September 1997: 12 Israeli soldiers are killed in a commando raid June 1999: Air raids knock out two power stations and kill 10 civilians

webTitle: Behind the blitz Barak is desperate to find a way out

fields.headline: Behind the blitz Barak is desperate to find a way out
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: When peace negotiations resumed in December between Israel and Syria, it was widely recognised that the greatest hazard facing them was the war of attrition between Hizbullah guerrillas and the occupying Israeli army in south Lebanon. The US joined Israel in entreaties to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to restrain the "Islamic resistance" in Lebanon.
fields.body:
When peace negotiations resumed in December between Israel and Syria, it was widely recognised that the greatest hazard facing them was the war of attrition between Hizbullah guerrillas and the occupying Israeli army in south Lebanon. The US joined Israel in entreaties to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to restrain the "Islamic resistance" in Lebanon.

But he would have none of it, knowing all too well that the pain inflicted on Israel in its Lebanese hell-hole was a key reason why the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was signalling his readiness for a Syrian peace settlement in which Israel not only gets out of south Lebanon, but comes down too from the Golan heights it seized from Syria in the Six-Day War of 1967.

He wanted to retain the ability to go on inflicting the pain till he had cast-iron guarantees that these withdrawals would actually happen.

South Lebanon is a last, potent card in Mr Assad's otherwise historically weakening negotiating hand. But it is a double-sided one.

Given the overall imbalance of military power between the two adversaries, south Lebanon can at any time be turned into a far more potent card in Israel's hand. Its blitz on Lebanese power stations Monday night and early yesterday - the second in less than a year - was a dramatic illustration of that.

It was also through adroit use of the Lebanon card that Mr Barak persuaded Mr Assad to come back to the negotiating table in December. He pledged to pull his army out of south Lebanon by July this year. That, paradoxically, was more menacing to Mr Assad than the Israelis staying: if Israel were to get out of Lebanon - which it can do unilaterally without without Syria's say-so - it would have far less incentive to withdraw from the Golan too.

That was the Israeli government's stick. But more important, there was also the carrot. This was Mr Barak's assurance that he would honour the commitment, supposedly made by the late Yitzhak Rabin, that a full Golan withdrawal would mean pulling back to the June 4, 1967 ceasefire lines - "in other words, to the very shores of Lake Galilee" on which Mr Assad insists. Or that was how the Syrians chose to interpret as such an assurance.

When negotiations recommenced in the United States late last year, Mr Assad was quickly disabused. His negotiators at Shepherdstown, Virginia, apparently found that the Israelis still had not come clean on the withdrawal commitment, still insisted that discussion of other issues - security arrangements, "normalisation", water - take precedence over the primordial question of territory.

A leaked US document showed that while Syria had become much more conciliatory on most issues, the Israelis would not even use the word "withdraw", only "redeploy'. And this "redeployment" would exclude civilians - which appeared to mean that Israel's Golan settlements would remain.

It was clearly time, in Mr Assad's judgment, to apply pain in south Lebanon. The Hizbullah, traditionally backed by Iran but recently appearing to go into decline, obliged with a vengeance. In the space of a week, they managed, among other things, to kill five Israeli soldiers and assassinate the second-in-command of the South Lebanese Army, Israel's demoralised local ally.

And they achieved all this within the precise, American-brokered and UN-monitored "rules" of south Lebanese warfare, under which neither side is permitted to attack civilian targets, but the Hizbullah is free to attack military ones in the border zone.

Almost invariably it has been the Israelis who break these rules, in a big way, whenever the pain becomes too much. They did so Monday night, and yesterday an Israeli minister, Haim Ramon, publicly asserted that his country no longer deems itself bound by them.

This is an ominous threat in an increasingly ominous situation: for it is now obvious that the Israeli leader cannot withdraw either without walking open-eyed into potential disaster. Hizbullah has made it plain that it will seek to turn any pull-out into rout and humiliation of a kind Israel has never experienced before.

Furthermore, what guarantee could there be, in such circumstances, that Hizbullah would not simply move up to the international frontier to carry out raids into Israel proper? The whole purpose of the 25-year-old "security zone" was meant to prevent this. What guarantee could there be that Mr Assad, desperate for diplomatic leverage, would not support them?

If Hizbullah and Mr Assad do not back off, Israel will have only one means to create conditions for withdrawal, let alone for a wider peace, and that is to go for the jugular in Lebanon, using that military superiority to clobber Mr Assad into submission.

Caught in his risky gamble and whip-lashed by public opinion, Mr Barak is in danger of being forced down that path. An Israeli general said yesterday that, if necessary, Israel would now mount "other actions, bigger and stronger".

The Israeli paper Maariv summed things up last week: "The Syrians must be given a choice: continue to talk peace with Israel or fight with it in Lebanon."

fields.headline: Zoo's killer elephant 'pregnant'
fields.trailText: John Aspinall's zoo yesterday speculated that the elephant which killed a keeper on Monday might have been in a disturbed state because she was pregnant. However, they also revealed La Petite had previously charged - though not hurt - another keeper, in an Austrian zoo from where the elephant had been bought for breeding.
fields.body:
John Aspinall's zoo yesterday speculated that the elephant which killed a keeper on Monday might have been in a disturbed state because she was pregnant. However, they also revealed La Petite had previously charged - though not hurt - another keeper, in an Austrian zoo from where the elephant had been bought for breeding.

At a press conference near Hythe, Kent, the zoo defended its safety record following the death of Darren Cockrill, 27, from Canvey Island, Essex. But Mike Lockyer, a director of the Port Lympne zoo and another Aspinall zoo near Canterbury, admitted: "We don't know why it happened. She [La Petite] could be pregnant."

Since 1980 four keepers have been killed at the zoos. Port Lympne is inspected every five years by Shepway district council, and is due its next inspection this year. Monday's death will be investigated by the health and safety executive and the council. The zoo said it was confident it would be cleared of any wrongdoing.

The keeper had been feeding the elephants in a row of interconnecting stalls, the zoo said, and his prone body was found in La Petite's stall. Five other elephants, kept in a stall next door, were standing over the body in an attempt to protect it.

Mr Cockrill had been at Port Lympne eight years. "He was a good, sound keeper," said Mr Lockyer.

webTitle: Why aggressive Londoners make for a lonely city

fields.headline: Why aggressive Londoners make for a lonely city
fields.trailText: Most London guide books confine themselves to introducing visitors to principal hotels and extolling the virtues of St Paul's Cathedral. But tourists who pick up the Lonely Planet guide will be warned of the perils of "white van man" and directed to the Millennium Dome for architectural inspiration.
fields.body:
Most London guide books confine themselves to introducing visitors to principal hotels, recommending a few good restaurants and extolling the virtues of St Paul's Cathedral. But tourists who pick up the Lonely Planet guide will be educated in underground etiquette, warned of the perils of "white van man" and directed to the Millennium Dome for architectural inspiration.

In a controversial assessment of Londoners, they are described as victims of increased pollution and overcrowding, leading to an increasingly aggressive manner.

While the guide is quick to point out the drawbacks of what it describes as one of the planet's most crowded cities, it is also keen to stress the positive aspects of London which are rarely celebrated. The dome, for instance, replaces more traditional tourist attractions as a must-see.

Nevertheless, the negative spin is predictably challenged by those tasked with attracting visitors to Britain. The London tourist board insisted that far from being turned off by the capital's cheesed-off inhabitants, Londoners are viewed as almost universally friendly and helpful.

The guide, which is published today, warns visitors that Londoners are not the easiest breed with which to strike up companionships. "It's not especially easy to cause offence in London - unless you're trying to. Having said that, it's worth remembering that most Londoners would no more speak to a stranger in the street than fly to the moon."

Visitors are told of the capital's residents: "Don't try and be their friend: they're too absorbed in their own world of workmates, school friends and family." However, if their world is successfully breached, Londoners make the most loyal and trustworthy friends, it stresses - even if they are blighted by road rage. (Beware of white van man's propensity to "punch your lights out - ie do untold damage to you".)

The guide's authors - Steve Fallon from Boston, Massachusetts and Pat Yale, from Bristol - are particularly exercised by the ageing underground system ("slow, unreliable, and terribly expensive"). It does, however, have a "rigid etiquette" which visitors ignore at their peril. "Where there's an escalator you absolutely must stand on the right so that people in a hurry or keen to get in some exercise can rush up or down on the left. This is an extremely important rule - we kid you not - and should you break it you risk getting pushed aside or verbally abused."

Responding to the guide, Louise Wood, of the London tourist board, denied that the capital's citizens are difficult. "All our surveys indicate tourists think Londoners are very friendly. Four out of five visitors thought people here were quite friendly or very friendly. And even the underground equals or exceeds visitors' expectations," she said.

However, Jennifer Cox, of Lonely Planet, stood by the guide's strident assertions.

"I challenge anybody to say that they don't recognise the view of London in this book. The sheer volume of people and traffic is driving us to become very aggressive," she said.

fields.headline: Six-organ transplant man dies
fields.trailText: Stephen Hyett, the first person in Britain to have a six-organ transplant, has died suddenly aged 38, at Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridge where he had the operation.
fields.body:
Stephen Hyett, the first person in Britain to have a six-organ transplant, has died suddenly aged 38, at Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridge where he had the operation.

He will be cremated today.

Six years ago surgeons replaced his stomach, liver, kidney, pancreas, duodenum and small bowel in a 14-hour operation, after which he made a remarkable recovery.

He had suffered from Gardner's syndrome, which disabled his digestive system. It meant he could only take nutrition through a drip and was literally wasting away.

A former soldier, Mr Hyett was married with two daughters and lived in Haverhill in Suffolk.

webTitle: First x-ray image of a black hole

fields.headline: First x-ray image of a black hole
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Scientists today reveal the nearest thing yet to photographic evidence of a black hole as they unveil the first results of one of Europe's most ambitious space missions.
fields.body:
Scientists today reveal the nearest thing yet to photographic evidence of a black hole as they unveil the first results of one of Europe's most ambitious space missions.

Early images from the European space agency's new XXM orbiting x-ray telescope, to be rechristened Newton today in honour of the British scientist, show a veil of superheated gas being sucked into an invisible, unimaginably dense object - clear evidence of a black hole.

Martin Turner of Leicester university, who led the group of 10 European institutes that built Newton, said yesterday: "These first pictures are tremendously exciting, after so many years of work. They are all that we hoped they would be."

The Newton image, produced by the most powerful x-ray telescope ever built, shows a group of galaxies, Hickson-16, which are colliding with each other. A blue spot on the image shows where galaxies have merged and a black hole has been formed at the centre.

fields.headline: Woman to head British Library
fields.standfirst: British Library
fields.trailText: The British Library has appointed its first female chief executive. Lynne Brindley, currently pro-vice chancellor and librarian at Leeds university, will replace outgoing chief executive Brian Lang on July 1.
fields.body:
The British Library has appointed its first female chief executive. Lynne Brindley, currently pro-vice chancellor and librarian at Leeds university, will replace outgoing chief executive Brian Lang on July 1.

She is also the first professional librarian appointed to the post since the library was formally separated from the British Museum in 1972.

Ms Brindley, 49, said: "I feel enormously privileged. I am looking forward to developing programmes to enhance traditional library activities, to reach out to new publics and to put digital library developments centre stage."

Ms Brindley's previous roles have included high profile management positions at the London School of Economics and Aston university, and a stint as a senior management consultant with KPMG. Between 1979 and 1985 she worked for the British Library in bibliographic services and as head of the chief executive's office.

Library chairman John Ashworth said: "I am delighted that, for the first time in its history, the library has a chief executive who is also a professional librarian."

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said: "The British Library is at the beginning of a new era following its successful move into St Pancras and I am sure Lynne will make a most distinguished contribution to its development."

webTitle: Mentally ill police chief is retired

fields.headline: Mentally ill police chief is retired
fields.trailText: A police chief accused of sexual misconduct against female employees is to be retired on medical grounds after he was found to be mentally ill.
fields.body:
A police chief accused of sexual misconduct against female employees is to be retired on medical grounds after he was found to be mentally ill.

Andrew Timpson, the chief constable of Warwickshire, went on sick leave one day after misconduct allegations surfaced last September.

Last night Warwickshire police authority refused to say what settlement Mr Timpson would receive after leaving his £87,000-a-year job, but it is expected that he will receive an annual pension of £57,000.

A five-month investigation, headed by Norman Bettison, the chief constable of Merseyside, found that Mr Timpson was depressed and had been prescribed the anti-depressant drug Prozac.

Mr Timpson, 48, failed to cope with the pressures of the job he started in 1998 and a psychologist who examined him concluded that the Prozac could have stripped him of his usual inhibitions.

The Warwickshire police authority chairman, John Rennie, said Mr Timpson will not face disciplinary action. "We cannot crucify him by hauling him before a hearing," he said.

Mr Rennie said four of the five allegations against Mr Timpson were accepted, with the exception of one alleging that in April 1999, he had made improper sexual remarks to a female colleague.

In July of the same year, he ordered a male officer to arrange a date for him with a woman officer from another force.

Mr Rennie said: "She was not interested. It was very irresponsible for a chief constable to send out somebody to fix them up with a date."

Mr Timpson also admitted that he tried to enlist the services of a management consultant friend to assess his own performance without the correct authority.

He also instructed an officer to see that a candidate for the post of chief constable's driver passed a test necessary to getting the job.

When a vacancy for the same job arose months later, he is also said to have offered the position to a female member of staff regardless of whether she was suitable for the job.

Mr Rennie said: "Mr Timpson's behaviour and comments on occasions were inappropriate and fell below the accept able standards that one would expect of a chief constable.

"He accepts the allegations although, because of his condition, he does not recall every one of them".

Mr Bettison, who conducted the inquiry, said: "If one were to take each individual allegation in isolation then, objectively, one might say there was a need for advice or rebuke.

"With the exception of the insulting comment, one might conclude that each allegation would not warrant a full disciplinary hearing."

Mr Rennie said Mr Timpson's behaviour, which included "unpredictable mood swings", was totally out of character and was the result of stress and possibly a side effect of Prozac, which he had been prescribed.

He had been put on sick leave in September 1999 by his own GP, who diagnosed him as suffering from "stress and agitated depression".

A source with knowledge of the internal inquiry told the Guardian that Mr Timpson was genuinely ill and was not hiding behind ill health as an excuse to avoid further action.

A medical report prepared by a consultant occupational physician, Lyndon Wall, said the chief constable's conduct came at a time of personal and professional stress.

As well as being appointed to his new role in Warwickshire, he headed a labyrinthine police corruption inquiry, Operation Lancet, into the Cleveland police force.

"All the allegations took place in a period after he was taking the drug Prozac. One of the drug's reported side-effects is a disinhibition of behaviour," Dr Wall said.

"Domestic problems and particularly some inbuilt way of dealing with stress were also factors. He had no history of mental illness.

"I assessed him as permanently medically unfit to return to his post as chief constable or any other comparable post and recommend he is retired on grounds of ill health," Dr Wall added.

Mr Timpson, a father of four, reportedly failed to live with his wife when he became Warwickshire's chief constable, and instead set up home with a mistress.

The inquiry dismissed tabloid newspaper reports that Mr Timpson was involved in a homosexual relationship.

Mr Bettison, who conducted the inquiry, said: "If one were to take each individual allegation in isolation then, objectively, one might say there was a need for advice or rebuke. "With the exception of the insulting comment, one might conclude that each allegation would not warrant a full disciplinary hearing." Mr Rennie said Mr Timpson's behaviour, which included "unpredictable mood swings", was totally out of character and was the result of stress and possibly a side effect of Prozac, which he had been prescribed. He had been put on sick leave in September 1999 by his own GP, who diagnosed him as suffering from "stress and agitated depression". A source with knowledge of the internal inquiry told the Guardian that Mr Timpson was genuinely ill and was not hiding behind ill health as an excuse to avoid further action. A medical report prepared by a consultant occupational physician, Lyndon Wall, said the chief constable's conduct came at a time of personal and professional stress. As well as being appointed to his new role in Warwickshire, he headed a labyrinthine police corruption inquiry, Operation Lancet, into the Cleveland police force. "All the allegations took place in a period after he was taking the drug Prozac. One of the drug's reported side-effects is a disinhibition of behaviour," Dr Wall said. "Domestic problems and particularly some inbuilt way of dealing with stress were also factors. He had no history of mental illness. "I assessed him as permanently medically unfit to return to his post as chief constable or any other comparable post and recommend he is retired on grounds of ill health," Dr Wall added. webTitle: Dream of opera career soured by Mr Blobby role

fields.headline: Dream of opera career soured by Mr Blobby role
fields.trailText: Since he was a boy, Sam Perry has had one dream: to be an opera singer.
fields.body:
Since he was a boy, Sam Perry has had one dream: to be an opera singer.

And, when he won a place at the prestigious Royal Northern College of Music and left his native Australia for Manchester, it looked as if that dream might become reality.

But his career as a tenor ended abruptly with a role at a Somerset theme park, as Mr Blobby from Crinkley Bottom. Six hours a day he wore a rubber suit and burbled inanely as the pink creature from Noel Edmonds' BBC programme.

Yesterday, it emerged that his former employer, Cricket St Thomas estate, had paid an out-of-court settlement worth thousands. A doctor had diagnosed a combination of the heat, the costume's weight, and the strain on Mr Perry's voice as having so damaged his larynx that his Royal Northern professors told him he would never again sing classically.

Mr Perry, 23, from East Coker in Somerset, is re-training as a musical theatre performer. Last night he said that, as Mr Blobby, he drank five litres of water a day and collapsed with heat exhaustion, and still dreamed about what might have happened if not for the summer job. "I had my life mapped out - Covent Garden, the Paris opera house, and the Met in New York."

Clarke, Wilmott & Clarke, his lawyers, argued the park had breached its duty of care. "It's a claim usually brought in manufacturing, and we don't believe it's ever been used in this sort of instance before."

webTitle: Judges' ruling may keep Pinochet in Britain for months

fields.headline: Judges' ruling may keep Pinochet in Britain for months
fields.standfirst:
Question Jack Straw on the Pinochet case online today at 1.15pm
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The chances of Augusto Pinochet returning to Chile soon receded last night after the high court opened the prospect of further legal action in the 15-month saga.
fields.body:
The chances of Augusto Pinochet returning to Chile soon receded last night after the high court opened the prospect of further legal action in the 15-month saga.

The possibility that the Chilean former dictator will stay under house arrest emerged when three judges agreed to convert an application to seek judicial review of the decision not to release the general's medical reports into a full hearing.

The decision could open the way for the Belgian government and the six human rights groups to take their objections all the way to the House of Lords, delaying a final decision in the matter for weeks or even months.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, decided that the general was not fit to be extradited to stand trial, but agreed with him not to release the reports on which the decision was made. Even if the judges rule that only the countries seeking Gen Pinochet's extradition (for alleged crimes committed while Chile was under his rule) should be allowed access to the reports, it will consume time while Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland study them and make representations.

Human rights groups said the decision was an important victory, but Lord Justice Simon Brown, sitting with Mr Justice Latham and Mr Justice Dyson, stressed that the reason for their decision was to save another "unfortunate" tribunal from having to sit through the legal arguments again. However Lord Justice Brown did concede a challenge in the Lords was a possibility.

During yesterday's hearing Jonathan Sumption QC, for the home secretary, rejected arguments that Mr Straw had acted unlawfully and unfairly in not disclosing the reports on which he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings. However Mr Sumption told the judges that, if they thought it in the public interest for them to be released, Mr Straw would comply. He has made no secret of his desire to see the reports in the public domain, but has not done so because of undertakings given to Gen Pinochet.

Mr Sumption rejected a suggestion by Lord Justice Brown that the reports be released to set minds at rest that the decision was fair. "To release the reports simply for the purpose of improving PR and getting [Mr Straw's] critics off his back would, in my submission, have been extremely unfortunate thing to have done." He urged the judges to throw out the case on the grounds that Spain, leading extradition attempts, had not seen fit to challenge Mr Straw's decision.

 A poll for Channel 4 found that 58% of 1,000 people questioned agreed Gen Pinochet should stand trial in Europe, and 35% said he should be allowed to go home.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Shipman in prison move
Harold Shipman, the GP sentenced to life for murdering 15 women patients, has been moved from Strangeways jail in Manchester, it was confirmed yesterday. He is understood to have been transferred on Monday to Frankland prison in County Durham.
fields.body:
Shipman in prison move
Harold Shipman, the GP sentenced to life for murdering 15 women patients, has been moved from Strangeways jail in Manchester, it was confirmed yesterday. He is understood to have been transferred on Monday to Frankland prison in County Durham.

Shipman was moved after it became known that the mother of two prison officers at the jail could have been among his victims.

Boy, 11, bailed on rape charge
An 11-year-old boy appeared before magistrates in Skegness, Lincolnshire, yesterday charged with the rape of a 12-year-old girl. He was granted conditional bail to appear at the town's youth court on March 14.

The boy is accused of raping the girl at an address in Lincolnshire on Saturday.

Missing girl sighted
Police hunting a missing schoolgirl said last night there had been a number of sightings of her. Amy Brumby, 15, from Ickburgh, near Mundford, Norfolk, has been missing since she failed to turn up at school on Monday.

Hi-tech milk heads for shops
Milk which uses beer-brewing technology to increase its lifespan is to go on sale across wide areas of the country. Shoppers will be able buy the Cravendale PurFiltre from Monday. It uses a fine filter to remove bacteria, and is said to last seven days in a fridge after opening.

Jaguar forced to drop advert
Jaguar has been ordered to withdraw an advert for its XK8 series judged to encourage motorists to speed.

The Advertising Standards Authority said the advert, showing a blurred image of the vehicle with the heading "suddenly weekends are a blur again", could encourage people to drive irresponsibly.

Woman dies outside court
An elderly woman died yesterday after giving evidence at a court case involving a couple crushed to death after being hit by a police car. Frances Mitchell, 83, of Mannofield, Aberdeen, collapsed outside Aberdeen sheriff court.

Big dipper man back for more
Richard Rodriguez, 41, from Miami, who spent 47 days on the big dipper at Blackpool Pleasure Beach in 1998 to set a world record for a continuous ride, is to return in June aiming to stay on for 2,000 hours - three months.
