webTitle: Wiser, older shoppers ready to splash out

fields.headline: Wiser, older shoppers ready to splash out
fields.standfirst: Belts loosen after years of restraint, survey finds
fields.trailText: British consumers, older and wiser after years of restraint, have begun to "loosen their belts" and spend again.
fields.body:
British consumers, older and wiser after years of restraint, have begun to "loosen their belts" and spend again.

Despite being more indebted than ever, consumers last year showed a greater inclination to spend than save, while the internet and other new technologies played an increasing role in altering buying habits, driving down prices and empowering consumers, according to a report published yesterday.

The 16th annual British lifestyles survey published by the market researchers Mintel examines consumer trends and opinions and concludes that Britain has entered a period of "solid confidence" and that spending will rise. "People have built up a cushion against adversity," said Paul Rickard, head of research at Mintel.

"We're not seeing anything spectacular, but people are sticking their heads above the parapet, loosening their belts."

The report says the ageing population will cause dramatic changes in consumer habits, but shoppers are more discerning and expect increased competition to work in their favour.

The next five years will see the "grey pound" becoming more important as the number of men over 60 increases by 5%, mainly due to medical advances, and the number of women over 60 rises by 1%. The number of retired people with disposable income will therefore rise.

The number of women aged 30-59 will increase by nearly 4%, many of whom may be divorced and will need to plan for their retirement.

But while such consumers are ready to spend, they will not do so at any price. "The third millennium consumer will wait for the sales or for prices to go down to a level they are prepared to pay. In short, they want value for money," said Peter Ayton, Mintel's chief statistician.

"People are more savvy; they know that if they wait longer the price will come down - the 'hurry hurry hurry' sales mentally no longer holds."

The internet and other new technologies will become crucial, said Mr Rickard: "In terms of total consumer spending the web will have an impact on prices. The service industries will be forced into higher productivity thanks to the internet. Some sectors, such as books and CDs, have already responded more bullishly than others.

"The web will create consortia of buyers who will drive prices down; the balance of power will fall more and more to the consumer."

Owning a computer has already become a priority for one in five of the population, with demand for internet access predicted to increase growth in the electronic appliances sector by 55% over the next five years. Digital versatile discs and digital television will fuel the expansion. Meanwhile the mobile phone, owned by 40% of the population, is seen as a priority by only 12%.

The top lifestyle priority for most people, however, remains home ownership, with 63% rating it as their most important asset. It accounts for the bulk of consumer debt. The total level of personal debt is £600bn, £10,000 per head of population, but reducing what they owe is also a priority for many. About 40% of men and 35% of women see it as important.

The report indicates a big change in attitudes to travel, with people now considering holidays as a necessity, not a luxury, and taking more short breaks. The rise of budget airlines has contributed hugely to this trend, reducing the gap in cost between foreign and domestic travel. Since 1985 there has been a 3.8% increase in people taking three or more holidays a year, and a 5.3% rise in breaks of fewer than six days.

British attitudes to health, however, remain somewhat unreconstructed. While 16% of our income goes on food, alcohol and tobacco, a mere 1% is devoted to health and fitness.

How lifestyle changes have affected spending trends

The home
The south-east property boom has fuelled a 26% rise in prices since 1989. Spending on services such as domestic and garden help has grown by 45% in a decade, while major home improvement is the main spending priority among affluent middle-aged women.

Household goods
The largest area of growth has been in home offices and new technology, a negligible market a decade ago but now worth £2bn. Sales in the brown goods sector have doubled in five years, and the television market is still strong.

Food, drink, tobacco
Convenience foods rose by 16% to 1994 and by a further 17% since. They are particularly important to 15-24 year-olds and "sedentary" females. Wine has seen a 7% increase in sales, testimony to the British consumer's "increasingly sophisticated" palate. Hot drinks out-performed soft drinks in the past five years. Oddly, smokers are keener on music than are non-smokers.

Entertainment
Eating out becomes more popular as prosperity spreads. In 1999 we spent £21.4bn in restaurants and pubs, equivalent to almost half of what we spend on eating at home. Gambling, cinemas and theme parks have flourished at the expense of traditional entertainment such as museums and zoos. The toy market, stimulated by the emergence of computer games, has soared by 75% in a decade.

Travel
Now seen as a necessity, we take more and shorter holidays thanks to cheaper flights and better connections, which have in turn hit the domestic market. Spending on cars is £41bn, equivalent to £1,516 per car on the road. 53% of adults regard their car as important to lifestyle, and 38% would buy a new one as a priority, given financial security.

Personal goods
The clothing market has grown by 38%, with footware and jewellery performing particularly well. Sales of toiletries have increased by 69% in 10 years.

Health
The NHS is still cherished by 37% of people, while 9% want private health insurance. Improvements in diet have seen the consumer base for laxatives shrink.

Financial services
Pensions account for £60bn of gross expenditure, with personal schemes growing by 13% as occupational schemes fell by 28% to 1994. Since then, however, the mis-selling scandals have seen the trend reversed.

webTitle: Smith pledge on free entry to new Tate

fields.headline: Smith pledge on free entry to new Tate
fields.standfirst:
But culture secretary's hope of free museums for all is fading
(Chris Smith's statement)
fields.trailText: The new Tate Modern museum - "the greatest new art gallery for a century" - will be free for all, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, guaranteed yesterday.
fields.body:
The new Tate Modern museum - "the greatest new art gallery for a century" - will be free for all, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, guaranteed yesterday.

But as he praised the Tate for bringing in the £135m museum, on the south bank of the Thames, in London, on time and on budget, Mr Smith's dream of free universal admission to all national collections seemed to be fading fast.

Children can already get into all of them for nothing - and pensioners will be able to do the same from April - but Mr Smith's goal to extend the scheme to everyone from next year has been blocked by several museums which currently charge.

They say a proposed £30m government compensation deal would not cover their losses at the ticket office.

With several institutions, led by the V&A and the Science Museum, both in London, also arguing that they would lose out on VAT rebates if they did not charge, Mr Smith was forced yesterday to revise his plans and say merely that he was "committed to making sure that those museums that do not charge for admission should continue to be free".

Even so he refused to admit defeat. He said talks would continue over the next month. The extra money needed is around £10m, a fraction of the lottery cash that Mr Smith, as a millennium commissioner, loaned the dome last week to cover its cash flow crisis.

"There is money on the table, but some museums are very keen on charging," Mr Smith said. "It is up to their trustees. The government can not impose it. We were able to get them to accept free admission for children and pensioners. One or two of them resisted that. We are still in discussions with them."

A change in their VAT status might have won over some of the museums. But the option ran into trouble in Europe.

The free admissions crusade was dealt a further blow when Matthew Evans, the new and controversial head of the museums, libraries and archives commission, said: "Frankly, I don't think universal free entry was ever on the cards".

David Barrie, of the National Arts Collections Funds, which has campaigned for free entry, said the fight must go on. "We are not prepared to give up on the 'golden ideal'. If the political will were there at the highest level, the financial obstacles could easily be overcome."

Mr Smith announced that he was raising the Tate's subsidy by £5m to ensure that the vast Tate Modern "would not just be for tourists but for the whole nation".

"Access will be free, but the experience will be priceless," he said. Many touring exhibitions, which had previously passed London by could be shown in the new Tate, housed in the remodelled Bankside power station, he said.

"This is the first time the Tate's collection of modern art will be satisfactorily displayed. The Tate Modern will undoubtedly come to be regarded as one of the foremost galleries of modern art in the world.

"It is important that this wonderful collection - and its breathtaking new home - should be available to the widest possible public."

The first painting, a tiny geometric grid by Mondrian, has already been hung in one of the museum's 84 galleries. The entire project is expected to be ready well before it is officially opened by the Queen in May.

While the Turner Prize show and the circus that surrounds it will continue to be held in the old Tate Gallery - to be renamed Tate Britain - on the other side of the river at Millbank, all the international modern art in its collections, including works by Bacon, Picasso, Hockney and Hirst will be moved to the Tate Modern.

Nearly 2m people a year are expected to flock to the Tate Modern. It is expected to bring £50m a year to the rundown area of Southwark which surrounds it.

fields.trailText: The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, came under pressure last night to stop sitting as a judge in the House of Lords after a judgment by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, came under pressure last night to stop sitting as a judge in the House of Lords after a judgment by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

The court ruled that a Guernsey flower grower who was refused planning consent to turn his flower-packing shed into a home, was denied a fair hearing when his appeal was heard by a judge who also presided over the island's legislature.

The judgment could severely limit Lord Irvine's role as a judge to the point where it becomes impractical for him to exercise it except in a limited range of cases.

Seven judges ruled unanimously that Richard McGonnell was denied a "fair hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal" when the bailiff of Guernsey, the island's senior judge, turned down his planning appeal. The bailiff had presided over the legislature years before when the island's draft development plan, which affected the future use of his shed, was approved.

The Strasbourg judges ruled that the bailiff's role in hearing the planning case violated the fair hearing guarantee in the European convention on human rights although he has only a casting vote in the legislature.

There was no suggestion of bias, said the seven judges, but the fact that he presided over the legislature when the plan was approved was "capable of casting doubt on his impartiality". The judges said any direct involvement in the passage of legislation or executive rules was likely to be sufficient to raise doubts if a judge was later called on to determine a dispute over the interpretation of the act or rules.

Lawyers said that the ruling would prevent Lord Irvine from sitting as a judge on any case involving legislation passed or amended since the Labour party came to power, or any legislation of the previous government during whose passage he played an active role as opposition spokesman.

It may also stop him sitting on a huge number of cases where compatibility of legislation with the human rights act could be an issue once the act comes into force next October.

Last night a spokesman for Lord Irvine, who has sat as a judge in seven House of Lords cases since becoming lord chancellor in May 1997, said he would continue to sit. He took the view that the McGonnell case revolved around the particular role of the bailiff of Guernsey in this particular case.

But the spokesman said he would not sit in any case concerning legislation he had been involved in, or anywhere the government's interests were concerned.

A working party of the influential law reform group Justice, recently called for the lord chancellor to lose the right to sit as a judge.

Justice said last night: "The separation of judicial and political roles is vital to secure the impartiality of the courts and, with it, the integrity of the justice system. This decision is an important vindication of the right to an impartial tribunal."

fields.headline: Teacher dumps pupil in lay-by
fields.trailText: Police were last night investigating a social worker and teacher who left a nine-year-old boy with severe learning difficulties by the side of a busy road in what is claimed was a punishment for misbehaviour.
fields.body:
Police were last night investigating a social worker and teacher who left a nine-year-old boy with severe learning difficulties by the side of a busy road in what is claimed was a punishment for misbehaviour.

Shortly after being abandoned in a lay-by on the A76, the boy was found by transport police wandering on railway lines near Hulford, Ayrshire.

It is understood the teacher and social worker from Hillhead primary school, Kilmarnock, decided to leave him in the lay-by three miles from his home after he began fighting with other children in the back of a car.

East Ayrshire council said it had yesterday suspended teacher Michael Roos and social worker Maureen Law, pending its own investigation and formal disciplinary hearings.

Local SMP Margaret Jamieson said: "I am concerned that a child was left in that position. It must have been very worrying for the parents. I was astounded it had happened."

The boy, who cannot be named, had been on a day trip last Thursday with two other children from his school to a games hall in New Cumnock, Ayrshire.

He was sitting in the back seat of the car with the other children, also known to have behavioural problems, while the teacher and social worker were in the front.

As they were driving along the A76, the boy removed his seat belt and began fighting with the other children. The driver told him to get out of the car and wait by the roadside until the other children had been dropped off at their homes.

When the teacher and social worker returned, the boy had disappeared. Police later found him wandering on the Glasgow to Dumfries railway line.

Strathclyde police yesterday confirmed they had launched an investigation into the incident. British transport police are also investigating.

East Ayrshire council said the matter was being treated as extremely serious.

Anne Stafford, head of policy at Children First, welcomed the council's action. "For any adult or professional caring for a child, physical safety is a priority.

"We don't know all the facts, but clearly the child is young and vulnerable and he ended up being placed in a vulnerable situation."

fields.headline: Missing million heirs
fields.trailText: Millions of people buy lottery tickets every week dreaming of winning a fortune, perhaps even becoming a millionaire. But national lottery chiefs know of at least five people holding tickets worth more than £1m who don't seem to want the money.
fields.body:
Millions of people buy lottery tickets every week dreaming of winning a fortune, perhaps even becoming a millionaire. But national lottery chiefs know of at least five people holding tickets worth more than £1m who don't seem to want the money.

They appealed yesterday for five unsuspecting millionaire jackpot holders to come forward to claim their prizes, won on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, even going so far as to suggest it might be worth digging up millennium time capsules people placed lottery tickets in.

The unclaimed winning tickets were bought for the millennium big draw 2000 and the national lottery game draw on January 1, but so far the five ticket holders have failed to come forward to collect their winnings.

Camelot's director of public affairs, Louise White, said yesterday: "Players were more likely to have been celebrating the new year and recovering the next day and may have forgotten to check tickets.

"We also urge anyone who buried lottery tickets in time capsules in these areas to consider digging them up."

The unclaimed prizes represent the biggest combined total amount left unclaimed after a lottery draw. In 1996 the biggest single ticket prize of £2,054,754, which was bought in the Hull area, went unclaimed.

A lottery spokeswoman said last night: "This is the third biggest individual prize uncollected, but combined is the biggest we have ever had at any time.

"They are million pound winning tickets and they could create five millionaires, but each of the tickets could also be a syndicate ticket."

The lottery has created 901 millionaires since it began on November 14 1994. The total amount of unclaimed prizes has reached £289m, although this does not take into account the unclaimed winning tickets from the millennium draws.

More than £7.7bn has been raised for the good causes including unclaimed prizes and the contribution from Instants tickets and the Thunderball game, while the duty paid to the government so far amounts to more than £3bn.

There are currently £38.1m worth of unclaimed prizes within the 180-day deadline.

The winning numbers in the big draw 2000 were 1575 and 2832. Two people, who bought tickets in Hampshire and Northamptonshire, have yet to claim their £1m prizes.

In the national lottery game draw on New Year's Day the six winning numbers were 23, 48, 2, 14, 27, 5, and the bonus number was 38.

Three of five ticket-holders who shared the jackpot have yet to claim prizes worth £1,170,389 each.

The tickets were bought in Bolton, Enfield, north London and Cumbria.

fields.headline: Don't blame us, says Adams
fields.standfirst:
Crisis deepens as Mandelson introduces emergency bill
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, warned yesterday that the fragile Northern Ireland peace process was facing its greatest threat yet as his party mounted an intensive operation in London to halt the growing tide of criticism of republicans over the IRA's failure to disarm.
fields.body:
Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, warned yesterday that the fragile Northern Ireland peace process was facing its greatest threat yet as his party mounted an intensive operation in London to halt the growing tide of criticism of republicans over the IRA's failure to disarm.

Mr Adams met Tony Blair at his request for more than 75 minutes just before Peter Mandelson unveiled the emergency bill paving the way for the restoration of direct rule on Friday after only 10 weeks of devolution.

The Northern Ireland secretary risks the collapse of the Good Friday agreement if he allows David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, to resign as first minister before the critical meeting on Saturday of his party's ruling council.

An increasingly exasperated Mr Adams said there was no legal basis for the government to suspend the new institutions over decommissioning.

"In our view the Good Friday agreement is under the greatest threat so far," he said. "That threat doesn't come from Irish republicans. It comes from the decision of the British government to act upon the Unionist unilateral deadline on the weapons issue."

Mr Adams, who said he was fed up playing the role of messenger forever being shot at, appeared to suggest Sinn Fein might not take part in any second review of the agreement. He joked at taking a sabbatical, although other party leaders have indicated that Sinn Fein would remain on board. "I don't intend to spend the rest of my life trying to shore up a process that is going to be in perpetual crisis," he said.

Hours after his intervention, Mr Mandelson underlined the government's growing irritation with the republican movement when he attacked Sinn Fein for being "lordly and arrogant" in rejecting pleas for the IRA to disarm.

Mr Mandelson called for certainty that disarmament would happen. "If the war is over, why do arms still need to be retained?" he said. "If violence is a thing of the past, why can't weapons of violence be put permanently beyond use?"

He attempted to assuage republican fears by saying that the restoration of direct rule would be a "pause" to preserve the position of Mr Trimble and to allow negotiations to continue. "It is a choice between pause or bust," he said. "I am not going to let the government of Northern Ireland simply collapse into a black hole."

As he unveiled the special legislation, Mr Mandelson was watched from the Commons gallery by Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun, Sinn Fein's two ministers in the power-sharing executive at Stormont, who were also at the crisis talks in Downing Street.

Mr Trimble insisted during the debate that he stood by his demand for "product" - his code for the IRA to begin to disarm. "Words themselves are not enough," he said.

Senior government sources back Mr Trimble's claim that there was a tacit agreement over decommissioning in ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the agreement last autumn. Mr Trimble agreed in November to devolution with Sinn Fein in government before decommissioning, but only achieved a slim majority of his party's 860-strong council after offering to reconvene in February to take a final decision.

webTitle: Labour MP's ex-wife tells libel court of married life ruined by violence

fields.headline: Labour MP's ex-wife tells libel court of married life ruined by violence
fields.trailText: An MP threatened his former wife with a knife and hit her with such severity that she later required hospital treatment for a vision problem, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An MP threatened his former wife with a knife and hit her with such severity that she later required hospital treatment for a vision problem, a court heard yesterday.

Catherine Wray told the court of session in Edinburgh that the Labour MP, Jimmy Wray, who sparred as a boxer in his youth, had attacked and verbally abused her during their marriage.

Mrs Wray said her husband had been violent and had often grabbed her by the throat. She said that on a visit they paid to the European parliament in Strasbourg, the MP had thrown her across a hotel room into a wardrobe.

Mrs Wray said she later had to hide her tears from other Labour MPs when she bumped into them in a lift.

After the couple split up, Mrs Wray told the court she had gone to the former family home and had offered to make her husband a meal. In response, she said the MP threatened her with a knife.

"There was a kitchen knife and he held it to my throat. He said: 'You're driving me off my fucking head.'" said Mrs Wray.

On another occasion, when he was visiting a drugs centre, Mrs Wray said he grabbed her by the throat and threatened to "crush her like a nut".

Mr Wray, MP for Glasgow Baillieston, denies the claims. He is suing Associated Newspapers for defamation over an account of Mrs Wray's allegations which was published in the Mail on Sunday in 1998.

Mrs Wray, 50, of Milngavie, near Glasgow, said the MP first became violent to her soon after their marriage in 1985. She said he punched her in the stomach while she was hanging some curtains. It was the first attack in what she said was a marriage marred by her husband's "split personality".

Questioned by John Mitchell QC, for the newspaper group, Mrs Wray said she had never reported any of the alleged incidents to the police because she did not want to create trouble for her husband.

"I protected him because, to me, he had a psychological problem," she said. Before the couple split up in 1995, Mrs Wray had two miscarriages. She told the court that her husband blamed her for one of these.

"He said it was my fault. He said I had been drinking and had been wearing high heeled boots. I hadn't been drinking."

Mr Mitchell put it to Mrs Wray that it might be alleged that she drank alcohol to excess, which she denied. Mrs Wray said the house where the couple had lived in 1986 was "absolutely dreadful", and added: "My doctor came round when I was pregnant and said the house was far too damp to bring a baby into."

Mrs Wray told the court that on one occasion her husband had punched her with such force that she had been thrown across a caravan they were using in Brittany. She said she told her husband she wanted to go home and he had reacted with fury.

After their initial break up, the couple had tried to patch things up and Mr Wray told his wife he would seek help for his violent temper. The reconciliation did not work.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Secret deal for Portillo
fields.standfirst: Pact with Hague allows rival to dictate Tory policy on all key economic issues except Europe
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the newly annointed shadow chancellor, has been ceded the freedom by William Hague to dictate the Conservative line on all key treasury issues except Europe.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the newly annointed shadow chancellor, has been ceded the freedom by William Hague to dictate the Conservative line on all key treasury issues except Europe.

Mr Hague guaranteed his likely successor the right to determine economic policy in a private letter written shortly before the recently elected Kensington and Chelsea MP's surprise appointment last week.

The deal, echoing the Tony Blair-Gordon Brown agreement in opposition six years ago, was thrashed out during weeks of discussions between the pair.

Evidence of the agreement emerged yesterday when the Tory leader was forced to admit that his flagship tax-cutting policy is no longer a firm guarantee - merely an "aspiration".

Party officials were quick to dismiss as a slip the A-word, which got Mr Blair into trouble over NHS spending last month. But Tory MPs were in no doubt that the new shadow chancellor's greater realism was again making its mark in reshaping the party's commitments as the general election campaign looms.

Asked about his "tax guarantee" at a press conference to harden party policy on drugs, Mr Hague restated his opposition to Labour's "stealth taxes" and promised voters that he wanted to cut them: the so-called "tax guarantee".

But then he diluted his previous stance. "We offer them a powerful argument that a country that wants to compete in the future has got to bring down the burden of taxation over time - and that is the aspiration expressed in the tax guarantee," he said.

There would be "more details of what that means, and we will be more specific" as the general election approached, the Tory leader added as reporters pressed him to define what exactly his pledge now means.

Mr Hague insisted the policy was a guarantee, but said the issue needed to be discussed further with Mr Portillo.

"The guarantee to reduce taxation is a guarantee, but of course there are further details to be added to that, and there is a lot to discuss with the new shadow chancellor and the whole team," he said.

That was enough to prompt treasury ministers and the Liberal Democrats to denounce as fantasy the Tory policy process, which was "descending into chaos" because economic conditions beyond the control of any government could easily render it impossible to fulfill in a parliament.

Within 48 hours of being appointed a week ago Mr Portillo quickly junked two of his predecessor Francis Maude's policies: opposition to Labour's popular national minimum wage and to the operational independence of the Bank of England.

But on Sunday he went further. Having said mid-week that he was "fully on board" for the tax guarantee, he now sounded an equivocal note about Mr Hague's party conference promise last October - to "guarantee that taxes will fall as a share of the nation's income over the term of the next parliament" if the Tories win.

"Michael is much more of a realist and he's going to make a huge difference," said one Tory MP. "He's thought long and hard in the two years he's been away from Westminster. He wants to get the language right."

Another senior Tory said: "There was never any point in bringing back Portillo and shackling him to policies that would cost us votes. Radical surgery was needed to save the patient and his arrival is meant to signal a fresh start. Portillo is sensitive enough to know he must consult Hague, but he also knows that Hague will not block him."

Mr Hague gambled on handing his biggest rival such a key portfolio within two months of his byelection victory.

But the surrender of economic policy to the Conservatives' crown prince has fuelled fears among Hague loyalists that Mr Portillo will be able to position himself to seize the leadership after a predicted election defeat. The former treasury chief secretary has surrounded himself with a kitchen cabinet of unofficial advisers dominated by Tory MPs and ex-apparatchiks who have fallen out with Mr Hague. Mr Portillo has also been consulting trusted political colleagues and aides.

The "Portillistas" include three former Conservative central office staffers who left during Mr Hague's reign - Andrew Cooper, Michael Simmonds and Ceri Evans. Mr Portillo's readiness to consult the trio is alarming the leader's camp, some of whom are already accusing him of planning a "party within the party" to take the credit if poll ratings improve.

Mr Cooper, whose political affiliations at Tory central office were obvious from his Michael Portillo screensaver, is the former director of political operations. But he has an SDP past and campaigned against Mr Hague when the Tory leader won the Richmond byelection in 1989.

Mr Simmonds, who works with Mr Cooper as a private consultant offering companies strategic advice, is said to be "hard right and as dry as dust". He had to sign a gagging clause to qualify for a payoff when he left Tory HQ. The former director of marketing and membership was sacked by Mr Hague after a mole hunt fingered him as the insider who leaked a "dump Thatcherism" speech by the then deputy leader Peter Lilley.

Mr Evans, former director of presentation, left central office last summer to work on the Steven Norris London mayor campaign. He used to advise William Hague to wear pale blue shirts and gold silk ties to look better on TV.

Bernard Jenkin, the party's transport spokesman, who saw the supermarket boss and political novice Archie Norman installed as his boss in place of the sacked John Redwood, is also close to Mr Portillo.

So are the millionaire Alan Duncan, a trade and industry spokesman carpeted last year by his former friend Mr Hague after voicing criticism of his leadership in the New Statesman, and the Hague backbench critic David Ruffley, who was a special adviser to Kenneth Clarke.

Peter Lilley, branded a cabinet "bastard" alongside Mr Portillo by John Major, is smarting at his dismissal by Mr Hague when he tried to ditch the party's uncaring Thatcherite image.

The maverick rightwinger Eric Forth, who intended to run Mr Portillo's leadership campaign if he had held his seat in 1997, still reveres the former defence secretary.

One prominent Tory MP yesterday stressed that Mr Portillo was "a universally respected good loyal fellow, solid and trusted".

But a colleague warned that taking advice from Mr Cooper and other former central office staff could backfire for Mr Portillo. "It would be very difficult for anyone to take them back because of their public naughtiness, bad-mouthing members of the shadow cabinet. The perception is that it would not go very well with William Hague's office if they were taken in."

However, another Westminster supporter welcomed the new shadow chancellor's high-profile stance. "We planned it so Portillo would hit the ground running. He knew he had to make a difference immediately and we think he has."

Party officials were quick to dismiss as a slip the A-word, which got Mr Blair into trouble over NHS spending last month. But Tory MPs were in no doubt that the new shadow chancellor's greater realism was again making its mark in reshaping the party's commitments as the general election campaign looms. Asked about his "tax guarantee" at a press conference to harden party policy on drugs, Mr Hague restated his opposition to Labour's "stealth taxes" and promised voters that he wanted to cut them: the so-called "tax guarantee". But then he diluted his previous stance. "We offer them a powerful argument that a country that wants to compete in the future has got to bring down the burden of taxation over time - and that is the aspiration expressed in the tax guarantee," he said. There would be "more details of what that means, and we will be more specific" as the general election approached, the Tory leader added as reporters pressed him to define what exactly his pledge now means. Mr Hague insisted the policy was a guarantee, but said the issue needed to be discussed further with Mr Portillo. "The guarantee to reduce taxation is a guarantee, but of course there are further details to be added to that, and there is a lot to discuss with the new shadow chancellor and the whole team," he said. That was enough to prompt treasury ministers and the Liberal Democrats to denounce as fantasy the Tory policy process, which was "descending into chaos" because economic conditions beyond the control of any government could easily render it impossible to fulfill in a parliament. Within 48 hours of being appointed a week ago Mr Portillo quickly junked two of his predecessor Francis Maude's policies: opposition to Labour's popular national minimum wage and to the operational independence of the Bank of England. But on Sunday he went further. Having said mid-week that he was "fully on board" for the tax guarantee, he now sounded an equivocal note about Mr Hague's party conference promise last October - to "guarantee that taxes will fall as a share of the nation's income over the term of the next parliament" if the Tories win. "Michael is much more of a realist and he's going to make a huge difference," said one Tory MP. "He's thought long and hard in the two years he's been away from Westminster. He wants to get the language right." Another senior Tory said: "There was never any point in bringing back Portillo and shackling him to policies that would cost us votes. Radical surgery was needed to save the patient and his arrival is meant to signal a fresh start. Portillo is sensitive enough to know he must consult Hague, but he also knows that Hague will not block him." Mr Hague gambled on handing his biggest rival such a key portfolio within two months of his byelection victory. But the surrender of economic policy to the Conservatives' crown prince has fuelled fears among Hague loyalists that Mr Portillo will be able to position himself to seize the leadership after a predicted election defeat. The former treasury chief secretary has surrounded himself with a kitchen cabinet of unofficial advisers dominated by Tory MPs and ex-apparatchiks who have fallen out with Mr Hague. Mr Portillo has also been consulting trusted political colleagues and aides. The "Portillistas" include three former Conservative central office staffers who left during Mr Hague's reign - Andrew Cooper, Michael Simmonds and Ceri Evans. Mr Portillo's readiness to consult the trio is alarming the leader's camp, some of whom are already accusing him of planning a "party within the party" to take the credit if poll ratings improve. Mr Cooper, whose political affiliations at Tory central office were obvious from his Michael Portillo screensaver, is the former director of political operations. But he has an SDP past and campaigned against Mr Hague when the Tory leader won the Richmond byelection in 1989. Mr Simmonds, who works with Mr Cooper as a private consultant offering companies strategic advice, is said to be "hard right and as dry as dust". He had to sign a gagging clause to qualify for a payoff when he left Tory HQ. The former director of marketing and membership was sacked by Mr Hague after a mole hunt fingered him as the insider who leaked a "dump Thatcherism" speech by the then deputy leader Peter Lilley. Mr Evans, former director of presentation, left central office last summer to work on the Steven Norris London mayor campaign. He used to advise William Hague to wear pale blue shirts and gold silk ties to look better on TV. Bernard Jenkin, the party's transport spokesman, who saw the supermarket boss and political novice Archie Norman installed as his boss in place of the sacked John Redwood, is also close to Mr Portillo. So are the millionaire Alan Duncan, a trade and industry spokesman carpeted last year by his former friend Mr Hague after voicing criticism of his leadership in the New Statesman, and the Hague backbench critic David Ruffley, who was a special adviser to Kenneth Clarke. Peter Lilley, branded a cabinet "bastard" alongside Mr Portillo by John Major, is smarting at his dismissal by Mr Hague when he tried to ditch the party's uncaring Thatcherite image. The maverick rightwinger Eric Forth, who intended to run Mr Portillo's leadership campaign if he had held his seat in 1997, still reveres the former defence secretary. One prominent Tory MP yesterday stressed that Mr Portillo was "a universally respected good loyal fellow, solid and trusted". But a colleague warned that taking advice from Mr Cooper and other former central office staff could backfire for Mr Portillo. "It would be very difficult for anyone to take them back because of their public naughtiness, bad-mouthing members of the shadow cabinet. The perception is that it would not go very well with William Hague's office if they were taken in." However, another Westminster supporter welcomed the new shadow chancellor's high-profile stance. "We planned it so Portillo would hit the ground running. He knew he had to make a difference immediately and we think he has."

webTitle: Hague goes to war over drugs

fields.headline: Hague goes to war over drugs
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday made drugs a political battlefield at the next general election when he unveiled draconian proposals to jail anyone caught with cannabis within quarter of a mile of a school.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday made drugs a political battlefield at the next general election when he unveiled draconian proposals to jail anyone caught with cannabis within quarter of a mile of a school.

Calling for the toughest crackdown on illegal drugs Britain has seen, the Tory leader accused the government of "turning a blind eye" to soft drugs amid indications from cabinet minister Mo Mowlam that police efforts should be concentrated on hard drugs like heroin and cocaine rather than cannabis.

"It is time for a stronger, firmer, harder attack on drugs than we have ever seen before. That is the common sense solution which Britain wants and will get under the next Conservative government," he said.

The hardline proposals for locking up people caught with cannabis within 400m of schools would be likely to lead to a significant increase in the numbers jailed for minor drugs offences. Most people caught with a small amount are released with a police caution. In London and most inner cities, the density of schools would mean that virtually no area was off limits.

Mr Hague's unequivocal call for a get-tough drugs policy based on increased imprisonment sets a clear line between the Tories and Labour and the Liberal Democrats, despite home secretary Jack Straw's insistence that he will make no compromise over pressure for a softer stance on cannabis use.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, has reinforced party policy of a royal commission on drugs with calls for an open, honest discussion on the issue. The Tories hope that they can exploit apparent top-level divisions within the government over the way forward on drugs.

webTitle: Tory's outburst after losing party whip

fields.headline: Tory's outburst after losing party whip
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Rod Richards, one-time leader of the Conservative group in the Welsh assembly, yesterday launched a scathing attack on his successor and the Tory party hierarchy after group members withdrew the whip from him.
fields.body:
Rod Richards, one-time leader of the Conservative group in the Welsh assembly, yesterday launched a scathing attack on his successor and the Tory party hierarchy after group members withdrew the whip from him.

In an astonishing outburst, the former Welsh office junior minister accused the party of malevolence and conspiring to oust him and dismissed his successor, Nick Bourne, as a "prat".

Mr Richards, whose forthright views have earned him the nickname Rottweiler, said the announcement that the whip had been withdrawn was an example of somebody "not getting their head around the politics of the day".

He added: "Anybody who can get the Conservative party in the news on the eve of a no- confidence vote in a Labour first secretary is either a political genius or a complete prat. We know which one we have got."

Mr Bourne, a law professor and former Conservative chief spokesman in Wales, took over as leader of the nine-strong Tory group in Cardiff last year when Mr Richards stood down to contest a forthcoming court case in which he denies allegations of assaulting a young woman in London.

The group decided to remove the whip from him after he abstained in a vote on the assembly's draft budget. Mr Richards, who absolved the group's youthful chief whip, David Davies, of acting against him, described the meeting at which the decision was taken as a kangaroo court conducted by the "malevolent seven.

"This is born of malice," Mr Richards said. "It is personal and a very, very sad day for the Conservative party."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Joan Baez gives a rare live performance at the first prize-giving ceremony of the BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards (8.0pm, Radio 2), hosted by Mike Harding. It's 40 years since the singer made her initial stunning impact on the Newport Festival audience, but, now in her 60th year, she is still going strong. The channel has launched the awards to widen the audience for all varieties of folk music.

The most familiar evidence of mankind's need for culture has been the palaeolithic cave paintings discovered in southern France and elsewhere. But Paul Bahn, an expert in the subject, demonstrates in Origins: The Human Factor (9.0pm, Radio 4) that our ancestors were not just handy with the stick-and-soot. Scratch marks on the stalactites hanging from the Cougnac cave, he says, offer clear evidence that they were used as a sort of Stone Age xylophone. He even tries to re-create the top single of 25,000 BC.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What the cast of Brookside watch on television
fields.trailText: What the cast of Brookside watch on television
fields.body:
Ron Dixon (Vince Earl): "I like comedy programmes. Sky are re-running Rising Damp. It ranks among the funniest things ever seen on television. I do watch Brookside. In the early days I'd go, "Oh no. I never did that did I?" Now I look at it and think, hey, that was all right. If they say they want to get back to the old roots, there it is."

Jackie Corkhill (Sue Jenkins): "I don't watch an awful lot of television, but I like good drama, I love Morse. Lynda La Plante's Trial And Retribution, loved that, super, but that's also because my husband's in it."

Mick Johnson (Louis Emerick): "At the moment I'm watching Clocking Off, by Paul Abbott. It's new, fresh, great performances, great writing. It's different, it's set in a factory and the characters all have different stories, and you're interested in it from the minute it starts to the end of the credits."

Mike Dixon (Paul Byatt): "I watch Countdown, Home And Away and Neighbours. 15-1, no that's a bit too clever for me. Not Richard And Judy though, no. I watch a lot of Friends. I like Joey, 'cos he's stupid."

Max Farnham (Steven Pinder): "Er, we've been instructed not to talk to the Guardian. Well, I watch Millennium, but it's not on anymore. I like the sport. Gormenghast? [Tactfully] I like drama, but I've got to get into it first."

Emily Shadwick (Jennifer Ellison) "I watch mainly comedies, The Royle Family and Vicar Of Dibley because they make me laugh. Eddie Murphy is great, Jennifer Saunders. I haven't got cable, no."

Bev McLoughlin (Sarah White) "I'm in mourning because Dinnerladies has just finished. I don't watch a great deal of television, so I don't get to the point where I think 'This is rubbish I'll turn off'. There's nothing I hate. I like news, documentaries. Docusoaps? They've run out of steam really."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Shanghai Triad

(Zhang Yimou, 1995)

8pm, FilmFour

Zhang Yimou, Gong Li, 30s gangsters - all the elements seemed to be in place for another masterpiece of Chinese cinema. But despite the luscious sets and cinematography there's something left to be desired here. The story of a triad godfather and his mistress (Li) is told from the perspective of a young boy, given the task of tending to her endless whims. An interesting device, but what he doesn't know, we don't know, and so we're in the dark for most of the film.

Richard Vine

The Picture Of Dorian Gray

(Albert Lewin, 1945)

9pm, TCM

Atmospheric Hollywood treatment of Wilde's gothic novel about a young man's pact with the devil in a corrupt Edwardian London. George Sanders sets the tone beautifully with his cynical, sneering Lord Henry Wotton who unwittingly sets up the deal, and Hurd Hatfield is perfectly smooth as decadent Dorian, remaining the picture of innocence while the portrait in the attic grows older. Elegant, witty and barbed: Oscar would have loved it.

Alien Nation

(Graham Baker, 1988)

1am, SciFi Channel

Deep in the Mojave desert an alien community lives alongside the locals. But there are tensions, and tough cop James Caan recruits alien Mandy Patinkin to help trace his partner's killer - a trail leading to another of the "newcomers", the shady Terence Stamp. At times a little ponderous in its liberal musings on brotherhood, but the performances make it a compelling and intelligent sci-fi drama.

A Summer's Tale

(Eric Rohmer, 1996)

4.05am, FilmFour

One of Rohmer's Tales of the Four Seasons, a typical chamber piece that seems quite frivolous, until you find yourself on the edge of the seat wondering how it will be resolved. Melvil Poupard (pictured) is Gaspard, a student holidaying in Brittany, awaiting the arrival of his girlfriend (Aurelia Nolin). There he strikes up a platonic relationship with another student (Amanda Langlet) and a physical one with her friend (Gwenaëlle Simon). There's the choice: will he plump for the affair romantic, intellectual, or sexual?

Paul Howlett

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: It's been a merry trip down memory lane in the US courts this week, with Sara Karloff - daughter of the late, great horror icon Boris - getting busy suing her father's former employers at Universal Studios for at least $10 million.
fields.body:
It's been a merry trip down memory lane in the US courts this week, with Sara Karloff - daughter of the late, great horror icon Boris (pictured) - getting busy suing her father's former employers at Universal Studios for at least $10 million. According to her suit - filed in LA Superior Court, and listing fraud, breach of contract, and violation of rights of publicity among its litigious bones of contention - Universal have repeatedly exploited her father's portrayals of Frankenstein's Monster and The Mummy without paying a dime to the big man's estate and, moreover, have reneged on a previous agreement to cough up their due. The case, currently wading through the US justice system, appears to rest on whether Universal actually used images of Karloff in its licensing materials, or simply generic portraits of large men with bolts through their neck: "The suit was brought to stop the unsavoury business practices of Universal", remarked Karloff's attorney Allan Browne, before lumbering into the distance with his arms outstretched in search of children to frighten...

Meanwhile, longtime animal-rights activist Pamelyn Ferdin - probably best known for providing the voice of Lucy in Charlie Brown - has managed to avoid (for now) a possible 30 days in clink, after her sentence for possession of an offensive weapon was stayed in LA District Court pending an appeal. The root of the problem was the actress's arrest last year during a protest against a Californian circus, having been seen brandishing a "bull hook" - the wooden rod used by elephant trainers - midway through the demonstration. Ferdin claimed, logically enough, that she only had said item on her person to illustrate the barbaric treatment of performing animals; sadly, however, the LAPD failed to make the connection, and promptly nicked her. She's back in court in March...

fields.headline: Your 15 minutes are up
fields.standfirst: Businesses featured in docusoaps have to carry on when the cameras leave. How do they fare in the months and years afterwards? And do they end up regretting their decision to allow us into their lives?
fields.trailText: Businesses featured in docusoaps have to carry on when the cameras leave. How do they fare in the months and years afterwards? And do they end up regretting their decision to allow us into their lives?
fields.body:
Free advertising, or commercial suicide? The jury may still be out on the likely after-effects for Cabal Communications following their decision to bear all on BBC2's Trouble Between The Covers, which ended on Monday, but past docusoap "victims" insist that longer-term benefits far outweigh any short-term embarrassment.

Take EasyJet, the cut-price airline featured in ITV's on-going Airline series, currently in production for series four, and due back on air in June. Week in, week out, its staff are seen under pressure, warts and all - and within hours of transmission, the company's call centre reports telephone bookings have "significantly increased".

"Opening the company up to the TV cameras was a gamble, but it was worth it," says EasyJet chairman Stelios Haji-Ioannou. "Viewers understand any problems portrayed in the programme are an exception rather than the rule."

With around nine million people tuning in to each programme in the last series, small wonder the EasyJet founder now believes taking part in the series has been good for business.

Derek Duke Hastings, chief executive of creative consultancy Park Avenue - which was seen developing a number of zones for the Millennium Dome in BBC 2's recent Trouble At The Big Top - also claims to have won new business as a result. And this despite being sacked from the Dome on camera, and shortly afterwards seen enjoying a spot of R&R aboard his luxury yacht.

Hardly positive PR for Duke Hastings - or his company, you might think. You would be wrong. "Clients have congratulated us on our resilience. Others saw us working against the odds and still delivering the goods. I was even contacted as a result of the TV series by some people who used to own my yacht back in 1945", Duke Hastings says.

"It didn't bother me that we were shown - how should I put it? - being 're-shuffled'. It's the nature of the business we work in that sometimes people will like what we do and other times they won't. At least it was set in context", he adds.

"I had hoped we would come over as a team. But it came over as being about me, which was a worry. Still, you've got to accept the camera focuses on personalities, and as long as you don't play to the camera you'll be OK. Ask anyone who saw the series and they'll say they had a better opinion of Peter Mandelson as a result: it's done him tremendous good."

Raising a business profile is an inevitable side effect of letting in the TV cameras - although increased awareness may not necessarily come about for the best reasons.

Take Liverpool's Adelphi Hotel, subject of another fly-on-the-wall documentary shown on BBC 1 three years ago. Exposed to and talked about by millions of viewers, the attitude of some of the staff featured and their particular style of customer service provoked as much comment as the "characters" that stole the show. According to one reticent insider: "It's taken a while to live down."

This was a view shared by a number of staff at London advertising agency St Lukes - the subject of a Cutting Edge documentary that went out on Channel 4 last year. Yet despite industry tales of crying in the corridors when the end result was seen, six months on, the agency's new business director Juliette Soskiss insists that the experience was "a good thing".

The St Lukes documentary focused on the ad agency's unique approach to self-management - the agency is run as a cooperative and is a champion of alternative work styles. And it ended on a sour note with staff at a low point after the loss of some business, asking whether their brave new approach to running an advertising agency would ever pay off.

Soskiss, however, believes that the agency came up trumps. (Surely further grounds for an investigation by broadcast watchdogs into the extent to which some of these documentaries border on product placement.)

"We are different and the programme rightly presented us as such. And we are human. We don't always get it right - who does? Overall we had a pretty positive response", she explains. To prove her point, Soskiss adds that St Lukes currently sends out at least half-a-dozen tapes of the show each week in response to inquiries. Shameless? Perhaps. But, she counters: "In the longer run, it's proved to be a helpful new business tool."

Whether the same will be true for Sally O'Sullivan and her crew at Cabal - which even let the cameras linger on the ankles of female staff in the ladies loo in one episode - will only become clear in coming months. But chances are it too will enjoy a boost.

True, TV audiences can only stomach so much reality. But Trouble Between The Covers still had all those key ingredients: colourful characters, tension and conflict. It got Cabal talked about. It boosted newsstand sales. And in six months and a dozen or so more docu-dramas time, people will remember the name... but not exactly why. By which time any lingering bad PR can be blamed not on the programme's subjects but its producers.

Maybe Sally O'Sullivan wasn't so silly to let those cameras in, after all.

Hardly positive PR for Duke Hastings - or his company, you might think. You would be wrong. "Clients have congratulated us on our resilience. Others saw us working against the odds and still delivering the goods. I was even contacted as a result of the TV series by some people who used to own my yacht back in 1945", Duke Hastings says. "It didn't bother me that we were shown - how should I put it? - being 're-shuffled'. It's the nature of the business we work in that sometimes people will like what we do and other times they won't. At least it was set in context", he adds. "I had hoped we would come over as a team. But it came over as being about me, which was a worry. Still, you've got to accept the camera focuses on personalities, and as long as you don't play to the camera you'll be OK. Ask anyone who saw the series and they'll say they had a better opinion of Peter Mandelson as a result: it's done him tremendous good." Raising a business profile is an inevitable side effect of letting in the TV cameras - although increased awareness may not necessarily come about for the best reasons. Take Liverpool's Adelphi Hotel, subject of another fly-on-the-wall documentary shown on BBC 1 three years ago. Exposed to and talked about by millions of viewers, the attitude of some of the staff featured and their particular style of customer service provoked as much comment as the "characters" that stole the show. According to one reticent insider: "It's taken a while to live down." This was a view shared by a number of staff at London advertising agency St Lukes - the subject of a Cutting Edge documentary that went out on Channel 4 last year. Yet despite industry tales of crying in the corridors when the end result was seen, six months on, the agency's new business director Juliette Soskiss insists that the experience was "a good thing". The St Lukes documentary focused on the ad agency's unique approach to self-management - the agency is run as a cooperative and is a champion of alternative work styles. And it ended on a sour note with staff at a low point after the loss of some business, asking whether their brave new approach to running an advertising agency would ever pay off. Soskiss, however, believes that the agency came up trumps. (Surely further grounds for an investigation by broadcast watchdogs into the extent to which some of these documentaries border on product placement.) "We are different and the programme rightly presented us as such. And we are human. We don't always get it right - who does? Overall we had a pretty positive response", she explains. To prove her point, Soskiss adds that St Lukes currently sends out at least half-a-dozen tapes of the show each week in response to inquiries. Shameless? Perhaps. But, she counters: "In the longer run, it's proved to be a helpful new business tool." Whether the same will be true for Sally O'Sullivan and her crew at Cabal - which even let the cameras linger on the ankles of female staff in the ladies loo in one episode - will only become clear in coming months. But chances are it too will enjoy a boost. True, TV audiences can only stomach so much reality. But Trouble Between The Covers still had all those key ingredients: colourful characters, tension and conflict. It got Cabal talked about. It boosted newsstand sales. And in six months and a dozen or so more docu-dramas time, people will remember the name... but not exactly why. By which time any lingering bad PR can be blamed not on the programme's subjects but its producers. Maybe Sally O'Sullivan wasn't so silly to let those cameras in, after all.

fields.headline: Late night let-down
fields.trailText: Pulling Power | Family Confidential | Playing the Field
fields.body:
Amid clouds of dry ice and strobe lighting, Jaguar Motors unveiled their F-Type "concept car". It was forty years since the E-Type, so a new suppository-shaped update was deemed in order for the millenium. Mike Rutherford, ex-guitarist of Genesis, and now presenter of Pulling Power (ITV) felt a Proustian shiver of pomp rock du temps perdu, as he ogled the shiny Jag laxative, gliding smoothly onto stage to "Eye Of The Tiger". "I'm telling you," he said, choking back the emotion, "have we got some hot metal for you tonight!"

Pulling Power has one of those late-night titles designed to draw in floating viewers on a trawl through the schedule for sex. Like the self-parodic Family Confidential: Confessions Of A Porn Sister (C5), the packaging is saucier than the content. With docs about the clitoris, primetime TV is now more sexually explicit than its late-night counterpart. As a result, it has swapped places with mainstream telly, producing magazine shows and thoughtful documentaries that could easily go out at 7pm.

While Pulling Power was stacked with items that would have looked pedestrian on Watchdog, Family Confidential told the story of two sisters, Lian and Karen, both single mums. Lian made soft porn videos, and Karen disapproved.

But Lian didn't have "sex with a strange man" in a chintzy sitting room because of sibling rivalry. "Thousand pound a day, you have a good laugh on set. I think I've chosen a damn good career."

The shocking thing about Family Confidential was how unshocking it was. There wasn't a single shot of Lian naked, and the low-key tone perfectly suited the downbeat banality of low-rent pornography. Lian hung a whip on her bedroom wall, next to a photo of herself aged twelve. "I look like Demi Moore, and move like Madonna", she said ironically.

Pulling Power's version of anti-sexy TV was to deliver its insomniac audience of porn-hungry shift workers features about the history of the Skoda and the Leicester traffic warden department.

Classic is a favourite word of motor shows. Everything is classic, even twin air bags. But, radically, Rutherford and co-host Michele Newman forewent the classic Clarksonisms of motor journalism - "if this car were any more sexy, it'd be wearing high heels and suspenders" - in favour of frill-free information.

Newman travelled to Prague and sung the praises of the Fabia, the "millenium Skoda", driving through cobbled streets to trance music and cruising repeatedly past the sunset at different skew-whiff camera angles. "I don't feel like I'm driving a small tinny car at all", Michele said confidently, but then read out the small print. "There is just one gripe. There's a delay when you put your foot on the accelerator."

Playing the Field (BBC1) returned for a second series to TV drama's favourite theme: all men are bastards.

Castlefield FC's all-women football team went on Shaz's Hen Night, hiring a stretch-limo and swigging champagne from the sun roof as the seething husbands sat alone in front of the telly.

Playing The Field is good drama, but still remains essentially Real Women with shin-pads. The Hen Night scene was identical to Real Women's Day At The Races, in which Michelle Collins and co. hired a stretch limo, swigged champagne and told each other what good friends they were.

Whereas the women got endless group-hugs, the men clung onto their chauvinism like that half-empty can of beer. "How often do you tell Therese you love her?" "You what?!"

Last night's episode began with Rick, Diane's husband, collecting his paper on the step, yawning, scratching his crotch, and lighting a cigarette. From these actions, we knew that Rick was a Bad Man. Scott, by contrast, the new team coach, ie new love interest, stumbled cutely with his words and ran his hands through his Rufus Sewell hair. From this, we knew that he was a Good Man.

From such drama shorthand are male characters drawn. Scott could pronounce "capuccino" correctly, while Rick referred to it as "that frothy stuff they have in London". What does he care? Like most uncaring, uncultured Bad Men in Britain, he's probably down the pub, scratching his arse, drinking that frothy stuff they have everywhere else.

fields.headline: Major urges halt to concessions
fields.standfirst:
Ulster debate
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: John Major yesterday called on the government to stop releasing paramilitary prisoners and to hold back from reforming the RUC if the IRA refuses to disarm.
fields.body:
John Major yesterday called on the government to stop releasing paramilitary prisoners and to hold back from reforming the RUC if the IRA refuses to disarm.

Speaking during a Commons debate on the emergency Northern Ireland legislation, which will reimpose direct rule if the IRA fails to make a move, the former prime minister warned that a series of recent concessions to republicans appeared to have had little impact.

"Confidence building is a two-way process and democracy cannot continue to offer incentives if there is no response," Mr Major told MPs during the second reading debate on the Northern Ireland bill. "Without decommissioning the concessions that have been made by democrats will have to be re-examined to see if they are still appropriate."

Mr Major, a supporter of the government bill, said the peace process was facing an "uneasy period", but not collapse.

The former prime minister, who launched the peace process with the Downing Street declaration in 1993, described decommissioning as "an absolutely necessary" ingredient of the process, though he understood what a challenge it posed to the republican movement.

"It is possible that the leaders of Sinn Fein and IRA are prepared to begin decommissioning but do not know how to do so, or do not have the courage or the confidence or the support at this moment of their movements," Mr Major said.

"Decommissioning is not just the decision of one or two leaders of Sinn Fein or the IRA. It is much more difficult than that. It requires the consent of the IRA army council and a full meeting of volunteers for whom criminality has been a way of life."

The former prime minister, who said he was still not sure whether the republican movement was committed to disarming even in line with the Good Friday agreement, issued a strong plea to the IRA to disarm because it would stabilise political life in Northern Ireland.

"One of the aspects of wholesale decommissioning is that the IRA disarmed is not an organisation that is sustainable," Mr Major said. "The disarmament of the IRA amounts to the disbandment of the IRA."

David Trimble , Northern Ireland's first minister, reiterated his insistence that the IRA must begin to disarm this week if Ulster Unionists are to remain in the new power-sharing executive.

Speaking in the same debate, the Ulster Unionist leader echoed Mr Major's call for the government to review the early release of prisoners and the reform of the RUC.

"People in Northern Ireland will find it incomprehensible if those deeply wounding changes are proceeded with as if nothing had happened, as if the default by the republicans was something that was going to be glossed over and the continued introduction of radical changes in order to appease them went ahead as if nothing had happened," Mr Trimble said. However, the UUP leader held out hope that the present "difficulty" - he insisted it was not a crisis - could be overcome. "It is important that we should retain confidence in our ability to work through this problem and to retain confidence that the hopes that agreement contains will be fully realised," he said.

Seamus Mallon , the deputy leader of the SDLP, issued a powerful plea to the government not to suspend the Northern Ireland assembly and power-sharing executive. The Northern Ireland deputy first minister said suspension would probably reduce the chances of disarmament.

MPs voted 352 to 11, a government majority of 341, to give a second reading to the bill in a division forced by rebel Labour backbenchers.

fields.headline: Ministers seek deal on section 28
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The government yesterday insisted it would stick to its plan to scrap the law banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools, as ministers sought a compromise that would bring rebel peers on side.
fields.body:
The government yesterday insisted it would stick to its plan to scrap the law banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools, as ministers sought a compromise that would bring rebel peers on side.

A formula involving tougher guidance, possibly enshrined in law, compelling schools to promote marriage and family life is the likeliest way forward after the government's defeat in the Lords over repeal of section 28 of the local government act.

Peers, including 15 Labour rebels, threw out the measure by a 45-vote majority on Monday during the Lords committee stage of the local government bill. There were clear signals yesterday that the government is ready to compromise. The prime minister's official spokesman said: "There are points we can take on board. Our sense is that a constructive approach can be worked out."

One Lords source said: "There is considerable room for manoeuvre." Without a compromise, the repeal of section 28 is likely to founder, with no hope of its resurrection before the next election.

Ministers in the Lords and the education secretary, David Blunkett, are to seek common ground with peers, religious leaders and parents' groups, aiming for guidelines that would reassure all but hardline opponents of repeal.

The local government minister, Lord Whitty, made clear during Monday's debate that the government would consider a compromise along the lines of a proposal from the Bishop of Blackburn, the Right Rev Alan Chesters.

His amendment, which was not put to the vote, would place a legal duty on schools to promote marriage and family life in sex education lessons, while not promoting any kind of sexuality, and to take steps to prevent bullying linked to sexual preference.

Lords sources indicated that the government aimed to have a compromise ready for Lords report stage, not yet timetabled. The repeal of section 28 would be restored when the bill returned to the Commons.

One source said: "The option of putting guidelines directly into the bill is being discussed. It is very difficult to enshrine something as sensitive as this in law, but there may be a way round it." The government has the support of Stonewall, the gay and lesbian campaign group, in its efforts to find a compromise. A spokeswoman said: "We don't have a problem with teaching that family life is an important part of heterosexual relationships, but I don't think that precludes you from recognising that there are other forms of family that require equal respect."

webTitle: Labour's man in Wales faces crisis vote

fields.headline: Labour's man in Wales faces crisis vote
fields.standfirst:
Assembly on course for constitutional turmoil with 10-word motion condemning first secretary over European funding for poor areas
Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: The infant Welsh assembly was heading rapidly towards a period of constitutional uncertainty last night as opposition parties made good their threat to table a motion of no confidence in the Labour first secretary, Alun Michael, over the issue of European funding for some of the poorest areas of Wales.
fields.body:
The infant Welsh assembly was heading rapidly towards a period of constitutional uncertainty last night as opposition parties made good their threat to table a motion of no confidence in the Labour first secretary, Alun Michael, over the issue of European funding for some of the poorest areas of Wales.

The terse, 10-word motion will be considered by members in a special hour-long debate this afternoon.

But Mr Michael, who faces almost certain defeat at the hands of the three opposition parties, remained determined to let his name go forward for re-election as first secretary should the motion succeed.

That would raise the immediate prospect of further no confidence motions and take the assembly into wholly uncharted constitutional waters.

The assembly's presiding officer, Dafydd Elis Thomas, is still wrestling with the question of how often such ping pong moves could take place.

Plaid Cymru, which has been gunning for Mr Michael over European funding since the assembly elections last May, tabled the no confidence motion immediately following yesterday's debate on the £8bn Welsh budget. It made its move after failing to secure an unequivocal guarantee that the treasury would come up with the match funding needed to unlock £1.2bn of grants earmarked for west Wales and the valleys as part of the EU's so called objective 1 programme to aid the most economically disadvantaged parts of Europe.

"Mr Michael should have made the case for Wales to get the money it deserves much stronger," the party's acting leader, Ieuan Wyn Jones, said last night. "He has been reluctant to battle with the treasury and his hotline to Tony Blair has gone cold."

Mr Michael, who insisted he had no intention of standing down, claimed the opposition move was a "nonsense" based on a series of artificial deadlines and figures that bore no relation to reality.

He maintained that funds were already in place for the first year of the seven year objective 1 programme. Negotiations were taking place with the treasury for the following years as part of the government's comprehensive spending review and he was determined to get the best deal for Wales. Under assembly rules Mr Michael will be forced to resign if the no confidence vote goes against him, as assembly arithmetic says it will.

But Labour has made it clear that he will be its only candidate for first secretary when the assembly presiding officer calls for nominations tomorrow morning.

Plaid Cymru confirmed yesterday that such a move would immediately trigger a renewed no confidence move. "The grounds upon which we would do it is that no first secretary who has lost the confidence of the assembly can immediately come back," the Plaid Cymru leader said. But he said the party would not be tempted to bring down any Labour successor in a similar way.

"We have made this an issue of confidence in Mr Michael's leadership. Our view is that he has not argued the case strongly enough with the treasury and made it absolutely clear to them that Wales needs the money to reinvigorate the economies of west wales and the valleys."

Mr Wyn Jones added: "What we would expect a new first secretary to do is to argue the case with the treasury. We wouldn't use votes of no confidence like confetti. This is a very serious weapon we are using and it is not a weapon you use lightly or often."

Ann Jones, chairman of the Labour group in the assembly, claimed Plaid had chosen to plunge the assembly into chaos by imposing a wholly arbitrary deadline on the objective 1 process.

 Wales is one of four UK areas earmarked to receive hundreds of millions of pounds from Brussels under the EU's Objective 1 aid programme.

 The programme is aimed at reinvigorating the least developed regions of Europe where GDP per head is less than 75 % of the EU average.

 The seven-year programme, which runs until the end of 2006, was agreed at the Berlin summit when west Wales and the valleys was included along with Cornwall, Merseyside and South Yorkshire.

 The four regions, desperate to be included before EU enlargement brought even poorer economies into the calculations, have been promised more than £3 bn between them - £1.2 bn of it for Wales.

 In order to draw down the EU money member states are required to come up with match funding for the regeneration projects.

 Opposition parties in Wales insist this funding should come from the treasury and be in addition to £8bn handed over to the assembly under the formula that governs the size of the Welsh budget.

 Labour says the issue will be resolved in the government's spending review, but there are already sufficient funds to kick-start the programme this year.

Ann Jones, chairman of the Labour group in the assembly, claimed Plaid had chosen to plunge the assembly into chaos by imposing a wholly arbitrary deadline on the objective 1 process.  Wales is one of four UK areas earmarked to receive hundreds of millions of pounds from Brussels under the EU's Objective 1 aid programme.  The programme is aimed at reinvigorating the least developed regions of Europe where GDP per head is less than 75 % of the EU average.  The seven-year programme, which runs until the end of 2006, was agreed at the Berlin summit when west Wales and the valleys was included along with Cornwall, Merseyside and South Yorkshire.  The four regions, desperate to be included before EU enlargement brought even poorer economies into the calculations, have been promised more than £3 bn between them - £1.2 bn of it for Wales.  In order to draw down the EU money member states are required to come up with match funding for the regeneration projects.  Opposition parties in Wales insist this funding should come from the treasury and be in addition to £8bn handed over to the assembly under the formula that governs the size of the Welsh budget.  Labour says the issue will be resolved in the government's spending review, but there are already sufficient funds to kick-start the programme this year.

fields.headline: Jackson's vote for Livingstone
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Glenda Jackson yesterday announced she would support Ken Livingstone with her second preference vote in Labour's London mayoral contest after a ballot of party members in her Hampstead and Highgate constituency backed the Brent East MP by more than two to one.
fields.body:
Glenda Jackson yesterday announced she would support Ken Livingstone with her second preference vote in Labour's London mayoral contest after a ballot of party members in her Hampstead and Highgate constituency backed the Brent East MP by more than two to one.

The declaration by the former transport minister, who is expected to come third in Labour's selection battle after Mr Livingstone and the former health secretary, Frank Dobson, followed renewed complaints over the conduct of the ballot and the tactics of Mr Dobson's supporters.

Ms Jackson's members voted by 147 to 62 in a consultative ballot to back Mr Livingstone over Mr Dobson on a low turnout. The result was dismissed by Mr Dobson's spokeswoman as "no surprise - we have known for weeks that they have been working together".

Mr Livingstone meanwhile seized on the fact that Pauline Green, former leader of the socialist group in the European parliament and a Dobson supporter, will be able to vote in the contest even though she has resigned as an MEP and now works for the Co-operative Union in Manchester.

With both the frontrunners' campaign teams agreeing that the outcome of the electoral college contest later this month is finely balanced, the vote of an MP or MEP - worth nearly half of 1% of the total - could tip the result one way or the other.

"It is unacceptable that a retired MEP working in Manchester could decide this," Mr Livingstone said last night. "Londoners will not tolerate it".

Although the former Greater London council leader is expected to win in the ballots of trade unionists and individual members, the 75-member section reserved for MPs, MEPs and Greater London authority candidates has a third of the total vote and is certain to opt heavily for Mr Dobson.

In an indication of the pressure being brought to bear on MPs who are refusing to endorse the leadership's preference for Mr Dobson, Rudolf Vis, the MP for Finchley and Golders Green, has told his local party that he has been offered extra Millbank support in the next general election if he drops his plans to abstain.
