fields.headline: Alan Pryce-Jones
fields.standfirst: Literary editor who internationalised the TLS
fields.trailText: My first impression of Alan Pryce-Jones, editor of the Times Literary Supplement from 1948 to 1959, who has died aged 91, was delightful, but none too serious. It was spring 1945 and Pryce-Jones, critic, writer, journalist - and then lieutenant colonel - arrived north of Venice at the British 8th Army headquarters.
fields.body:
My first impression of Alan Pryce-Jones, editor of the Times Literary Supplement from 1948 to 1959, who has died aged 91, was delightful, but none too serious. It was spring 1945 and Pryce-Jones, critic, writer, journalist - and then lieutenant colonel - arrived north of Venice at the British 8th Army headquarters.

We gaped as he and Guards Colonel Jocelyn Gurney filled the officers' mess with London gossip. Then he flitted on to Vienna, where the British wing of the allied commission took over the Hapsburg palace of Schönbrunn. He knew that city well because his then wife Poppy (Thérèse Fould Springer) was of French/Austro-Hungarian Jewish descent and had had extensive property interests. The couple had lived in Vienna before the 1938 Nazi takeover, and, indeed, an administrator had remained to look after the Fould-Springer estates. Alan went to visit those lands in Slovakia, narrowly escaping arrest by the Russians.

He was familiar with what was left of Viennese high society, and also with its writers and musicians. His job at the time was editing a semi-political newsletter for the British occupation. It was not terribly stimulating work, but he was conscientious.

Cultivated and open-minded, Pryce-Jones appeared much more superficial than he was, and his wit was shot through with kindness. The elder son of a colonel, he was educated at Eton and Magdalen College, Oxford, where, by his own account, he wasted his time but made many literary friendships, including John Betjeman, Osbert Lancaster and Anthony Powell.

Suspended for a term after climbing into college late at night, he never returned to Magdalen, and from 1928 to 1932 was assistant editor on the literary paper, the London Mercury, commissioning Betjeman among others, and travelling. In 1931, he published The Spring Journey, about his middle-eastern travels. People In The South, followed in 1932. In 1934, he married Poppy and enjoyed Viennese high life until 1938. Back in Britain year later, he published his novel Pink Danubeunder the pseudonym Arthur Pumphrey.

Then came the war. He served in France with the 4th Hussars, and then as an intelligence staff officer at Bletchley decoding centre. Italy and Vienna followed.

Postwar, Pryce-Jones was proposed by the TLS editor, Stanley Morison, as his successor. Morison, having turned the magazine into something tough and intellectual, handed it over to a serious, hardworking man, whom few outside international Vienna would have recognised. Pryce-Jones became seemingly rooted into the establishment; an Old Vic and National Portrait Gallery trustee, on the Royal College of Music council, a BBC Third Programme broadcaster and librettist of Lennox Berkeley's 1954 opera, Nelson.

Pryce-Jones was, in the best sense of the word, an amateur, but continued the Morison policy of keeping the paper highbrow. Yet, while not stiflingly academic, in academic quarters on both sides of the Atlantic, the TLS carried weight. The anonymity of its reviewers allowed in some surprising writers, whether obscure, bohemian, or supposedly strangers to the subject.

It was Pryce-Jones's talent to run across interesting people and get them writing, but where he really extended the paper's scope was in its for eign reviewing. There were special numbers devoted to American literature, and the United States came to provide an important part of the paper's readership.

He had reliable assistants, fully capable of making up the paper without him - as they had to do when he disappeared to an auction room, only to return weeks later after an official US tour. That was at a time when the choice of reviewers was semi-automatic: books on the US to Denis Brogan, on the Soviet Union to EH Carr, on science to the Times science correspondent, or on psycho-anything to Oliver Zangwill.

In 1953 Poppy died. On retiring from the TLS in 1959, he was the 0bserver's theatre critic for a year. Then he accepted an invitation to become a Ford Foundation adviser in New York. Once, visiting London, he explained that so many million dollars were left in the year's kitty, and they had to be spent before the year's end. How was that solved? "Well, we've commissioned 11 operas. They'll all be very bad."

He parted from the foundation on good terms, and successively from 1963 to 1971 worked as a book critic for the New York Herald Tribune, the World Journal Tribune and Newsday. In 1962 he was lyricist on the Julian Slade musical play of Vanity Fair, in London. In New York, he was Theatre Arts' theatre critic from 1963.

In 1968, he married Mary Jean Kempner Thorne, who died a year later. He lived in a house in Newport, Rhode Island, continued to travel and visit friends, and when ill stayed with his second wife's family in Galveston. His memoirs, The Bonus Of Laughter, were published in 1987. He seemed close to being a Catholic and was converted by Father D'Arcy before his move to the US.

He is survived by his son, David, from his first marriage, and a stepson from his second.

fields.headline: Bonnie Cashin
fields.standfirst: Her designs applied the democratic process to fashion
fields.trailText: Gene Tierney's wardrobe in the 1944 Hollywood film noir, Laura, is like no other of the period. She wore, not costumes for an actress's part, but real clothes that could have been owned by a real woman: separates, a witty raincoat and hat. They, more than the script or playing, suggest Laura chooses what she wears: not to advertise nubility or family wealth but to please herself.
fields.body:
Gene Tierney's wardrobe in the 1944 Hollywood film noir, Laura, is like no other of the period. She wore, not costumes for an actress's part, but real clothes that could have been owned by a real woman: separates, a witty raincoat and hat. They, more than the script or playing, suggest Laura chooses what she wears: not to advertise nubility or family wealth but to please herself.

They were the work of Bonnie Cashin, who has died aged 85. She was born in Oakland, California, designed for the Roxy Theatre in New York at 21, and then created sportswear for Adler & Adler from 1937 to 1943. She was already established when the US apparel market changed during the second world war: women with well-paying wartime jobs bought as many clothes as dearth of materials permitted, spending their income on quality casual wear. Cashin, like her contemporary Clare McCardell, got a big break.

Her ideas had developed along very American lines: mass-production of ready- to-wear clothing in standardised sizes had been invented in the US to uniform the civil war, and was the basis of the 20th-century business in sports and hardwork wear. Many Americans wore it all day, every day; it did not have the low-class connotations of European peasant smocks or servants' uniforms.

European tailoring and dressmaking were at their best when fitted individually, and were intended for display, not physical effort. But from the duster coats of prairie riders (later drivers) to shirtwaists, the female version of a male shirt, there was a tradition of sartorial freedom in America - schoolmarms, lady "typewriters" and telephonists had already shortened working skirts to their ankles by 1900. People wore democracy.

When Cashin showed boots with tweed suits in her 1943 collection, she was looking to America's past and future simultaneously. She claimed to "articulate with the body" rather than encase it; she loosely fitted and wrapped garments; she layered light separates for warmth.

She adopted and adapted anything which intrigued her: ponchos instead of coats; snaps, eyelets, toggles and industrial zippers as fasteners; canvas, jersey and, especially, leather as fabrics. Leather had been used as heavy-duty weatherproof wear in war, motoring and aviation: Cashin used light glove weights, dyed in colours bright as the Thai silks she loved and sewed as if they were fabric.

She was as adventurous with design as materials, again inspired by industrial details - the hooded jacket, the "pocketbook" pocket with a snap closing, the jump suit (outrageous in silk-lined leather in the early 60s), the shoulderbag imitating army ammunition carriers, and the leather tote bag modelled after a paper shopping holdall - now a standard. She was also inspired by ethnic costume, less by its elaborate decoration than by its simple cut.

Her film career at 20th Century Fox (including The Keys Of The Kingdom, 1944, in which she suggested the Chinese location with quilted robes) ended in 1949. The studios adored Dior's new look of 1947 because his excess of skirts, corsetted torsos and high heels were ideal for selling the bodies of movie stars. But Cashin was uncomfortable with the discomfort of that mode, sure that the American woman would never give up slacks, sweaters and unstructured coats.

She returned to Adler, then opened her own house, Bonnie Cashin Designs, in 1952, also creating outerwear for Philip Sills and gloves, bags and raincoats for specialised manufacturers. She sold through boutiques in London and Paris department stores, a commonplace idea now but not in the 50s and 60s. Cashin was famous in the world of Vogue but still a minority public taste in those decades, when democracy in fashion seemed to mean the right of women to dress as if they were a leisured class even when they were not, and to buy many, frequent changes of style.

She founded a new knitwear company in 1971, again concentrating on techniques previously used for folk or workwear, but although the recipient of almost every design honour in the US and Britain, she retreated from the business just as Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Donna Karan turned her ideas into empires. She lived to see her vision vindicated, the world clad in Cashin concepts, fastened with the metal clasps and snaps she pioneered; the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum showed her work in 1997, describing it as " for intrepid and independent women".

Among her charitable enterprises were revitalising the Indian handloom industry in the 50s, and funding the distinguished visitors' lectures at the Californian Institute of Technology to allow artists to talk to scientists. That she also thought was democracy.

fields.headline: Robin Scott
fields.standfirst: BBC mandarin of radio and television
fields.trailText: Robin Scott, who has died at the age of 79, pursued a copybook career in radio, television and video production while maintaining two little skeletons in his executive cupboard. The odder one to lurk in the background of a patrician controller of BBC2, but of which he became increasingly proud, was that he had once been a song-plugger in the music industry. Indeed, he discovered the 1950s pop singer Ruby Murray.
fields.body:
Robin Scott, who has died at the age of 79, pursued a copybook career in radio, television and video production while maintaining two little skeletons in his executive cupboard. The odder one to lurk in the background of a patrician controller of BBC2, but of which he became increasingly proud, was that he had once been a song-plugger in the music industry. Indeed, he discovered the 1950s pop singer Ruby Murray.

The secret he would have preferred to keep, though Huw Wheldon, for one, never tired of spilling it, was that his name wasn't Scott at all, but Scutt.

The son of a clergyman, he was born at Sandgate, Kent, and educated at Bryanston and Jesus College, Cambridge, where he read modern languages. On graduating early in the war, he went into the intelligence corps but was invalided out in 1942.

To put his fluent French to an alternative good use, Scott joined the BBC European service, the nursery of many a distinguished broadcaster. After the war, he remained in radio, except for the foray into the music business. His first television assignment was in 1955, to outside broadcasts, then held to be the embodiment of true live TV. In 1958, he was sent to run the BBC Paris office, followed by a spell as general manager of a rather forgotten enterprise, Trans-Europe Television.

Scott rejoined BBC outside broadcasts in 1965. The following year he was made assistant head of presentation, the department responsible for trailing programmes, ushering them on to the air and generally giving the two BBC channels, as there were by then, their overall personality. In line with the corporation's growing policy of switching key personnel between radio and TV, he was next appointed controller of both Radio 1 and Radio 2, but only a year later, in 1969, was back at Television Centre as controller of BBC2.

The five years Scott spent in this job were probably the most important of his career. Difficult as it may be to be understand now, there had been deep concern among BBC worthies as to how its second service should differ from its first. If it was too highbrow, too few would watch; if it was too popular, that would be just as much a failure - the BBC failing to live up to its promise to provide planned alternatives.

Scott's solution was to aim for 15% of the total audience, but be very happy if he happened to get more. His tenure saw such well-attended classics of the golden age as The Six Wives Of Henry VIII, Elizabeth R, The Search For The Nile, Clochemerle, The Stone Tape, War And Peace, The Ascent Of Man and The Pallisers.

His last BBC role, from 1977-80, was as deputy managing director, television, when he formulated the BBC's attitude to the still-remote prospect of satellite broadcasting. From 1981 to 1990, he was on the board of London Weekend Television, and, from 1991 to 1994, director of productions of NVC Arts, a company specialising in making video records of opera productions. Scott's Who's Who entry relating to this spell reads as a list of international grand- operatic events.

With his swept-back, silvery hair and cosmopolitan aura, he looked the very model of a pre-modern media general. His 1943 marriage to Judy Watson was dissolved in 1960, and the following year he married Patricia AM Smith.

fields.headline: Colin Siddons
fields.trailText: Colin Siddons, who has died aged 86, elevated physics teaching into an art. Winner of the prestigious Bragg medal of the Institute of Physics in 1992, he was one of the most brilliant of a generation who went into teaching out of necessity rather than vocation in the 1930s - and collided with that decade's stuffy, class- ridden society.
fields.body:
Colin Siddons, who has died aged 86, elevated physics teaching into an art. Winner of the prestigious Bragg medal of the Institute of Physics in 1992, he was one of the most brilliant of a generation who went into teaching out of necessity rather than vocation in the 1930s - and collided with that decade's stuffy, class- ridden society.

In 1947, he became head of science at Thornton grammar school, Bradford, where his genius for using common household materials to demonstrate scientific principles was honed. Washing- up bottles, kitchen foil, polystyrene plates, baked bean tins, 78rpm records, dande lion parachutes and pheasant feathers all featured in his Aladdin's cave of physics. His demonstrations were a highlight of the annual meeting of the Association for Science Education. After his retirement in 1968, he continued to teach at Bradford and Leeds universities.

Born into working-class Bradford, Siddons graduated from Cambridge university with first-class honours in physics. Eighty-three job applications and 13 interviews later, he got a teaching post in Devon. His public criticism of the local MP's support for Hitler did not endear him to the governors, and back in Yorkshire, in the wake of the 1938 Munich agreement, he joined the Communist party of Great Britain. After publicly speaking out against the war, in line with early CPGB policy, he was jailed for three months and suspended from teaching. He then spent the war with the 8th Army in the Middle East, learning Russian and teaching fellow soldiers politics, physics and astronomy. Back in Bradford in 1946, his teaching suspension was finally lifted.

Colin's humanism, left-wing politics, and zest for physics and teaching continued to the end of his life. As the Bragg award citation proclaimed: "Colin Siddons, during a lifetime in physics education, consistently produced experiments of wit and ingenuity that simulta neously make difficult principles accessible to the young, and can be extended to tax the most able prospective physicist. As well as delighting thousands of students with his lecture demonstrations, he has illuminated physics for many teachers in revealing his art of teaching".

Siddons's first wife, Joan, was a teacher, and he often tried out new physics experiments with her and their three children. Heartbroken when she died in 1968, he later married Mary, one of Joan's old schoolfriends.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Sir Frank Layfield (Obituary, February 8) joined the Max Lock Group of planning consultants shortly after he graduated from the hothouse of the short planning course at the Association of Planning and Regional Reconstruction that produced so many of the first rank of postwar British town and country planners.
fields.body:
Dr Mike Theis, director of the Max Lock Centre at the University of Westminster, writes:

Sir Frank Layfield (Obituary, February 8) joined the Max Lock Group of planning consultants shortly after he graduated from the hothouse of the short planning course at the Association of Planning and Regional Reconstruction that produced so many of the first rank of postwar British town and country planners.

He came to live with us in West Hartlepool, sharing in our cooperative household in that hard winter of 1946-47. His sense of fun, combined with extensive stretches of long, concentrated work, contributed much to the group's development. The practical application of his planning training to the local provision of educational facilities had a lasting effect.

He then came with us to Portsmouth, and acted as Max Lock's deputy, applying mechanically aided statistical analysis combined with the logical collection of field survey information. This allowed the resolution of the many conflicts inherent in the expansionist policies of Portsmouth into the resistant Hampshire hinterland to be based on sound evidence.

It was only with the decline in the use of planning consultants by new planning authorities after the 1947 Planning Act that Frank changed his profession to that of the law. It was natural that his legal speciality should be in his first skill in which he was so masterful.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Leak wrecked 'star wars test'
fields.body:
Leak wrecked 'star wars test'

A simple plumbing leak of nitrogen apparently caused the failure of last month's $100m (£60m) test over the Pacific of an interceptor for the controversial "star wars" missile defence system which the US is proposing to set up.

But investigators said they were relieved that no significant design problem was behind the test failure January 18. The first test last October succeeded. The third is due in April or May, but may be a few weeks later. Reuters, Washington

African floods hit game park

Torrential rains have filled rivers to their highest level for 50 years and left at least 26 dead in South Africa and tens of thousands homeless in Mozambique so far this week. The heavy rainfalls are due to go on.

Two hundred visitors were cut off by rising waters at the Kruger park, where the animals were also seeking high ground. Reuters, Johannesburg

Hearst case witness dies

A US sports journalist, Jack Scott, has died before being able to testify in the defence of Sara Olson, on trial accused of being part of the Symbionese Liberation Army group that kidnapped Patty Hearst more than 25 years ago. Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles

webTitle: Aux armes, citoyens, but not too bloodily

fields.headline: Aux armes, citoyens, but not too bloodily
fields.trailText: A French singer-songwriter is hoping to replace the bellicose lyrics of the Marseillaise with a more politically correct version that does not threaten to fertilise the fields of France with foreigners' blood.
fields.body:
A French singer-songwriter is hoping to replace the bellicose lyrics of the Marseillaise with a more politically correct version that does not threaten to fertilise the fields of France with foreigners' blood.

Antoine Capella, of Angers, says he has won the support of the speaker of the French parliament, Laurent Fabius, and a former senate president, René Monory, for his composition, Marseillaise de l'an 2000.

"The idea came to me when we won the football world cup," Mr Capella said. "I was with a bunch of friends, we were delirious with joy, roaring out the Marseillaise like everyone else - and I suddenly thought, what on earth am I singing? It's outrageous. It's fascist. In this day and age, it's not right."

The original lyrics were scribbled out overnight by an army captain, Claude-Joseph Rouget de l'Isle, in 1792 while his men were defending Strasbourg from Prussian forces.

They call on Frenchmen to unite under a "bloodstained banner" to mow down the "ferocious foreign soldiers" who have come to "cut the throats of our sons and our wives".

The anthem, known initially as the War Hymn of the Army of the Rhine, acquired its name when 500 troops from Marseille chanted it all the way to Paris. It was declared France's national anthem in 1795 and was written into the constitution in 1879.

Mr Capella said it took him 14 months to come up with a suitable replacement. "The idea isn't to decry the feats of our forebears; the last thing I wanted was to produce some kind of 'peace and love' hymn to the republic," he said. "What I hope my version stresses is the need to preserve the values they fought for; the universal values of the rights of man."

One part of the original proclaims:

March! March!
That [their] impure blood
May drench our furrows!
Mr Capella's version offers the gentler:
March! March!
That an azure sky
May shine on the horizon

La Marseillaise

webTitle: Anger at plan to exhume Saro-Wiwa

fields.headline: Anger at plan to exhume Saro-Wiwa
fields.trailText: The family of the executed Nigerian writer, Ken Saro-Wiwa, is at odds with the organisation he once led over plans to exhume and rebury him and eight other Ogoni activists hanged after a show trial in 1995.
fields.body:
The family of the executed Nigerian writer, Ken Saro-Wiwa, is at odds with the organisation he once led over plans to exhume and rebury him and eight other Ogoni activists hanged after a show trial in 1995.

Saro-Wiwa's eldest son, Ken Wiwa, has objected to the creation of a "burial committee" by the present leaders of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop). The committee, which had tried to take charge of the reburial of the "Ogoni martyrs", is backed by families of some of the other executed men.

In a statement from his home in Canada, Ken Wiwa said he was "deeply offended and insulted" that Mosop had not consulted his family. Mr Wiwa said his father left a will with specific instructions about his funeral and that the family had its own plans to rebury him on April 24.

The dispute flared up after Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, gave permission for the bodies of the nine men buried in anonymous graves in a Port Harcourt cemetery to be returned to their families.

Some members of Mosop believe that as Ken Saro-Wiwa was hanged as the movement's leader, Mosop should control the funeral arrangements.

The Wiwa family has itself been criticised by relatives of the other executed men for asking American pathologists to exhume and identify the remains. Some relatives say they were not consulted, while others say they want compensation from the government, and that the best way to keep attention on the issue is to leave the bodies where they are.

Esther Kiobel, widow of Barinem Kiobel, has criticised both sides. She claims the Wiwa family failed to seek her permission to exhume her husband, and accuses Mosop of trying to make political capital from the reburials.

"The different versions of the burial arrangements and the gimmicks, tricks, politicking, manipulations and dehumanisation of some elements in Mosop leave much to be desired," she said. "These people who gave their lives for the survival of the Ogoni people are now being used by some people to gain cheap political fame and for profit."

But Ken Wiwa insisted that the other families were consulted about the exhumations and that "the offer was warmly received and accepted".

Saro-Wiwa's relatives asked Physicians for Human Rights (PHR) to identify the hanged Ogonis but the organisation postponed the exhumation after the other families protested.

Saro-Wiwa was tried by a military tribunal for the murders of four Ogoni chiefs killed by a mob after they fell out with the Mosop leadership.

The tribunal convicted Saro-Wiwa of murder even though there was no evidence that he was present or gave orders for the killings. But the widows of the four murdered chiefs blamed him for creating a climate of intolerance and for the vilification of anyone who disagreed with his strategy.

fields.headline: Immigrants still fearful despite clam
fields.trailText: A small army of riot police yesterday tried to restore law and order in the southern Spanish agricultural town of El Ejido, torn apart by three days of violent clashes between white   locals and immigrant workers from north Africa.
fields.body:
A small army of riot police yesterday tried to restore law and order in the southern Spanish agricultural town of El Ejido, torn apart by three days of violent clashes between white locals and immigrant workers from north Africa.

As police began to arrest the ringleaders, who provoked a frenzy of racist hatred against the immigrants, ministers defended themselves from criticism that they had acted too late and ineffectually to protect them.

Some 50 people, mainly Moroccans, were injured in the riots which followed the arrest of a mentally unstable Moroccan man who admitted killing a local woman. Acrid smoke from fires which destroyed a plastics factory and petrol station hung over the town. Schools and shops remained closed while police cleared barricades and burnt out vehicles.

Red Cross workers distributed food parcels and tried to reassure north Africans, who make up a third of the town's population, that they would now be safe. But one man, who crouched in terror for 48 hours in his shanty, said he just wanted to leave. "It's amazing I'm still alive," he added. "How can they blame all of us for the action of one madman?"

The Moroccan government expressed concern, while many Spaniards, shocked out of the conviction that their country is one of the most tolerant in Europe, focused on the authorities' apparent reluctance to protect the immigrants.

The interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, denied that the delay in deploying enough police could have been linked to next month's general election. "There may have been errors," he said. "But our objective was to stop the clashes degenerating into full pitched battle."

Immigrant support groups called the situation in El Ejido, a centre for intensive year-round farming dependent on north African labourers, "a time bomb waiting to explode".

"The immigrants live in conditions of virtual slavery," explained Juan Goytisolo, a novelist. "They have no rights."

fields.headline: Inside tracks
fields.standfirst: Accusations of improper share dealing have ignited a tabloid war. But the truth about insider trading, says  James Buchan, is that it's hard to define, easy to refute and all but impossible to prove
fields.trailText: Accusations of improper share dealing have ignited a tabloid war. But the truth about insider trading is that it's hard to define, easy to refute and all but impossible to prove.
fields.body:
It takes just a couple of insider dealing stories to revive the old terror among the middling sort of British share owners: that the City of London is a club that makes its living from price-sensitive information outside investors only hear of when it is stale.

The latest panic over perceived misuse of privileged information began when it emerged that Mirror editor Piers Morgan had invested in a stock just before his paper's City pages advised readers to invest in the company. The Morgan story has since degenerated into a tabloid dust-up, with the Sun and Mirror daily swapping fresh allegations of dodgy dealing by the other's journalists - yesterday, it was the Mirror's turn to accuse The Sun's business editor of plugging shares he holds (an allegation the Sun promptly denied with the promise of a libel action).

Meanwhile, it was reported at the weekend that Christina Green, wife of the Monaco-based entrepreneur Philip Green, had bought shares in Marks & Spencer in December just before her husband announced he was thinking of buying the company.

In themselves, these cases do not tell us much. All parties deny wrongdoing. Morgan insists it was mere coincidence that he bought £20,000 of stock in Viglen Technology, just before the Mirror's City Slickers column tipped the shares. The bull market in company values has been going on, with one or two interruptions, since 1982 - everybody, and that includes journalists on the Mirror, think they have a right to capital gains. Morgan has since sold the shares and donated his profit to charity but the case is being investigated by the London Stock Exchange and the Press Complaints Commission.

As for Christina Green, she was evidently not investing in Marks & Spencer in the knowledge that her husband would launch an offer and the shares go up. (A takeover bid is made at a premium or supplement to the share price of at least 10% and usually more, otherwise shareholders have no incentive to sell to the bidder. That is why most cases of insider dealing arise in takeovers.)

She was, according to her husband's advisers, acting as a member of what the takeover panel calls a "concert party". A concert party, as everybody knows, must submit its shares to the bidder at cost.

This explanation has been accepted by M&S and it is understood that there is now no suggestion of impropriety by either of the Greens. The couple are aggrieved that M&S's advisers apparently revealed Christina Green's transaction to the weekend press. Yet all that tells us is that the battle for control of Marks & Spencer will be very, very personal.

Insider dealing, usually known in the US as insider trading, is hard to define, easy to deny and all but impossible to prove. There are very few takeover bids that are not signalled by a rise in the target company's shares, and the London Stock Exchange investigates about 20 cases a month - almost always to no avail. Integrated securities firms are supposed to operate invisible barriers to prevent takeover information leaking from the merger specialists to the dealing room across the way. Their very name - Chinese walls - suggests permeability.

Ultra-liberal theorists, such as those who used to be found on the editorial pages of the Wall Street Journal, liked to argue that there is nothing very much wrong with making a buck on inside information. Under the British Takeover Code, all people privy to price-sensitive information at the companies involved are bound to keep it secret, but in a large takeover bid that can mean dozens and dozens of people. According to reports from the US, details of three of January's large corporate mergers - America Online and Time Warner, EMI and Warner Music, and Procter & Gamble's unsuccessful deal with Warner-Lambert - were leaked on internet message boards run by Yahoo!, the internet service company, well before the companies announced the deals.

When a company official, a banker, lawyer, stockbroker or, as in recent cases, a temping pastrycook, secretary, printer, actress in adult films, companion of same, or journalist make capital gains from dealing on information the public doesn't have, it is not easy at first to see who actually suffers. In the cant phrase, insider dealing is a "victimless crime". The theoretical victims are, in no particular order, the principle of equality in share ownership, the good name of the stock market, public confidence in financial assets or the Mirror, the efficient allocation of capital, risk sharing and market volatility. Not exactly to die for.

Meanwhile, it is sometimes difficult to divide public information from what is non-public or privileged. For all that, as a US securities official once said to me: "Insider traders know when they are breaking the law, even when nobody else does." Or as one of my editors said: "If you know something about a share, don't deal in it. Just don't deal."

The notion that dealing on privileged information is wicked and punishable goes back to the great bull market of the 1920s. The shock of the 1929 crash and the severity of the depression set off a reaction against Wall Street. The senate convened hearings into Wall Street practice by a special counsel, Ferdinand Pecora. In the course of Pecora's brilliant cross-examination, brokers and bankers were revealed as mere crooks. The American public listened spellbound to tales of inside information and stock-price manipulation. In rage, congress passed the securities exchange act of 1934, which set up a new federal agency, the securities and exchange commission (SEC), to stamp out those practices. Corresponding criminal statutes were also enacted.

Their moment came in the 80s bull market when, in late 1986, a notorious stock speculator named Ivan Boesky turned state's evidence and began to spill details of widespread insider trading to the enforcement division of the SEC. Entranced, Rudolph Giuliani, the present mayor of New York City but then a campaigning US attorney in lower Manhattan, decided that Wall Street was an Augean Stables that he was destined to muck out. He sent the police in to lead out weeping stockbrokers in handcuffs. Those strong-arm tactics backfired but the SEC has continued to regulate the US securities markets with a mixture of bullying and blandishment. No one wants trouble with the SEC. As a commission official once explained to me long ago, insider traders are nice enough people with a strong fear of jail who can be persuaded to settle their cases with a fine, the disgorging of their profits and expulsion from the securities industry.

Back in 1986, the SEC communicated to British investigators Boesky's account of a dealing ring in the shares of the drinks company then known as Guinness. The gaoling of the Guinness defendants, including the chief executive Ernest Saunders, are the only significant convictions for insider dealing made in this country. A witness such as Boesky does not come along every day.

Yet in May, 1998, Alistair Darling, then chief secretary to the treasury, announced that the government would crack down on insider dealing. Out would go those hard-to-convince juries, baffled by the complexities of securities fraud. In would come a civil enforcement agency on the pattern of the SEC within the City super-regulator, the financial services authority. Two and a half years later, and all but defeated by the challenge of harmonising a modern US-style securities police with European human-rights law, this British SEC is still a way from coming into existence.

Does that mean a field day for the insider traders? Probably no more than usual. In highly speculative markets such as internet company flotations, there is very little hard information or indeed hard anything: much of what passes on internet bulletin boards for fact is just profitable bull.

Whatever outsiders think, the City of London has probably never been a cosy insiders' club. In my lifetime, it has been the scene of rising and falling fortunes, jealousies, personal rivalries and grinding competition at every level. It's this competition that leads City people to rat on each other, and it is the competition - in newspapers, in retailing - that has helped to embarrass Morgan and Christina Green.

James Buchan's history of money, Frozen Desire, is published by Picador.

Under the British Takeover Code, all people privy to price-sensitive information at the companies involved are bound to keep it secret, but in a large takeover bid that can mean dozens and dozens of people. According to reports from the US, details of three of January's large corporate mergers - America Online and Time Warner, EMI and Warner Music, and Procter & Gamble's unsuccessful deal with Warner-Lambert - were leaked on internet message boards run by Yahoo!, the internet service company, well before the companies announced the deals. When a company official, a banker, lawyer, stockbroker or, as in recent cases, a temping pastrycook, secretary, printer, actress in adult films, companion of same, or journalist make capital gains from dealing on information the public doesn't have, it is not easy at first to see who actually suffers. In the cant phrase, insider dealing is a "victimless crime". The theoretical victims are, in no particular order, the principle of equality in share ownership, the good name of the stock market, public confidence in financial assets or the Mirror, the efficient allocation of capital, risk sharing and market volatility. Not exactly to die for. Meanwhile, it is sometimes difficult to divide public information from what is non-public or privileged. For all that, as a US securities official once said to me: "Insider traders know when they are breaking the law, even when nobody else does." Or as one of my editors said: "If you know something about a share, don't deal in it. Just don't deal." The notion that dealing on privileged information is wicked and punishable goes back to the great bull market of the 1920s. The shock of the 1929 crash and the severity of the depression set off a reaction against Wall Street. The senate convened hearings into Wall Street practice by a special counsel, Ferdinand Pecora. In the course of Pecora's brilliant cross-examination, brokers and bankers were revealed as mere crooks. The American public listened spellbound to tales of inside information and stock-price manipulation. In rage, congress passed the securities exchange act of 1934, which set up a new federal agency, the securities and exchange commission (SEC), to stamp out those practices. Corresponding criminal statutes were also enacted. Their moment came in the 80s bull market when, in late 1986, a notorious stock speculator named Ivan Boesky turned state's evidence and began to spill details of widespread insider trading to the enforcement division of the SEC. Entranced, Rudolph Giuliani, the present mayor of New York City but then a campaigning US attorney in lower Manhattan, decided that Wall Street was an Augean Stables that he was destined to muck out. He sent the police in to lead out weeping stockbrokers in handcuffs. Those strong-arm tactics backfired but the SEC has continued to regulate the US securities markets with a mixture of bullying and blandishment. No one wants trouble with the SEC. As a commission official once explained to me long ago, insider traders are nice enough people with a strong fear of jail who can be persuaded to settle their cases with a fine, the disgorging of their profits and expulsion from the securities industry. Back in 1986, the SEC communicated to British investigators Boesky's account of a dealing ring in the shares of the drinks company then known as Guinness. The gaoling of the Guinness defendants, including the chief executive Ernest Saunders, are the only significant convictions for insider dealing made in this country. A witness such as Boesky does not come along every day. Yet in May, 1998, Alistair Darling, then chief secretary to the treasury, announced that the government would crack down on insider dealing. Out would go those hard-to-convince juries, baffled by the complexities of securities fraud. In would come a civil enforcement agency on the pattern of the SEC within the City super-regulator, the financial services authority. Two and a half years later, and all but defeated by the challenge of harmonising a modern US-style securities police with European human-rights law, this British SEC is still a way from coming into existence. Does that mean a field day for the insider traders? Probably no more than usual. In highly speculative markets such as internet company flotations, there is very little hard information or indeed hard anything: much of what passes on internet bulletin boards for fact is just profitable bull. Whatever outsiders think, the City of London has probably never been a cosy insiders' club. In my lifetime, it has been the scene of rising and falling fortunes, jealousies, personal rivalries and grinding competition at every level. It's this competition that leads City people to rat on each other, and it is the competition - in newspapers, in retailing - that has helped to embarrass Morgan and Christina Green. James Buchan's history of money, Frozen Desire, is published by Picador.

webTitle: Liberty in doubt:  Was she modelled on a black woman?

fields.headline: Liberty in doubt:  Was she modelled on a black woman?
fields.trailText: The statue of liberty has stood for generations as a symbol of hope for immigrants. And official history notes that the 151ft high monument was proposed by the historian Edouard de Laboulaye to mark the friendship forged between France and the US during the revolutionary war, writes Michael Ellison .
fields.body:
The statue of liberty has stood for generations as a symbol of hope for immigrants. And official history notes that the 151ft high monument was proposed by the historian Edouard de Laboulaye to mark the friendship forged between France and the US during the revolutionary war, writes Michael Ellison .

But now national park service researchers are examining whether it had more to do with reminding people of rather less willing immigrants, slaves, and the possibility that Lady Liberty was modelled on a black woman.

De Laboulaye, who put forward the idea of the statue at a dinner party in Paris in 1865, was prominent in the French movement to abolish slavery, said Diane Dayson, the statue's superintendent. "Our history states that he was an abolitionist but we don't know whether it was relative to the Statue of Liberty. The important thing for us is to validate the history one way or another."

Rebecca Joseph, a park service anthropologist, is looking into the theory that the statue might have been based on a black woman by following a clue in the museum of the city of New York. The institution has a 21in model by the statue's creator, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, completed 16 years before Lady Liberty was erected in 1886, that shows her with a broken chain around her hand rather than the more modest severed shackles on a foot of the final version in New York harbour.

The case was reopened when an unsourced internet text was unearthed, saying that "the original model was a black woman".

But Ms Joseph, who is due to release a final report in the summer, offered little hope for optimism among the revisionists or the traditionalists that their views about the statue's creation are right. "History is much more complicated than that. It's not a soundbite."

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Would Britain be a different place if children had the right to vote, as the think tank Demos proposed this week?
fields.trailText: The Question: Would Britain be a different place if children had the right to vote, as the think tank Demos proposed this week?
fields.body:
Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East
I'd like to see the voting age reduced to 16. In fact I'm hoping to introduce a 10-minute-rule bill on it soon. At 16 you can work, pay taxes, marry - why shouldn't you vote? And it's interesting to think about what issues younger children might be interested in. I do question and answer sessions in schools, and I'm constantly amazed by how mature and well informed young people are. One of the differences they bring, of course, is their longer perspective on life. So as well as the environment, they ask me about issues like provision of contraception and law and order.

Helen Rimington, solicitor with the Children's Legal Centre
There's certainly some evidence that children would be happier. Research shows that they feel alienated from the political process and would enjoy the chance to play a greater role. It's often said that children are "the future", but it's important to remember that they're part of the present, too, and that they'd appreciate the chance to have a say on the issues that directly affect them, such as education and the smacking debate. You might well see a difference in, for example, crime figures if children felt more included in society.

Sarah Cramp, 16, sixth-former from Leicestershire
I'd be dubious about giving children the right to vote - you get some very mature 14-year-olds, but you get a lot of immature ones as well. Of course, you could say that about adults, too! As for what would be different, environmental issues would get a lot more weight. Fossil fuels and renewable energy sources have far bigger implications for someone of my age than for a 50-year-old. But I don't know whether things would really change, because depending on what age you gave children the right to vote, they'd still only make up a small proportion of voters.

Francesca Stocks, 9, schoolgirl from South London
Children would be very concerned about issues they know a lot about and that affect them. We are told at school about people in poor countries, and if we could vote we'd want to do things to help them. People like me are concerned about animals, too - if we could vote, we'd be interested in them being well looked-after. I think there should also be a law about drivers having to slow down when they see a child on a bike. And parents shouldn't have to work such long hours - it isn't fair to them or us. A girl I know hardly ever sees her mum because she has to work so hard.

Sian Mathias, mother of three and social work consultant
Politics would be more radical. Children are much more idealistic and are quite intolerant of adults telling them something can't happen. They wouldn't be prepared to accept that we have to sell weapons, for example - they don't accept the muddled complications adults bring into play. Services would be more child-centred, and children would prioritise reform of the legal system, because the language and dress there don't make sense to them. But they'd be susceptible to personalities - independent candidates might have a better chance than mainstream politicians.

Helen Wilkinson, editor of Family Business (published this week by Demos)
What I'd suggest is that each child has a vote, but that the vote is cast in proxy by a parent until, say, the age of 16, when it transfers to the child. I'm advocating this because I believe it would weight the electoral process in a more child-orientated and therefore far-sighted way. It would also be about consciousness-raising, because politicians would have to give more thought to the needs of parents and families. It would bring to the fore issues such as parental leave, transport policy, road safety, childcare and how we organise our communities and our homes.

fields.headline: Bogeyman in the nursery
fields.standfirst: As David Irving is accused of racism over a ditty he used to sing to his baby daughter,  Lyn Gardner  mines the seam of bigotry and hatred in children's songs and stories
fields.trailText: As David Irving is accused of racism over a ditty he used to sing to his baby daughter,  Lyn Gardner  mines the seam of bigotry and hatred in children's songs and stories.
fields.body:
Last week in the high court David Irving was accused of being a racist. The historian, who is seeking damages over claims that he is a "holocaust denier", rejected the allegation. But he did admit, among other things, that as he wheeled his nine-month-old daughter past what he calls "half-breed" children, he would sing:

I'm a baby Aryan

Not Jewish or sectarian.

I have no plans to marry an

Ape or Rastafarian.

Irving is not alone in bringing prejudice, politics and fear into the nursery. Over the centuries rhyme, lullaby, fairy story, folk tale and children's literature have all been used as tools, particularly to force obedience on children, but also to demonise political enemies and those who are held in fear by the community. It is not so great a leap from the generic bogeyman who abducts children to the demonised image of the child-snatching Jew living next door. And who knows how many deaths these tainted stories might have been responsible for in times gone by?

Each generation selects and reinterprets the tales and rhymes to reflect its own anxieties and concerns. As the critic Carolyn G Heilbrun has observed: "Out of old tales we must make new lives." So we retell Beauty and the Beast from a feminist perspective and remake the children's TV favourite The Flowerpot Men with Little Weed as a feisty role-model for small girls. We excise Golly from Noddy and give Georgie Porgie, Pudding and Pie the push from the playground.

But some stories escape the axe. The Grimms' Jew in the Thornbush - a vicious, anti-semitic and supposedly comic tale in which the Jew ends up in the bramble bush with his eyes put out - is included in the current editon of Nursery and Household Tales. And the Welsh, too, are still seen as fair game. The rhyme that begins "Taffy was a Welshman, Taffy was a thief" was included in a treasury my daughter was given recently.

Plenty of parents would not worry about this, dismissing accusations of prejudice by saying that these are old rhymes and tales whose meanings are lost in antiquity. But in fact many of these stories and rhymes have continuously been rewritten and reworked, becoming in each incarnation a reflection of the society in which they appear. The counting rhyme "eeny meeny miny mo, catch a nigger by his toe" only became popular in that form around the time of the second world war, and is possibly linked to the arrival of the first black GIs in Britain. In its original English form the rhyme goes "catch a tinker by his toe". Black people, gypsies - both are obvious targets as the outcast and the bogeyman. My mother did indeed tell me that I shouldn't play with the gypsies in the wood.

To teach these things in the cradle is to risk raising children who will take the prejudices of the past with them into the future. Though not, of course, according to Irving. When it was put to him by QC Richard Rampton that the ditty he was teaching his tiny child was "poison", Irving defended himself by saying: "Do you think a nine-month-old can understand?" But how do nine-month-olds learn about the world except through what they see and hear?

But while we can excise what doesn't reflect our own vision of the world around us, we cannot excise our own fear. The world of the parent in lullaby and fairytale is an anxious one, where the cradle is always just about to fall. In Maurice Sendak's Outside over There, published only 20 years ago, the goblins steal Ida's baby sister just as surely as the Snow Queen snatches Kai and takes him to her icy palace.

In a world where children are ferried everywhere in cars and not allowed to play in the street, fairytales retain their power to socialise children to fit in with adult fears. The moral of Little Red Riding Hood has never been more potent: step outside the safety of your own home and the big bad wolf will gobble you up.

These stories are infinitely malleable and can be used in whatever way the parent decides. But if the tales have changed over the years then so has their audience. In a primary school where 18 different languages are spoken by the children, the concept of who is an outsider and who is part of the community is very different from that of a Black Forest hamlet 400 years ago - the world of the brothers Grimm. If we cannot make these old tales and rhymes relevant to us today then we must make our own. As Iona and Peter Opie have proved from their extensive studies of playground lore, children do it naturally all the time with songs and skipping games.

Yet what is interesting is the way that the bogeymen of one generation sometimes hold no fear for the next. My parent's generation found the Hammer horror films scary; mine perceives them as no more than campy spoofs. As a child, I found Heinrich Hoffman's Struwwelpeter, originally written as a send-up of all those 19th-century cautionary tales in which bad children came to swift ends, unbearably frightening. "The Scissorman will get you," admonished my mother when I bit my fingernails, and I thought he really would. My own children get the penny dreadful joke and greet these tales of Harriet who played with matches and Augustus who would not have any soup with gales of laughter. The witch in Hansel and Gretel holds no fear for them because their wider reading informs them that Matilda will defeat Miss Trunchbull and that Max will tame the Wild Things and still get home in time for supper. Times have certainly changed, and in modern fairy tales, the child is protagonist, not the passive victim of the bogeyman.

Even so, the old tales and rhymes will almost certainly live on. Marina Warner, whose excellent book No Go the Bogeyman, has just been issued in paperback (Vantage, £10.99), believes that they still have a place in modern society and may even perform a vital function. Like a safety valve, they allow us to confront our bogeymen without physically attacking them. "The danger comes when the fantasy is no longer seen as a fantasy, but as true." David Irving, take note.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Four years ago a California man, still unidentified, donated his sperm to one of the US's largest sperm banks, cashed his cheque, and went on with his life. He had no idea that soon he would be making history.
fields.body:
He might have been a university undergraduate looking to pay off his student loans, or a low-income guy trying to pay his rent. Four years ago a California man, still unidentified, donated his sperm to one of the US's largest sperm banks, cashed his cheque, and went on with his life.

He had no idea that soon he would be making history. But three American women, all members of the support group Single Mothers by Choice (SMC) became pregnant using his sperm, and all three gave birth to a set of twins.

Two sets were delivered on the west coast, one on the east. This should have been the end of the story, except recently, in a playground in California, something happened that confounded the oddsmakers. The women met each other. Their children met each other. And for the first time in the US, three sets of twin half-siblings sharing the same sperm donor played together, while their mothers sat back amazed at how much they looked alike.

"With the supply of donors limited and the number of single mothers growing, you assume there are half-siblings who share the same sperm donor all over the place," says Jane Mattes, the director of SMC (which also has a UK branch). "I knew it was only a matter of time before mothers would try to find those siblings, to give their children, who don't have a father, a sense of a larger family."

Four years ago Mattes started a sibling registry for members of SMC, in which they could register the sperm bank and donation number of their child's anonymous father, in the hope of matching half-siblings. Initially, few mothers signed up. Too daunting, says Mattes. But in the past six months, women have been clamouring to list their children, including the startled but thrilled trio of mothers with twins. So what happened?

"When we started the registry, the mothers had newborns. It wasn't an issue. But now the children are four and five, and mothers are starting to think seriously about things such as medical emergencies. What if they need blood, or an organ donation?

"But the real impetus is that their children are starting to ask questions. They ask about fathers, about siblings - and I think finding a half-sibling for them is a way of giving them another piece of family."

Mattes says 95% of the mothers who discovered that there were other children with the same sperm-donor father as their own child have arranged to meet "the other woman" and her child.

"Of those, 90% want to continue meeting on a regular basis. Only 10% found the meeting too stressful and backed off."

webTitle: Should you move to the country for the sake of the kids?

fields.headline: Should you move to the country for the sake of the kids?
fields.standfirst: Three mothers who left the city behind give their verdict.
fields.trailText: Three mothers who left the city behind give their verdict.
fields.body:
'Who's the odd one out?' Henrietta's story.

When I left London with my five-year-old daughter, I was stressed and frustrated, with little time to spend with Ngaio and none for myself. I was sure that the cleaner air and green spaces would be good for us both. And at first it seemed like the right move. I worked from home, and money went further than before. There was no commuting, noise or dirt to sap our energy. On a good day, our new home was close to paradise. But it soon became clear that, for us, there were particular drawbacks.

This was a deeply rural area, our little town: one short street of shops; two hours' drive from the nearest large town. As a Londoner who had loved living in black and Irish Harlesden, I missed cultural variety, but my mixed-race daughter missed it more acutely. Her primary school in London had had 60 nationalities on its books. Here, the local population was uniformly white and Ngaio was the only black face in the school. She was very tall for her age, but soon began to pretend to be half her size; she has been chatty, but became inarticulate. She longed for long straight hair and white skin and ankle socks. Ominously, her teachers began to describe her as noisy and attention-seeking, whereas those in London had told me that she was an asset to the class; helpful, honest, confident.

We visited the doctor when Ngaio began to suffer regular, severe stomach pains, almost certainly exacerbated by stress. He kicked off our first meeting with "So how do you pronounce this kind of name anyway?" After giving my six-year-old daughter a shockingly intrusive examination, he turned to me and said: "So I suppose she's adopted."

It took Ngaio three months to admit just how difficult it was at school, eventually telling me on Christmas Eve after wetting the bed for the first time in her life. Any new friend asked to tea was taunted with "You're going out with a black girl", resulting in an isolation that was devastating for a sociable child. When I brought the bullying to the school's attention - with examples of her being surrounded and punched, or being the daily butt of apparently harmless jokes such as "who's the odd one out in our school photo?" - I was told there was no bullying in the school and that Ngaio 's difficulties were of her own making. What's more, they added, my own "aggressive political stance" was "more appropriate to an inner-city ghetto". When people say, wistfully, that visiting the country is like stepping back in time, they are not wrong.

It didn't take long before I realised that, for all the disadvantages of city life, a multicultural environment would be a much healthier place for my daughter - and indeed, for any child. I was reluctant to uproot her again, but after four years, the pressure on her to be someone she is not had left its mark. She was ashamed of her colour, her size. We moved to Bristol, and within weeks she blossomed: happy at school, lots of friends, teachers who praised her.

When I ask her if she thinks moving to the country was a mistake, she says, "well, not for you", and she's right. I needed the space and time to take stock, and am a better mother for it. But she thinks it was a mistake for her. When we left London, I hoped that she would develop a sense of how people live outside urban areas. She did, but not in the way I had hoped.

'I was confined to our five acres' Maureen's story.

It was a brown shingle house with six bedrooms, three porches and a ballroom. It sat on five acres in a picturesque village in northeastern Connecticut. It had been built in 1912 by an artist with a "thing" about light. Almost every room had windows facing north, east, south and west. We fell in love with it the moment we walked through the door; when we found out what it was going for, we almost lost our minds with joy. "Think what a house this size would cost in San Francisco," we said, San Francisco being where we lived at the time. But not for much longer.

We'd come around to the idea that it just wasn't the place for bringing up children. You had to be a millionaire to have a house with a garden. You had to have eyes like a hawk when you went to a playground, because of all the paedophiles doing tai chi outside the gates. And the competition for nursery schools was horrendous. And so we said goodbye to our Russian Hill flat, and went off to live the dream.

We arrived in the middle of the first February blizzard. About 19 others followed. We would wake up in the morning and look at the freshly fallen snow on the Scotch pines outside and marvel at the quiet. When I looked out the window while doing the dishes, the floor, or the laundry, I would imagine the rolling, empty lawn as it might be in five or 10 years' time, filled with our laughing children and their friends.

But at the time we had only one toddler, and I couldn't find a single friend for him, and believe me, I tried. The social scene was, I soon discovered, very much tied up with which church you went to. I would have had every inch of my diary pencilled in, had I become a Mormon, an Episcopalean, or a follower of the Swami Sachidinanda. Left to my own devices, I became pathologically dependent on my favourite television programmes. A friend later told me that she became very concerned for me after she visited me and I spent the whole weekend talking about Renko from Hill Street Blues as if he was a personal friend. I began to get worried myself when I hired a local teenager to do some babysitting. She came into the kitchen just as I was buttering sliced bread: her jaw dropped as she gasped, 'You don't bake your own bread?'

No, I didn't, I told her. To myself, I vowed I never would. But no matter how hard I tried to keep my domestic standards low, my life was becoming more traditional every day. I had no life outside my family and home. Because there was nowhere else I could walk without trespassing on someone else's property, I was confined to our own five acres. The most exciting event of my week was the car trip to the supermarket. I got lonelier and lonelier. My phone bills soared but couldn't fill the emptiness inside me. Eventually, we declared defeat and sold the place.

Four of the 11 houses I've lived in since then were technically in the countryside. But these are my rules: never more than 17 miles from a city. Once the children hit 10, and unless you want to spend six hours a day chauffeuring them between parties, never live in any place that is not connected to that city by a regular bus service. Never let a day pass without going to that city. For me, the road to hell is lined with swaying trees.

'This morning we saw daffodils' Rebecca's story.

Our family moved out of London on a whim. I had been completely unprepared for the difference the birth of a child would make to me. As an editor for a London publisher, I resented pregnancy and spent the first weeks of my maternity leave calling the office every day. It dawned on me only slowly that a baby needs time and attention, and even more slowly that some of that attention must come from me. When I went back to work it was part-time. But I'm not a great one for compromise (and neither is the publishing industry). It was quickly clear that no one was very happy with the arrangement.

Meanwhile, what had once given London its buzz had begun to seem materialistic and aggressive. Planes roared overhead; cars beeped along the road; music blared out at odd hours. In the streets people in designer clothes shouted into their mobile phones with glazed looks in their eyes. My designer clothes were dotted with baby sick. I never put the roof down on our soft-top because it didn't seem safe for the baby. Living at the centre of things was a memory since we never went out any more. Walking with the pushchair, I became obsessed that my baby's head was at the level of all the car exhaust pipes. So when we went to Wales on holiday I was feeling restless. The sun shone, the birds sang, wild flowers nodded along the lanes. We put the roof down on the car - no traffic. We wandered on to the mountains behind the house leaving the door unlocked. The baby, always wakeful in London, breathed the fresh air and slept for 12 hours four nights on the trot. Three months later we'd agreed the sale of our Richmond terrace, and the purchase of a dilapidated farmhouse in Powys.

We had lots of practical considerations when choosing our rural idyll. I wanted to be within walking distance of some amenities. We didn't want to have to drive miles every day when the children started school. But I wanted space and beauty. The house we found is a mile from Brecon, a small market town with a few good schools, a cathedral, theatre, cinema, and shops which, in an old-fashioned way, will sell you anything and everything.

These days when I go into town with my children and two-year-old Flora wanders briefly out of sight I have no need to worry; the shopkeepers know us and will keep an eye on her. It has never occurred to me to tell her that she shouldn't talk to adults. At nursery school, Flo meets children from a wider range of backgrounds than, I suspect, she would in fee-paying Richmond. There's not much wealth in this mainly agricultural area, and people work hard, but quality of life is not only about income.

This morning I wandered outside with Flora, spotting snowdrops and half-emerged daffodils in the garden. We went to say hello to the horse in the field across the lane. As we walked back a rabbit bolted into the brambles, making us jump; while searching for it, we discovered a hen pheasant hiding in the undergrowth. Before we got to the house Flo wanted to visit the lambs in the barn. It all took about 10 minutes.

In a year or two she will go for such walks on her own, roaming freely in a way few Londoners can imagine. It can't help but give a child confidence and independence, or stimulate the imagination, more than any expensive, organised activity could.

No doubt as teenagers my daughters will complain of boredom, and want to spread their wings. My hope is that, when they do, their country childhood will give them a sense of rootedness they'll keep for ever.

 Richard Bacon
fields.trailText: Ah yes, the fresh-faced ex-presenter of children's favourite Blue Peter: The very same.
fields.body:
Ah yes, the fresh-faced ex-presenter of children's favourite Blue Peter: The very same.

And remind me what became of him? Your short-term memory's playing up again. He was sacked from Biddy Baxter's happy family in 1998 - a small matter of a Sunday tabloid exposing his more excitable recreational habits.

Do what? "BLUE PETER GOODY GOODY IS A COCAINE-SNORTING SNEAK" shrieked the headline, over a piece in which he boasted of having "been on an adventure" while "sniffing two wraps" in a London nightclub. Cue abundant grinding of teeth and an enforced career hiatus.

But now he's back? Yup. As the BBC explained while announcing his new project, "Richard made a mistake and has paid a heavy price."

What, £60 a gram? No, having to spend the last year as Johnny Vaughan's understudy on The Big Breakfast.

That'll be Johnny Vaughan, convicted cocaine dealer? It will. Anyway, having completed his stint in small-screen rehab, Bacon is now launching his own yoof-TV show, Sussed.

Sorted. No, you fool, that's the title. Aimed at teenage voters, it's designed to give "young adults a voice on issues that affect their lives" (like how to explain those constant nosebleeds to your mum). You know, snorting up the facts from the media mirror with the trusty razorblade of truth. That sort of thing.

And who can we expect as guests? Diego Maradona? George Bush Jr? No, but they've got Paul Boateng (not quite the same, is it?).

Do say: "Haven't you ever thought (sniff), right (sniff), that we should (sniff) do that thing we were talking about (sniff), right, and (sniff) just, you know, (sniff) do that, and then, right (sniff), if we did that (sniff), right (sniff), then that'd be really cool (sniff). Do you know what I mean?" (sniff).

Don't say: "Sorry, have you got a cold?"

fields.headline: The price of crying rape
fields.standfirst: She claimed her colleague raped her, but seemed to be working happily with him days after the alleged attack. She said he continued to harass her, but signed his get-well card. It may not be surprising that a libel jury decided she was a liar. But did Lynn Walker deserve financial ruin, and was it right for the judge to deny her anonymity?  Nicci Gerrard  and  Clare Dyer  report on the treacherous business of examining dark and complex allegations in the bright, unforgiving glare of the courts
fields.trailText: She claimed her colleague raped her, but seemed to be working happily with him days after the alleged attack. She said he continued to harass her, but signed his get-well card. It may not be surprising that a libel jury decided she was a liar. But did Lynn Walker deserve financial ruin, and was it right for the judge to deny her anonymity?
fields.body:
If we are burgled, we go to the police. If we are mugged, we go to the police. If we are threatened, we go to the police, and if we are de-frauded, crashed into, lost. But if we are raped - ah, then, no: we do not automatically go to the police. A great majority of rapes go unreported (as many as nine in 10). It is usually a hidden crime - behind closed doors, in bedrooms or cars or down dark alleys, with the victim as the only witness - and for many women it remains a secret violation: undetected, unpunished, unknown.

It is obvious why. We've read the statistics, and know that only 10% of reported cases ever make it to court, and only 24% of those are successful. We've read enough of the discomfiting stories in newspapers, where women are required to disclose intimate details of their past sexual history, for there is still a crude equation in which past promiscuity equals permanent willingness; only the innocent, the unworldly, the virginal and demure are favoured as suitable "rapees" (the accused, on the other hand, do not have to reveal their sexual history).

For many women it can feel that they, not their attackers, are on trial. We know by now that "no" sometimes doesn't mean no, and that in any case some women utter "no" after the event, in retrospective shame and revulsion. That stranger-rape is terrifying, but that the newly-named genre, date rape, can slide all the way down the spectrum of brutal crime, into the murky and obscure world of private relationships. We know that "consent" is a slippery word, endlessly interpreted, and that his consent can be her refusal.

That while yesterday's feminism condemned rape as the ugliest crime of a misogynist world, today's post-feminist world condemns instead the culture of "victimhood", where women allow themselves to be helpless, frail and diminished. That sex is a dark and tangled affair full of violence and misunderstanding and double meanings, and that the court is a harsh, brightly-lit, monolithic space where the private becomes glaringly public, and traumas are brutally replayed.

And we know that especially with date rape there is very often little or no proof - it is frequently his word against hers, his character against hers. In a recent survey in America, 3% of men said they forced a woman to have sex with them against their will, while 40% of women said they had been thus forced. It's as if we no longer even know what rape means, and a dizzying gulf opens up between the genders. Men think they are having sex and women think they are being violated. Men think they're asking for it and women think that they are saying no.

Into this treacherous arena comes the strange story of Lynn Walker, the pharmacist who accused a colleague of raping her, and who on Monday was ordered to pay him a staggering £400,000 in damages. She now faces financial ruin. Her limited assets (mainly a £70,000 house) are frozen and she is only allowed £150 a week of her Boots salary to live on. She has been branded a liar, and because the judge ordered her anonymity to be lifted, her face - a pleasant, anxious, bruised-looking face - is plastered across every newspaper.

In 1996, Walker had accused Martin Garfoot - a senior pharmacist who worked with her at a branch of Boots in North Shields - of behaving inappropriately towards her. Later, at a more formal meeting with managers, she said he had put his hand up her skirt and called her a "frigid cow". In January 1997, after he had been suspended while Boots investigated her claims, she upped the stakes once more, claiming that he had "almost" raped her.

Boots decided the allegations were not proven, and moved Garfoot (46, married, with two teenage children) to another branch. But Walker kept on with the allegations, and so he sued for libel and slander. In court her accusations escalated: he embarked on a campaign of physical and sexual harassment, he forced his penis into her mouth, his fist up her vagina; he attempted anal sex, he raped her; he made threats which led her to fear for her life.

It was not difficult to understand why the jury, made up of eight women and four men, decided that Walker's allegations were false. They heard how she had made no mention of any incident to either her doctor or the police. They also saw CCTV videos showing Walker standing next to Garfoot a week, and a fortnight after the alleged attack, smiling at him and apparently at ease. Would she have gone on staff bowling nights with him, called at his home, signed a get well card, accepted lifts from him, given him a present if her accusations were true?

The jurors plainly thought not. But why did they feel the need to ignore the judge's recommendations and order damages that would financially wreck Walker? What on earth was going on, that a woman should make up such a ghastly story about her life, and that a jury made up mainly of women should be so punitive?

In court, the jury were told that Lynn Walker was a church-going teetotaller, whose ex-husband had had affairs with other women and had on occasions hit her. She was under pressure at work, and she was depressed.

The stereotypical picture that inevitably emerges from these few facts is of a lonely woman, sucked into the nightmarish fantasies that she so graphically recounted in court. We have become familiar with the figure of the victim-fantasist - like Binjamin Wilkomirski, who imagined himself a Holocaust survivor and wrote his fake-memoir Fragments in a rhapsody of imagined and heroic suffering. Or like the young and disturbed women who people Kate Roiphe's influential The Morning After, crying rape to get attention, struggling to get to the centre of their lives in a mutant version of feminism.

So, some women, because they are vengeful, maybe, or full of lonely fantasies, lie about being raped. They tell tales; make themselves the star of their own drama; the hero-victim who finds meaning and identity in suffering. But most women turn in the opposite direction, and don't talk about being raped at all. For them the law is a blind alley. They know what all women know: that the intolerable grey area of rape doesn't easily fit into the black-and-white world of law, and that justice can be very rough indeed. How can the rights of the complainant and the defendant be balanced? Over the past decade, legislation has been passed that supposedly makes it easier for women to report rape. It is illegal for a husband to rape his wife (it used to be impossible: to be a wife was to be always-consenting).

Police officers are trained to deal sensitively with women who claim to have been raped. Date rapists have been successfully prosecuted. Counsel can no longer automatically cross-examine the rape victim in detail about her past sexual history. And yet at the same time, the number of successful prosecutions has dramatically declined, and attitudes towards rape have become disconcertingly lenient and full of contradictions. There's a split among women themselves: some think that a distinction should be made between rape and "non-consensual sex'"(there was I, thinking that rape was non-consensual sex). Some think the law should be altered even more in women's favour and others argue that that is to treat women as feeble and child-like. Some think that all sex is a kind of rape.

Post-feminists have become positively light-hearted about it. Fay Weldon announced that she had been raped once but it was no big deal, and she mainly felt rather sorry for the little man who pounced on her in the back of a cab. Germaine Greer was contemptuous about the emotional trauma of rape. Camille Paglia implies that most heterosexual sex is gloriously a kind of no-means-yes rape, a violent and delirious Lawrentian struggle between man and woman, and only priggish, unawakened women do not realise that sex is a war. Kate Roiphe accuses her debilitated colleagues on campus of seeing sexual harassment wherever they turn because they are fearful of their own sexuality. When Jill Craigie disclosed that, decades previously, she had been raped by Arthur Koestler, Frederic Raphael asked her what she had expected of him. When Michael Tyson arrived in Britain he was given a hero's welcome (and after all, goes the refrain, what did that girl think was going to happen when she went back with him to his room?). In these readings, there are rapes that are not rapes; crimes against women which are not really crimes at all. Women really shouldn't be making such a fuss.

For many years the legal process in rape cases was itself a form of institutionalised misogyny. Remember the rapist who conducted his own defence and interrogated his victim in pornographic detail about her experience for two days in the witness box? One of the reasons women are protected when they report rapes to the police is because we know that the level of intimidation is enormous.
