webTitle: Day in the life of a crash-test dummy

fields.headline: Day in the life of a crash-test dummy
fields.trailText: My boy Jed loves to run. He loves to run just as I loved to run when I was eight years old. It was a blissful age: old enough to feel you were the master of your body, yet still too young to be disabled by the pain of puberty.
fields.body:
My boy Jed loves to run. He loves to run just as I loved to run when I was eight years old. It was a blissful age: old enough to feel you were the master of your body, yet still too young to be disabled by the pain of puberty. When I was eight I could run faster than all the other kids I knew, faster and further and with more sureness of foot. I could out-sprint every rival to the top of any hill. I could spring across stepping stones without wetting my feet. Now my elder son rejoices in his own athletic powers and gives me comfort in the process. When he is still, he is distant and full of doubt. But when he runs he bursts with spirit and delight. Best of all, he reminds me of me.

Last week I watched him as he ran across a road, a quiet, residential one that goes right past his school. He dashed away towards his mates, while his younger brother Billy waited beside me, planting goodbye kisses on his baby sister Estelle. Then, everything went into a terrible slow-motion. A car shot into view, bearing down on Jed at the very second he hared beyond the pavement and on to the asphalt. As my hands flew to my face, the driver hit the brakes, missing him by no more than a yard. Jed skipped up the farther kerb and stole a glance in my direction. I yelled: "Are you, all right? Are you OK?" He nodded, unconcerned. Then he bolted through the school gates and was gone.

Twenty minutes later, Billy too was in the school, Estelle was with her minder, and I was sitting alone at home, sobbing with relief. Then I stopped my sobbing and got into some serious self-torment. I imagined making a phone call to Jed's mother: "Dilys? It's about Jed. He's dead." Could it be said better? Maybe, but only if I liked Dilys enough to try. My masochistic reverie continued: first, a vigil at the morgue, organised in shifts because Dilys wouldn't be in the same building as me; then funeral arrangements dominated by me explaining to the undertaker and sundry interested clerics that regardless of what my dead son's mother said about Jed's "other dad", this Chris chap was merely a stepdad and, therefore, an imposter, a presumptuous poseur and, of course, a Pillock too. Then there'd be an ugly graveside scene: Dilys insisting that Chris shovelled dirt on to the little coffin at the same time as I did; Chris looking keen; me getting angry; me telling big daughter Gloria and Angie, my wife, to just leave me alone; me swinging a right hook, dispersing Chris's teeth in all directions.

I woke up. I stood up. I ate a chocolate biscuit and drank the last two inches of wine from a bottle left open from the night before. Then I walked back to the school, asked permission to see Jed, fished him out of his classroom and sat him down beside me on the cold corridor floor.

"Are you all right? It nearly hit you."

"No it didn't. I saw it coming. It slowed down to let me over."

"Are you sure?"

A nod.

"Look at me? Are you sure?"

Another nod.

"Please will you look at me . . ."

Reluctantly, he turned his face my way. A blank face.

"I believe you, Jed. It just looked different from where I was. Do you understand? Do you understand why I had to come to see you? Do you understand how frightened it made me feel? Do you?"

Silence. His eyes drifted off towards his classroom door.

"I'm here because it made me think about how terrible I'd feel if that car had knocked you down. Do you know how terrible I'd feel? More terrible than anybody else. And I really do mean that: more terrible than absolutely anybody else. Please look at me."

Was I being cruel? Cruel to be kind? Was it kind to make him hear the things he tries to close his ears to? Was it kind to make him hear that nobody feels for him the way his part-time father does, and to go on making him hear it until his self-protective layers were finally worn away?

"Have a tissue," I said, feeling in my jacket pocket as a tear trickled down to his chin. "I always have a pocket full of tissues. Proper parents do."

Sorry, Jed. Just had to get that in.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar: an apology
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar: an apology

In an article published on one of our Comment pages, page 20, February 4, under the heading Piers will stay at large, we said, "The pressure on Mr [Piers] Morgan to explain why exactly he invested £20,000 in a company run by his friend Sir Alan Sugar just before his newspaper tipped the shares and sent the price up 100% - more or less doubling the Mirror editor's money - is growing rather than fading."

Sir Alan Sugar has asked us to say that he is not a friend of Piers Morgan and had nothing to do with Mr Morgan's decision to purchase shares. The Guardian accepts that and apologises unreservedly to Sir Alan if it appeared to be suggesting otherwise.

In a piece in our National Roundup, page 14, yesterday, we described Councillor Mike Storey as the Labour leader of Liverpool city council. He is, in fact, like the council itself, Liberal Democrat. Apologies.

In a column in The Guide, page 52, February 5, we said that Tony Blair was the fourth Labour prime minister and that he went to Cambridge. He is the fifth, and he went to Oxford.

Our interview with the Rev Timothy Kinahan who had been a passenger on the Lufthansa Airbus hijacked in 1993 (page 4, G2, yesterday), was unfortunately illustrated with a scene from a hijacking in 1977 also involving a Lufthansa aircraft, a Boeing 737.

In our obituary of the film director Claude Autant-Lara, page 18, February 7, we appeared to anticipate his death, saying that he died on February 12. In fact, he died on February 5. Apologies.

Near homophone, from page 16, February 7: "Devolution was Labour's way of ditching the Scots Nats". Ditch, to abandon or discard; dish, to ruin or spoil (the chances of someone). Both from Collins Millennium.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the Readers' Editor by telephoning 0171 239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Frost and fruit
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley
fields.body:
Tamar Valley

At midday, sun filters through branches to strike Cleave's isolated wall, warming the local-quarried shillet face and casting shadows from regenerated woodland.

Down the valley, Nanie Rowe's wood, at the junction of Radland and Morden millstreams, is indistinct - conifers in a blue haze, tall chestnuts silhouetted on the horizon. Earlier this morning, and rare for this winter, streamside trees were thick with rime frost - icy lace below a tangle of sunlit trees.

Running down a steep slope the wall is open-ended, standing between a field hedgebank and the lower green lane which is edged with old holly and oak.

Ten feet high, capped with thick slates and reinforced with regularly spaced 27in square pillars, it was built almost a century ago, reputedly by itinerant stonemasons working for half-a-crown a day.

Nothing remains of fruit trees once grown against it, just forged nails driven into the mortar, some with flat round heads for espalier straps.

In this valley above Cotehele Quay, there is no longer a contrast between south-facing horticulture and the colder shady side which has always been wooded. Where early daffodils and strawberries grew in neat rows on warm slopes facing the sun above the frosty bottom, are larch planted some 20 years ago and self-sown thickets mixed with pittisporum trees, relics of shelter belts, once cut for florists' foliage.

Hazel, ash and sycamore have crowded out dying apples and cherries but daffodils and double whites persist among encroaching bramble and fern.

The substantial shelter wall, like the nearby ivy-shrouded ruin and a longer wall in Danescombe valley a couple miles away, enhanced the natural micro-climate so laboriously exploited by market gardeners.

The north side is cold, open to Kit Hill and Hingston Down. Towards Harrowbarrow, among cereal and bulb fields, is a cluster of polythene tunnels - today's method for maximising production of early strawberries and runner beans.
fields.bodyText: Tamar Valley At midday, sun filters through branches to strike Cleave's isolated wall, warming the local-quarried shillet face and casting shadows from regenerated woodland. Down the valley, Nanie Rowe's wood, at the junction of Radland and Morden millstreams, is indistinct - conifers in a blue haze, tall chestnuts silhouetted on the horizon. Earlier this morning, and rare for this winter, streamside trees were thick with rime frost - icy lace below a tangle of sunlit trees. Running down a steep slope the wall is open-ended, standing between a field hedgebank and the lower green lane which is edged with old holly and oak. Ten feet high, capped with thick slates and reinforced with regularly spaced 27in square pillars, it was built almost a century ago, reputedly by itinerant stonemasons working for half-a-crown a day. Nothing remains of fruit trees once grown against it, just forged nails driven into the mortar, some with flat round heads for espalier straps. In this valley above Cotehele Quay, there is no longer a contrast between south-facing horticulture and the colder shady side which has always been wooded. Where early daffodils and strawberries grew in neat rows on warm slopes facing the sun above the frosty bottom, are larch planted some 20 years ago and self-sown thickets mixed with pittisporum trees, relics of shelter belts, once cut for florists' foliage. Hazel, ash and sycamore have crowded out dying apples and cherries but daffodils and double whites persist among encroaching bramble and fern. The substantial shelter wall, like the nearby ivy-shrouded ruin and a longer wall in Danescombe valley a couple miles away, enhanced the natural micro-climate so laboriously exploited by market gardeners. webTitle: Rumoured takeover trio deny holding M&S shares

fields.headline: Rumoured takeover trio deny holding M&S shares
fields.trailText: Three executives rumoured to form the management team assembled by Philip Green as part of his potential bid for Marks & Spencer have denied that they own any shares in the retailer.
fields.body:
Three executives rumoured to form the management team assembled by Philip Green as part of his potential bid for Marks & Spencer have denied that they own any shares in the retailer.

The three men - Asda's Allan Leighton, Debenhams' Terry Green and Bass finance director Richard North - who have been repeatedly linked to the bid plan, all received Section 212 notices yesterday morning. The legal notices, which require details of shareholdings to be disclosed, demanded information within 24 hours.

Last night M&S said it had not yet received replies from the three men, but the executives each said that they did not own any M&S shares. Marks & Spencer's decision to fire off a volley of 212s is being interpreted as a get-tough campaign designed to force Mr Green to put up or shut up. The executives were targeted just days after the retailer sent 212s to Mr Green and his wife Christina and to the entrepreneur's investment bank advisers Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette.

The reply to the notice sent to Mr Green, which revealed that his wife had bought £25m of M&S shares days before the Monaco-based businessman confirmed he was contemplating a hostile bid for the struggling chain, was revealed on Sunday.

Yesterday Mr Green insisted he and his wife had acted "by the rulebook".

fields.headline: Bitesize banks are tempting prey
fields.trailText: Chief executives of some of the best known retail banking names will probably be dusting down their defence strategies against unwanted bids once the NatWest war is out of the way.
fields.body:
Chief executives of some of the best known retail banking names will probably be dusting down their defence strategies against unwanted bids once the NatWest war is out of the way.

Corporate financiers say these institutions could follow merchant banks by sliding into foreign hands because of their fall from grace on the stock market.

One City source yesterday described names such as Abbey National and Halifax as "bitesize" for a European predator. Spain's BSCH or German banks Deutsche and Dresdner are mentioned, and even Citigroup of the US or Chase could be interested.

While "bitesize" might make it seem a bit too simple - most of the potential attackers named would need to raise capital to meet the £13bn or so price tag on potential targets - the fact remains that the share prices of Abbey National and Halifax are down 40% since the start of November.

Over a slightly longer time horizon, however, Halifax and Barclays have outperformed the sickly sector while Abbey has trailed the pack. Even the "star", Lloyds TSB, has fallen 25% since November - while Alliance & Leicester, one of the smaller stocks in the sector, has almost halved in value during the period.

The banks have lost out as investors grab anything related to dot.coms and increase their exposure to Vodafone. They are also feeling the pain of being associated with the "old-fashioned" world of bricks and mortar and the perception of fierce competition from start-ups as such Prudential's Egg.

Little wonder the banks are trying to chase the dot.com story - perhaps in the hope it could rejuvenate their share prices in the way media group Reuters did yesterday.

Halifax is setting up Greenfield, a telephone-cum-internet bank, while Abbey is launching web services and A&L has said its new chief executive - yet to be named - will need to be well versed in all things "e".

As the banks prepare to announce a bumper set of 1999 profits, a bid by a foreign predator - whether real or perceived - could in fact help the them retain independence, by reviving share prices.

webTitle: 100m euros London exchange aims for new business in cross-border trade

fields.headline: 100m euros London exchange aims for new business in cross-border trade
fields.trailText: The battle for position in Europe's growing market in cross-border share trading intensified yesterday with plans for a new 100m euros(£61m) electronic exchange based in London.
fields.body:
The battle for position in Europe's growing market in cross-border share trading intensified yesterday with plans for a new 100m euros(£61m) electronic exchange based in London.

The new venture, which is to be launched in September and which will cover 6,000 stocks, is the brainchild of OM Gruppen, which owns Sweden's stock exchange, and the American investment house Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

But another contender in the market, Brussels-based Easdaq, warned that the new exchange would increase market fragmentation.

Executives from Morgan Stanley and OM argued, however, that their initiative - which is aimed at retail investors and small institutional trades - would add to liquidity by bringing in new business.

The demand for cross-border share trading in Europe is being driven by a move away from nationally based investment strategies, developments in technology and the introduction of the single currency.

In 1998, London and Frankfurt announced plans to link up to facilitate cross-border trading and six other exchanges - Paris, Madrid, Milan, Zurich, Amsterdam and Brussels - have since agreed to join the alliance; but progress towards a pan-European trading system has been slow.

Frustration among institutional investors about the problems of cross-border deals has tempted other organisations to offer similar services.

Last year American exchange Nasdaq unveiled plans for a pan-European trading system and a number of other, smaller, organisations are looking to offer cross-border services as well.

The OM-Morgan Stanley exchange, which has been named Jiway and will offer settlement and clearing as well as trading, will be 60% owned by the Swedish group and 40% by Morgan Stanley, although the two are "looking for other partners", according to Morgan Stanley's managing director, Jerker Johansson.

Jiway is expected to be launched two months ahead of Nasdaq's European trading platform, although initially it will only be available in the UK, Germany and Sweden before being rolled out across Europe. The aim is to concentrate on trades up to 50,000 euros.

Easdaq director Clive Pedder said the new exchange "represents further fragmentation".

"We don't see what value it adds beyond the various pan-European initiatives already under way." But Mr Johansson insisted: "We are creating new liquidity because we are creating new trading flows."

Morgan Stanley and OM believe the venture will cut the costs of cross-border dealing by up to 50%.

webTitle: No frills and £9m profit for Ryanair

fields.headline: No frills and £9m profit for Ryanair
fields.trailText: Ryanair, which claims to be the fastest growing low cost airline in Europe, yesterday recorded its best third-quarter results and announced plans for seven new European destinations to be revealed next week.
fields.body:
Ryanair, which claims to be the fastest growing low cost airline in Europe, yesterday recorded its best third-quarter results and announced plans for seven new European destinations to be revealed next week.

Pre-tax profits for the three months to the end of the year rose by a third to £9.8m, in contrast to British Airways' £60m loss for the same period.

Michael O'Leary, the company's chief executive said: "The more BA cuts back, the more we get to carry the great unwashed. We're not proud."

Revenue grew 35% to £70.6m and passengers volume were up by 17% to 1.4m, giving average revenue per passenger of £39.

Mr O'Leary said that the high profile sale of tickets for £5 excluding tax on all its routes last weekend had been a success with bookings up 300% for the time of year. About half came through its new website, Ryanair.com.

The airline expects the proportion of sales it makes through the net or via its own salesforce to rise from 25% to about 60%, saving several million pounds a year in marketing costs. It believes that passenger volumes will grow from 6m to 7m this year.

Mr O'Leary said that while BA and other competitors tried to reduce capacity and raise fares, Ryanair would do the opposite. It would continue to offer the lowest fares on more and more seats.

Michael Cawley, the company's commercial and financial officer, answered criticism from some passengers who say that they had not been able to get the recent cheap fares when they tried to book.

He agreed that telephone bookings were sometimes slow and that people rang off in frustration. But it was now possible to book on the inter net, which should make life easier for passengers.

Mr Cawley said that over the year, fares averaged out at around £40, which included higher fares of £90 paid by business passengers. He said: "We are not perfect, but we do offer a very cheap service and the level of complaints is lower than any other airline, including BA."

webTitle: Take away the target and BP is in trouble

fields.headline: Take away the target and BP is in trouble
fields.standfirst: Investors fear Big Oil strategy will come unstuck over Arco
fields.trailText: Next week BP Amoco will report a 40% rise in annual profits and yesterday it had a boost from investment house Goldman Sachs, which opened coverage of the oil group's shares with a recommendation of "outperform".
fields.body:
Next week BP Amoco will report a 40% rise in annual profits and yesterday it had a boost from investment house Goldman Sachs, which opened coverage of the oil group's shares with a recommendation of "outperform".

But BP Amoco's stock price has plummeted since mid-December as fears have grown over plans to acquire Atlantic Richfield - or Arco - and some investors have fled to other stocks.

Critics say the image of chief executive Sir John Browne as a man who walks on water is in danger of going rusty. They note that the decision by the American regulator to try to block the $30bn (£18.7bn) Arco deal comes on top of $200m write-offs against financial losses in Russia and $750m in Venezuela.

Pessimists argue that BP Amoco's huge success, which brought record third quarter profits of nearly $2bn over the last couple of years, has been built on cost-cutting and rationalisation.

Take away new takeover targets such as Arco as a valuable source of savings and the strategy looks in trouble, they argue.

But the Arco deal is not dead yet. The federal trade commission's bureau of competition led by Richard Parker voted to try to block the takeover in the courts, and a hearing begins on March 10 in front of a Washington district judge.

The company is hoping the biggest ever legal challenge to a merger could be over within six weeks. But the losing party could take any verdict to the federal appeal court, and that could take months.

The best thing for BP Amoco's credibility is that the investment community is convinced that the federal trade commission has acted from political rather than economic motives.

The FTC insists BP Amoco Arco would be in a dominant position on the west coast of the United States, allowing it to manipulate oil prices. They are supported by Californian attorney general Bill Lockyer, who also asked a federal court this week to block the deal, arguing BP Amoco exercised "monopoly power" in the state.

But the integrated oil group and most financial analysts have dismissed this argument. Sir John has offered to sell assets to win the Alaskan state approval for the deal and has pledged to maintain Arco's policy of selling cheap petrol.

The political argument is about the increasing power of Big Oil - BP has already merged with Amoco while Exxon has linked with Mobil - and the fact that this is presidential election year.

Political flavour
The likely Democrat victor, Al Gore, still has green credentials and the federal trade commission is said to want to curry favour with him by blocking the rising power of especially foreign-owned oil.

But while investors are sympathetic about BP Amoco being caught in the political crossfire they are less enthusiastic about the way they were not forewarned that there could be trouble.

Until the final legal challenge last Tuesday, BP Amoco insiders had been dismissive of American newspaper articles suggesting the merger was in trouble. Analysts, too, say they have been subjected to hectoring for expressing doubts. So when things go wrong there is no shortage of commentators who are willing to put the boot in - strictly off the record, of course.

"The unblemished record was always a myth," said one analyst. Look at the trouble with Sidanko [in Russia], write-offs in Venezuela and the fact that places such as Colombia and West of Shetlands have failed to live up to their earlier promise.

"If [Sir John] Browne was not in overall charge he was the head of exploration when decisions were made."

Back to fundamentals
BP Amoco said yesterday that it fully expected to win the Arco case, but pointed out that the American group only represented 15% of the overall asset base.

A spokesman added: "Arco is worth having, but it is not fundamental.

"Our strategy is about growth - both organic and acquisition. We have a lot of interesting projects in the Gulf of Mexico, Angola and the Caspian [Sea]." There are also still more fans than critics of Sir John and BP Amoco. Supporters such as Goldman Sachs - which have set a target price of 607p for the stock - argue that the Arco problem is a minor blip. They point out there are still huge benefits to be squeezed out of the Amoco merger, which has already caused the loss of nearly 15,000 jobs. "Its ridiculous to say that BP Amoco is just about cost-cutting and cannot achieve significant top line growth. Look at the string of recent exploration successes," said one analyst.

He believed there were technical reasons for the share slide - which has hit Shell as hard as BP Amoco, whose stock ended yesterday down 4p at 495p.

"Most of the top FTSE stocks have lost ground over the last month as fund managers switch to Mannesman Vodaphone, where they are badly underweight given the new size of that group," he said.

fields.headline: Engineering
fields.trailText: Engineering stocks, star performers? Surely some mistake. Analysis by the corporate finance arm of Ernst & Young, published today, confirms what sector members have been saying for some time: the FTSE engineering and machinery index outperformed the all-share index last year.
fields.body:
Engineering stocks, star performers? Surely some mistake. Analysis by the corporate finance arm of Ernst & Young, published today, confirms what sector members have been saying for some time: the FTSE engineering and machinery index outperformed the all-share index last year.

Wow! Well, the gain was only 3% and hardly worth a crate of Bollie but many of the leading engineers did remarkably well, largely because, surprise, surprise, they rode a wave of mergers, acquisitions and restructuring. Oh, and, according to E&Y, were "driven by a commitment to focus and thrive [rather than diversify and merely survive]".

Nicholas Legh, corporate finance partner, says of the 40 stocks in the sector index: "Over the last five years only five of them beat the all-share index but 14 of the 40 managed to better it [last] year by 3%, which is not bad for a sector without a dot.com in sight."

Star performer was Cookson with a 92% increase. In the last five years it has spent £600m on 29 acquisitions, including $503m on Enthone in the US, and raised £150m through nine disposals and transformed itself, under chief executive Stephen Howard who took over in 1997, from a cumber some conglomerate into just three core divisions: electronics, ceramics and engineering, dropping plastics on the way.

FKI, up 78%, made parking meters 30 years ago but, under Robert Beeston (ex-BTR), has got rid of its automotive unit and, via the recent $368m purchase of Pinnacle Automation of the US, has moved into the e-commerce world.

Others outperformers are TI Group, up 47%; Glynwed, up 45% and hardly a piece of metal in sight; BBA, up 34% and big in nappies and business jets; and Wagon, up 27% on the back of car doors.

After being despised as over-diversified these "metal-bashers" have found manna in diversification as well as focus. Mr Legh has an answer to this conundrum: the City wants growth and this is what they are delivering, Transtec apart.

In the last five years it has spent £600m on 29 acquisitions, including $503m on Enthone in the US, and raised £150m through nine disposals and transformed itself, under chief executive Stephen Howard who took over in 1997, from a cumber some conglomerate into just three core divisions: electronics, ceramics and engineering, dropping plastics on the way. FKI, up 78%, made parking meters 30 years ago but, under Robert Beeston (ex-BTR), has got rid of its automotive unit and, via the recent $368m purchase of Pinnacle Automation of the US, has moved into the e-commerce world. Others outperformers are TI Group, up 47%; Glynwed, up 45% and hardly a piece of metal in sight; BBA, up 34% and big in nappies and business jets; and Wagon, up 27% on the back of car doors. After being despised as over-diversified these "metal-bashers" have found manna in diversification as well as focus. Mr Legh has an answer to this conundrum: the City wants growth and this is what they are delivering, Transtec apart.

webTitle: Reality will bite for battling bourses

fields.headline: Reality will bite for battling bourses
fields.standfirst: Small investors get an opening
fields.trailText: Markets are supposed to be all about competition, so stock markets - those most capitalist of institutions - should be about competition in spades. These days they are. Scarcely a month goes by without yet another runner being declared for the season's most valuable prize, the great pan-European share trading handicap to be run over regulatory hurdles throughout 2000.
fields.body:
Markets are supposed to be all about competition, so stock markets - those most capitalist of institutions - should be about competition in spades. These days they are. Scarcely a month goes by without yet another runner being declared for the season's most valuable prize, the great pan-European share trading handicap to be run over regulatory hurdles throughout 2000.

The starting line-up to date: eight established national exchanges which are planning to run together under the same colours - provided they can agree what they should be - Nasdaq, which has very impressive form in the US; Easdaq - a rather smaller European version; London's Tradepoint and a couple of electronic crossing networks which essentially work by matching deals between institutional investors.

Yesterday we had another entrant, the oddly named Jiway - an internet based joint venture between Swedish stock market owner OM Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter - which will woo retail as well as institutional investors.

The question is not so much which will win but how many will finish in the prize money.

The driving force behind cross-border share dealing is coming from big institutions. They want to trade big blocks of shares across borders through a single system as cheaply as possible. They are unhappy with the form shown by the traditional exchanges, which have been under orders since the summer of 1998 but are not expected to get out of the stalls until November.

As a result they are putting modest bets on some of the rival runners, too.

One worry is that the more entrants to the market, the more the available business will be split.

In a sense such competition should be good for the investors, but there is a snag. One of the key determinants of share prices is liquidity - the number of shares available to be traded.

If there are lots around, the market can accommodate even quite big deals without moving the price - but if only a relatively modest quantity is there to be bought or sold, even quite small orders can produce sizeable price movements. If the amount of shares on offer is fragmented across more markets, there will be less liquidity

Nobody should worry too much. The big institutions will press for as much competition as possible to keep costs down, but if a lack of liquidity impacts on prices they will soon concentrate on fewer systems.

The exchanges and electronic networks know that and, once they are in operation, will look at consolidation. Demutualisation among the exchanges will help that process - although it will be interesting to see what effect the competition has on the value demutualising bourses can command.

But while the big players will make sure that their views are taken into account, the interests of smaller investors must not be overlooked.

They are becoming more important on the back of the accessibility and cost reduction provided by internet-based systems. If Jiway proves successful, that could help to ensure that their views, too, are heard.

Courtroom TV

Stephen Byers' decision to refer the Carlton-United News & Media merger to the competition commission should come as no surprise.

The deal runs up against the constraint imposed on the share of the advertising market a single firm should be allowed to hold, although the level is under review, and yesterday's announcement makes it clear Mr Byers wants the issue of the ITV programming market looked at as well.

This is fair enough. But the commission needs to deliver its judgments on the issues referred to it by Mr Byers as speedily as possible, and it needs to look at the regime under which the ITV companies are forced to operate. The merger raises issues that go to the heart of what ITV is and what it should be.

The sector is changing rapidly. It is a moot point whether or not yesterday's decision to refer the bid to the commission will open the way for a foreign company to launch an offer for one of the companies. Certainly Granada is waiting in the wings, and will be watching the commission's deliberation with great interest.

This is not simply a question of terrestrial television. The ITV firms also face challenges for audiences and advertisers from non-terrestrial competitors.

It is right that the authorities should be concerned with issues such as protecting the regional character of ITV, and not only in the provision of news. The government, sensibly, does not want to be rushed into making important policy decisions in such a sensitive area as broadcasting.

But the companies need a commercial framework within which they can function effectively - not just now, but in the future. Over to the commission.

webTitle: Steel plants at risk from pound

fields.headline: Steel plants at risk from pound
fields.trailText: A new threat to the Llanwern steelworks near Newport, south Wales, arose yesterday after a Corus executive warned that the continuing strength of the pound could force a change in production locations.
fields.body:
A new threat to the Llanwern steelworks near Newport, south Wales, arose yesterday after a Corus executive warned that the continuing strength of the pound could force a change in production locations.

Fokko van Duyne, joint chief executive of the group formed from last year's merger of British Steel and Dutch rival Hoogovens, said Corus would be forced to take steps "if the pound stays at this level".

Mr van Duyne's comments, in Her Financieele Dagblad, an Amsterdam daily paper, prompted the main UK steel union to demand urgent talks with Corus executives on the future of all British steel plants.

Of the four main integrated steel plants - Llanwern, Port Talbot, Redcar and Scunthorpe - Llanwern is seen as the most vulnerable by industry sources, although Corus said Mr van Duyne's remarks "did not herald any imminent closure" in the UK and the group was not targeting a specific plant.

Llanwern, which employs around 3,000 people, produces 3m tonnes of strip each year - the same as its sister plant in Wales, Port Talbot, which employs about 3,250 and enjoys the additional benefit of a deep water harbour.

The cloud over Llanwern's future appeared just hours before the national assembly in Wales debated a vote of no confidence in first secretary Alun Michael.

At the time of the Hoogovens-British Steel merger last September, Mr Michael was forced to issue the first emergency statement in the assembly on Llanwern's future. Corus accounts for 3.5% of the Welsh labour force and 2% of Welsh output.

Michael Leahy, leader of the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, said: "Both our Welsh plants are among the most productive in the world and their future should be bright. The worrying aspect is the exchange rate, and that's crippling."

The former British Steel last week reported £167m pre-tax losses for the half year to October 2 and said the strong pound kept it in the red into the new year - despite a recovery in prices and a stringent review that has cut the workforce by up to 7,000 in the past three years.

Corus is likely to shed up to a further 3,000 jobs this year and yesterday axed 60 out of 330 jobs at two Scottish plate works: Dalzell, near Motherwell, and Clydebridge, near Cambuslang, Glasgow.

Corus estimates that the rise in the pound, down at DM2.30 in 1996, has cost it £900m in profits since then at an average DM3. But analysts such as Peter Dupont at Commerzbank say this excludes this year's rise, to as much as DM3.25, and the cost is likely to be more than £1bn.

Mr Leahy said the union had been given assurances at the time of the merger that there would be no plant closures, but industry sources suggested these could be triggered if the pound stayed overvalued for the foreseeable future.

One option could be to close Llanwern and switch production to Ijmuiden, the ex-Hoogovens plant whose annual output exceeds that of the two Welsh plants combined, at 6.5m tonnes.

A nearby long products site is to close, releasing an extra 1m tonne capacity for strip, while a new thin-slab caster will add 1.3m tonnes a year.

Mr Dupont cautioned, however, against the costly transfer of production to Holland, arguing that downsizing was much more likely if the pound stayed strong.

fields.headline: BSkyB plans TV by phone
fields.standfirst: Media delivers: Copper option goes to Kingston's customers
fields.trailText: BSkyB, in a notable departure from its satellite television business, is planning to deliver pay-television services over the telephone network.
fields.body:
BSkyB, in a notable departure from its satellite television business, is planning to deliver pay-television services over the telephone network.

The company has established a joint venture with the Hull-based telecoms operator, Kingston Communications, taking advantage of technology which enables the upgrading of copper wires for high bandwidth applications.

The formation of the joint venture is expected to be an nounced with BSkyB's half- year results today.

The venture will be owned on a 50:50 basis and will initially focus on Kingston's domestic network in Hull and parts of Yorkshire.

It is expected to launch aggressively across the country after British Telecom's local network is opened up for competition, due in July next year.

The so-called unbundling of the local loop will allow competing companies to take over BT lines and install their own technology to upgrade the ca bles as and when they sign up new customers.

Shares in BSkyB were yesterday 143p higher at £16.10, while Kingston was 4p down at £10.13.

Kingston started a 60-channel TV service in October last year in Hull under the Kingston Interactive Television brand name, but it remains unclear how the new venture will be marketed.

The Kingston service already has a carriage agreement with BSkyB alongside Flextech, Discovery, Viacom and Turner.

The service using the ADSL or asymmetric digital subscriber line technology will also give BSkyB further exposure to the internet through services which can be pumped straight to the TV.

The Kingston Interactive service enables users to download at speeds of around 256kb, compared to existing ISDN line speeds of 56kb. The system requires new kit in the telephone exchange and a decoder in the home.

Kingston's tie-up with BSkyB will help the company to fund investment in the infrastructure. The business has spent around £3m upgrading its own network in Hull and each customer connection is an additional £400 including the free set top box.

Since flotation last year, Kingston has belied its sleepy origins as a municipally-owned telephone company created by a historical quirk which left it separate from the system that became BT. Kingston-upon-Hull city council still owns 49.9%.

The company has been the first in Britain to offer a commercial ADSL service. By contrast, BT is still running a series of pilot programmes focusing on high-speed internet access and video on demand.

Cable companies have avoided Hull because of the strong grasp Kingston has over the local telephone network, although BSkyB is in 34% of homes.

The move into ADSL will allow BSkyB access to the large parts of the market that are keen for pay-TV services but remain reluctant to install a satellite dish. Insiders said Kingston was keen to use BSkyB's marketing experience in the pay-TV market.

fields.bylineHtml: David Teather, Media Business Correspondent

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Euro-less UK attracts cash
fields.body:
Euro-less UK attracts cash

Foreign investors flooded into Britain last year, despite the government's decision not to join the single currency at its launch, a report showed yesterday.

The UK remained one of the top global destinations, according to preliminary estimates from the United Nations. But it was displaced from the number two slot it occupied in 1998 by Sweden, which also stayed outside the euro zone.

One of the government's five tests for British euro zone entry is its likely impact on inward investment. The evidence from yesterday's report is that so far staying outside has not deterred investors.

The report also showed that Britain has replaced the United States as the leading source of outward investment flows. The final report will not appear until September.

Worldwide, investment appears to have shaken off the aftermath of the Asian crisis. Cross-border investment totalled $827bn last year, a rise of 25%, according to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (Unctad). "Developing countries rebounded from their 1998 stagnation," the report noted.

However, developed countries are the destination for nearly three-quarters of international investment.

The driving force behind recent increases is cross-border mergers and acquisitions, according to Unctad. Cross-border mergers topped $1.1 trillion in 1999 and 2000 is expected to be another record-breaking year.

The organisation said the trend warranted "careful analysis in terms of their impact on development".

Cable protest dismissed

Regulators have dismissed a complaint by BSkyB that cable operators were acting unfairly in the way they bundled television and telephone services.

The independent television commission and the office of telecommunications said they found no reason to act after investigating the satellite broadcaster's claims that cable companies were pressuring customers to take TV and telephone services and were selling them at unfair prices. They said cable operators were not refusing to supply the services separately and some customers were taking up only one option.

Whitbread to sell 187 pubs

Whitbread has confirmed it is to offer for sale the pubs and restaurants business obtained when it acquired Swallow Group.

A small number of properties would be retained and converted to Whitbread branded pubs, the company said.

The business for sale comprises 187 pubs, 146 managed and 41 tenanted, supported by a head office infrastructure. Located predominantly in the north-east and Yorkshire, the estate includes successful branded concepts such as Bramwells and Barcentro.

In the financial year ended September 30, the business, including the retained pubs, generated sales of about £64.4 m with an operating profit of £14.6m.

fields.headline: Last encores please
fields.standfirst: Bands like Radiohead and Manic Street Preachers might never have made it without Britain's pub venues. But now they're disappearing.  Dave Simpson reports
fields.trailText: Bands like Radiohead and Manic Street Preachers might never have made it without Britain's pub venues. But now they're disappearing.
fields.body:
Upstairs at the Duchess of York pub in Leeds there's a sofa. It's a leather, moth-eaten affair that could have come straight from the set of Steptoe and Son. But people from all over the world have stopped to admire it. "That," they say, excitedly, "is the sofa where Kurt Cobain slept."

On March 25, the pub will close after a farewell gig featuring Chumbawamba. The sofa will have to find a new home. "It'll probably end up in a skip," sighs Duchess promoter John Keenan.

The Duchess is legendary in the north. Over the last decade it has played host to some of the biggest names in pop. Nirvana, Oasis, Manic Street Preachers, Radiohead, The Verve and many more learnt their trade here. Now, musicians and rock fans alike are in mourning as another hallowed pop shrine bites the dust.

"I'm really saddened that the Duchess is closing," says Embrace singer Danny McNamara, "because we couldn't get gigs anywhere else when we started out. We actually got signed by playing at the Duchess because it was one of the few venues where record companies would be prepared to come and see you."

The local music industry is up in arms. One irate missive to the Yorkshire Evening Post compared the closure to London's Marquee turning into a chain bar and Liverpool council's notorious 70s decision to concrete over the original Cavern. Recent events, however, suggest that this is more than just a local issue, and that the Duchess is the latest victim in a nationwide cull of key venues that has left the grass-roots live "circuit" which spawned our finest bands in danger of extinction.

Newcastle's Riverside (bought by club giants Gatecrasher and converted into a club), Manchester's Boardwalk, Birmingham's Edwards No 8 and even London's acclaimed Embassy Rooms have closed, and many other venues are teetering on the brink. "In the past three years we have profiled 50 venues," says Crispin Parry of national pop-venues magazine Circuit. "Twenty of them are now extinct."

There are some who won't mourn the passing of the smaller, sweatier, smoke-filled rooms, but the ramifications for pop music are potentially catastrophic. Where will the next Manics, Oasis or Beatles come from if there is nowhere left to play?

The problems facing grass-roots venues are symptomatic of lean times in the music industry. Since Britpop, there hasn't been any great upsurge of live bands to justify the number of venues major cities have sustained. Record companies are signing fewer bands than they used to, and are spending money on massive marketing campaigns rather than pushing bands as live acts. This means fewer "name" bands for small venues and ultimately fewer punters inspired to start bands of their own. It adds up to an even greater threat of being dominated by manufactured pop horrors like Steps and S Club 7.

Live music also suffers from an image problem. Compared with superclubs, or even Playstation, the idea of seeing a rock band in a small venue (and the accompanying imagery of old men, urine-soaked toilets and feedback-ridden speaker stacks) lacks glamour for young people. "Small gigs aren't as sexy as they used to be," admits Parry.

On a business level, pub venues are being damaged by the same corporate impulses behind theme pubs and fast food. The Duchess, for example, is not closing due to a lack of demand for its live music but because the property company that owns it wants to turn it into a shop. Following a Thatcher ruling that breweries could own only 2,000 pubs each, financially risky pub venues were sold en masse to property developers. They realise that they can earn more money by taking advantage of a venue's prime commercial position.

Seventy miles up the road from the Duchess, Paul Jackson, the promoter of Hull's famed Adelphi, is tearing what's left of his hair out at the crisis facing a venue that has been crucial to the careers of bands such as the La's, Radiohead and the Stone Roses. "The situation is absolutely desperate," says Jackson. "In three months my overdraft has gone from £2,500 to £9,000. I don't know how long I can hold out."

Eager to capitalise on the recent bar boom, Hull's corporate bar owners have flooded the city's crucial student/cultural area with drinking houses. A price war has erupted, with the artificially cheap beer in these bars making a night out at an independent venue like the tiny Adelphi suddenly uncompetitive.

"I remember what it was like to be a student with £5 in my pocket," confesses Jackson. "If you can get a pint for 20p somewhere you'll go there. But at the moment it's a step away from them paying people to drink their beer. It's a battle only the big corporations can win."

Jackson, like most of his customers, who include Adelphi-spawned hitmakers The Beautiful South, voices despair at the state of Hull's cultural heartland. "It's all beer and squidgy sex."

John Power of Cast is horrified at the threat to the Adelphi's future. "The La's and Cast both played that venue and others like it for ages before we got successful. That's where we learned our craft. These venues absolutely must be supported, not shut down. It's bad for our business and a shame for future bands."

The crisis isn't limited to pubs. Student venues - another mainstay of pop culture at a grass-roots level - are suffering equally at the hands of government policies. "Since student unions' funding changed in the mid-90s, there's been no slush fund to absorb any losses," explains Charlie Myatt of tour bookers 13. "Events managers came in whose job was to make money out of entertainments rather than provide a service. The best way to make money is to put on clubs and discos and not risk money on bands. There's a drip effect because then nobody in the student unions knows how to put on a band." Meanwhile students - who don't have as much money to spend as they used to because of student loans - prefer clubs to gigs.

Competition between promoters causes more problems. Myatt points to national gig promoters muscling into smaller clubs in order to forge relationships with potentially lucrative new talent. "You'll get a big company now promoting a 200-capacity venue, which takes money away from small promoters."

It's not all gloom and doom, though. The smaller promoters are fighting back. The Duchess's John Keenan is looking for another venue and after 25 years as a promoter (initially as a pivotal figure in the late-70s punk scene) insists he hasn't lost his hunger or his enthusiasm. He says he is addicted to the thrill of putting a potential Oasis on in front of 12 people and "watching them grow and grow".

"I want to be able to show younger teenagers what it feels like to be at a live gig," beams Parry. "Hopefully they'll come away saying 'That was really exciting. I can't wait to go back.'

webTitle: Give our show a happy ending

fields.headline: Give our show a happy ending
fields.standfirst: The actors in Streets Alive know first-hand how hard life is if you're homeless. After you've been a 'spect-actor' in one of their plays, you will too.  Lyn Gardner  reports
fields.trailText: The actors in Streets Alive know first-hand how hard life is if you're homeless. After you've been a 'spect-actor' in one of their plays, you will too.
fields.body:
In a carriage of a Kent-bound train there's a curious scene unfolding. A young man and woman brace up to each other, and the woman acts out the stabbing of the man, substituting a plastic Coke bottle for a knife. Another person looks on. They repeat the scene several times until they feel they have got it right, oblivious of the commuters around them. Some stare in amazement; others feign indifference.

For these young actors, intent upon their impromptu rehearsal, such reactions are nothing new. They know what it is like to be stared at, blatantly ignored, or even stepped over in the street. Suzi, Mel and Stuart are members of a theatre company, Streets Alive, made up entirely of homeless and ex-homeless people. Nineteen-year-old Suzi currently lives in a shelter in south London.

A couple of hours later, in the tranquil surroundings of Princess Anne's old school, Benenden, the company's latest play is under way. The audience of 15- and 16-year-olds are obviously gripped by Island of Shadows' story, which tells how a 14-year-old called Lucy is sexually abused by her uncle, thrown out of home by her stepfather, rejected by her father and ends up alone on the streets of London.

She is easy prey for the streetwise Poison; he, in turn, introduces her to the violent, unpredictable drug addict Odin who runs a prostitution ring. It is a cautionary tale, an everywoman story. But it is also true, and it belongs entirely to Suzi, Mel and Stuart. They have lived it or know those have lived it - or died it. Turning it into theatre has not been an easy process. "We had to leave some things out. They were just too painful," says Stuart, who spent 10 years on the streets from the age of 14 after a childhood mostly in care.

The production is raw and rough. But the play's lack of polish and upfront emotional toughness is part of its power. It feels real - and totally at odds with the well-bred surroundings of Benenden.

It is real. Every year over 100,000 young people under the age of 16 run away from home. Some of these will end up on the streets of London and other cities. Yet they are too young to have access to cold-weather shelters and homeless people's hostels that might offer them some degree of protection. Knowing that if they are picked up by the police they will almost certainly be returned home or back into care they are particularly susceptible to those who say they will help them - but too often merely exploit them.

The performance comes to an end and everyone claps. But the real drama of the evening is yet to begin. Patrick Young, a former head of drama in a London school and the founder of Streets Alive, steps forward. "We are asking your help to make Lucy's story have a more positive ending," he tells the audience. "What could she have done to change what happens to her?"

For a moment there is silence. Then hands are raised. One girl hesitantly suggests that Lucy could have tried telling her mother that her uncle was abusing her. Gently Young invites the girl to come up and join the actors and act out the scene. After initial hesitancy she is soon enthusiastically playing the role of Lucy, while Mel acts out Lucy's mother's reaction to the revelation. Mel doesn't make it impossible for the girl playing Lucy but she doesn't make it particularly easy either. At the end of the scene most people in the audience agree that Lucy has made some kind of progress.

Soon there is a forest of hands in the air and a succession of girls make suggestions and then act out strategies that might improve Lucy's lot - from calling Childline to lying about her age so she can get a bed in a cold-weather shelter.

Streets Alive's technique - in which the audience effectively rewrites the play - is called Forum theatre. It was developed by the radical Brazilian theatre practitioner Augusto Boal in the 70s. Forum theatre is widely used by groups working in prisons and the community, and another company, Cardboard Citizens, has also done pioneering work with the homeless using the technique. But Streets Alive is unique in that it is made up entirely of young people talking directly about their experiences to other young people. Those who've been there to those who might go there.

At the end of the evening there is a question-and-answer session. The girls are obviously intrigued by the actors' past lives and their involvement with Streets Alive. Mel, Suzi and Stuart talk remarkably freely. "I've had a very chaotic life and being with this company has transformed it," says Mel, who joined the group after participating in a post-show forum at a festival last year. "I'd given up on myself and gone awol for four years. This makes me face up to myself, every time I'm on stage." Suzi puts it even more succinctly: "It feels like I'm saving myself."

The area where theatre and therapy meet is always a dodgy one. One person's evening of personal growth can be another's night of boredom in the front stalls. But for all its lack of sophistication as theatre - in the summer the company does larger-scale outdoor pieces for festivals involving drumming and fire - Island of Shadows comes close to fufilling both social and theatrical functions for its young audiences. As Young says: "Theatre is the form we use because something magical happens in the process of live performance. It involves transformation for the actors and between groups of people who in other circumstances may never come together."

What it also involves is the transformation of the audience into "spect-actors", as Boal calls them. This is a million miles away from the dreary issue-based work of so much theatre in education.

But it also has dangers. At a school in south London we visit, it is clear that for some of the audience the play has raised issues that connect directly to their lives. After the performance the cast are generous in talking to individuals, but it is the end of the school day and the children have to go home. I am disturbed that there is no follow-up work from the company, that all they can do for these youngsters is give them num bers for telephone help lines.

"The whole thing has been a vertical learning curve, we've been finding out as we go along," says Young. He already tells teachers that the company is happy to return to any school if they feel it would be useful. But he also knows that what the company urgently needs is an education worker, properly structured workshops and support mechanisms not just for its members but also for its audiences.

But, of course, these things cost money. Streets Alive has just received 20% of the money it needs after an award last week of £20,000 from the City Parochial Foundation. Young receives no wage, and the whole thing currently operates on performance payments from schools and with the help of volunteers and the in-kind support of organisations such as the Royal National Theatre and the Guardian. Without proper funding the company may not survive in the long term, and yet it is a potentially superb educational tool and also has a crucial social function. As Suzi says: "Streets Alive has helped more than any rehab."

Keeping the group together is a daily struggle, and there is a conduct contract that everyone must sign, including Young. "We have recovering users in the company and our expectations of them are high - but we are also prepared to be generous," says Young. "What we help them do is to like themselves more. Success for us is when someone comes off the streets and does one workshop or stays three months." Two former members have moved to the south coast to set up their own company.

Back at Benenden the girls gather round, their bright, open faces and squeaky-clean hair a sharp contrast to the slightly bedraggled company. Yet everyone is talking together quite easily. Two worlds have been brought together by an act of theatre.

On the train on the way back to London, Mel is in pensive mood: "We're the people who have gone head on into a brick wall and survived. Maybe I'm supposed to be here for some reason. Maybe the reason is Streets Alive."

Streets Alive is on 0171-583 0275 and patrickyoung@streetsalive.org.uk. The company's website is www.streetsalive.org.uk.

fields.headline: All play and no work
fields.standfirst: Mark Espiner on a company staging Shakespeare on the factory floor
fields.trailText: Tobacco and Shakespeare - two of the longer-lasting products of the Elizabethan age - are coming together in Bristol. In a disused tobacco factory not far from the docks, a new company is performing two of the playwright's greatest works.
fields.body:
Tobacco and Shakespeare - two of the longer-lasting products of the Elizabethan age - are coming together in Bristol. In a disused tobacco factory not far from the docks, a new company is performing two of the playwright's greatest works. But it is looking beyond his gift with words in order to put them on stage.

The company has adapted Shakespeare's entrepreneurial flair to raise the capital required to establish five annual seasons of his plays. Just as Shakespeare and fellow thespians Richard Burbage and Will Kemp owned a share of the Lord Chamberlain's Men, the key players of the Shakespeare at the Tobacco Factory company also own a stake in their acting business.

Investment has not been restricted to members of the company: Bristol's theatre enthusiasts have also been invited to buy shares. The response, according to artistic director Andrew Hilton, has been extremely encouraging. The 30 or so shareholders have produced enough money to stage King Lear and A Midsummer Night's Dream, with a cast of 16.

While rehearsing in a room next to the factory's performance space, Hilton has rediscovered other practical aspects of Shakespeare's stagecraft, including cross-casting. He describes the process of casting his actors for both a comedy and a tragedy as a "new kind of torture". But he recognises that it is a valuable aspect of theatre. Today's audiences, he says, have been deprived of one of the pleasures of live theatre performance: seeing the actor transform him or herself from one play to the next. "A particular delight," he adds mischievously, "is that our Lear will also play Bottom."

But these are not industrial-size productions. The bare factory floor has been transformed into a performance space with enough room for just 200, a fraction of the lucrative 3,000 capacity of Shakespeare's Globe.

"There is a real excitement about rehearsing Shakespeare, but something is lost when it is moved from rehearsal to the traditional proscenium arch theatre," says Hilton. "I don't want to lose that. I want the audience to share the excitement - and I think that can be done in this kind of naked space."

That some of the actors and key company members are prepared to take the financial risk of putting on plays with low ticket prices (£9 and £12) in a theatre with so few seats says as much about their confidence in their craft and the demand for it as it does about the bankability of Shakespeare.

It's hard to tell what the bard himself would have thought about it all. Shakespeare was an artist and businessman who went from playwright and actor to company shareholder and then investor in theatre property, yet never fully realised his greatest asset - his intellectual property. He left it unprotected, to be published, translated, studied, performed and reinterpreted by everyone who came after him. "Neither a borrower nor a lender be," he wrote, but he didn't say anything about buying shares.

King Lear opens tonight at the Tobacco Factory, Bristol. Box office: 07989 468584.

fields.headline: Turning brains into billions
fields.standfirst: British universities produce some of the most talented science graduates in the world. So why do foreign companies reap the profits?
fields.trailText: Science is one of the 13 cross-cutting themes being investigated during this year's comprehensive spending review (CSR). The intellectual framework for the review is New Labour's aim of transferring new ideas and inventions into the world con- quering hi-tech companies of the future.
fields.body:
Science is one of the 13 cross-cutting themes being investigated during this year's comprehensive spending review (CSR). The intellectual framework for the review is New Labour's aim of transferring new ideas and inventions into the world con- quering hi-tech companies of the future.

This ambition also informs a proposed new science and innovation strategy. And at the end of last year chancellor Gordon Brown stunned the cash-strapped academic world by committing £68m to an institute promoting industry-academic links, to be run jointly by the University of Cambridge and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

If the 4,000 companies founded by MIT's students and staff joined forces, their annual $232bn sales would make them the 24th largest economy in the world. World wide, the MIT-spawned companies employ 1.1m. For all the excitement over the explosion of small hi-tech businesses in Cambridge's Silicon Fen, a British Hewlett-Packard, Texas Instruments or Intel is yet to emerge.

The government's challenge is highlighted by the productivity of UK university researchers: with 1% of the world's population, we do 6% of the world's science, produce 8% of all scientific publications, and attract 9% of all citations of publications.

Yet look at the chart: patents tell a different tale about how well advances in basic research are exploited for commercial benefit. The UK's share of the patents granted by the United States and the European Union is well down the league table.

David Sainsbury, the science minister in charge of the review of science policy, has two questions: is Whitehall using science and research effectively, and doing enough to ensure it is exploited to the benefit of the economy at large? The science budget for 1999-2000, overseen by the office of science and technology (part of the department of trade and industry) is £1.5bn, which goes to universities and research councils. Universities get £1.1bn in research grants from their funding councils. Other than defence, Whitehall spends a further £1.4bn on research (defence R&D totals £2.6bn). Adding UK contributions to the EU research budget of £400m, the science total is £7bn.

Following the review, Whitehall departments will draft science and innovation strategies related to their overall plans. Previous studies have suggested that little, if any, of the research commissioned by departments is ever used by civil servants when they advise ministers or make policy. Clearer guidelines will, it is hoped, ensure ministers do not again fail to heed early scientific advice, as was the case with BSE.

The review is meant to help "joining up". An example: convinced that extra funds for human genome research would underpin the growth of the UK's fledgling biotechnology industry, the treasury and the Wellcome Trust agreed an unprecedented boost to university research budgets over three years, following the first CSR. Yet research spending has been cut back at agriculture, which is responsible for BSE and GM foods; defence, where technological superiority is acknowledged as the key to modern warfare; and at health. The review is likely to push for changes to the funding packages for academics. There are concerns about the distorting influence of the "research assessment exercise" in universities, which has lured too many researchers into the race to publish academic papers at the expense of more practical work.

Convincing evidence to substantiate claims that the brightest emerging talent has for some time been abandoning the UK for greener intellectual pastures remains elusive. But some think a more free-market approach to university salaries would pay and retain the best researchers in the UK, without any need for extra public cash.

Treasury officials are also considering whether further transatlantic academic links could be forged, a move likely to delight universities, such as Oxford, which could only look on jealously at the Cambridge-MIT deal.

Outdated and unchanging attitudes towards research in industry, particularly small companies, remains the biggest obstacle. Here one radical proposal being looked into is an American-style scheme to channel government research money into small businesses.

But the universities worry that the review is missing the big picture. The treasury's entrepreneurial push is almost exclusively concerned with innovation in the traditional sense of creating wealth through industrial growth, rather than making ours a better society to live in.

Should innovation be limited to industry? It is new knowledge in the broadest sense - encompassing the arts, humanities and social sciences as well as the physical and biomedical sciences - which forms the mainspring of innovation. The success of PC gaming heroine Lara Croft owes as much to graphic design and narrative power as it does to technical wizardry.

It is after all the creative industries - music, film and fashion - in which the UK still excels on the global stage. Future multimedia internet businesses will be the cross-products of an eclectic mix of ideas and discoveries from the arts and sciences. Even in this area, though, there are ominous signs that home-grown brains are being exploited for American gains. Where does Tim Berners-Lee, the Oxford graduate who invented the World Wide Web while working in basic research, now work? MIT, of course.

webTitle: England take fans on Euro charm offensive

fields.headline: England take fans on Euro charm offensive
fields.trailText: The Football Association is preparing for one of the toughest challenges in its 137-year history. With less than four months to go to the start of Euro 2000 it will attempt to change the negative image of England football fans.
fields.body:
The Football Association is preparing for one of the toughest challenges in its 137-year history. With less than four months to go to the start of Euro 2000 it will attempt to change the negative image of England football fans.

After years of behaving like marauding invaders, instilling fear in towns and cities wherever they travel and leaving a trail of violence and smashed bars, England's fans, the FA concedes, suffer from a serious image problem and the time has come for them to show their nicer side.

In a ground-breaking partnership with the 27,000-strong England Members Club a series of initiatives are to be undertaken to give England fans an image makeover in the hope of ensuring a peaceful European Championship while burying the negative, violent, extreme right-wing stereotype.

The FA and EMC are planning a series of goodwill visits by England fans to venues in Belgium and the Netherlands, where the national side will play during Euro 2000.

An anti-violence campaign, backed by England's coach Kevin Keegan and some leading players, is also to be launched with the message "Yes to football, No to violence" and thousands of posters and car stickers bearing the slogan will be distributed in the run-up to Euro 2000.

England fans who purchase tickets for the tournament will be given a guide containing information on restaurants, museums and other cultural attractions in an attempt to encourage them to sample life in the towns and cities they visit.

The EMC is to hold regional meetings of supporters so that they can discuss the makeover and how to distance themselves from the minority who cause trouble.

Other measures are to be announced in the coming weeks.

Officals from the FA and the EMC are anxious to appeal to the "majority" of England fans who they claim set out to enjoy a match but sometimes get drawn into violence orchestrated by a well-organised, right-wing minority.

Appeals will also be made for self-policing with fans urged to point out and distance themselves from troublemakers. England fans will be encouraged to follow Scotland's example, where self-policing led to the Tartan Army turning their back on violence and becoming among the world's friendliest supporters.

With songs such as "No surrender to the IRA" dominating some England away matches and the threat of violence concerning locals in the run-up to Euro 2000, Mark Perryman, a leading EMC member, said: "The only people who can isolate the minority are the fans themselves. We need to separate ourselves from the right-wing No Surrender brigade.

"We need to travel to Euro 2000 as ambassadors not invaders. We have to win the argument that violence has nothing to do with being passionate about England.

The trouble is that there is a beered-up, racist, violent fringe that sets the tone at England matches. We have to set a different tone."

The decision to tackle the negative image of England fans is believed to have come from the EMC, which approached the FA.

Adrian Bevington of the FA, who is working on the image makeover, said: "There's a stereotypical view of an England fan. However, the reality is that majority are genuine football fans who enjoy the travelling and the culture."

The FA and the EMC both deny the image makeover is linked to England's attempt to host the 2006 World Cup. Fifa's executive is due to decide on the hosts two weeks after the Euro 2000 final on July 19. Bevington said: "This is not driven by 2006. This is about the reputation of England fans."

The EMC initially discussed the idea of tackling the image of England fans prior to France 98 but suffered a setback after violence at England matches. Perryman said: "In my lifetime as an England fan we have always come back from tournaments with a worse reputation. It's going to be a long, slow haul but I'm confident things can change."

fields.headline: Collymore to move for £½m
fields.trailText: After years of idiosyncratic and even antisocial behaviour, Stan Collymore yesterday discovered his true worth when Aston Villa agreed to sell him to Leicester City for a nominal fee.
fields.body:
After years of idiosyncratic and even antisocial behaviour, Stan Collymore yesterday discovered his true worth when Aston Villa agreed to sell him to Leicester City for a nominal fee.

Less than three years after he moved to Villa Park from Liverpool for £7m, and less than five since his £8.5m transfer from Nottingham Forest made him the most expensive player in Liverpool's history, he went to Filbert Street in a pay-as-you-play deal that will net Villa the grand total of £500,000 at best.

After several days of highly public wrangling, the two clubs finally reached agreement yesterday afternoon, paving the way for Collymore to talk formally with Leicester about personal terms. If they can agree, he may sign a three-year contract this morning and could then be included in the squad for Saturday's Premiership game against Watford at Vicarage Road.

It was a measure of Villa's desire to divest themselves of the troublesome former England forward that they accepted Leicester's pitifully small offer - which does not include even a down payment - only five days after they insisted that the price was a non-negotiable £3m.

If Collymore completes this highly embarrassing exit from the club he had supported since childhood, it will mean that Villa will have lost an astonishing £6.5m in only 33 months. He joined them in May 1997.

Although the Leicester manager Martin O'Neill initially insisted he was only interested in signing the 29-year-old forward on a free transfer, he struck a deal with Villa's manager John Gregory after agreeing to pay £250,000 after Collymore has made 25 senior appearances for Leicester, and a similar sum when, or if, he reaches 50 first-team games.

Collymore has not started a senior game for Villa this season, after the collapse of his working relationship with Gregory over the player's well-documented off-the-field problems, including stress and depression, for which he received counselling.

Last week it seemed that struggling Bradford City would give him the opportunity to resurrect his career in West Yorkshire. But although they offered to make him one of the highest-paid players in British football with £40,000 a week - £20,000 basic salary, £10,000 appearance money and an annual bonus of £500,000 while the club remained in the top flight - he declined the offer.

 Leicester's Neil Lennon and Gerry Taggart have been excused from Northern Ireland's friendly against Luxembourg on February 23 to prepare for the Worthington Cup final against Tranmere at Wembley four days later. The manager Sammy McIlroy obliged his old friend Martin O'Neill, the Leicester manager, even though the Luxembourg game will be his first match in charge.

Collymore's fees

1989 to Wolverhampton Wanderers (trainee)
1990 to Stafford Rangers (free)
1991 to Crystal Palace (£100,000)
1992 to Southend United (£100,000)
1993 to Nottingham Forest (£2m)
1995 to Liverpool (£8.5m)
1997 to Aston Villa (£7m)
1999 to Fulham (loan)
2000 to Leicester City (nominal fee)

webTitle: Price pinch tightens on first-time homebuyers

fields.headline: Price pinch tightens on first-time homebuyers
fields.trailText: First-time buyers are feeling the squeeze of higher house prices, figures showed yesterday. Selling prices for new homes were an average 19% higher in the final quarter of last year than the same period of 1998.
fields.body:
First-time buyers are feeling the squeeze of higher house prices, figures showed yesterday. Selling prices for new homes were an average 19% higher in the final quarter of last year than the same period of 1998.

Statistics for housing development underlined the divide between "hot spots" and more depressed areas of the country.

The average expected selling price of new homes was £123,000 in September to December 1999, a 19% increase on the £103,000 recorded in the last quarter of 1998.

The proportion of new homes topping £100,000 rose to a record 47%, against 35% a year before.

The National House-Build ing Council, which compiled the figures, warned that first-time buyers were being shut out of the market.

The figures, relating only to new homes, show increasing pressure on building land in the south as demand grows.

Housing starts in Greater London during the last quarter rose 43% on the same period in 1998 to 3,210, the rise in the south east was 12% to 4,690. In Northern Ireland there was a 29% rise to 2,467.

But starts declined by 2% in the east midlands to 2,8981, by 30% on Merseyside to 535, by 8% in the north east to 1,204, by 7% in the west midlands to 2,603 and by 3% in Yorkshire-Humberside to 2,626.

In Scotland the decrease was 11% to 3,386, and Wales saw a 20% drop to 1,241.

fields.headline: Wrought with iron
fields.standfirst: The Fall of the House of Usher Oval House, London ***
fields.trailText: The Fall of the House of Usher Oval House, London ***
fields.body:
Being handed a synopsis before you've even entered the theatre is not a good sign. But what Graeae's production of Edgar Allan Poe's gothic masterpiece lacks in clarity, it certainly makes up for in atmosphere. If the piece does sometimes confuse, then adaptor Steven Berkoff must share the blame. There is plenty to intrigue in an evening of physical theatre that can hold its head up with the best - a major achievement from a company made up of actors with disabilities. Choreographer Liam Steel, who did such good work on Frantic Assembly's Hymns, also gets credit here.

As Edgar, friend to the doomed Roderick and his sister Madeline, David Toole swings between the spiralled headboard of the wrought iron bed like a restless, legless monkey. It makes you think of prison bars and zoos, as if he is always looking for an escape from that airless, decaying room but can never find one.

What really makes this 70 minutes fascinating is the way Graeae hitches the metaphorical meanings of the story to its own identity as a theatre company. There is something very interesting and extremely unsettling about seeing a tale about degeneration, physical decay and mental disintegration played out on what is effectively a vast sick bed by actors with obvious physical impairments.

The whole point about this evening is its utter physicality. Jenny Sealey piles on the gothic horror to tremendous effect, with lashings of music, scudding storm clouds and white muslin curtains that blow in the wind like ghosts that have been disturbed. But the quiet authority of the performances ensures that this never seems like overkill. At the end you hurry away into the night gasping down the fresh air with relief.

Until February 19. Box office: 0171-582 7680.
