webTitle: Sun to sue Mirror for libel in squabble over share stories

fields.headline: Sun to sue Mirror for libel in squabble over share stories
fields.standfirst: More about the Mirror share deal scandal
fields.trailText: The row over the share dealings of the Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, escalated into a tabloid war yesterday as the Sun began legal action against the Mirror.
fields.body:
The row over the share dealings of the Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, escalated into a tabloid war yesterday as the Sun began legal action against the Mirror.

The Sun editor, David Yelland, told Radio 4's Today programme he would sue the Mirror over a front page story which accused the Sun's business editor, Ian King, of tipping shares he owns.

The Mirror story, headlined "Sun's rank hypocrisy", was clearly retaliation for similar stories its rival has run in the past week calling for the resignation of Mr Morgan and his city staff, who are all under investigation by the press complaints commission over their share dealings.

It detailed Mr King's shareholdings in a number of companies, including Dixons, Reuters, Glaxo Wellcome and Lloyds TSB, and listed occasions on which he had written about those companies.

Mr Yelland, who said he was fully aware of Mr King's stocks, said the revelations about his city editor were "an absolute disgrace", adding: "When Ian King joined the paper he told me, as he has to do under PCC rules, what stock he owned.

"He has never tipped those stocks, he does not tip stocks. He has written about these companies in the sense that the chairman of one these companies exercised some options, or the earnings came out... This is why we have instigated legal action this morning. This is libel."

Mr King added: "I haven't done anything wrong, I've complied with the code at all times, and there is a world of difference between what I'm being accused of and what the Mirror lot have done."

The PCC code states that journalists must not buy or sell shares about which they intend to write, or write about those shares without disclosing their interest. Senior sources at both newspapers yesterday conceded that the guidelines needed tightening as a result of the current fray.

Last Friday, Trinity Mirror announced that an internal inquiry had cleared Mr Morgan of acting improperly. He sold all his shares in Viglen Technology - tipped by his newspaper the day after he bought his £20,000 stake - and pledged to give his profits to charity.

Anil Bhoyrul, one of the Mirror's so-called City Slickers, is also under investigation after the Guardian revealed that he held a stake in Belgo, a restaurant chain his column repeatedly tipped last year.

fields.headline: How the eye can lie
fields.standfirst: Painted Illusions: The Art of Cornelius Gijsbrechts National Gallery, London ***
fields.trailText: Painted Illusions: The Art of Cornelius Gijsbrechts National Gallery, London ***
fields.body:
They must have been easily fooled in the 17th century, you think when you first look at the purportedly eye-fooling art of Cornelius Gijsbrechts. Gijsbrechts made a career of painting trompe l'oeil as court painter to the rulers of Denmark from 1688 to 1672 - the only period of his life when anyone knows anything about him. On the tricksy level you expect of trompe l'oeil - painting intended to deceive - his paintings don't deliver. His still lifes look like painted still lifes, however much you squint.

Yet there is something stranger and gloomier going on here than a picture puzzle. As you scrutinise paintings of dead animals hanging on bare walls you begin to think something is rotten in the state of Denmark. Illusionistic painting was used in the 16th and 17th centuries to multiply the world's riches. But Gijsbrechts' court paintings are a claustrophobic dead end: every way you turn you come to a wooden wall.

He paints dead game, guns, money bags, letters, combs, in shallow relief on wooden shelves or glass cabinets. He spent a lot of time getting wood right. Gijsbrechts paints the shallow perspectives of his closed spaces so immaculately that you do start to imagine you're looking into a real space. webTitle: Frisky with the lads in the workplace

fields.headline: Frisky with the lads in the workplace
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: This week I have been co-responding. This is not as racy as it may sound.
fields.body:
This week I have been co-responding. This is not as racy as it may sound.

Once upon a time, of course, co-respondents were the third parties in divorce proceedings - I visualise the men in trenchcoats and trilbies like Cary Grants gone bad and the women in those sculptural forties hairdos and dark lipstick.

In the tribunal you co-respond when, for example, an applicant sues both the employer and a named individual for discrimination. If the employer doesn't want to throw in its lot with the individual, they get separate representation. You and your client are then co-responding with the company and its counsel.

In this instance I am for Mr Alleged Harasser. The company is being represented by someone I strongly suspect of being an ex-member of the Famous Five, probably Julian.

Julian is very jolly: "We won't have too much trouble with this one." Me: "You think not?" Julian: "Well, it certainly sounds like she encouraged the chaps to take a few liberties with her, all that banter, showing her brassiere and so forth."

It strikes me that it is not only Julian's suit which belongs to the opening years of the recently departed century. I have already advised Mr Alleged Harasser that it is unlikely that the tribunal will accept that the Applicant welcomed him putting his hand down her trousers to see if she was wearing French knickers.

Since Julian is so gung-ho about the whole thing, however, he readily agrees to cross-examine first. This means I avoid having to put most of the "You liked it really, didn't you Mrs?" questions and Julian can feel he is doing the gentlemanly thing.

And it all goes rapidly wrong for him. The Applicant's counsel turns out to be a large American woman with a glittering look. Julian launches boldly in: "Now, Miss Applicant, it would be right to say that you could be a bit frisky with the lads in the workplace?"

"Aaaabjection!" We are all a bit startled by this, which turns out to be Applicant's counsel standard form of objection to a line of questioning. Readers may be familiar with this transatlantic practice from episodes of Ally McBeal.

The tribunal chair, probably clutching vaguely at some idea of respecting cultural differences, makes no move to stop these interjections so every few minutes Julian finds his increasingly spluttery questions penetrated by a sort of nasal yowl: "Well, Miss Applicant, but it would be right to say that your workplace garb could be somewhat saucy?" "Aaabjection!" And so on.

This is co-responding at its finest. You and your client huddle under cover whilst the casualties pile up.

The hearing doesn't finish in the day allotted to it so my client won't have to give his evidence until a resumed hearing in some months time. He's happy. I'm pleasantly relaxed. Julian is looking a bit bruised and bitter. He tells me that most of his work is construction and defamation. Maybe the chaps are more civilised in the High Court.

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst:
We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of novelist Jilly Cooper
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of novelist Jilly Cooper
fields.body:
This desk belongs to an author - the old-fashioned typewriter is a dead giveaway. This is a woman who, although she prefers a casual lifestyle, can be a real girlie girl, who enjoys being feminine (eg, pink nail varnish, pink and lavender paper). Although as a writer she may be wise in the ways of the world, there is something still of the little girl in her, who yearns to be protected - by a big, strong man, perhaps (rockinghorse clock and teddy)?

The scissors tied to the typewriter and the notepad tied to the table leg remind me of mittens on strings that perhaps she wore as a child: she may be a bit scatty and disorganised (the piles of papers and folders on the desktop and surrounds fit into the creative chaos category), but she has strong priorities. These things are hers; she needs them for work and they shouldn't be borrowed by partner or children. Similarly, the hand lotion on the sill, which only she can reach. However, such actions also reveal a wry sense of humour. The prominence of the dog biscuits on the desk and dog basket under her desk, reveal an animal lover, and a person who perhaps gets a bit lonely when creating. The painting of a dog tells me that there are many people she likes less well than animals.The plastic ring and paperweight speak of someone down to earth, who is not that interested in material possessions. She judges you not on what you have but on how big your heart is - because her heart is big, too. She's generous and giving. Could this be Jilly Cooper?

Did our expert get it right? Jilly Cooper responds:

It's very sweet and very accurate. The nail varnish is only there because I was going out and the lavender paper is what they buy in the office. The rockinghorse clock and teddy were presents rather than things I bought. .

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Rhys, 38 Journalist
fields.body:
Elizabeth Rhys, 38 Journalist

I was made redundant from a television production company where I worked as a script assistant. I panicked and phoned a few temp agencies but got nowhere. I calmed down and decided to leave work calls for a few weeks until I felt better. I went to the personnel officer for help with my CV and interview techniques, then I booked a holiday with the redundancy money. That way, I could look on the redundancy as a positive thing. Also, I couldn't stay at home and mope as I had to get another job.

Penelope Easton, 42 Arts consultant

I was the head of marketing and publicity for the Barbican when the new director started culling staff. It was a total shock. When the director's assistant broke the news I was furious and said something like, "How dare you!" Then I went out and got legless with friends who had recently been made redundant. It was comforting to know I was not alone. I kept in contact with the people I knew in the arts and eventually got a job through networking. It's important to keep in touch with the area of work you were in, even if it's only on a social basis.

Lyle French, 31 Education consultant

I was made redundant from the BBC World Service where I worked as a researcher; my manager called me into her office. The worst part was going back to my desk and seeing the concern on my colleagues' faces. I'm sure they all knew. I only told a few close colleagues at first and, after they had offered advice and sympathy, I felt strong enough to tell everyone else. I stayed on for a fortnight to finish off all my work and was as professional as possible. I'd always found my manager profoundly patronising, and whenever I saw her she'd give me this sad smile. That really irritated me, so I was just polite and rather curt back: it was important to keep my dignity.

David Bonta, 39 Architect

I was made redundant at a time when I was up to my neck in work. The partners of the firm disagreed over when I should leave. I had to pin them down to a meeting to discuss what I should finish and what should be left for my colleagues. During the meeting they started arguing in front of me, which was extraordinary. I felt that I was being more responsible towards the firm than they were. If I'm ever in a similar situation, I'll let the bosses sort out their own problems and concentrate on getting my portfolio and references together.

Patricia Cooper, 28 Office manager

I worked for an advertising agency and was made redundant when the company went bankrupt. I was distressed, but it was worse seeing the couple who owned it fighting to keep their house. I'd started as a receptionist but took on the accounts and the media-buying because, as each person was made redundant before me, I had to fill in the gaps.

Rather than feel resentful, I made use of my time to learn new aspects of the business; I was determined to feel positive. After I left I used my experience to get a better job.

fields.headline: If push comes to shunt
fields.standfirst:
So you're being head-hunted? Don't celebrate too quickly - head-shunting is the wily employer's way of offloading unwanted staff.
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: So you're being head-hunted? Don't celebrate too quickly - head-shunting is the wily employer's way of offloading unwanted staff.
fields.body:
When Jackie, 30, a marketing manager who works in London was approached by a head-hunter on behalf of a rival firm, she admits to being flattered. "I'd been with my company for eight years and was looking for a new challenge, although I'd not done anything about it. The call came out of the blue," she recalls. Several weeks of covert negotiation ensued, culminating in a job offer from the second firm. Jackie accepted and resigned. However, she was subsequently surprised to find that her former employer had been in on the recruitment process from the start - and, in fact, was behind it. "My old boss had given my details to the head-hunter who then gave me a call," she says.

Jackie had been head-shunted.

Head-hunting is one of the most flattering things that can happen to anyone at work but there is no kudos in being poached if it's because your current boss is trying to get rid of you. After all, no one likes to feel that they are not wanted. However, head-shunting is becoming increasingly common because companies find that it is much easier and cheaper to dump a difficult employee in this way rather than risk being sued for constructive or unfair dismissal by edging them out by more conventional means.

Usually, the employer calls a recruitment consultant and praises a worker to the skies, at the same time making it clear that there is no scope for promotion at present within the firm. The move may be prompted by a personality clash between colleagues or, say, by the individual's inability to work happily within a team. If the problem can't be solved by moving the worker to another department, by mutual consent, head-shunting becomes an option.

In some cases, an employer may actively encourage a member of staff to move - discussing alternative job opportunities and providing good references to speed a move, even using personal contacts to do so. However, sometimes the worker may not even realise he or she is being managed out of a job - a process which can involve a range of techniques, from the gradual erosion of responsibilities and undermining of confidence to the latest phenomenon - head-shunting, when the employer asks a recruitment consultant to find that person another role with another firm.

"Head-shunting is becoming quite common and not always obvious - either to the employee or to the personnel department," says Elaine Aarons, head of employment at the London office of Eversheds, a law firm. "It is, however, a situation open to discrimination claims as the argument that someone just doesn't fit could be influenced by either gender or race."

Clues that head-shunting is in progress may include unjustified complaints about the work of someone about whom no one has previously complained, or being side-lined as part of departmental or company-wide restructuring.

Part of the reason head-shunting is being used more often is that it is more expensive to get rid of staff. Since last autumn the highest compensation in cases of unfair dismissal has risen from £12,000 to £50,000.

To avoid getting enmeshed in disputes, a growing number of companies will offer external career counselling to "problem" staff. "Sometimes if a person isn't performing in a role we will be called in to understand why, and work with that person to develop a career plan to better meet their skills and expectations," says Julia Davies, marketing manager of Sanders and Sidney, a careers consultancy .

"While we will always remain neutral, this process may lead to someone deciding that it's time to move on - it's about encouraging individuals to take responsibility for their own careers."

Other employers, however, opt for the do-it-yourself approach. "While some are quite frank and will discuss redundancy and redundancy packages, others just let things drift," says Aarons. "It's not uncommon for an employer to fudge things and reduce someone's responsibilities, turning a blind eye with the knowledge that the employee won't be happy with the new arrangement in the hope they will then up sticks and go."

It's a process which can be Machiavellian. Various recruitment industry people talk (but will not name names) of instances where bosses have tipped off head-hunters that a member of staff would be "receptive" to an alternative offer of work.

Some employers see it as kindness, not cruelty. "Sometimes you recruit people who just don't work out," he says. "And this is often a reflection of your own poor judgment. If you can resolve it without either side losing out by using personal contacts to find someone a more suitable role I don't see a problem with that."

It's a tricky area for all concerned, however. Aside from the risk of a successful claim for constructive or unfair dismissal, employers leave themselves open to litigation if they put too shiny a gloss on the references of a difficult employee whom they are trying to shed.

Just before Christmas the court of appeal highlighted the dangers of providing misleading references. It warned that employers hoping to offload troublesome workers by supplying glowing references risked being sued for negligent mis-statement and could be liable for all recruitment, training and legal costs of the new employer.

Many recruitment consultant, question the ethics of head-shunting. "In the case of someone who doesn't fit in, it may seem the easiest, kindest way of dealing with the situation but not all employers have the best interests of the employee at heart," says Kate Dann who chairs the Association of Search and Selection Consultants. It would be unethical for a recruitment consultant to accept payment from an employer looking to shunt a member of staff and a new employer subsequently taking them on, she adds. "We take a very dim view of head-shunting. There is, to my mind, an element of shadiness to it."

For the worker in question, the process is usually deeply upsetting. A person may feel he or she is being marginalised but proving it is usually difficult. Head-shunting may occur following a merger or takeover, or due to restructuring by a new boss - often roles and positions change so that it is harder to measure job differentials.

"The severity of the situation depends on your employment history and job prospects," Aarons says. Especially if you are employed on a notice period of three months or less. "If your prospects are very good, the claim you may have against your employer for being forced out may be less than you think."

Luckily for Jackie, the outcome of her situation was happy. "Shortly before I left my previous company, my department was restructured and my boss replaced. I didn't get on as well with her successor and what seems to have happened is that he wanted to replace me with someone he had worked with before."

With no grounds to make her redundant, Jackie's new boss helped her on her way with a quiet word in a friendly head-hunter's ear. "I found out after a few weeks in my new job," Jackie says.

"And I was annoyed when I heard but only at first. In retrospect, there probably would have been a parting of the ways. I love the new company where I've been working quite happily now for nine months."

fields.headline: Heart of the maelstrom
fields.standfirst: Anne Sofie Von Otter/ Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen/Swenson Barbican, London ****
fields.trailText: Anne Sofie Von Otter/ Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen/Swenson Barbican, London ****
fields.body:
Just when you think it's safe to go back in the water, up pops Kurt Weill again like a hungry shark ready to drag you away. This event, however, was cause for some rejoicing, for in place of the faffing around with rarities that has dominated his centenary celebrations, we finally got his greatest music alongside works by Mozart and Schoenberg.

The Seven Deadly Sins, his last collaboration with Brecht, is a work of horrific compression, which tells us more about the human condition in half an hour than most of us would care to face in a lifetime.

Two sisters - alter egos, both called Anna - are sent by their revolting parents to earn the family fortune in the grim world of capitalist expansion that is 30s America. The seven sins are what Anna I, ever the practical realist, is prepared to exploit - but they also represent the emotions that the idealistic Anna II must choke back, with ghastly consequences, under the influence of her sister's systematic abuse.

Brecht and Weill envisioned the pair as being performed by a singer and an actress-dancer. Of late there's been a tendency for one performer to take both roles, and so it was here, with Anne Sofie Von Otter turning in one of the most unnerving accounts of the piece to be heard for some time. She avoided the brazen superbitch approach favoured by some interpreters. Instead, she took her cue from Brecht's line "We're not two people, just a single girl," and took us on a voyage through a hideous emotional maelstrom.

She started with vaunting self-confidence, but by the time we got to Anger, expressionistic slithers in her voice hinted at incipient disturbance, and when she reached envy, the final sin that destroys Anna II, the blanched tone, crazed expression and manic delivery indicated complete derangement.

It was a stunning performance, which she immediately followed with some of Weill's best Broadway numbers, including a version of Speak Low, which made me go weak at the knees.

The conductor, Joseph Swensen, made much of the score's savage irony and extravagant sleaziness. The Bremen Kammerphilharmonie, however, is a problematic ensemble, its reputation not quite justified on this outing. Their new music director is Daniel Harding, who on this occasion could be observed seated among the percussionists, bashing hell out of a tam tam when Weill's score requires it. The brass and woodwind are flamboyantly brilliant, but the string tone is thin.

This was fine for Weill's Deco punchiness and oddly bracing in the overture to Mozart's Don Giovanni, but when we came to Schoenberg's Verklaerte Nacht, the dry sound and the occasional imprecision of detail robbed the score of much of its colour and most of its sensuality.

webTitle: US intruder stokes up home loan rivalry

fields.headline: US intruder stokes up home loan rivalry
fields.standfirst:
Fighting talk as E-Loan insists borrowers don't need brokers

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Two of the biggest providers of internet mortgages have locked horns over how best to serve the growing number of borrowers taking out a home loan over the net.
fields.body:
Two of the biggest providers of internet mortgages have locked horns over how best to serve the growing number of borrowers taking out a home loan over the net.

On one side is E-Loan, the California-based "global market leader" in online mortgages, which opened for business in this country a fortnight ago. John Charcol, this country's best-known mortgage broker, is the chief opposition.

Since setting up four years ago, E-Loan has grabbed a quarter of the online home loan market in the US (a share worth $4.5bn in 1999), and is promising "a simple and transparent way for the British to finance their homes" far removed from the world of "commission-hungry" mortgage brokers and financial advisers.

The company, whose UK launch came just days before the government announced a clean-up of the £115bn-a-year mortgage industry, said: "If consumers are given all the right information, many could make better financial decisions than a broker or an independent financial adviser."

Such fighting talk ruffles the feathers of John Charcol, founded in 1974 and which launched its own net service - Charcolonline - in November. Chief executive Keith Scott says: "E-Loan's experience in the US, where they have been particularly successful, is not going to be replicated in the UK because of the structure of the marketplace and the nature of the competitive landscape."

Where the two companies differ fundamentally is on mortgage advice. E-Loan is a strictly non-advice service - it says that by allowing people to research and select loans that best fit their circumstances, it puts the consumer in the driving seat.

Critics say that surveys by the Consumers' Association and others have shown that the public rely heavily on advice when it comes to finding the best mortgage for their needs. So who is winning the battle for borrowers in the UK? This is not easy to answer.

The UK online mortgage market is still in its infancy but few doubt its multi-billion pound potential. Home loans are already the most popular financial services product researched on the net. One survey found that more than four in 10 people said mortgages were the personal finance product they were most likely to buy online.

John Charcol is only prepared to say it is writing millions of pounds of online business a week, though Mr Scott is quick to add: "By that I mean much more than £1m." E-Loan is even cagier and will only disclose that its website had more than 10,000 "unique users" in its first week of operation.

Kent-based Independent Mortgage Brokers, the first online mortgage brokerage to be set up in the UK, is not so reticent. "It was started back in 1997 by me and another guy in my spare bedroom," says Anthony Webb, its 34-year-old chief executive. Now with 27 staff and looking to move from its Dartford offices to larger premises, it was valued two months ago at £14.4m.

"It's absolutely incredible, the explosion of interest," said Mr Webb. In December 1997, four months after the company started trading, its web site had a total of 102 users; last month it played host to 5,247 users. The amount of business it is writing has tripled in a year - from £1.5m worth of loans arranged in January 1999 to £4.7m last month.

Two years ago, the average client was very much the "high net worth" individual, and it was not unusual to see mortgages in excess of £1m being taken out. Now the typical loan value is between £70,000 and £80,000, and it is younger people who have never owned a home before leading the charge.

"Since the start of last year first-time buyers have made up 40% of our business," says Mr Webb.

"This generation is now so switched on to internet purchasing that they have no hesitation in coming to us as their first port of call, whereas the older, more traditional consumer often seeks us out due to frustration when conventional services have failed them."

Charcolonline
